Any denomination applying for permission to establish a second or minority school upon a Reserve where one has already been provided, be the same of the Day or
Boarding School type, should, it is considered, be required to prove to the satisfaction of the Department that it has a reasonable prospect of securing an average attendance of at least eight pupils, being children of parents belonging to the denomination so applying.

The only salary that should be paid to a teacher of such Schools by the Department should be a per capita annual grant for each unit of attendance, calculated by the Department's method, always provided such average does not fall in the aggregate below eight, and such salary shall not exceed $300., and an additional annual grant of $7.00 might be paid for each pupil who shall have attained to the standard decided upon by the Department, and obtained at least 60 per cent of marks obtainable for English in such standard.

No assistance should, it is thought, be given towards the erection of, or furnishing of, the school house or teacher's quarters, but if an average attendance of not less than eight pupils shall have been maintained during twelve consecutive school months, the Department of Indian Affairs might contribute a sum not exceeding $200. towards the cost of the school building, and keep the same in repair on condition that the furniture shall be kept in a proper state of repair, and shall be replenished when necessary, by the denomination.

School Material shall be furnished by the Department of Indian Affairs.

All Regulations of the Department governing Day
Schools and their Teachers, except insofar as they are modified by these special Regulations, shall apply to second denominational schools, when any assistance is afforded them by the Department.

Holidays.

Day Schools should, it is considered, be kept open during 221 days in each year, the balance of 144 days to be holidays, and be given, (excepting Sundays and Saturdays), at such time as Agent and Teacher shall consider most conducive to the best attendance; such Regulations being applicable to Day Scholars attending Boarding Schools.

Prizes to Day Schools.

Prizes should, it is thought, be continued as at present, but that consideration in awarding them should be given also to the percentage in the number of children of school age available, taken in connection with the enforcement or otherwise of compulsory measures to secure attendance, and to number of children who have attained a certain standard, and to order, discipline, cleanliness of pupils and of premises, including garden.

Allowances for advancement of pupils to the appointed standard should, it is recommended, be made upon the certificate of Inspectors.

The following Regulations are recommended to apply to all Boarding or Day Schools on or contiguous to Reserves.

(13)
Teachers.

No Teacher shall enter upon duties without the approval of the Department having been first obtained.

When no School Teacher's certificate exists, the Department shall order an examination of qualification to be made.

Certificates of moral character shall be furnished.

When Teachers are engaged it shall be on the understanding that any infringement of the Department's rules may be visited with reduction or stoppage of salary, or dismissal, and that such reduction or stoppage or dismissal may be made when the Department considers that sufficient advancement is not being made by the scholars, or when the Teacher shews a lack of energy in procuring as large an attendance as he should, and which the number of children of school age should afford.

The Department shall have the power to transfer a Teacher from one school to another of the same denomination, but in that case the cost of transport shall be paid by the Department, except the transfer is through the Teacher's own fault, or made at his request.

No changes of Teachers shall be made without the sanction of the Commissioner.

No substitute shall undertake the duties of my Teacher temporarily, without the sanction of the Indian Commissioner or Indian Agent, and, if the latter, he shall report to the Indian Commissioner the circumstances which necessitated the same.
No Teacher shall absent himself without permission of the Agent, excepting during recognized holidays, and in the event of such permission being given he shall report when he leaves and when he returns to duty, and the Agent shall report the circumstances to the Indian Commissioner which led to such leave being granted.

The following Regulations respecting the duties and powers of Teachers of Reserve Day Schools and Boarding Schools, insofar as they are applicable, are recommended for adoption.

Teachers shall be in and open their schools for the reception of pupils, in the morning at least 15 minutes, and in the afternoon at least 5 minutes, before the time specified for beginning school, in order to afford shelter for pupils as they arrive.

Teachers shall, during school hours, devote themselves faithfully and exclusively to the business of the School.

Teachers shall give the children under their charge constant employment in the studies prescribed by the authorized course, inclusive of gardening, and endeavour to render the exercises of the School pleasant as well as profitable.

Teachers shall devote themselves, as far as possible both in and out of School, to the improvement of the minds, morals, personal deportment, and habits of their pupils, and, while exercising firmness, shall endeavour to influence them by appealing to their reason and af-
factions, rather than to their fears.

Teachers shall keep a daily and general Register, and enter in the latter the date of admission of each pupil, his or her name, age, date of promotion to higher classes, and such other information as may from time to time be required by the Department to be kept.

Teachers shall keep in some conspicuous place in the schoolroom, a Time-table, showing the order of exercises for each day in the week, and the time for each as prescribed in the programme of studies, and shall see that the same is strictly observed.

Teachers shall divide the pupils into classes, as prescribed by the programme of study, which must be strictly observed, and no Teacher shall take any class beyond the limits prescribed for the same until its course of study shall have been thoroughly mastered.

Teachers shall examine each class during the last week of each half year, in the presence of the Indian Agent or other visitors; and each pupil in the school, unless for good reasons specially excused, shall be called upon to review or recite in the course of such examination, and the result shall be recorded.

Teachers shall exercise strict vigilance to prevent injury to all school property, including material, furniture, buildings, out-houses, fences, garden-tools, under their charge, and give notice to the Agent of any necessary repairs or replenishment of supplies required for the use of the School.

(16)
Teachers shall see that all yards, privies, and other out premises are kept in proper order.

Teachers shall see that school-houses are locked during other than school hours, and shall require each competent pupil in proper rotation to sweep the room daily, in the morning and evening, and to dust the windows, walls, seats, desks, &c.

Teachers shall be most careful to keep the school-room thoroughly ventilated, fresh, and clean.

Teachers shall not voluntarily absent themselves from their duties without permission of the Agent, and if compelled by sickness or urgent cause to do so, a competent substitute shall, with the approval of the Agent, be obtained, and the whole matter reported to the Commissioner without evitable delay.

Teachers shall receive visitors courteously, and afford any that may be authorized every facility for examining into the state of their schools. They shall keep a visitor's book, in which shall be entered the dates of visits, and the names of visitors, and they shall inform visitors that they may enter remarks in it.

The nature of and necessity for regulations affecting pupils shall be explained to the latter at least once in every month, and, when opportunity offers, to their parents, whose interest and co-operation should, as far as possible, be secured.

It should always be borne in mind that the duties of the Teacher do not end with teaching, but he must work diligently in going among the children and their parents.
to secure a proper attendance.

It is respectfully recommended that the following Regulations respecting Pupils be adopted.

No child under six years of age can become a pupil in any Indian Department Reserve Day School.

If pupils do not come to school clean with respect to their persons they should be compelled to wash and tidy themselves during school hours, and they should be required to be kind and courteous to each other, obedient to their teachers, diligent in their studies, and conform to the rules of the school.

No pupil, unless present for at least one half of the morning or afternoon, shall be entered on the Register as present for that half-day, nor should the pupil be allowed to share in the mid-day meal.

No pupil should be allowed to depart before the hour appointed for closing the school, excepting in case of sickness or other urgent necessity, in which case the teacher's consent should be first obtained.

Fifteen minutes recess shall be allowed, at 10.15 A.M., and at 12.15 P.M., during which time the school-room must be thoroughly ventilated, but pupils should not be permitted to leave their classes at any other time, unless the teacher considers that a case of urgent necessity exists.

Regulations which it is recommended be made applicable to all Schools supplied in whole or in part by
1st. All Returns required by the Department shall be regularly, punctually, and correctly made, and any information asked for shall be promptly and correctly given.

2nd. The Department's Curriculum of Instruction must be closely adhered to. The vernacular is not to be taught in any schools. As soon as possible, the native language is only to be used as a vehicle of teaching, and should be discontinued as soon as practicable.

3rd. No change with regard to any matter submitted to and approved of by the Department of Indian Affairs shall be made without its sanction.

4th. Any deviation from, or failure to comply with, any of the Department's Regulations shall be held to justify it in discontinuing its assistance in whole or in part, and the Department of Indian Affairs shall be sole judge as to whether its Regulations have been satisfactorily observed or not.

5th. The Department's officers shall have the right of inspection at all times, full control of the school during such inspection, and access at all times to all Registers, books, papers, etc., connected with the school.

One of the duties of the 6th. A school district shall, subject to charge at any time, be allotted to each School Inspector, who shall inspect all schools within the same, irrespective of denominations, they may not be deprived of the means to fulfill their duty.
Note. If it be considered necessary to have two School Inspectors, it would seem advisable to abandon the present system of sending both through the whole country, to follow in each other's wake, and inspect each the schools of his denomination only. Religion need, in no way, enter into the work of inspection.

7th. Instruction must, in all schools, be given primarily in the English language, even where French is taught.

The Indian Commissioner for Manitoba, Keewatin, and the North West Territories is empowered to carry these Regulations into effect, save where specially otherwise directed.

General remarks.

1st. The whole plan as above framed leaves too much room for subsequent arbitrary regulations on the part of the Indian officials.

2nd. It does not take enough into consideration that its regulations are for Indian and not white children.

3rd. The teacher, amongst the Indians, should enjoy a respectable position. From it, he is paid, secure a salary inferior to any other employee on Indian reserve, although he is very poorly built and obliged to live with Indians without any of the comforts of civilization. His position or rather his mission don't seem to be at all appreciated by the Indian department or at least by the author of this plan.

It will be seen from these Regulations that the Programme of Studies as they laid down was much lower than at present called for and that the qualification required for teachers was correspondingly low.

At the time the negotiations were entered into with the various local Governments for the Inspection of Indian Schools by their Public School Inspectors, the Department had not much experience in the management of Indian Schools. Although many of its schools had for a long time been in operation they were nearly, if not all, conducted by the various religious denominations. Quarterly School Returns were called for and received very irregularly in most instances, payment of teacher's salaries not being as now, contingent upon the receipt of such Return. The Agents of the Department were not then required to make periodical visits and reports on the schools in their Agency and no such reports were received; the only mention then made of them was a short sentence or paragraph sometimes occurring in their Annual Report on the affairs of their Agency. Appropriations were annually made for School purposes, salaries paid, material supplied, buildings put up and repaired and fuel provided but the Department had little if any knowledge as to what good was resulting from such outlay.
The present system of inspection has been in force for thirteen years in some of the Provinces and in all for more than ten years. The expenditure for these semi-annual inspections has been close upon $1000 a year for Ontario and Quebec alone, or all of the money voted by Parliament for the cost inspection, fuel, cleaning, books and maps for the whole of the schools of the two Provinces, while nearly, if not all of the information in the Inspector's Reports is now received by the Department through its Agents under the new Regulations, which require them to visit and inspect our schools, and from other sources long before the Inspector's Reports reach the Department; the Reports of some of the Inspectors being delayed frequently for months, so that when received it is too late for the requisite action to be taken. Most of their suggestions relate to the repairs to school-houses and outbuildings and the supply of school material and should be forwarded immediately after their inspection.

Public School Inspector's Reports on the qualification of teachers and progress of the pupils are also of slight value to the Department as many of our schools are so remote and the salaries so small that it is difficult
to obtain properly qualified teachers to take positions, while the irregular attendance of children at such schools is greatly against their progress. The Public School Inspectors have so far failed to better the condition of affairs and improvement can only be looked for by the exercise of vigilance and energy on the part of the Department and its officers and its own officers and not from the paid officials of other Governments over whom the Department has no control. The undersigned is confident that one visit from an official from head-quarters, who knows the requirements of the Department in regard to Indian Schools would be productive of better results than any number of inspections by an Inspector who is not even allowed to communicate directly with the Department, and who takes his orders from his own Government. This Department has no power to command the services of these Inspectors and they only make their inspections when it suits their convenience or that of their Government.

The most we can at present expect is that our teachers should use their best endeavors to instruct the children in the elementary branches and that this instruction be given in English,
and that they should use every means in their power to induce parents to send their children to school. The chief fault with our teachers is their neglect of this duty, where they are interested in the work good results are obtained both as regards progress and attendance.

The class of work done by our schools does not call for Inspectors holding Provincial Certificates. Any of our Agents of ordinary education and intelligence are competent, on hearing the school children go through their exercises, to give an opinion as to whether they are deriving any benefit from their attendance or not, and they should also be able to report on the fitness of the teacher for the position. In addition to this the undersigned begs to state that it is only through the officers of the Department it can look for any improvement. They are now aware that school matters form one of their most important duties and with very few exceptions are attending regularly and carefully to this duty.

As an instance of the cost of inspection the undersigned would refer to Mr Separate School Inspector White's account for inspecting the Catholic Schools from Manitoulin Island up to Fort William which, with visits to two schools in Eastern Ontario, amounted
to $188, or $376 for the year. Inspector Kelly's account for visiting the Six Nation and New Credit Schools comes to $76 or $152 for the year, while Mr McCaig, who visited two Protestant Schools on Manitoulin Island and the Shingwauk Home renders a bill of $34.50. These are the only Inspector's reports yet received for this fall, but the cost of these three inspections foots up to $300 for the half-year.

The teachers of the denominational schools are appointed by the various denominations and the Department has been in the habit of approving of their nominees. Very few of these teachers hold anything higher than a Permit and in many instances even that qualification is lacking. Some of the teachers are Indians with only an imperfect knowledge of English, who find it easier to give their explanations in the Indian language than in English, which will account for the slow progress in English made by the pupils who, although able to repeat sentences in English off their book, do not understand what they read.

The Public School Inspectors, no matter how painstaking their examination
and inspection cannot remedy those defects and both teachers, parents and pupils are well aware that they are not officers of this Department and that they have little to fear from their reports, which have resulted in nothing but the expenditure of large sums of money for the past twelve or fourteen years. What they do require to feel is that the Department is taking a personal interest in their work and its results and that good work will be appreciated and that carelessness will lead to dismissal or the closing of the schools. This they can only be taught by the Department itself through its officers.

Other disadvantages also exist in the present system. The inspections are made too early in the fall and too late in the spring for Indian Schools, as they are not fairly in operation at such times. The Indians migrate in the Spring long before the Public Schools close and do not return until some time after they are re-opened in the fall and the Inspector's rarely, if ever, make a special visit for the purpose of inspecting an Indian School, but take them in their regular round of duty as Provincial Inspectors and charge this Department, in most instances with full travelling expenses.
These Inspection Reports are published in the Departmental Reports of the Ontario Government and most likely in the other Provincial Blue Books, this the undersigned considers to be unfair to our Department as our schools cannot be expected to compare favorable with the Ontario Public Schools or the Public Schools of the other Provinces.

Two sets of Inspectors are required now, the Public School and Separate School Inspector, both going over the same ground, but visiting only their own schools, while if an officer of the Department were to make a visit neither denomination would object, as they all recognize the right of the Department to make any inspection it considers necessary.

In regard to the inspection of Industrial Schools, the undersigned begs to repeat what he has already stated in his report on the Shingwauk Home, which is, that very little, if any, benefit to the Department is derived from such inspection, as the Inspector merely makes a hurried xixit examination of the pupils in their studies and does not make the minute examination into the details connected with the management of such Institutions which the Department requires and ought to be furnished with. The Public School Inspectors do
not know what the Department requires in regard to its schools, and their reports appear to be written solely with a view to brevity, very few of them making any remarks, and when they do so, only repeating their previous suggestions, most of which are wholly impracticable for Indian Schools.

If, however, it is not considered expedient to dispense with the services of the Public School Inspectors, altogether, the undersigned is of the opinion that they should be more under the immediate control of the Department than they now are and that they should only visit the schools when instructed to do so by the Department. If this concession could be obtained a great deal of unnecessary expense and many useless trips would be avoided.

Your obedient servant,

At the Summer Institute for Indian workers—composed of the Superintendents and Supervisors of Indian Education, Indian Agents, Superintendents of Indian Schools and school employees—which was held under the auspices of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs at Chilocco, Okla., U.S.A. in the month of July last—the following Resolutions were passed.

RESOLVED, (1) That at this time, pending the allotments of lands in severalty to reservation Indians, it is important in the interests of economy and effective service that liberal appropriations be made by the Government for the support of Indian schools.

RESOLVED, (2) That there is urgent need of efficient and faithful service of all school employees and that the interests of the Government as well as the Indian demands that no others should be retained in the service.

RESOLVED, (3) That no system of Indian education is complete without it embraces manual training, and that the future of the Indian youth requires that they be taught to labor for their own subsistence.

RESOLVED, (4) That, in view of the fact that Indian education is largely conducted through governmental aid and instrumentality and that a strong disinclination prevails on the part of the parents growing out of their inability to appreciate its advantages, to send their children to reservation schools, it becomes necessary to adopt some method of compulsory attendance at such schools.

RESOLVED, (5) That the future civilization of the Indian involves their gradual emancipation from a dependent condition of development not be accomplished in a day, but must be the outgrowth of the Indian school system, and that the time required to accomplish this object depends largely upon the perfection of such system and the force and personal character and efficiency of the employees engaged supplemented and consummated by the guidance and uplifting
uplifting of those forming their environments in future homes.

RESOLVED, (6) That, as it is the opinion of the members of the convention of Indian workers assembled at Chilocco that manual training is an essential part of education for Indians, we urgently request that competent persons be appointed tego from school to school to give employes instructions in practical manual training.

During the discussion of the 10th instant in the House on Indian School Estimates, the Minister stated that "one of the difficulties we have to face is to determine what shall be done with the pupils after they leave the industrial schools. They have then become so far removed from the ordinary Indian that they ought to be in a position to get along as well as an ordinary white man. But experience shows that in very few cases is the Indian boy or girl capable of taking care of himself or herself in contact with the white race."

Mr. Sprague, in reply, said "If these schools are not giving moderately good results, the question arises as to what we should do. We have had them long enough on trial to enable us to determine whether they are a success or a failure, and it is important should consider as to whether it would not be better to change the system."

Indian workers claim that the children are not deficient, either mentally or morally, and the twenty years' experience of Col. Pratt of the Carlisle Institute proves this conclusively, for he has turned out hundreds of Indian youths from that institution who have taken their places as citizens of the United States and more than hold their own in every
walk of life. The labors of the Rev. William Duncan of Metlakahtla resulted more than twenty years ago in founding an ideal community which was an example of industry and morality to the whites in the neighborhood.

If one school can produce hundreds of thrifty, law-abiding citizens and if one man can convert a white tribe of untutored savages into self-respecting and self-supporting members of society, why cannot equally satisfactory results be obtained at our schools, which are entrusted to religious denominations who have control while the Department has the responsibility. The fault must be in the system.

The first school in the West was opened about 17 years ago, partially modeled on the American system of that date and adhered to ever since with very discouraging results. The present system ensures moral and religious training, order, industry, regularity, discipline, respect, obedience and other virtues but it confers no worldly wisdom or self-reliance on the pupils, no individuality or force of character. They are wards when they enter, wards when they leave and are content to remain wards until they die.

The money spent on the education of Indian children at our schools in industrial schools should represent something better than the perpetuation of a race of dependents.

The present system which is responsible for spoiling an Indian and not making him equal to holding his own with ordinary type white settlers, is all wrong and cannot be changed too soon, and I respectfully submit that the adoption or partial
adoption of the George Junior Republic methods, which I have been studying for some time, is worthy of consideration.

I shall now describe this remarkable community, which was founded and organized by Mr. William R. George at Proeville, Tompkins County, N.Y., about five years ago. It is certainly a most novel educational experiment and the principles upon which the republic is established might be well adopted by our Department and applied to some of our schools. "Nothing without Labor" is the Republic's motto and this motto is strictly adhered to, except in case of sickness. The two great basal principles of the Republic are "Necessity" and "Opportunity".

The idea of the Republic originated in the Fresh Air movement. In 1892 Mr. George brought thirty boys from the slums of New York to his home in Proeville for a holiday. They were a troublesome lot and until he hit upon the scheme of self-support and self-government he was in constant worry, as the boys robbed orchards and generally misbehaved themselves. A neighbor complained to him about two boys stealing his apples and identified them. Mr. George called the boys together and asked them to decide what their punishment should be. They decided that the one who planned the raid should be flogged and that the other boy, who was tempted, should be let off. This decision satisfied everyone. Friends had given Mr. George clothing for the boys, which they thought they were entitled to, but Mr. George said "No, you must earn them". They did not like the idea of working for what they claimed should be a gift, but at last they had to come to terms and understand that
they would receive nothing without labor. These summer outings continued until 1895 when a permanent home was established. Mr. George secured forty acres of land and put up one or two buildings and his work has expanded so that he has two hundred and fifty acres now under cultivation and twenty buildings put up and five more in course of construction.

The citizens of this Republic enact their own laws and provide the proper machinery for enforcing their observance. Mr. George, however, provided at the outset a sound framework for the guidance of the community, which enjoys perfect liberty under a reign of self-imposed law. The boys and girls make the republic work, all over twelve years being entitled to citizenship. Children under that age have guardians appointed for them, who are responsible for their physical, moral and social progress.

As there is nothing without labor, every citizen has to work and earn enough money to pay for his board and clothes. The citizens are divided into three classes—unskilled workers, the middle class and skilled workers and work is carried on under helpers or instructors. Fidelity or conscientious effort count for more than natural aptitude. Unskilled labor is paid for at the rate of 50 cents a day; 70 cents is paid the middle class and 90 cents is the highest. The half-day system is in force. No one need work—but no work no pay—no pay no food, lodging or clothes. There is no room for idlers, who are treated as vagrants, being fined or imprisoned and then made to work out their sentence. Girls are eligible for office and vote and office-holders are paid according to a tariff. Attendance at school
counts as labor and is paid for accordingly. They have a metal currency of their own with a banking system and three per cent a month is allowed on deposits.

The Republic has passed beyond the experimental stage and has shown that the children have a keen sense of justice and discrimination, that they are superior by over of discipline and administration over their fellows to the superintendent and his helpers; that their suggestions as to government and administration were wise and practical and they have shown themselves as capable of making laws as of executing them.

The Republic is not planned so much to found a Utopia as it is to have the children adjust themselves to the questions as they really exist under the laws of the country at the present time. They follow the law and the constitution. The object from the beginning has been to inculcate self-reliance and orderly and intelligent conduct of affairs, as well as to give them a due sense of the value of money and other property. The non-producer is an injury to himself and a burden to the community and is dealt with accordingly.

The citizens of this Republic enjoy the wealth and blessings of variety and run no risk of losing the individual in a system which gives full sway to the personal element.

You will see from the subjoined list of publications kindly sent me by Mr. George how widespread is the fame of his undertaking. I have marked the magazines and articles I have been able to obtain at the Parliamentary Library and elsewhere.
Dr. George is described as a large-hearted man of thirty-three, of infinite tact, patience, and perception, who is assisted in his enterprise by his wife and mother and an able staff of teachers and instructors. The Republic receives no state aid and is wholly supported by voluntary subscription. He informs me that the cost per capita is about $140.00 per annum, which is to be reduced now that he has more land. He is a firm believer in the Cottage System and always has eight or ten of the children living with him, making it a point to have every child under his own roof for at least two months each year. To show how successfully this plan works I may mention that it is always spoken of by the citizens of the Republic as "Happy George" and his wife as "Mother George".

I have endeavored to give you some idea of the purposes of Dr. George in establishing this Republic and the methods adopted to carry it into execution, and in concluding I cannot do better than quote Dr. George's own words: "It is an attempt to diminish pauperism and crime by instilling into neglected children in fact any class of children, lessons of morality, responsibility, and self-control. The lessons are taught in such a way that the children can and learn by experience the results of laziness, disorder, and disobedience of moral laws. That they may learn these lessons naturally as possible and in a way to make them most useful in after life. The children are allowed to form a system of society of their own modeled as far as possible upon the great Republic in which they will ultimately become citizens and the largest measure of self-government is allowed them."
"The result is not by any means an ideal state, but it is believed that under this system each child receives just the treatment which its case demands and that the lessons learned are exactly in line with the experiences which it will meet in mature life. It is said that the Junior Republic is so radically different from any reform school, military institute or boarding school."

Mr. George, to whom I sent a copy of our Annual Report, writes me that he would very much like to have me visit the Junior Republic and thinks that possibly I might get some ideas that might be of advantage.

The interest I take in our schools led me to correspond with Mr. George and I may say candidly that it is my earnest wish that the Department would let me visit his Republic and study its workings. His new departure is endorsed by numbers of the principal educators in the United States and has attracted the attention of thousands of readers on this continent and in Europe, and I am surprised that it has not been more fully examined by our provincial governments which have to face similar problems.

Respectfully submitted,
The Association for Referring Indian School Graduates.

Many have spoken to me in favor of the object of our Association, since our last meeting; and too—some objections have been raised.

Yet there has been no objection grounded upon actual experience sufficiently strong to make me change my belief in the need of this work. Rather, from studying it further I feel the need more deeply.

The results of no previous trial of placing Indian graduates out at work can be taken as a measure of the success to look for in this, because there has not been any organized effort of this kind in America before.

We shall not only find work for the young Indians but we shall welcome them among us, and encourage and entertain them throughout their stay. All who would become Associates must pledge themselves to this. It will not be by any means a difficult undertaking, for every one who has ever worked sympathetically among Indians has experienced a rare fascination that makes many apparent sacrifices easy, even acceptable to him. I shall not attempt to analyze or explain this unusually remarkable attraction, but assuredly it exists, and I trust every Associate will feel it within a few years.

The main object of the Association
is to take out into the cities some of the graduates of our Catholic Indian Industrial Schools; the graduates of other Indian schools to be cared for by associations in connection with the various missionary bodies in charge, if desired.

One of the first things to understand definitely is that we should prefer to have Western Indians cared for by Western branches of the Association, if possible, and too that we do not propose bringing out whole classes of graduates.

We will take rather the individuals whose abilities and temperament particularly recommend them, and who are desirous of coming.

Some of the school-principals are timid about sending their pupils out to the cities. In their regard for the darker side of city life they forget that the spiritual side is trebly more active than in country life. We must have them send out a few young graduates at first, for they can do it, if they will—then let the work of our Association be thorough and earnest—not merely a kindling of fine ardors and sympathetic interest in the beginning, and the daddists' inertia afterward—and the results will be so great and the reports sent home so bright, that it will soon be considered an honour and a desirable thing to pupils and parents for a graduate to be chosen to work in town.

The proposed Constitution explains itself. Each Indian boy or girl brought into town will not only be the protege of the Association, but will be under the particular care of some one Associate. These Associates will call upon their proteges from time to time, and the Indian should always feel at liberty in any difficulty to go to that Associat
for advice or encouragement.

There will be a Chaplain attached to each branch. We are most fortunate in Ottawa in the Chaplain whose appointment we anticipate. He is deeply interested in the spiritual and social advancement of the Indians and has but recently returned from a Western mission.

The pleasant little evenings to be held at an Assembly Room will be as helpful to the Associates as the Indians. There is nothing we need more to learn as Christian workers than the great want at present of brightening the right path for the masses of workers in the world.

Work in this age is strenuous and exhausting. Body and spirit alike need some refreshment afterward. But people have forgotten how to actually take a rest; they prefer to find relief in pleasure of some sort.

Then since Vice flourishes here and everywhere in every conceivable form of attractiveness, there is no earthly reason why Virtue should stalk through our homes or assemblies in a shroud. Tasteless has its beneficial side.

The world, including the religious world, has need of robust workers, and to work up to the best that is in us we have need of the best of recreation. Let us learn through the Indian Institutes the possibilities the leisureed class have in this age of humanism to lift and cheer the conscripts of life—the tired workers.

Women can do so much good in this way, and today for some reason they form the majority of Christian workers along these lines. Yet the work of association of ladies for meeting social problems of Indians or white men is not for women alone. There is
place for men-workers too.

We need men in our Association and everywhere in our everyday life of the type of Arnold J. Rugby. A man whose simple character and high ideals never set him on a pedestal so high that his down-stretched hands could not meet the weaker ones of his stumbling brethren.

The plan of the Association is not offered to you as a perfect one at all. It lies open and inviting amendments. It is only a beginning, but there must be some germs of the right method in it since so many different Indian workers have testified that the quickest way to develop the Indian is by bringing him into contact, industrially and socially, with white people, and as one cannot repeat too often, white people of the right sort. This is the underlying principle of our Association.

The Indian boys and girls at the Industrial Schools receive the training they need to fit them for work among us; their race is destined to become citizens of Canada with us — and who has a better right than they to the honour of Canadian citizenship when they are fitted for its responsibilities? And though that time is quite distant still, the sooner the work of fitting them is begun in every possible way the better the Indian will be prepared.

I was talking recently of this and other matters of Indian education and
Progress to a man, a clever man he is too, but who confessed he has not studied the Indian Question.

He suggested that I seemed anxious to have the Indians come on too quickly, more so than was practical; that in fact my enthusiasm outran common sense.

"Look at the centuries it took our own ancestors in Northern Europe to become even as civilized as these Indians are now," he said.

And I did look back to our own "flint-burling, hair-mantled" ancestors, as Carlyle describes them, and acknowledged the truth of what he said.

But—when our ancestors were coming out of barbarism the world was younger, and the nations were growing up together. The Indians are differently circumstanced now. They are a race of children constrained more and more each year to come into contact with a fully-developed race.

There is no time to wait with folded hands for their complete evolution, though it is true people might take them up more gladly then—when the need for it was gone.

The highest ideals and standards of our civilization are none too good to set before the Indian. Our Schools recognize that but, when school life is finished, there is the Reserve before the young people, and to phrase it mildly, it is not always easy there to live up to the Schools' standard of health and industry and general progress.

Outside of Churches and Schools
the white people Indians usually meet are not often best calculated to advance them, spiritually or materially.

They come in contact commercially with the close bargainer whose acts almost unconsciously suggest to the Indian that money is the highest good in life to white people; and that it is excusable to stretch one's conscience a bit to obtain it.

Some of the men freighting in the West or jobbing in the East meet social good-for-nothings selling outside of saloons.

Very friendly fellows, these white men, and for quite a small consideration they will go in and buy the Indian a flask of liquor! They do it warily, for in their code it is a sin to break the law if you permit yourself to get caught.

In the lumber camps from Lake Superior eastward you will find a great many Indians at work, but with all respect for some thoroughly good shanty men I have met in the west, I should say the gangs in most of these camps are not likely to edify anyone or elevate one's standard of life.

As to the women, in the East a few of them selling wares meet well-dressed women on the verandahs of summer cottages and hotels; and I know they come in contact with the trim exteriors of many good homes. But how can the Indian woman imitate what she has never seen—the strict cleanliness and cosy appointments of a well-ordered home among her white sisters?
The Indian mothers are, as a rule, more affectionate than the white mothers of America; this is one of the beautiful traits of their character. But the great majority of them have a pitiful disregard for the laws of hygiene in bringing up their children and can not make their homes bright or attractive, because they often have not the vaguest idea of how to set about it.

The younger, educated generation feels this keenly.

Indian girls from Kamloops, Regina, All Hallows and Qu'Appelle Industrial schools have been from time to time at service in the towns near those schools. They have given such satisfaction that there is always a demand for them.

Madame Forget of Regina, who has an Indian girl in her employ at Government House, says there is no need of an organization to find places for Indian graduates at Regina, as the graduates of these schools, wishing to enter domestic service may practically choose their own places at good wages.

But the principals of the schools seem to have withdrawn their encouragement from the outward movement. A new plan has been taken up in the West to the exclusion of all others—that of marrying the graduates and settling them in small colonies isolated from their uneducated relatives.
Isolated, they say,—yet on the same reserve, and that in a country where 20 miles is a mere jaunt.

It is a good plan and if a real desire and aptitude for farming could be developed in the Indians as a whole it would be practically the best and only plan. Its progress will be very slow however upon many reserves, because it depends greatly upon what manner of man the Agent is. As yet it has been introduced to any extent upon only one agency.

For the Eastern Indians this plan is not at all a suitable one. Most of the Quebec Indians have not the land to spare for this, and the North Shore Ojibways simply will not farm if there is a lumber-camp, a mine or a fishing station within fifty miles of their reserves.

The Agent for the Kamloops Indians reports them as industrious, sober, law-abiding, yet many of them are employed on railroads, fishing, mining and freighting.

In the last Report of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs we read that after years of opportunities for taking to agriculture the Micmac Indians have cultivated only 8 acres to each unit of the population.

The Oka Indians are the only really agricultural Indians of Quebec. Ontario has quite a number in the Western peninsula, but the North Shore, Lake Superior, Pat Portage and Manitoba
Indians do little more than gardening. In a few inspectorates in the North-West Territories, where the land is very fertile and easily worked or suitable for ranching, the Indians may be classed as agricultural. In British Columbia again those near the Canning factories and railroads prefer these industries to farming.

But few races manifest a desire to be entirely agricultural and among Indians least of all is the desire universal. Perhaps when nature-study comes to be introduced into every Indian school a taste for agriculture may be developed in the Indians, but just now there is a generation of educated young people on the reserves waiting to begin life at some congenial work.

An Ethnologist recently discovered in the peninsula of India records inscribed in a form of Japanese characters similar to the few Siouan inscriptions that have been found in the Eastern States.

When deciphered these records strengthened the former impression of ethnologists, American and Japanese, that the Indians of America and the Japanese are of the same stock.

Now, the Japanese, as we know, are particularly clever in fine handiwork. So too are our Indian men and women at basket-work, bead-work, bark-work, mat and blanket weaving and in making lacrosse sticks and snowshoes. They have been fitted by nature and by
centuries of ingenious handiwork to become efficient workers at our various industries.

Then the two schemes should be encouraged and permitted to supplement each other. The farming colonies for the majority, if you will, but others for those who want to come and see the world and take their place with us.

The boys could be placed at various trades, or as gardeners, and a few at more intellectual work, possibly. Most of the girls would find work at domestic service, but at least a few of the most capable and cheerful should be thoroughly trained as nurses, and then joined to the Victorian Order sent back to help their people. The good they could do therein preventing the spread of tuberculosis and other disease is inestimable. Indian women are usually left-handed, soft-voiced and sympathetic; they would seem to be particularly fitted for the nurses' profession and have in fact proven it after graduation from American schools.

Our plan has also this recommendation—that it will educate the public up to a knowledge of the capabilities and good traits and social needs of these people toward whom we will have undeniable responsibilities for many decades yet.

It is one of the remarkable things in connection with the Indian question that white people in general even the most cultured know nothing of the Indians of today.
Summer tourists know the fat Indian perching under her load of baskets; fortunate men who go back to our Western hills and lakes each year, know there the "Silent, Smoky Indian" skipping there as guide. But these can not be taken as altogether representative types of a race that improves upon acquaintance. When their reserve is once laid aside we learn that they are honest, tactful, grateful, humorous, obedient and less quarrelsome than white races.

At the Congress of Indian teachers at Buffalo this year, Major Pratt, Superintendent of Carlisle, who has almost 1500 pupils under his supervision says that although 620 of his boys and girls are at work in Pennsylvania families more than 1000 applications for help had to be refused last year. The applications came from farms, shops and homes.

The Superintendent of Phoenix School Arizona, has over 300 pupils working out half their time as housemaids and laborers. The Indian girls from the school are so much in demand that he could send out 1500 more within a radius of 5 miles.

What these men and other Americans have been doing with their Indians for the past 15 years surely we can also do.

Descendants of various races, we Canadians are beginning to build up the fires
A patriotic love for our own Canada. Yet back of us is a very substantial shadow of the people who love Canada as a man can only love his fatherland. They are the people whose birthright we are enjoying.

We have dispossessed them as amicably as possible, it is true, and handed them back on to Reserves, and, when we except the handful of missionaries and officials, have tried to forget the Indians' existence.

But he has been coming in to a stage of civilization, where we can and should help him new ways. Honor and justice demand of us everything we can do now for the people we have pushed back into an ignoble dependence.

Nothing that we purpose doing for the Indian is going to improve the prospects of the white labourer. The white man has 2000 centuries of civilization behind him; at any rate; if not quite worthless, he should be able to take care of himself industrially—I do not say socially.

This work for the Indians is lying at our hands waiting to be taken up. Shall we refuse it?—and to our own reproach and regret afterward let the responsibility slip from our shoulders to await more tragic workers? I think not; I hope not. For myself I shall never quit the work until these necessary steps have been taken for the Indians' advancement, and successfully taken.

Katherine Hughes.

At meeting held in Ottawa, Sept. 15, 1901.

In interests of educated Indians.
Ottawa, Canada. Sept. 14, 1901

Esteemed Lady,

I have learned with great pleasure the interest which you are taking in the welfare of the Indians boys and girls, especially in the making of some arrangements whereby these boys and girls, after leaving the industrial school, should be provided with some employment.

It is indeed deplorable to see these boys and girls receiving a good education at many sacrifices on the part of the Government and the instructors, and then being forced back to their reserves, where it is almost impossible for them to avoid falling back into their former way of living.

What a delusion for these poor children! They have been brought to the schools in order to educate them and to ameliorate their condition; and afterwards they are permitted, and even forced to relapse into their former ways, because there is no opening for them where their education could be of any benefit to them, and because there is a lack of persons who would be disposed to accept their services. It would have been better to allow them to follow the customs of their sires, than after filling their minds with ambition by a superior education, to blight their hopes and to allow them to retrograde into their former way of living.

Wishing you God's choicest blessings for the good work,

I remain,
Sincerely Yours,

† D. Falconis, Asch. of Langley
Apostolic Delegate

SCHOOL ESTIMATES.

Indians, Manitoba and Northwest Territories: Day, Boarding and
Industrial Schools ........... $203,302.00

Mr. LaRiviere: I wish to ask the Minister if the policy hitherto
followed by the Government with regard to industrial schools is being
changed? I understand that one of these industrial schools in Manitoba
and another one in the Territories are being closed, and that board-
schools on the reserves are being substituted in lieu thereof. Is
that a new policy on the part of the Government?

Mr. Sifton: I have discussed this question of industrial schools
in the House several times before and I stated that my views were, my
views have not changed and the policy of the Department is just the
same as it was when I explained it on a previous occasion. My own be-
lief is that the system of industrial schools as I found it in opera-
tion when I took office, is not the best, or the most effective, or
the most economic way of improving the condition of the Indians. I
thought the system adopted was an artificial system. I found that In-
dian boys and girls were being kept in these schools in some cases
until they were 23, 24 and 25 years of age. The Dominion of Canada
is not under any obligation to conduct a system of education for an
Indian tribe, under which the education of each child became so ex-
pensive and artificial. I put in force a rule that children were not
remain in the schools after the age of eighteen and that rule has
been followed except in a very few cases where for special reasons
it has been relaxed. We have substituted a less elaborate system;
a system of what we call boarding schools where a larger number of
children can be for a shorter time be educated more economically and
generally more effectively. What we desire to do is not to give a
highly specialized education to half-a-dozen out of a large band of In-
dians, but if possible to distribute over the whole band a moderate
amount of education and intelligence so that the general status of
the band would be raised. While none of those engaged on behalf of
the different churches in Indian education were not of my view at the
time, I believe they have pretty well come to that opinion now. I
did not think it was justifiable for me to change the policy which had
been
been deliberately entered upon and in regard to which a large amount of money had been expended, so I stated to the House that while on the whole I held that view, I was not prepared to discontinue the industrial schools which existed. I thought I was bound to continue them on the existing lines, but that the rule should be enforced that pupils should not remain to an advanced age. I held, however, that in the establishment of further institutions the principle should be followed of contracting a boarding school rather than an industrial school system. My hon. friend (Mr. Laiviere) is probably aware that the authorities of St. Boniface Industrial School have found that the principle which I have advocated was the principle which should be applied in carrying out their work, because the Department accepted a proposition of theirs by which they agreed to take off our hands at a valuation the buildings and the property of the industrial school at St. Boniface and to build three boarding schools in lieu thereof. They agreed with my opinion that the boarding schools, where a less elaborate and lengthy system of education would be carried on and a larger number of children benefitted (those schools being placed at different points upon the reserve) was more beneficial than the carrying on of one industrial school at St. Boniface. We are carrying on the industrial school which exists at the present time. Our desire is not to multiply them but to inaugurate boarding schools wherever additional educational facilities are required. Experience shows that in order to get really effective results, the boarding school must be resorted to. In some places where we have day schools, and where we cannot incur the expense of a boarding school, the results are not as satisfactory as we could hope.

Mr. Laiviere: Do I understand that the boarding schools are as effective as the industrial schools? I would remind the hon. gentlemen that the education of the Indians does not merely consist of teaching them to read and write but that in addition they have to be civilized. In that case if you keep the Indians within their reserve I am afraid the civilization of the Indian will not be attained. I believe the best way to civilize them is to remove them from their reserves and get them to lead a civilized life at least for a certain time. I fear that the civilization of the Indians will not be attained by keeping them on their reserves, removed from the knowledge and influences of
I do not think that the question of cost should be taken into consideration in such a case and I fear that we are going back on a system that was found to be good. I see from the last report of the Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs that he proclaimed the system of industrial schools to be far better than the other systems on that very account.

Mr. Sifton: The result of my observation and study in connection with the industrial schools was this, that the attempt to give a highly civilized education to the Indian child, keeping him in a school until he was 22 or 23 years of age and attempting to teach him a trade, was practically a failure. I have no hesitation in saying (we may as well be frank) that the Indian cannot go out from a school, making his own way and compete with the white man. Experience shows that when you give an Indian every possible chance until he is 22 or 23 years of age you cannot afford to turn him loose to look after himself; you will get no satisfactory result, an Indian cannot succeed in competition with other people. That was why the teachers in some of the schools insisted on keeping the pupils after the age when they ought to be sent out. Then I asked: Why do you keep these pupils here? The answer was we did not know what to do with them. If they go out they must either attempt to compete with other people or go back to the reserve. I am no doubt myself that a system between the day school and the industrial school whereby any child could be taken in at a moderately early age and kept for four or five years of training in the school, is the system under which you could get the best results.

I may say that the inspectorate of Mr. Graham, the Qu'Appelle inspectorate, this system has been inaugurated. Mr. Graham has set apart a portion of the reserve where the pupils from the industrial and boarding schools are encouraged to settle and take up allotments, so that that have practically a separate settlement, one being alongside the other they have a certain amount of encouragement to continue a civilized life. That system has been in operation for a comparatively short time, but Mr. Graham is satisfied that it is going to prove successful and I myself am satisfied on general principles that it will probably be the most successful way of bringing about a higher state of civilization amongst them.
Mr. W.J. Hoche: Might I ask the hon. minister if it is the intention to continue the Elkhorn Industrial school and are the trades still being taught to the Indian pupils in that school?

Mr. Sifton: No change has been made in the Elkhorn school except that we are trying to cut down the expenses. The expense has been very high, I think unreasonably high, and there has been a contest between the head office and the Commissioner in regard to keeping it down. The expense was cut down a little during the past year. My hon. friend will find in the report of the Department the following statement:

"We are encouraging the boys to take up agriculture, as we feel that this is the most important industry that can be taught them. The boys are instructed in carpentry, painting, bootmaking, farming and gardening. A number are also employed in general work about the institution and in keeping the grounds in order. The girls are taught cooking, housework, laundry-work, dressmaking, plain sewing, knitting and crocheting. They perform all the necessary household duties in all of which they show great aptitude."

Mr. Clarke: When the idea of schools, day, boarding and industrial was up I intended to ask the hon. minister as to the percentage of Indian children that pass through the Indian schools who retain the veneer of civilization which they receive there? I visited the Indian school at Brandon, was very much interested in the work, and would like to know from the hon. minister if these children after passing through the school, are sent back to the reservation, and if so, how many of them lapse again? How many of them retain the polish they got in the schools and what becomes of them?

Mr. Sifton: I could not offhand give the hon. gentlemen the exact statistics.

Mr. Clarke: I just want the hon. gentleman to state generally.

Mr. Sifton: Speaking generally the result has been that the pupils of the industrial schools have not been able to go out in ordinary life and compete with white men. I have stated my opinion as to what was the result and what was likely to be the result of this form of Indian education. I am perfectly satisfied that you cannot take the child of the ordinary prairie Indian, put him in an industrial school, keep him there until he is 21 years of age and turn him loose to earn...
This living amongst white men. He has not the physical, mental or moral get-up to enable him to compete. He cannot do it. The result has been that to a large extent the Indians who have been educated in this way have gone back to the reserves. I do not think that this work has been in any way lost because I can say to my honourable friend from my own knowledge having lived in the Northwest since 1876, that there is the most marvellous change in the general character of Indian bands.

Mr. Clarke: Is that the result of the infusion of educated civilized Indians into the reservation?

Mr. Sifton: I think that is very largely the result of the educational work that is being carried on. I think we have got less per dollar from the money we have expended in the industrial schools than we have from any of the other schools. I believe in the day and boarding schools. We have got a great deal more for the money which has been expended on these schools, while we have not educated them to such a high point, we have infused a great amount of education amongst a larger number. A very promising experiment is being made by Mr. Graham, the inspector of the Sul'Appelle Agencies, who has been most successful in bringing about a better state of affairs amongst the Indians under his charge. He has made good practical farmers out of them; they raised 65,000 bush. of wheat last year; we are now buying cattle from them for supplying other reserves; they are most successful and we have ceased the distribution of supplies amongst them. Mr. Graham has adopted this plan: He has set aside locations on certain portions of the reserve and he encourages the young men and the young women who come from the schools to marry and settle down on these locations. He endeavours to see that they are not interfered with by any of the rest of the Indians. As a matter of practice, one of the most serious difficulties in improving an Indian band is that just as soon as an Indian couple show an inclination to thrift and gather a little property around them, all their Indian relations think it necessary for them to work just in proportion as this couple is prosperous. Their relations take their supplies and consequently they have no encouragement to accumulate property. Mr. Graham has been most successful in this experiment. A few years ago I put him in charge of three different agencies.
Agencies and lately I have promoted him to be inspector, so that he has a larger scope for his activity. I believe Mr. Graham will solve the problem if it can be solved, and he will solve it by endeavouring to promote settlement in a separate locality of those who come from the schools, and where they can have as much higher or civilized life as they could if they settled amongst other Indians.

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Sup't. General,

With reference to your memo. of the 20th August last,
I beg to submit statements showing the total cost of operating
A & B: the Industrial schools throughout the Dominion from their in-
ception to the 30th June 1903, returns are not yet in for the
year ended 1904, together with a statement showing the amounts
contributed by the Government towards the erection and equipment
of boarding schools, and, so far as the records of the Depart-
ment go, the contributions made by the religious denominations
carrying on the work among the Indians.

The total cost of operating industrial schools amounts
to $2,648,494.54, exclusive of Ontario, the expenditure in this
Province has been about $20,000 annually for some years past,
while the expenditure for the year ended 30th June 1903 for in-
dustrial schools was $208,241.67. This has been increasing
annually. The accompanying statement shows the amounts expended
on each of the industrial schools in the different provinces
for that year.

In reply to your enquiry as to what benefit is derived
from the training of pupils in industrial schools, I cannot do
better than refer you to remarks of the Minister as contained
in the Hansard of the 18th July of this year when discussing
the school estimates in the House. (See page 6956 of Hansard
at seq., an extract from which accompanies this memo.) It
has never been the policy of the Department nor the design of
industrial schools to turn Indian pupils out to compete with
whites. The industrial schools were established for the pur-
pose of giving the Indian pupils a better education than the
day or boarding schools afforded and to bring them more into
the ways of civilized life than the residence on the reserves
permits; and I think I may safely say that they have succeeded
in this. If they have not gone farther, it has been in part
to the system in vogue at these schools. I have always main-
tained that more lasting results would be secured if the system
were changed so as to necessitate the pupils working their
own way through school instead of being carried on holens volens.
The returns giving the status of discharged pupils, who have
passed through industrial schools, show in the majority of in-
stances that the results have been satisfactory. The girls
are
in nearly every instance have turned out well and married and
endeavouring to keep a comfortable home. The Indian boys where
opportunity offers are working for themselves or others with
fair success. Many of the reserves are unfitted for agricul-
ture and the returned pupils have to take up the occupations
of the other Indians of the tribe, and in such case the train-
ing at the school has not been of any great advantage to them.
Where they are able to do a little farming the training
has been beneficial; but they are all handicapped for want of
means to make a start, and I claim that if they had the oppor-
tunity of earning something while at school instead of depend-
ing upon the generosity of the Government to supply them, much
better results would follow.

Since the industrial schools were established consider-
able modifications have been made from the original design,
which was formerly to give them trades instruction in addi-
tion to farming; now the efforts of all these schools are devoted
to agriculture, and such trade instructions as they receive
is merely to supplement this design and make them handy all
round farmers, carpentering and use of tools being taught to
all the male pupils. The girls are all instructed in house-
hold duties and should make excellent housekeepers. These
schools are not designed to turn out servants or employees.

Sir:

For some time past there has been a growing conviction on the part of those engaged in educational work among the Indians of the Dominion, that a time has come when it would be in the interest of the Government, the Indians and the churches to re-consider the whole question. The experimental stage has had its day and if the results have not been all that was desired or hoped, yet the experience gained may be very useful as indicating wherein past methods have been defective, and whether any of them are capable of improvement or should be discarded for something entirely different.

During the past few months several informal conferences have been held between representatives of the Anglican, Methodist and Presbyterian churches for the purpose of comparing views, giving the results of experience in Indian educational work, and ascertaining how far the Churches would be prepared to co-operate in bringing the matter to the attention of the Government, and, if desired, in helping to outline a uniform policy applicable to the whole Dominion. These conferences have shown important that on many points there is a general consensus of opinion among the churches, and a sincere desire to co-operate with the Government in any comprehensive plan that will promise better results than have been secured in the past.
We recognize in common, we believe, with the Head of the Indian Department that the present annual expenditure in that Department is very large; and it has occurred to us that by a careful revision and modification of the educational policy a considerable reduction might be effected, or at all events, such a system inaugurated as would result in far better work. The latter point is the more important; for even large expenditure for the benefit of these wards of the nation should not be objected to if only the work accomplished is in some good degree commensurate with the outlay, but unless good results on a larger scale can be secured, the present expenditure can hardly be justified.

As the object of this memorandum is to invite the attention of the Government to the general question of Indian education with a view to such action in the future as may be deemed wise and expedient, it is unnecessary at present to go largely into details, but we respectfully beg to submit a few suggestions to indicate certain lines along which, in our judgment, changes might wisely be introduced.

As the result of a somewhat lengthy experience we are convinced that the ordinary day school on an Indian reserve is of very little use, and in most cases might be dispensed with to advantage if more efficient provision can be made in some other way, which we deem quite feasible. It seems to be practically impossible to secure anything like regular attendance at the ordinary day school, and the difficulties in the way of inducing the children to use the English language are insurmountable. To secure useful results it is essential that the Indian children during the educational period, should be kept entirely apart, wherever possible, from the associations of life on the reserve, and that the educational process should be continued until an age is reached when they will be capable of taking care of themselves.
As an alternative for the day school we would suggest a system of well equipped and properly conducted boarding or industrial schools, supplemented by a limited number of institutes where further training might be given to the most promising pupils from the boarding schools. These schools should be, as a rule, at some distance from the reserves, but so located as to be of easy access to the largest number of Indian children, and the equipment should depend, to some extent, upon the surroundings of the school. Where good land is available and climatic conditions are favorably, the chief, if not the sole industries should be:

(a) For the boys:—Mixed farming, including the raising and care of live stock, cereals, field and garden vegetables, etc. The teaching of ordinary trades seems practically useful.

(b) For Girls:—All kinds of housework, including care of rooms, making of beds, cooking, laundry work, sewing, knitting, butter-making, poultry raising and ordinary garden work.

The age limit for pupils in boarding schools might be from six or seven to twelve or fourteen years, according to circumstances, but each pupil should have at least five years of continuous residence. In view of the suggested age limit, farm work would be on a comparatively limited scale at the boarding schools, but quite sufficient for a good beginning. In localities where farm work is impracticable other forms of outdoor industry for boys would have to be considered. But as the raising of cattle and the cultivation of the soil constitute the forms of industry to which the Indian, under proper training, will most readily adapt himself, and are physically and morally the most wholesome, we respectfully submit they should receive special attention wherever possible.

It is probable that boarding schools such as are here referred to would meet the needs of the majority of the Indian children; but doubtless there will be a certain number for whom further
further provision should be made. We would suggest, therefore, the maintenance of a limited number of well equipped industrial institutes to which pupils from the boarding schools, who have reached a prescribed standard, might be sent for further training. If taken in at the age of 12 or 14 years they should not be allowed to depart (save under exceptional circumstances) till they have attained their majority, or say 18 years for the girls and 21 years for the boys. We also deem it important that during their stay in the institute the older boys and girls should receive, under careful regulations, a graduated scale of remuneration for their work, and thus be encouraged to cultivate habits of thrift and have something wherewith to begin life when institute days are ended.

And this leads to a point perhaps the most important of all, touching the Indian educational problem,—namely the entire lack of provision to start the young Indians in life when the training time is over. When leaving the institution, at the very door-step there is a yawning chasm without any bridge by which it may be crossed and into which even the most promising pupils must inevitably fall. That is to say, when the institute is left behind, the only refuge is the reserve, or worse still, the hunting lodge, where a few years will undo, in most cases, many years of careful training and frustrate the best efforts of those who seek to raise the Indian into independent manhood. This does not mean that it is useless to educate the Indian. The fatal defect,—the missing link—is just at the point where his education ends and his independent industrial life should begin. We venture to say that if a given number of foreigners, on their arrival in this country, were put upon a reserve and treated in all respects as Indians, in less than a generation they would be Indians to all intents and purposes. So long as the Indian is treated as a ward and a minor, he never can be developed into a man and a citizen.
As a remedy for the evil referred to what we would respectfully suggest is this: That when an Indian youth has reached his majority and has graduated with credit from an institute, he be given land in his own right, 40 or 80 acres to begin with, and the promise of the balance of the quarter section when he has shown his ability to use it properly. The title to the land to be given at the end of say three, four or five years, when the occupant has proved his capability to maintain an independent position. But the land alone will not suffice. The occupant should receive assistance to provide necessary but inexpensive buildings, a few head of live stock, necessary farm implements to begin operations with, seeds of various kinds and provisions to tide him over the first year at least till the returns from the land begin to come in. Unless this or some analogous plan can be adopted, we see little hope for the industrial future of the Indian tribes.

In regard to the boarding schools we would respectfully call the attention of the Superintendent General to the impossibility of maintaining them on the present per capita basis, and as these schools, at least those within treaty limits, are established in furtherance of the treaty obligations of the Government, there does not seem to be any sufficient reason why the churches should meet the deficit out of moneys contributed for purely religious purposes. If the whole cost is borne by the Department this may raise the further question whether these shall be Government schools pure and simple, and what part, if any, the churches should have in their management. In cases where the Indians belong chiefly to one denomination the case might be met by allowing the authorities of the church in question to nominate the Principal, provision for religious instruction (which we deem most important) to be a matter for mutual arrangement between the Department and the churches concerned.

There are other aspects of this question worthy of careful
careful consideration which we have not touched upon, but if the Government is disposed to go into the whole question, either by commission or directly by the Indian Department, we shall be most happy to render any assistance in our power and to cooperate in plans that may be deemed most advantageous to the Indian youth of the country.

Respectfully submitted,
