OTTAWA, 11th January, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The memorial hereunder which is undated and unsigned, regarding the question of Indian education, purports to set out the joint views of the three Protestant denominations engaged in this work among the Indians, but before a uniform policy applicable to the whole Dominion could be considered, the Roman Catholic Church would have to be asked to co-operate as they have charge of a larger number of schools and have been longer in the field than any other denomination. They also have more intimate acquaintance with the Indians.

The Minister himself has recognized the desirability of a revision and modification of the educational policy and if the co-operation of all the churches interested can be secured, a better system might be devised than the one at present in operation, one which would give more satisfactory results for the money expended. The memorial then proceeds to offer a few suggestions indicating certain lines along which changes might be introduced.

It is suggested that a day school on an Indian reserve is of very little use and in most cases might be dispensed with to advantage if more efficient provision could be made in some other way which is deemed quite feasible. This is at present to a large extent correct as out of the 228 day schools in operation on the 30th June last, 98 had an average attendance of less than 10, but the chief failure of day schools in obtaining satisfactory results is owing to
to the class of schools established. Many of these schools should be discontinued for lack of attendance but the others should be improved, as a properly conducted day school can make its influence felt on a reserve. Better equipment and larger salaries would be required to put them on a sound basis. Chap. 32, 57-58 Victoria, Sections 167-168 provide for the compulsory attendance of all Indian children between the ages of 7 and 16 at a day school, and for the punishment of parents or guardians who refuse or neglect to cause their children to attend. Regulations were made by His Excellency, the Governor General in Council on the 10th Nov. 1894 for the carrying out of this Act.

The alternative suggested for the day school is a system of well-equipped and properly conducted boarding or industrial schools where children from 6 or 7 to 12 or 14 years might be placed and receive the training indicated in the memorial. We have 46 boarding schools now in operation in the Dominion which have been established at the solicitation of religious bodies. They have provision for 1523 pupils and had an average attendance for the year ended 30th June last of 1449, and are in receipt of a per capita grant of $60 in the Provinces of Ontario and B.C., and $72 in Manitoba and the North-West. Nearly all the schools of this class are in financial difficulties and are poorly equipped and badly placed. The Government grant not being sufficient to carry on the schools under the most economical, the missionary societies find themselves hampered in their efforts to improve their condition.
Although these boarding schools have been established and put up by the different churches, the Department has contributed large amounts towards the cost of the buildings, and if these suggestions are approved of a number of the present boarding schools should be abandoned, as it would never be possible to make them successful. With regard to the industrial training to be given in all such schools, it should be with the end in view of fitting the pupils, if they are to return to their reserves, for the conditions they will encounter when they leave school.

The age limit suggested in the memorandum is rather young. It would be a hardship to take children from their parents at such a tender age, even if the law permitted this to be done. It is doubtful whether the Act gives power to compel Indians to send their children to industrial or boarding schools, and the Courts have held that even when admitted to such schools with the parents consent, they cannot be held under the present regulations if proceedings are taken for the issue of a writ of habeas corpus. See Judge Richards opinion re application of Roderick Cameron to secure the control of his two sons who were pupils at the Rupert's Land Industrial school, file 117377---10. This being the case, it would seem wiser to improve the system before extending the schools. The present schools are not popular among the Indians.

The most valuable suggestion made in this memorandum is the one referring to the starting of the young Indian in life when his school career is ended and it should receive most careful consideration.
The question of increasing the per capita grant to boarding schools should also be considered, as it is plain that they cannot be maintained at the present allowance, and it would appear to be better to raise the grant than have to pay deficits. If, however, the grant is raised, some more definite arrangement should be made with the churches conducting these schools, which would relieve the Department from responsibility for their financial management, and they should in all cases be placed in charge of the most competent men, who should devote their whole time and attention to their management.

This memorial is worthy of careful consideration and the sooner the whole Indian school question is gone into the better.

In conclusion I may state that Rev. Dr Sutherland, when here last spring expressed himself in favor of the views enunciated in this memorandum and the Presbyterian Church authorities have also expressed similar views.
Department of Indian Affairs.

There is such a notably weak feature in nearly all Indian Schools that I wish to direct attention to it. It accounts, in my opinion, for much of our educational effort which is admittedly wasted. For it is beyond doubt that Indian children have the capacity to learn and that the reason of non-success in education is not to be found in want of intelligence.

From the moment they enter schools, whether day, boarding, or industrial, teaching should commence which is directly aimed at making them understand the difference between the status of a reserve Indian and an Indian who has all the rights of a citizen. Such teaching could no other be given, would be of greater practical value than all other combined. Yet I have never known a school in which it was given, and this is the weak feature in our schools to which I refer.

Nothing in the least approaching invidious or disagreeable comparisons should enter into such teaching; but the lesson should be learned as completely as may be before children leave the schools.

development it means nothing. In white schools we aim to teach what is not taught in the homes not what is taught there for that would be superfluous. The school teaching plus the home teaching is designed to produce the character.

Teachers are trained to do the school's part of teaching in white schools; curriculums are framed to systematize that part of the child's teaching; Inspectors are appointed to see it done.

But put these same teachers, curriculums and Inspectors into operation, as we do, on Indian children and no matter how well they operate the Indian children's character is left unmade. What the white child learns in his home and at his mother's knee remains unlearned. Yet this is the most important part of life's lesson to the child.

It is some seventeen years since, having in view the strengthening of this weak feature, I drafted a course of study for Indian Schools which had as an end in view the teaching of Indian children what they could not learn in their homes. I now, with seventeen years added experience assure you of the absolute need of such teaching, and that it has not been given. It was complained that a text book was needed. One was written and was sent to print, but was subsequently withdrawn for reasons unnecessary to relate, but which had nothing to do with the needs of the case. The needs were recognized and admitted.

The best teaching given on lines of white education, except on one or two reserves where home teaching is sound, has failed and must fail to have ultimate good effects commensurate to its excellence, because knowledge without character must always be in great degree a dangerous thing. Our experience has shown that it is so.

Ottawa, March 21st., 1908.

Reverend and dear Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the Memorandum of resolutions agreed upon by a Joint Committee representing the Methodist, Presbyterian and Anglican Churches in the month of April 1907 with additions made on the 29th of October; comprising altogether eight sub-heads.

These resolutions embody certain recommendations which you have thought proper to submit to the Department on the subject of Indian education, and since their receipt they have been the subject of careful consideration. Before dealing with the present position occupied by the question of Indian education it seems desirable to give a short review of the whole subject in order that it may be seen how the existing establishment has arisen, and why it is maintained. It is self-evident that the prime purpose of Indian education is to assist in solving what may be called the Indian problem, to elevate the Indian from his condition of savagery, to make him a self-supporting member of the state, and eventually a citizen in good standing. The work of Indian education from the earliest times has always been experimental, having this object in view, and if these methods have been open to criticism in some important particulars, yet it can safely be said that the general effect of the policy has made for the betterment of Indian conditions throughout the country.

The first efforts to educate the Indians were undertaken by the early missionaries to this country. Probably the first regular school established was at the Grand River, after the Six Nations had been settled there by Governor Haldimand. The imperial authorities under whose direction Indian affairs were administered up to the year 1860 did not make any special grant for education. The first funds set
apart for these purposes arose from the commutation made by certain tribes of their annual distribution of ammunition. This formed the nucleus of what was called the Indian school fund, an account which was held as part of the Indian Trust Fund. This contribution began in 1848 and ended on the 30th June 1862. This Indian School Fund maintained Industrial schools at Mount Elgin and Alderville which were conducted by the Methodist Church upon a per capita grant. Thus, at the inception of the Indian school question, we find two main characteristics which have ever since continued, i.e., the principle of the per capita grant and the denominational interest. The Indian School Fund remained the sole financial aid to Indian education until 1875-6 when a grant to assist it was made by the Parliament of Canada. This financial aid enabled the Department to open day schools on various reserves in the Maritime Provinces and the Provinces of Ontario and Quebec. The trust funds of the Indian bands also began to be made use of to a certain extent as the interest of the Indians themselves in education increased.

The early Treaties or Surrenders by which the Indians ceded territory to the Crown did not stipulate for education as one of the considerations for this cession. The first mention of education as an obligation to be met by the Government appears in the Indian Treaty known as Treaty No. I, which was signed in the year 1871. This provision for education was included in the subsequent treaties and it is in part owing to the endeavor of the Department to carry out these Treaty stipulations that the large expenditure has arisen. But these treaty stipulations have been more than fulfilled. As a rule the educational clauses of the Treaties simply state that teachers shall be provided when the Indians desire them. The inception of an educational policy was thus left to the Indians but has been initiated solely by the Government with a view to advance their general interests.

The first grant by the Dominion Government towards Indian
It was not until the year 1879-80 that any appropriation was made for Indian education in Manitoba and the North West Territories, and in that year the sum of $11,000.00 was granted. The Indians of British Columbia received no educational benefits from Dominion expenditure until the year 1874-5 when $2474.47 was spent from the general appropriations. In 1878-9 the question of establishing Indian Industrial Schools in the West was first taken up.

The first industrial school was established at Battleford in 1883. The Department adopted the principles which had long governed Indian education in the older Provinces and this school was conducted by the Church of England. In the following year industrial schools were established at Qu'Appelle and High River under the guidance of the Roman Catholic Church. The principle of the per capita grant was extended to the schools in the new district in the year 1891 as a step in the direction of economy. It may, therefore, be said that the Department in establishing these schools merely extended the system already in vogue in the Eastern Provinces. In the year 1887 the Department inaugurated the policy of expansion which resulted gradually in a very large increase in expenditure. No new principles of action were however adopted and the schools were conducted practically under the same rules and regulations and systems of payment. In the year 1878-79 the whole school appropriation for Canada was $16,000.00; in 1888-89 the expenditure was $178,980.93; for the year 1908-09 the appropriations will be $445,837.00. In addition to this expenditure from Consolidated Revenue the Indians themselves contributed an annual amount of over $10,000 from their own funds for the maintenance of day schools on their reserves, making a grand total of $456,000.00.

In the interval between 1882 and 1898 the Department had also completely wiped out the Indian School Fund, capital $39,148.83, and interest, and the account was accordingly closed on the 1st July 1898.

In addition to this large expenditure from Consolidated Revenue and Indian Trust Funds the religious denominations interested in the welfare of the Indians and the development of educational facilities have provided large sums of money to assist in the work. The exact amount so spent is not available, but is doubtless known to the financial agents of the Churches interested. From statements furnished during the eight years ending the 30th June 1906, published in the Report of the Department, it is gathered that the denominations contributed during that time at least $435,000.00 toward this end; and from this amount some idea may be formed of the aggregate of the expenditure during the whole term. This outlay has principally taken place in connection with Boarding Schools which were for the most part established by the Churches, erected by them, and supported to a large extent from Church funds; the Department contributing relatively small amounts for buildings and equipment, and an even per capita grant of $60.00 and $72.00 per annum.

The growing inability of the religious denominations to finance the claims made by the Institutions which they have been largely responsible in establishing has led to the demands for increased grants and for a re-consideration of the educational methods referred to in your memorandum.

The financial aspect of the question is important as without
a very large increase in appropriations the present establishment could not be maintained; the number of pupils at present on the roll could not be provided for, nor the buildings at present occupied could not be rebuilt, enlarged or improved. If the policy outlined in the joint memorandum were to be adopted without any effort at rearrangement or retrenchment a moderate estimate of the necessary appropriation would be $981,979.00.

If there had been no doubt that the educational system heretofore maintained was best calculated to further the civilization of the Indians, the increased appropriations might be justified and probably an extension of educational work along the same lines, but it is clear that the present system with its large expenditure has not operated as was expected towards the civilization of the aborigines. The high death rate in the schools and the adverse influence of the reserve environment on discharged pupils has tended with other causes to minimize the effect of educational advantages. These influences have always been known to the Department and have been accepted as one of the inherent difficulties of the problem.

The Department has by regulations, enforced by medical officers, endeavored to prevent the admission to the schools of pupils tainted with tubercular diseases or children unhealthy in any other respect; and considering the extent to which disease is rife amongst the Indians, it may be stated that a fair measure of success has followed the efforts to select only healthy pupils for residence in the schools.

The Department has endeavored also to maintain an interest in pupils discharged from the schools, as it was early recognized that one of the great difficulties to be overcome was to prevent whatever degree of improvement had been received during the school life from being lost the moment it came in contact with the relatively savage life of the reserve. To this end the Department has assisted the most promising graduates with gifts of agricultural implements, cattle, seed
grain and material to build houses, and has endeavored to separate as far as possible promising young Indians from the influences of the ordinary Indian life; and these efforts have been reasonably successful. But despite all this official care and the interest manifested by the religious denominations it is open to question whether the very large expenditure from all sources has been justified by the result; whether as regards the Indians of the plains and British Columbia the system was not in advance of the needs of the case, and whether a better plan would not have been to proceed on a less extensive scale and to postpone the more elaborate system of residential schools until such a time as the Indian has become more or less civilized by the pressure of influences from without, and had shown the improving effect of the instruction and supervision in agricultural pursuits freely given by the Government.

It would seem to be good policy at this juncture to attempt to devise a better system of Indian education, applying to each locality methods which would best achieve the desired result and at the same time while not increasing the financial obligations of the Government would remove from the Churches a burden which they do not now find themselves able to bear. With these preliminary remarks the sections of your memorandum may be considered seriatim.

(I) That the Government be requested to create an Advisory Board of Indian education to which all Churches and organizations engaged in Indian work shall have the privilege of nominating two representatives each.

(I) - There would appear to be no objection to the Churches creating an Advisory Board, having two representatives from each Church, for the purpose of consulting with the Department on educational questions in which the Churches are interested. The Department has at all times been willing to give full consideration to the representations of the churches, but it has been found confusing to deal with a large number of persons in authority who are interested in the Indian work.
(2) That in addition to the elements of an English education the Indian boys shall be trained in agricultural or such other pursuits in their different branches as may be possible where the School is situated, and also in such manual pursuits as may be useful to them in an outdoor life in the district to which they belong. Similarly with the girls that they be trained for domestic life and elementary nursing.

(3) This has always been the policy of the Department with reference to Indian education in residential schools. Often from the difficulty of collecting pupils from districts where the curriculum of the school can be of direct benefit to them it has not been carried out, but as the future policy of the Department and the contemplated rearrangement of residential schools would have in view a closer relation to the policy, it is hoped that it may be carried out with greater strictness with better results.

(4) That all the schools, resident and non-resident, shall be so constituted, equipped and conducted that the policy briefly outlined in the above clause may be most perfectly realised, and that the Government shall provide suitable buildings and equipments therefor.

(5) This clause is germane to No. 2, and it follows wherever day schools or residential schools are established suitable buildings and equipment should be provided. The general management of the school should reflect as closely as possible the policy to be adopted.

(6) That pupils, as a rule, shall be discharged at the age of eighteen, but it should be arranged that in exceptional cases, pupils may be retained longer on the recommendation of the Church in charge of the school and with the consent of the Indian Commissioner. Also it should be made possible for especially promising pupils to receive extra training for any special vocation at the expense of the Government, such pupils meantime to be under the supervision of the school.

(7) The existing rule is that pupils should be discharged at the age of 18, and, until it is clear that some other age limit could be established with advantage, that age may be allowed to stand. Exceptional cases should be considered on their merits, and the recommendation of the advisory board would be considered when the general question for the further education of promising
pupils comes up for consideration.

(5) While realizing the difficulties of administering a policy of compulsory education, we are convinced that such a principle is in the best interests of all concerned - of the parents, of the children, and of the State, and should be enforced so far as can be wisely and rightly done. If this becomes the accepted policy of the Government, is it too much to expect that the influence of Government employees be brought to bear in the kind but firm enforcement of the law?

The policy of funding the treaty money for children attending Boarding or Industrial Schools, having been found to operate against securing pupils for these Schools, should be discontinued, and all Government donations in excess of Treaty obligations should be withheld from such parents as refuse to send their children to school.

(6) The question of compulsory education will receive at once full consideration. Sections 9, 10 and II of the Indian Act, Chap. 81 of the Revised Statutes, empower the Governor in Council to make regulations to secure the compulsory attendance of children at school, and under a previous enactment, Chap. 32, 57, 58 Vic., regulations governing the education of Indian children were passed by His Excellency in Council on November 10, 1894. These regulations are still in force and go as far as was deemed advisable, as it was not considered that attendance at boarding and industrial schools could be made compulsory, and that no rule should be adopted which would provide for the arbitrary separation of parents and children. It has always been the wish of the Department that officials and employees should give their active influence in furthering the educational policy, and the attention of Agents generally will be again directed to this very important phase of their general administrative duties.

The funding of treaty money for children who attend boarding and industrial schools (which were undertaken in order that, on leaving school, they might have a small amount of cash to expend in the purchase of some necessary articles to begin life on the reserve) might be discontinued. It has often been questioned whether the trouble which the administration of these small accounts
entails was compensated by any genuine benefit to the mass of depositors, and if the withholding of annuity money from parents operates against the securing of pupils it may be thought well to reconsider this question.

The suggested step of withholding Government aid in excess of treaty obligations could hardly be adopted as part of a general educational policy. In very few agencies are donations given beyond treaty obligations and these are principally extended to destitute Indians, and it is necessary not to permit any harshness to Indians who cannot well provide for themselves.

(6) That whereas the Indians are wards of the Government, and their education, at least in part, secured by treaty, it is only reasonable that the Government should bear all expenses involved in such training as is contemplated, which would include a larger per capita grant. The Churches anxious and willing to continue to co-operate with the Government in the civilization and Christianization of the Indians are convinced that the moral and spiritual side of education cannot be hoped for except by the appointment of teachers in every way qualified for a work so peculiar and important. The request is therefore made that the appointment of teachers be entrusted to the Churches on terms to be mutually agreed upon.

(6) - The increased per capita grant suggested in Clause 6, if adopted, will virtually place the Government in the position of bearing all expenses involved in Indian education. The present establishment includes schools which while recognized by the Government were established in the first instance by the Churches, and it is thought that a rearrangement of these schools and the adoption of a new type of school would further the interests of Indian education and at the same time render it unnecessary to apply to Parliament for an increase in the gross appropriation. The expression of willingness on the part of the Churches to co-operate with the Government is noted with pleasure; and it is most important that teachers well qualified for the work should be appointed.
(7) That sanitariums and medical equipment and nurses and medical attendance be provided in central or suitable locations for the treatment of tubercular and other contagious diseases.

(7) - As you are no doubt aware the Department has a system of medical attendance which is intended generally to provide for this branch of the Indian work throughout the country. At a very early date it was recognized that this class of relief was one which would largely devolve on the Dominion Government and Parliamentary appropriations have since Confederation been obtained for this purpose. Of late years hospitals have also been established and in the older Provinces the hospitals for white communities have been made use of by the Indians. For the approaching fiscal year the Department has asked Parliament to vote the following sums for medical attendance, medicines and hospitals:

Within the last few years the experiment has been made of establishing tent hospitals for the treatment of tubercular diseases; one at Saddle Lake, one at Touchwood Hills, and one at Birtle, also a well equipped small hospital at Morley for the same purpose for the use of the Stony Indians and the pupils of the McDougall Orphanage. In British Columbia the Department has assisted in the establishment of five hospitals where Indian patients may be treated. It will be understood from these facts
that it will be necessary simply to extend the present provisions of the Department if thought advisable; no initiative is needed as would seem to be implied in this clause of the joint memorandum.

It might be wise however to test the results of the hospitals already established before increasing their number. Wherever well equipped hospitals are provided by municipalities which could be used by Indians it would seem a good policy to use these for treatment instead of multiplying the number of small hospitals intended solely for Indians; and this system the Department is following wherever the conditions warrant.

In addition to this professional attendance and supply of medical accessories the Department makes as large a use as possible of professional knowledge with reference to contagious diseases, tuberculosis, and sanitary measures generally. It issues to its Agents positive instructions in all matters of sanitation on the reserves and places them in possession of the simple and obvious methods of preventing the spread of tuberculosis; and they are made clearly to understand that a principal part of their duty is to enforce these regulations, and to keep constantly before the Indians the desirability of practising such preventive measures.

The question of nurses will be dealt with in remarks to be made on clause No. 8.

(8) The salary for a day school teacher to be $500. The Church to appoint teachers who have Provincial certificates.

We agree to manage residential schools in Ontario at a per capita grant of One Hundred Dollars, and One Hundred and Thirty Dollars per pupil in all such schools west of the Great Lakes.

This grant not to include the cost of material for the plant, nor anything that may be regarded as a fixture in the building, such as any plumbing or heating apparatus, etc.

Any deficits in the cost of management to be met by the Church managing the school. The Department to make the buildings of residential schools thoroughly sanitary and with sufficient
ventilation, supplying medical men and nurses wherever necessary.

As the suggested changes may involve larger financial outlay, attention is called to the fact that at present there are more residential schools than are necessary to supply the needs of the territory occupied, and that it might be a wise policy to reduce the number or to transfer some of them to more needy localities.

(8) - This clause deals with the financial side of the question.

As stated in my preliminary remarks, if the present educational system could be shown to have justified the expenditure upon it, it might not be difficult to ask for increased appropriations; but as the consensus of opinion seems to be that such is not the case, I would find it difficult at present to justify the increase which would be necessary if the augmented scale of per capita allowances and teachers' salaries was to be adopted for the present enrollment; and if any change were to be made it would involve an increase of as before shown of about $166,142.00 and a capital expenditure of about $350,000.00.

At the outset it might be remarked that the question is complicated by the fact that the Roman Catholic Church while equally interested with the Protestant denominations in the evangelization and education of the Indians has not asked for any generally increased grants, and do not seek more favorable terms. You will recognize the impossibility of dealing with the question at all and overlooking the rights of a Church so largely interested in the work to treatment equally favorable.

The educational needs of the Indians vary in different Provinces and it would seem to be advisable to divide the subject into several classes geographically, and to deal with each separately:

NOVA SCOTIA, NEW BRUNSWICK, PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND,
QUEBEC, ONTARIO.

The day schools throughout Indian reserves in these Provinces are usually more or less in touch with surrounding
civilization and as the Indians themselves are more or less civil-
ised the conduct of the schools should approximate as nearly as
possible to conditions which appertain amongst white people. It
might be laid down as a rule that the teachers of Indian schools
who are well qualified for the special work should be paid a salary
of from $300.00 to $500.00, and the principle of annual increases
should be resorted to in order to give an incentive for diligence
and application; and that the interest of teachers and pupils
should be stimulated in every possible way in order to increase
the average attendance.

The residential schools in Ontario situated in settled
districts and drawing their pupils from Indians that are already
well advanced in civilization should be useful factors in improving
the standard of Indian life. The increase in the grant from $60.
to $100. per capita does not seem to be excessive, and I would
feel inclined to recommend the Government to increase the grant at
these schools to that rate; if it were found possible to carry
out the changes which will be mentioned later on and if the increase
does not involve a general increase in the appropriations.

It may be remarked, however, that these schools within
the next few years should prove their usefulness as it might be
better to allow the day schools on the reserves to furnish what-
ever would be required in the way of literary education and to
give more attention to the improvement of general agricultural
conditions throughout the older Provinces, as they are by no means
in as forward a condition as they should be. After the increased
grant has been paid for a year or two an inspection of the school
accounts will show whether it was larger than required.

MANITOBA, SASKATCHEWAN, ALBERTA AND NORTH WEST TERRITORIES.

It is probably the fact that the educational system
adopted for use in the unorganized territories in the year 1883 was in advance of the real needs of the case; that a more permanent influence for good would have been exerted by Industrial education carried on upon the reserves, and made up not only of tuition at day schools but of the generally civilizing influence of instruction given to adults in agricultural, ranching and domestic pursuits.

It must not be lost sight of that in several districts of the Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta the Indians are practically self-supporting, and as a basis of material progress is always necessary before education can have any lasting value, it may be said that the best interests of the Indians have been served by instruction carried out upon the reserves and not by the elaborate system of education. It would seem to be advisable to get back to these first principles and to expend whatever appropriations are placed at the disposal of the Department largely in improving conditions on reserves.

In line with the foregoing remarks it would seem to be advisable to close certain residential schools which have been for some time in operation. The Industrial School at Calgary has been abolished, the St. Paul's Industrial School at Middlechurch was not rebuilt after the late fire, and in considering a further reduction in the number of Industrial Schools it occurs that either the Brandon or Elkhorn School might be done away with altogether, as well as the School at Regina. The Brandon School, while well conducted, has not served the purpose for which it was established, as the pupils are drawn from districts where agriculture cannot extensively be carried on. The Elkhorn School while it is also well conducted is an expensive institution. The School at Regina while it draws its pupils from an agricultural district has been a source of considerable unforeseen expense to the Depart-
and of late years has not been very successful.

The closing at the end of the present fiscal year of the following Boarding Schools might also be carried out:

Crowstand, Emmanuel College,
File Hills, Gordon's
Round Lake, Onion Lake,
Peigan, Morley,
Old Suns, Blood,
Sarcee.

On the reserves which have heretofore been served by these schools an improved type of day school might be established. The staff would consist of a married teacher, and, on the larger reserves, of a nurse also; and a nutritious and simple noonday meal might be served to the pupils at the school. The nurse might be occupied in house and tent visitation, directing sanitary measures, and the wife of the teacher should have domestic qualifications which would make her useful in instructing the Indian women in the ordinary domestic employments. Such a system might be given a trial for four or five years. Children of whose strong constitutions and general health there could be no reasonable doubt could be drafted into the existing Industrial Schools which would be placed in a thoroughly sanitary condition and the tuition at which would be especially designed for the localities where they are situated. The experience of the Department with the best Day Schools under its control has shown conclusively that most efficient work may be done through this medium. The best Day Schools in the older Provinces are doing an excellent work. Those at Lorette, St. Frances, Caughnawaga and the Six Nation Reserve may be specially cited; and in dealing with the school on Mistawasis Reserve,

in the Province of Saskatchewan, the Indian Commissioner
felt called upon to remark that the report shows the school to be in a highly creditable condition. If we had Day Schools like this, our Boarding Schools might be dispensed with.

The experience of the United States Indian Department also shows that the Day Schools as conducted in that country, which include gardens and substantial hot lunches for the children, are considered the strongest civilizing influence that can be brought to bear upon the Indian. If it is to be considered any disadvantage that the children should remain with parents living a semi-civilized life, against this disadvantage must be weighed the positive gain which would result from the children being brought up surrounded by the conditions under which they must gain their livelihood.

As the sanitation of Indian dwellings is gradually improved, the Indian children who are tainted with tuberculosis will have a better chance to overcome the disease than if they were closely housed in Boarding Schools or sanitariums, and the danger to other pupils would be minimized. If this change was carried out with reference to the Protestant Schools just mentioned and certain Roman Catholic schools as well it would enable the Department to pay the increased grant to the industrial and boarding schools to be maintained in the future without asking Parliament for largely increased appropriations.

Schools in unorganized districts which draw their pupils from the reserves where the Indians maintain themselves by hunting might be allowed for the present to continue, but it is thought that the number of pupils in residence should not be increased beyond the present provisions. As the Indians settle upon their reserves and as new conditions arise these schools might also be abolished and the new type of school substituted.

It will be observed that the new departure consists of
maintaining Residential Schools in the unorganized districts, where Indians spend their winter on their hunting grounds and are not settled on the reserves, and the provision of an improved type of Day School, with a few large residential schools for Indians who have already settled on the reserves and are supporting themselves to a greater or less extent by agricultural pursuits and ranching.

BRITISH COLUMBIA.

The situation in British Columbia requires special attention and it would not seem to be advisable to authorize the large capital expenditure which would be necessary if the establishment is to be maintained as at present, until the needs of each locality are carefully enquired into and the necessity of each existing school demonstrated. In some localities where the question of entirely rebuilding or enlarging and improving certain school buildings would have to be immediately considered it might be found advantageous to establish Day Schools. The location of several of the Boarding Schools was not considered with sufficient care when the buildings were erected, and it would seem hardly advisable to spend any considerable amount on their improvement. The closing of the Matlakatla Industrial School and the maintenance of an efficient Day School at that point are now under consideration. It will be necessary to spend in the neighborhood of $30,000.00 to put the present buildings in a satisfactory condition. There are now only 13 boys in attendance and the school accounts show a deficit. As all the pupils are drafted from Matlakatla it would not seem to be necessary to continue the large expenditure for this institution. It should be remembered that the British Columbia Indians are practically self-supporting, and the policy
of removing the children from their parents and separating them from the ordinary vocations by which in their future lives they must obtain a living is questionable. From these general causes it seems advisable in this province to proceed with a good deal of circumspection before large expenditures are incurred which would tend to perpetuate the present system. It is therefore not at present proposed to extend the increased per capita grant to the Schools in this Province, or to provide for augmented capital expenditure.

If these changes were carried out the residential schools to be maintained would be thoroughly overhauled and increased ventilation and improved sanitation would be provided for. As the Department now provides medical attendance and medicines for the schools, no change is necessary in that regard, and the question of the possibility of engaging nurses as instructors would be considered. The increased grant to be paid to the Schools would carry with it the obligation on their part to meet all deficits, and to provide whatever labor for repairs etc is necessary; as at present.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Oliver,

I beg to draw your attention to the present position of the Indian School problem and to make certain suggestions which will tend to carry out as nearly as may be practicable the plan outlined in the Department's letter of the 24th of April last, which plan was approved by the Advisory Board. As you are aware, this plan contemplated the payment of per capita grants at the rate of $100.00 to the pupils in residential schools east of the Great Lakes and $150.00 to pupils in residential schools west of the Great Lakes, excluding the Province of British Columbia. The payment at the increased per capita rate was in effect made conditional upon the closing of the Regina and Mikahem Schools, Emmanuel College and McDougall Orphanage, and the Old Sun's Church of England School on the Blackfoot Reserve. It was hoped both by the Department and the Churches interested that this new scheme could go into effect from the 1st of April 1908, but lack of funds in the existing appropriations and the inability of the Department to obtain larger grants rendered this impossible. The Estimates for the fiscal year 1909-10 have been made out without any increase owing to the urgent request that our Estimates should conform as nearly as possible to those of 1907-08; but it seems obligatory that the Department should take some steps either to obtain increased grants or to make some use of money already voted in the direction of the proposed change of plan and increase in grant to the Schools. I have, therefore, to make the following suggestions, dealing with the Province separately:

ONTARIO: As the Shingwauk Home, situated at Sault Ste. Marie, is in constant financial difficulties and as the Department has declined
to be responsible for any further deficits, it is thought advisable to withdraw from the support of this School and to use the grant for other purposes. The institution is badly situated for agricultural operations and the pupilage is drawn not only from the Diocese of Algoma but from remote parts of Ontario. It is proposed with a portion of the money saved by this closure to improve certain Church of England Day Schools on Reserves in the Province of Ontario, to secure if possible a better class of Teacher at a higher rate of pay, and to modernise the buildings and equipment where necessary; and to increase the grant for pupils at Mt. Elgin (Maths.), Chapleau and Moose Factory (C. of E.) to $85.00 per capita. This is an increase of $25.00. The proposed rate for the Province of Ontario was to be $100.00 per capita, but the Department has not the funds at present to provide that rate.

The only other Schools that should be provided for are the Roman Catholic Schools at Wikwemikong and Albany and the Mohawk Institute at Brantford. As the latter School is supported by the New England Company, I do not think the Department should increase the grant. Sufficient funds can be found for increasing the per capita grant to the Roman Catholic Schools mentioned. This Church has not joined as yet in the new movement and it might not be thought advisable at present to increase any particular school without reference to a general understanding between that Church and the Department.

Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta etc.: If the Regina and Elk Horn Schools were closed before the end of the year the Department would have available $95,350.00 from this source with which to increase the per capita grant and to establish a certain number of Day Schools of the new type. It would be impossible, however, to increase the grant to Boarding Schools to $150.00 per capita, and after re-considering that rate I think it is probably higher than is necessary and might be reduced to $100.00 until the experience of a couple of years have proved that rate to be insufficient. There are 600 pupils estimated in Protestant Boarding Schools which at an increase of $100.00 would require
$16,800.00 additional to pay the grant. I would recommend that the Institutions at Regina and Elkhorn be closed and that the per capita grant be increased to $100.00 for Protestant Boarding Schools in these Provinces.

Dealing with the Roman Catholic Schools in the same Provinces it will be necessary to provide $29,036.00 to place the grants to pupils on the same basis. I think that in advance of any expression of willingness to consider a reduction in the number of Boarding Schools it would be premature to offer this increase, but at the same time I think the authorities of the Church should be approached more directly on this question with a view to arriving if possible at a harmonious conclusion.

The Protestant denominations have suffered great diminution of their teaching forces without embarrassing the Department in any way, and I think that with reference to the savings effected or to be effected in the money voted or in any additional demands which may hereafter be made upon Parliament this fact should not be lost sight of. The following items have disappeared from the Estimates owing to Schools being closed, and the expenditure has been correspondingly reduced:

St. Paul's.................. $15,000.00 G. E.
Emmanuel College........... 4,304.00 "
Calgary........................ 4,550.00 "
Newley.......................... 3,240.00 Meth.
Metlakatla...................... 7,200.00 G.E.

Total reduction, $34,294.00

If the Shingwauk Home be closed $6000.00 may be added to this; Regina $14,700.00, and Elkhorn $14,550.00, making a total diminution in our Estimates on account of the closing of Protestant Boarding Schools aggregating $68,544.00. This is a prominent and outstanding fact that will not be lost sight of by the Protestant denomination and should be kept in mind by the Department.

BRITISH COLUMBIA. Owing to the saving which has accrued on account of closing the Metlakatla School the Department was
enabled to take preliminary steps toward establishing Day Schools of
the new type at Massett on the Queen Charlotte Islands and at Aiyumish:
and possibly at Hazelton. These three Schools are under Church of
England auspices, as was the Metlakatla School. It seems only fair to
divert any portion of the appropriation which may be thus saved to the
purposes of that denomination. In Boarding Schools in British Columbia
there are 165 Protestant pupils and 160 Roman Catholic pupils. In
this Province the grant is only $60.00 per capita so that $40.00 would
have to be provided to raise it to $100.00, and this would necessitate
granting $6,000.00 in the Supplementary Estimates.

YUKON: Affairs in the Yukon are on the same standing as
they were before the Supplementary appropriation which last Session
provided $10,000.00 for the erection of a new Boarding School building.
I am inclined to think that whatever may be the urgency of the Church
of England for further expenditures for Indian purposes in the Yukon,
the Indians themselves will not suffer seriously if the Department takes
time to consider slowly and carefully the needs of the Territory along
this line. We have had some correspondence with the Rev. Mr. O'Meara
and later on I will bring various matters to your attention.

RECAPITULATION: I am of the opinion that if the action
above outlined is taken; that is, if the Shingwauk Home, and the Regina
and Elkhorn Schools were closed; if the Brandon School was given a
constituency from which pupils could be drawn who would benefit by
agricultural training; if the per capita rate was advanced to $200.00
for the Mt. Elgin Institute in Ontario and to $85.00 in Manitoba and
the North West Territories; and if a sufficient amount was provided in
the Supplementary Estimates to give British Columbia the same treatment
from the Ist. of July prev., the Advisory Board would probably be
satisfied. In this connection I may say that in a memorandum dated
the 4th. of Sept. 1908 the Board stated that "It is very earnestly
hoped that even yet the Superintendent may see his way out of the money
saved by a concentration of the work and closing some of the schools, as
suggested in his proposals, and the cutting down of expenses in the Department, to make a reasonable beginning in the way of the improved schools and some increase in the per capita grants although not up to the full standard suggested.* I think it will also be possible from the general avail of the appropriation to begin three or four Day Schools of the new type in various localities; probably two in the Prince Albert district and one or two at points to be suggested by the Presbyterian Church, whose educational opportunities should be strengthened on account of the closing of the Regina School. If these suggestions meet with favor, I think that we may safely anticipate that the Advisory Board will be gratified that a start has been made.

Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs.

Kindly, Yet Severe Criticism Of Treatment Of Indians Is Voiced By Native Clergyman

Rev. Edward Ahenakew, of Saskatchewan Diocese, Speaks of His People as One Who Knows Chance to Be Educated—Says All Indian Needs is More Schools Needed

Pleads for People

REV. EDWARD AHENAKEW, L.T.H., Missionary to the People of His Race—The Indians—at Onion Lake, Sask.

"I have been educated and I never have heard of any authority for treaty money. Half the time I forget I have anything to do with them. If my children had been educated I might today be under their support. Education will give the Indians self-support and give him self-support, and he will block to the roots of his hair if you offer him anything else. The only thing that savors of charity is helping the future of the Indians, the lives of the Indian children, on the reserves of which he knows our government has put them."

According to the terms of our treaty with the government, any Indians who are educated are entitled to have it. I know one child who has for years asked for a school and who has never been able to get one. It is simply a question of money. Whatever the reason may be, the fact looks like a great injustice to the Indians who want to secure their chance of success in life. The race is not being supplied with its proper food.

The government is doing a great deal, but perhaps I have seen a more efficient way to educate a white man would. I remember my own boyhood. I can look back on my days at home and see how much education was gradually my mind and feelings. It is possible for other Indian boys.

It long to see the day when the government will make a special study of Indian conditions; find out the needs and study out the remedies. They are doing much, but not with as much personal interest as they should. Education is needed—and this during youth. In the schools—if our children won't come there, show them why. They know not what they need. If their parents want something for them, send them to the White people have to send their children to the schools. We are neither fair to the Indian nor to the white people who have to live in the same country with them."

Copy of Resolution re Indians—

September 21st, 1918.

Dear Mrs. Burrows:

I have your letter of September 20th this morning and hasten to make reply to so important a question as has been raised at the Portage.

When the early navigators and discoverers first visited the shores of Canada, it was found that the new Eldorado was inhabited by a people who had at least the title of birthright. The Indian Question was therefore a first consideration with those who wished to live here.

As long as the new comers were merely traders in the offing the Natives were disposed to be friendly. "Off shore" relations were welcomed by the "on shore" people. When however Indians began to learn that we were not casual guests, but agriculturists who looked towards early settlement and permanent possession, the Indians assumed another attitude less favourable to the strangers. The history of New Canada became a struggle, leading up to final domination of the Red Man, by his White Brother.

Now while Canada has been acquisitive, assertive and progressive she has earned the name of being just and generous. So with the passing of the years she made a Treaty with the Indians guaranteeing them protection and assistance, which would raise them to the status of white people, when the conditions were fulfilled. The Government took on a Paternal relation and the Native
Population became the Wards of the Nation. This Treaty was extended from time to time until nearly the whole land has been covered by a Pact of Peace.

Seeing the justice of provisions made for their benefit, the Original Inhabitants were willing to try us and finally came to trust us. So with the passing of time and the fulfilment of obligations, the old enmities died away, and erstwhile enemies became loyal friends. Canada proved that a peace policy was a paying proposition and that kindness brought contentment.

One of the conditions of this newer order of things, was the question of the education of the aborigines. Canadian Policy saw that if trouble existed, it usually arose through ignorance. The hardest people to deal with was the uneducated class. If an unschooled Native under Treaty Agreements could be counted as a friend he might under educational advantages become an intellectual friend, and a better ward of the country, for this advancement.

So the Day School on the Reserve was tried, but the Reserves were large, too large for one school. The distances from some homes were great, and boating was dangerous. Then the Indians moved about a good deal, taking the family with them. Winter attendance was not large, owing to cold and insufficient apparel. It was felt that we were not accomplishing enough by this method.

Next followed the Boarding School on the Reserve, where children could be gathered, fed, clothed, educated and sent back to improve native society, at the age of eighteen. For
say four years or more, they would be under the good influences of christian teachers, whose example was as much as their teaching. They would not be too far away from natural scenes and surroundings, and old associations. Altogether this was an ideal project, which promised well.

In all this, there was a missing link. It was thought that education alone, was not all that was required. The next move was to teach the larger boys and girls, home and commercial industries, so they might be fitted to work their way through life, by the skill of their hands and the sweat of honest toil. This too has been carried out in the Industrial Schools.

Here then you have a complete system of help, the DAY SCHOOL on the Reserve, THE BOARDING SCHOOL in some near by town or village, and the INDUSTRIAL SCHOOLS in the midst of civilized society, with all their stimulus and training. The real object of all is to elevate the Indian industrially, intellectually, morally and this goes a long way towards making him a worthy citizen.

The work of these schools cannot but be helpful. We see it every day in the dress and appearance of the ex-pupils, in the tidiness of their homes, in the care of their children, in the preparation of their food, and in many other ways.

Canada undertook this work with the conviction that it was good business, and she gave definite promise that she would not weary or fail in her purpose, as long as grass grows, or water runs, or sun shines. Our national
promise is as good as our bond, but we are bound by covenant as well. Shall we go back on the history of the years? Shall we break our Treaty engagements? Shall we deny "the least of his brethren" the advantages promised in solemn avowal, and fulfilled at the present time in the most practical manner?

Two or three features of the case must not be overlooked.

(1) Convinced that the Churches could supply better men and women to fill positions in these schools, that less extravagance would exist under religious management, and that the morals of the children would be more carefully guarded by Christian people, the Government transferred the control of these schools to the leading Churches of the land. In asking for the discontinuance of a given school, a blow is aimed at the Denomination controlling that Institution, and another organization might tomorrow petition against some other School, and where would all this end.

(2) In opposing the education of the Natives, you come into opposition with the declared policy of the Parliament of the country, and the Minister directly responsible for the existing state of affairs, who may think that he and his coadjutors in office should know as much about such matters, as any women's organization, unfamiliar with all the facts of the case.

(3) This is a broad question which should be approached in a very thoughtful and considerate manner. What will Indians, born in the wild woods, untaught, untrained, untamed be to us as the years pass? There are things
that might well be left alone, unless better things can be put in their places, and I for one, well knowing that many failures may be cited, would hesitate to destroy the foundations of education, which our wisest legislators have laid for the uplift of our Native Race.

With much respect,

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Mrs. J. H. Burrow,
High Bluff,

MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Scott,-

Re. Indian Education, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and the Northwest Territories.

After the acquirement of the Northwest Territories and Rupert's Land by the Dominion Government in 1870 steps were taken to secure the extinction of the Indian title to these lands and treaties were entered into by the Government with the Indians with this end in view, the principal stipulations of which were the setting apart of reserves, the payment of annuities and the establishment of schools for the Indians.

In fulfillment of the latter agreement the Department set about formulating a school policy, the result of which was the establishment of industrial schools at Battleford in 1883 and at Qu'Appelle and High River in 1884, the first in charge of the Church of England and the two latter under the Roman Catholics. The cost of their maintenance and management was borne by the Department for about ten years, when they were put on the per capita grant system.

It was the intention of the Department that the boys should be taught trades in these industrial schools, preference to be given to carpentering and blacksmithing, and that the girls should receive instruction in domestic science. Many of the schools undertook, in addition to carpentering and blacksmithing, printing, shoe making, tailoring and other trades, and this necessitated the employment of skilled instructors. This policy, to a large extent, had to be abandoned. The cost of obtaining competent instructors in the various trades was found to be prohibitive and now more attention is given to agriculture and...
and carpentering.

In the meantime day schools were established on some of the reserves and in 1883 there were thirty-five in operation for longer or shorter periods while the Indians were on the reserves. All these schools received Government grants, which were supplemented in many cases by the missionary societies working among the Indians.

The religious bodies engaged in Indian education, recognizing the nomadic habits of the Indians and the consequent irregular attendance of the children, inaugurated the boarding school system and the Department recognized their efforts by allowing them a per capita grant. In the early days the buildings were put up by the churches on the reserves in the neighbourhood of their missions, and they were allowed a per capita grant of $60.00 in the eastern and $72.00 in the western provinces. They were paid at these rates until the first of April, 1911, when, by the terms of an agreement between the Department and the management of Indian boarding schools, the grant was raised to from $80.00 to $125.00, according to the location of the schools, as set forth in the memorandum which accompanied the printed Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools.

This agreement was the result of a conference between the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and the members duly appointed by the Anglican, Roman Catholic, Presbyterian and Methodist churches to represent them at the said conference. The lengthy correspondence which led up to this conference is on file 289032 and the result is embodied in the agreement.

The authorities of the churches engaged in educational work among the Indians signed the agreements, which were to run for a term of five years from the first of April, 1911. As the war broke out before the expiration of the time limit, the schools were conducted on the same per capita grant up to the first of April, 1917, when an additional $10.00 per capita was allowed to each school.

The churches claim that this extra grant does not, by any means, meet the increased cost of maintenance and management, and they are pressing the Department for a revision in the terms of the agreement. There is no doubt
doubt that the grant now allowed for the maintenance of pupils in residential schools is insufficient, unless liberally supplemented by the churches, who claim that a much larger proportion of the cost should be borne by the Department.

If the Government decide to increase the grant to residential schools while the present high cost of living prevails, it will require an additional vote of at least $60,000.00 to meet an increase of $15.00 per capita for the present enrolment, which is practically the limit the existing buildings can provide for.

Financial returns received from these schools show the per capita cost to be from $150.00 to $175.00. In the last report of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs for the United States it is stated that a per capita grant of $200.00 is allowed there for schools of this class.

As appears from a statement showing the cost of the Indian day schools in the western provinces for the year ending the 31st of March, last, many of these schools might advantageously be closed, on account of the small average attendance and the high cost of maintenance and management. If this were done increased accommodation would be required at some of the boarding schools, as it would not do to deprive the children of an opportunity of receiving an education.

To improve the attendance at some of the outlying day schools the transporting of the children to school was tried, but the results obtained did not justify the expenditure incurred, and the Department was forced to discontinue the driving of the children. On some of the reserves no less than three drivers were required, and the children were insufficiently clad and often had to wait a considerable time for the conveyance.

The giving of a midday meal at the day schools, which was also tried, is still continued and has been found to give satisfaction, as it has no doubt increased the average attendance, but it has also largely increased the cost. The cost of maintaining the day schools in the western provinces will average over $1,000.00 each.

If the Department is prepared to assume additional expenditure
expenditure in connection with the residential schools new agreements should be made with the churches. Many of the schools which would require enlargement are at present the property of the churches and, if the Department has to spend money in enlarging and improving them, they should be acquired by the Department, or it should have a lien on the property for the amount expended.

To give effect to the suggested change the Regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children should be amended so as to empower the Department to place children in residential schools where no day schools are in operation on the reserve.

The School Estimates which have been prepared for 1919-20 call for a parliamentary appropriation of $735,515. apportioned as follows—residential schools $576,885, day schools $128,775, repairs $22,355, assistance to ex-pupils $5,000, and salary and expenses of school inspector for British Columbia $2,500.

To carry out the suggested increased per capita grant, additions to existing buildings and new buildings would require about one million dollars for the next fiscal year.

From the 1st of July, 1877, to the 31st of March, 1918, the Department has expended $14,428,709.25 from consolidated revenue for Indian education; the greater portion of this sum has been handled by the churches engaged in educational work among the Indians.

Unless the Government is prepared to introduce legislation to expedite enfranchisement, the Indian problem will always remain unsolved, and a trial might advantageously be made on some of the reserves in the older provinces.

Accompanying this memorandum is a statement showing the cost of Indian day schools in the west for the year ending the 31st of March, 1918, and a copy of the Correspondence and Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools.
It might be considered advisable to again investigate the subject of Indian Education, with a view to improvements. There is no doubt that there is room for improvement, and that the solving of the problem might be assisted by a general survey of the work, the introduction of some new methods, and an attempt to methods employed more directly toward the end to be accomplished. I would not, however, suggest the appointment of any commission to inquire into the matter. The facts are well-known to the officers of the Department and to those interested in Indian Education. It is only necessary to arrive at some consensus of opinion, in order to institute reforms. Mr. Graham and myself propose to take this action, and to present the results for your consideration.
When we were considering improvements in Indian education, it was thought that the Day School in the Western provinces was susceptible of greater usefulness, and we endeavoured to increase it by establishing a grade known as the Improved Day School. The special features of these schools was a warm meal at noon and the transportation of the children from and to their homes. The teaching staff was to consist of a man and his wife. Several of these schools were established, but I cannot say that the beneficial results have been commensurate with the increased expenditure. The per capita cost is variable, but in some cases it is higher than the per capita cost of Residential Schools. I think it has been established that Day Schools on reserves in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta are not a success, and it is questionable whether they should not be abandoned, except in the few cases where they are known to be vigorous and really useful, and the money devoted to augmenting the pupilage at the Residential Schools.

Applications are now being received for permission to increase the number of authorized pupils, and the reason given is that the influenza has made many orphans, and that these must suffer unless the schools take the place of their parents. It must be said that this pressure upon the accommodation of the schools began with the war; the Indians at once found it difficult to provide for their families, and endeavoured to ease the burden by transferring part of it to the schools.
The highest per capita grant which is now paid is $135.00 per annum, and it is represented that we should increase our contribution to $150.00, that is, make an all-round further increase of $15.00 per capita for all pupils (4,500) of residential schools. This will necessitate annual provision by Parliament of $67,500.00.

The policy of the Government from the earliest date of Indian education up to the present time has been one of association with the religious denominations, that is, the evangelization and education of the aborigines went hand in hand. It is my opinion that we gain a great deal from this association, not only do we gain by reason of the zealous nature of the people who devote themselves to this work in a missionary spirit, but we gain financially from the large amounts which are collected by the denominations towards the maintenance of the schools. If the Churches were to withdraw altogether from their association with the Government, we would have to provide more generously for the present establishment. It, therefore, becomes a duty to consider carefully the present condition of Indian education, and to weigh most carefully and sympathetically the representations which are being made to us from the denominations that our share in the cost of maintaining the schools is not now proportionately borne by us, that the high cost of provisions and wages have told most heavily against the finances of the schools, and that there exist everywhere deficits, which it is difficult or impossible for the Churches to meet.

Owing to the financial pressure on the management of the schools, the Superintendent General decided and Parliament provided funds to increase the per capita grants by $10.00 from the 1st of April, 1917. It must be remembered that the running expenses of these residential schools are not met by the grants from public funds alone, they are supplemented by the missionary societies, who have always been liberal in providing funds for the purpose.

NOTES ON INDIAN EDUCATION:

It has become urgent to review the whole subject of Indian education. The necessity arises from the financial difficulties which face the Department and the religious denominations interested in the schools, owing to the increased cost of living. The responsibility of the Government for Indian education has been recognized for many years, and is now part of the fixed policy of the Department. The earliest attempts to educate Indians were made by the Jesuit missionaries many years ago, but there was no co-operation between the missions and the Government until the Protestant missionaries of Upper Canada succeeded in enlisting the sympathy of the Government in the welfare of the Indians. They had experimented by taking Indian youths into their own families or providing lodging and boarding accommodation for them while they were under tuition, and, when the experimental stage was successfully passed, it developed into the establishment of regular residential schools, supported by financial assistance in the form of grants per capita from the public funds and from Indian funds.

When, after Confederation, Canada took over the Northwest Territories, treaties were made with the Indians; these treaties provided that education should be extended to the aborigines. Although the form or method of the education was not definitely fixed, after a special report had been made by a Commissioner appointed to look into the question, the system already established in the East was, to all intents, transferred to the West, and the Government
began to establish residential schools and day schools. The type of residential schools were known as industrial, but, ere long, the missionaries, in their zeal to evangelize, began to establish small boarding schools on the reserves near their missions, and as an integral part of their missions, and gradually the Department found itself supporting these schools, making grants for maintenance, buildings and other purposes. These latter schools developed, and in some ways were more vigorous than the industrial schools, but the need for normalizing the effort and making the establishments as uniform as possible became very evident about the year 1910.

The missionary societies were dissatisfied with the financial grants the Department was making, we, on the other hand, were dissatisfied with the nature of the appeals which reached us, and the difficulties of administration in the absence of any definite understanding.

Acting on the suggestion of the undersigned, who was then Superintendent of Indian Education, the Honourable the Superintendent General invited representatives of the Churches to meet him in Ottawa, and, after a thorough discussion, it was decided to increase the grants to the boarding schools, and to place them under a contract, in which the responsibilities of both parties would be plainly defined. It was clear that one of the chief causes of criticism was the condition of the buildings in which the schools had been established, these buildings were nearly all owned by the missionary societies, and the character of their construction had been influenced prejudicially by limited financial resources. The result was that the buildings in many respects were inadequate; they were unsanitary and they were undoubtedly chargeable with a very high death rate among the pupils.
The Churches became responsible under the contract agreement for improving their buildings, which were to be brought up to a certain standard before they could receive the increased per capita grant, the Department also undertook the responsibility of substituting for buildings owned by the Crown modern structures specially designed for needs of the service. The policy was formed that these schools, being public institutions, should be as well constructed as any other class of public building, and should be in all respects a credit to the Dominion. We pledged ourselves to spend reasonable amounts from year to year until this rebuilding programme was finished. The new arrangement provided for a material increase in the per capita grant, namely, from $60.00 in the eastern and $72.00 in the western provinces to from $80.00 to $125.00 according to the location of the schools and the nature and condition of the buildings. The Churches diligently carried out the scheme of building improvements, and the Department was able to do its share from adequate Parliamentary appropriations until the outbreak of the war.
