To His Royal Highness, Victor Christian William,
Counsellor, Duke of Devonshire and
Governor General of the Dominion of Canada.

May it please Your Royal Highness:-

We, the Chiefs and Headmen representing the Indian Bands living upon the shores of and adjacent to Lake Winnipeg, in the Province of Manitoba, having failed to have received due and just consideration, through the prescribed channels for the administration of Indian affairs, in the matter of an attempt to deprive us of the hunting rights granted to our peoples and the encroachment upon the educational rights as embodied and written in the original treaties made between the British Crown and our Indian peoples, do herewith, humbly, respectfully and earnestly crave the help of Your Excellency and that Your Excellency will order that the hunting rights of Your Indian peoples be acknowledged and maintained, and that the education of Indian children be given under the sole management of the Government, as prescribed in our treaties, without any interference or influence from any source whatever, political, religious or otherwise.

We respectfully beg to quote the words written in the treaties made and concluded at Berens River on the 20th of September, 1875 and at Norway House on September 24th, 1875, with which the promises written in the treaty memorandum as promised by the Commissioner appointed to make a treaty with the Indians of the Stn Peter's Band, are identical,-

"Her Majesty"
"Her Majesty further agrees with Her said Indians, that they, the said Indians, shall have right to pursue their avocations of hunting and fishing throughout the tract surrendered as herein-before described, subject to such regulations as may from time to time be made by Her Government of Her Dominion of Canada, and saving and excepting such tracts as may be from time to time be required or taken up for settlement, mining, lumbering or other purposes, by Her said Government of Her Dominion of Canada, or by any of the subjects thereof duly authorized therefore by the said Government."

The first movement to deprive us of our rights was made by the Missionary in the Fisher River Reserve who agitated with the Game Department of Manitoba, and we were notified by the Game Guardians that we were subject to the Game Laws of the Province of Manitoba. This movement has found favour with the Department of Indian Affairs and we have recently been notified by the Department that we must obey the Game Laws of the Province of Manitoba.

At the meetings of the Indians of the Peguis and Fisher River Bands with the Game Guardians, our Indian Agent pointed out the injustice of applying Game Laws to Indians at a moment's notice and without consulting the Indians or the enacting of proper legislation for such a purpose and further suggested to the Game Guardians and to the Department of Indian Affairs, that no definite steps be taken until a dis-interested person be appointed to accompany him upon the treaty trip in the Fisher River Agency, that it might be clearly seen, that any attempt to apply Provincial Game Laws to Indians living in a locality composed of granite rocks, muskegs and water, and where none could raise sufficient vegetables or grain to keep a family in food for a month, and where, in hundreds of square miles
miles there could not be found sufficient hay to maintain one cow, would be contemptibly unjust.

A most casual inspection of the districts where thousands of our Indian people are living will corroborate these statements and at once establish the fact that, whatever laws are, or are not made that will operate to deprive the Indians of their right to hunt, the Indians cannot live where they now are without the right to hunt as given them in their treaties.

If the Provincial Game Laws must be applied to Indians, they, the Indians, must be removed to a locality where there is soil to cultivate or hay lands where they can raise cattle. And inasmuch as the Indians living in the localities referred to have no knowledge of any pursuits except hunting and cannot speak any language except that of their race a grave responsibility rests upon the Government of the Dominion of Canada.

We respectfully solicit the defense of Your Royal Highness in this matter of vital importance to ourselves and all our Indian people.

In the matter of our schools we respectfully beg to quote from our treaties made with the British Government:

"And further, Her Majesty agrees to maintain schools for instruction in such reserves hereby made as to Her Government of the Dominion of Canada may seem advisable, whenever the Indians of the reserve shall desire it."

In some unknown way, perhaps with a laudable desire for mutual benefit, a system of education of Indian children has been arranged in the past between the Department of Indian Affairs and the different Churches or Religious Organizations, the Churches being given
given the privilege of nominating the teachers, only, and the Government paying the teacher's salaries and all the expenses of the school management.

Whatever may have been the imagined benefit to be derived from such a system, it condemns itself at once, inasmuch as it at once places the teacher under two masters and has also been the means of causing serious religious quarrels among our people.

This apparently small matter of granting the nomination of teachers to religious organizations has been sadly abused and has assumed such aggressive proportions that teachers are engaged and dismissed without any reference to the officials of the Department, and Indian Department Officials and regulations are ignored and defied. To such an extent has this been allowed and encouraged that at Berens River the Methodist Missionary boldly abducted two Roman Catholic children from the Roman Catholic school, in spite of the protest of the teacher in charge and the Indian Agent's warning against such a course of action, and placed the children in the Methodist Boarding School at Norway House.

Some teachers have also complained that they do not receive the amount granted by the Government for their salaries.

We earnestly pray Your Royal Highness to order that all Indian schools shall be operated solely and entirely by the Government.

We will at all times welcome and assist to the very best of our ability any Church or Religious Organization who wishes to bring to us the Gospel of Jesus Christ, but we will not tolerate or uphold any who has any influence with our teachers, schools or matters pertaining to the treaty made with the Indians by the Government, or who by their determination to secure worldly power and material benefits, give the lie to their professed object
of taking Christianity to the Indians.

Under the present system of Indian education the teachers do as they like, some of whom are incompetent, and many of our schools would be as well closed. Reports of progress and conditions by self-interested persons should not be accepted and an investigation will reveal the truth of our statements, and more.

We regret the trouble and loss of time we are causing Your Royal Highness, but we are at our wit's end to know how the affairs of Indians can be given due consideration, and we have wondered if it is because the Indian has no vote that his affairs are treated with contumely, his rights assailed and those who dare to lift a voice on his behalf, suppressed.

Our only hope is in British justice and an appeal to the British Government to administer our affairs in accordance with the terms of the treaties made between that Government and the Indian people of the Dominion of Canada, and we still have faith in those treaties which the Commissioners appointed to make treaties with us stated, were alike binding upon the Government and the Indians.

In the further interests of Peace and Good-will, and that there be no cause for dis-satisfaction amongst our people, many of whom are unable to understand the differences of award according to merit, we respectfully suggest that the monetary recognition of the sacrifices made by many of our young men upon the field of battle in France, to the parents or relatives of the fallen, be equal.

Confidential and Personal.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Mr. McLean:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo with which you enclosed a copy of petition signed by Indians of the Peguis, Fisher River, Berens River and Bloodvein Bands.

I cannot give you much more information as to the instigator of the petition than is contained in my letter of January 28th last, with which I enclosed copies of the petitions as advised.

The first I heard of the intention of the Indians to take their grievances to the Governor was from a returned soldier who had settled in the Fisher Bay district who stated that he had been warned by the people that the Missionary in the Fisher River reserve was a Game Guardian and that the Indians were forbidden to hunt.

This man had also a grievance against the Land Department for some mixup over his homestead being given to another while he was serving in the Army, and stated that he was taking this to the Commissioner of Immigration and said he would also present the case of the Indians being restricted in their hunting privileges.

Then I heard of meetings of Indians had been held in the Fisher River reserve after which the meeting was held in the Halfway House on January 20th as advised. Then a meeting of the Peguis Council was asked for January 27th, and it appears the Peguis Council had invited the Fisher River Council to be present also, with Chief William Berens.

Chief Berens stated that he had told the North West Mounted Police
that he and all his people would not submit to the Provincial Game Laws, that they would all go to jail willingly as they might as well be there as to attempt to live where they are without the game, that he had so informed the Hudson's Bay Co. who had stated, "go ahead and get the furs and we will buy them".

Chief Everett of the Fisher River Band brought several cuttings from newspapers including one containing an alleged statement by Chief Game Guardian C. Farber, of Winnipeg, that the taking of game for food by Indians at all times was the Indian's indisputable right.

The Indians were most indignant and angry and stated that unless they received satisfaction they would wait upon the Governor General in person, condemning the Indian Department and Officials for "taking sides with the Game Guardians instead of protecting the rights of the Indians". I had always advised that the Peguis Band did not appear to have any such hunting rights claimed by the others, but at the meeting with the Game Guardian on March 29th, 1916, Mr. Game Guardian Joyce read a copy of the address of the Commissioner which was made to the Indians of the St Peter's Band at the first treaty, stating that the game was theirs, (the Indian's) and that they had right to hunt over all lands not enclosed. It was also argued that when the St Peter's people had their annuity changed from $3.00 to $5.00 it was by an agreement between the Government and the Indians, otherwise the Department would be taking their treaty money and reserves next, which was no more a part of the treaty than the right to hunt game, and no less.

It was quoted that the conviction of Andrew McPherson upon a plea of guilty was evidence that the Province had no power to punish a treaty man for exercising his right to hunt, as nothing was done to him, and the hearing of his case was refused by three or four local Police Magistrates because he was an Indian &c.

It would appear regrettable that at least, a pretense of treating with the Indians was not made in this matter and it is perhaps not too late for the Department to consider how this game question can be settled satisfactorily to all and in the meantime to advise the Indians of the receipt of their petition through the hands of the Governor General, but that, while the Department has always had the interests of its Indians before anything else, it has also many other Bands claiming its
attention, and that this will be further carefully considered.

I advise something like this as the Indians are impatient and I heard some of them talking in Indian that they had better come to Ottawa and publish their grievances in the press as have several other Indians. I have endeavoured to hold this down by advising that to do either would destroy any efficacy their petition may have, and would be an insult to the Governor General.

In reference to the St Peter's surrendered question it was stated that the Indians considered the Department was bribing those now coming out with the $70.00, that Mr Bradbury had been bribed to drop his defence of this question, and also other officials. Those who have come out stated that at the meetings held in St Peter's last winter they were promised in unmistakable terms that they would be paid the "$90.00" by the Agent in the Peguis reserve. At the treaty payments last summer, just before commencing to pay annuity I was asked by the Council if I would kindly step to the outside of the pay-tent; when there I was asked if I had any money, other than the usual annuity to pay them; if I knew or had heard of any being expected for them, other than the annuity, to which I could but answer, no. The interpreter then said that was all they wished to ask me.

I really think there was no necessity to make any offer of payment for work on the houses ans less to advance the amount from $2.50 to $3.50 per day. Now the Indians no doubt have the idea that if they kick long and hard enough they will get something more, and as there is no doubt that several Indians in the Peguis Reserve received little or no building assistance, other than the materials, they are joining hands in voicing their dissatisfaction. It would seem to be a most necessary rule to give to all Indians alike, or nothing to any.

In the matter of the education of Indian children the greatest complaint has been from Fisher River; several times the Fisher River Council have been to see me to ask that the school business be taken out of the hands of the Churches, and at meetings I was asked what powers the Minister had in the schools, to which I could only reply as advised by the Department, - only the nomination of teachers. I was accused of assisting the minister against the Indians in this school matter upon one occasion, and the Indians took or sent a petition to the late
Chief Inspector Glen Campbell, who sent it to me, but I did not report this as I thought it was because the former Fisher River Chief was a "Shaker", but the present Chief who is a Methodist makes the same complaint and request that the schools be managed solely by the Government.

The Peguis Council also make the same request which I think is founded on the fact that some of the Council wished a friend of theirs to be given the South Peguis School and approached me about this and I informed them that I had no say in the appointment of any teacher.

The war has no doubt hastened this attitude, but any one of ordinary vision could see that the handling of school matters by the Churches in face of the enlightenment of the modern Indian could only result in the alienation of the Indians from the Churches.

I have spoken to the Revd T. Ferrier upon this line but Mr Ferrier stated that if they could not have the appointing of the teachers his church would step down and out from any Missionary work in the reserves; some Roman Catholic Priests spoke to me on the S.S. Wolverine in reference to the situation at Berens, and I suggested the solution of placing the school business in the hands of the Department, only, which was replied that the Roman Catholic Church would never give up the privilege of appointing the teacher.

If this is the spirit of the Churches it will be the greatest blessing for all concerned if they will withdraw from the reserves, and it should not be a question of the Churches giving up this courtesy, but if the Department considers it advisable to terminate it; at any rate the school affairs should be either under the Church or the Department, but, as the Indians hold the original treaty and demand that they be treated according to the terms of their agreement it would seem they have some say in the matter. Cooperation seems impossible as the Missionaries in most cases, although they quote cooperation, really desire approbation of all they do, right or wrong, and to order all things.

In the case of Jackhead, the only man proposed for this school was a man who was a failure in the same work at another place.

In speaking upon the subject of Indian education with the late Lieutenant Revd Hetherington, assistant Principal of the Brandon Industrial school, he said, "it is no wonder we have such poor results in our
Indian school matters, for whenever we have a man who is a down and out failure, his name is brought up at conference, and he is given a school or mission with the Indians". It seems impossible to avoid disaster if such persons have anything to say in the management of education. While I am quite sure aware that there are noble exceptions it cannot be expected that persons of intelligence will offer themselves for the position of teacher in an Indian school under the existing humiliating conditions.

In the statement of the Indians that some teachers have complained they do not receive the amount granted for their salaries I would say that Joseph Everett was reported to have been dismissed from the Bloodvein school through the efforts of the Revd F.G. Stevens of Fisher River. Joseph came to me in the early spring of 1917 and stated that he had applied for a settlement of what he claimed was due for his services and presented a statement signed by the Revd T. Ferrier in which Everett was charged for an amount due Miss Jotcham for her travelling expenses enroute to or from Norway House, and further made a claim that he was short some $200.00. This I was told was later paid to him. I entered into some lengthy correspondence with the Revd J. Arnup in this matter.

George Sinclair, who was at Pekangekum and Berens River made a statement that all that he had received for his summer work was $80.00.

It was stated at Fisher River that the extra grant of $50.00 given by the Department to Miss Royan would not be given her as she had made a contract with the officials of the Methodist Church to teach the Fisher River school for a certain sum which would not be increased. Miss Royan wrote me several letters after she had left the Fisher River reserve and finally advised me that she had been paid this amount.

Mrs Lowes of Berens River claimed to have never received but $500.00 for her services as teacher. At her request I took this up with the Revd T. Ferrier who stated to me that they only paid $500.00 to a female, and $600.00 to a male teacher. Mrs Lowes wanted to know what was the difference so long as she had the qualifications. Mr Arnup stated that the salary of the teacher and missionary was a joint one, but Mrs Lowes repudiated this and said she wanted the salary that was granted.

A change from the present conditions could not possibly be
worse and if I was asked what I would prefer I would say that, if the Churches wanted it so bad and the Indians could be satisfied thereby, by all means give the whole management into the hands of the Church officials of all Indian schools; but with the differences of religion among the Indians and that each denomination is against the other it seems there can only be expected an increase in the troubles upon the Indian reserves. One of the Peguis Councillors has upon more than one occasion urged the Council to request that the teachership be always given to educated Indians so long as they are proved to be competent.

In conclusion I would say that the Peguis Band particularly are a very persistent and "want to know" Band, and have many relatives and friends in Winnipeg who can give them every information upon law or anything else, and the questions asked in the Council meetings are often difficult to answer.

However, the time appears to now be ripe for all classes of people to have their wrongs or grievances overhauled and adjusted with little consideration for the wants of the few that does not justly administer to the needs of the many. The Department of Indian Affairs has a most responsible task to administer the affairs of a nation almost helpless before the advance of civilization. While admitting my many shortcomings I consider it a privilege to be able to do something for the advancement of the Indians and should rejoice to be able to assist in so working that a contradiction may be made to a statement I have heard, that the Indians are progressing, not with the cooperation of the Department with the Churches, but in spite of it.

I am sure you are tired. I enclose the petition herewith.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent,
Fisher River Agency.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant asking to be furnished with certain information in regard to the Indian schools in operation in each of the four western provinces of Canada.

In reply I beg to say that I am sending you under separate cover a copy of the last Annual Report of this Department, on pages 80 to 95, inclusive, of which you will find the number and kind of schools in each of these provinces and the names of the religious denominations under which they are conducted.

In regard to your request to be informed how these schools are supported I beg to inform you that the Department pays the salaries of the teachers and all other expenses in connection with the day schools and the boarding and industrial schools are conducted on a per capita grant system.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, requesting to be supplied with a list of the teachers in Indian schools in Ontario, giving their age, salary and qualifications.

In reply I beg to say that the Department does not furnish this information.

Whenever it is possible to do so, the Department secures qualified teachers with professional training for Indian schools. In schools of the older settled parts of the province, the Department has been fairly successful in securing qualified teachers, but it has sometimes met with difficulties in doing so in schools situated on the reserves in outlying districts. In these latter cases, it has been found impracticable to insist upon teachers having certificates in all cases. The qualifications of teachers in Indian schools vary, some having no professional qualifications and others having certificates of the highest standard. Many of the teachers who have no professional qualifications have, however, had long experience and have met with a great measure of success in Indian school work.

This important feature of Canadian Education is, as already mentioned, the concern of the Dominion Government. What corresponds to a Department of Education exists as a branch of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa with a Superintendent of Indian Education at its head. As the Indian population of Canada exceeds 100,000, it will be seen that the task of this Education branch would be equal to that of one of the provinces of Canada even if this population were collected in one province, but the scattered condition of this population and the specialized nature of the work among it places the task beyond comparison with that of such a province. It should be mentioned at the outset that the Indians in each province are educated according to the curriculum, textbooks, etc., of that province, so that there is a basis of comparison between the status of Indian Education and that of the education of whites in the province.

Education among the Indians in Canada, especially in Lower Canada and the Western part of Nova Scotia, was carried on at a very early date by the French, chiefly through the efforts of the Jesuits and other orders. As these efforts will be discussed in more or less detail in connection with the movements in education in each province, it will not be necessary to describe them here.

The needs of the North American Indians were first drawn to the attention of the English people by tracts published by John Eliot, who came to the country in 1631. The effect of these tracts, and of the work among Indians by Eliot upon Cromwell and others and upon the Long Parliament was such that in 1649 an ordinance was passed enacting that there should be a corporation in England consisting of sixteen persons to be called "The President and Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in New England" with power to acquire lands, goods and money. A general collection was directed to be made in England and Wales for the purposes of the corporation and the equivalent of nearly £60,000 was forthwith obtained. The Society at once appointed Commissioners and a Treasurer in New England who with income obtained from the corporation paid itinerant missionaries and school teachers among the natives. It is important to mention this Society at the outset, as considerable reference will be made to it in discussing the education of the provinces, especially the
older provinces of Canada towards which it directed its efforts after the American Revolution and played a part not only in the education of the Indians, but in that of the white settlers as well. The corporation was conducted for some time under the ordinance, but after the Restoration, a new charter of incorporation was granted by Charles II in 1662 under which the company called now "The New England Company" still conducts its operations. In what is now Canada this company was preceded by the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign parts who had catechists and school-masters appointed in the Bay of Quinte district and at the Grand River, but who yielded the field to the well-directed efforts of the New England Company. The distribution of the latter's invested funds has assisted materially in the education and development of the Six Nations Indians. Up to 1834 the whole of the clear rents and profits of the company's trust estates and funds was faithfully applied for the benefit of natives in Upper Canada and New Brunswick. Assistance by way of grant was also given to education in the district of Rupert's Land and in British Columbia where (at Lytton) there is still an industrial school under the supervision of the company. The most productive work, however, was performed in Upper Canada at Rice and Mud Lakes and at the Six Nations Reserves, the latter place absorbing most of the funds and attention of the company. Day-schools, missionaries and an institution for the instruction of pupils in residence, which is still in a flourishing condition, have contributed very largely to the present advanced position of the Six Nations Indians.

The Wesleyan Methodists also have contributed and are still contributing largely to Indian Education. In 1829 these had eight day schools with 251 scholars in Upper Canada conducted under the direction of missionaries from New York State. Before long Wesleyan missionaries from Great Britain were in the field and a residential school near Belleville was operated at the expense of the British Wesleyan Conference. This school developed into an industrial school at Alderville, erected in 1848, and the Mount Elgin Institute, erected in 1851, was founded by the same Society. To establish and maintain these schools, the Indians consented to set apart one quarter of the amount received in commutation of their annual distribution of ammunition. This contribution had begun in
and ended in 1862. At that time the annual payment of $6,879.75 had served to meet the expenses of conducting the schools and there remained $36,208.74. The Alderville buildings were burned in 1861 and not rebuilt, but the Mount Elgin Institute still survives. Both institutions were supported by an annual per capita grant for each pupil in attendance.

When the attention of the British Government was called to the condition of the Indians in Canada, the status of those in Lower Canada was so high as to render effort there less necessary than elsewhere. In 1842 there were about 3,727 known to the government not including the hunting tribes of the Northern nation. This population was scattered between the seven permanent settlements and ministered to by the priests of the Roman Catholic Church. A school was established by Protestants at Chateauguay in 1829 where education included manual training. An agricultural school and experimental farm was established soon after at Christierville near St. Johns and the pupils were transferred there from Chateauguay.

A scheme for civilizing the Chippewas and Ottawas of Lake Huron and Manitowaning, the first government attempt in Upper Canada to improve the condition of the Indians by direct instruction given to the whole community, proved a failure. Workshops and schools under the scheme were flourishing in 1844, but by 1845 all signs of progress had vanished. The experiment was not repeated until the modern policy of instruction in farming was instituted by the Dominion Government and spread to the Western tribes in 1879.

The first treaty with the Indians was formed by Lord Selkirk in 1811 and its sphere comprised nearly all the original province of Manitoba, a part of Saskatchewan and also of Dakota, Minnesota and New Ontario. In consequence of the discovery of minerals on the shores of Lakes Huron and Superior the Government of what was then called Canada deemed it desirable to extinguish the Indian title and in 1850 entrusted negotiations with the Indians to Hon. William Robinson who made two treaties which shaped the course of future treaties. The main features of the Robinson treaties were annuities, reserves for the Indians and liberty to fish and hunt on the unceded domain of the Crown. The number of Indians included in these treaties was about 2,700. In 1862 another treaty was made by Hon.
William McDougall, the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, with the Indians on Great Manitoulin Island on Lake Huron. Eleven other treaties have been made with the Indians between the Great Lakes and the Rockies. A treaty in 1871 was made with the Indians in Manitoba providing for an annuity to each Indian reserve of about 640 acres for each family of five or 128 acres for each man, woman and child and an annual allowance of ammunition, seed grain, agricultural implements, etc. Schools were also to be established on the Reserves. The half breed was also given a scrip of 240 acres. The Sioux Indians being refugees from the United States were not given annuities, but were granted reserves and some help to start farming.

The last treaty was made in 1921 to protect the Indians from the results of the oil rush and covered the Mackenzie River District. No treaty has been made with the Indians of British Columbia, but their welfare has received no less attention on that account. The effects of these treaties and of the British North America Act have been to make the Indians minors and wards of the Dominion Government which is responsible for their education. It is worth observing that while Indians, with special exceptions such as those who served in the Great war, are without the franchise, those of them who qualify for the professions are ipso facto enfranchised.

At the making of the treaty of 1871, the provision made for education was understood to be day schools on the reserves. For a number of years this was the only system adopted. At present the Indian schools are divided into three classes: (1) Day schools situated on the reserves; (2) Boarding schools situated on the reserves or nearby; (3) Industrial or non-reservation schools. As the name indicates, the industrial school educates along industrial lines in addition to literary education. The same is true of the boarding school. Special attention is paid to the manual arts, domestic science, agriculture, and the training proceeds until the age of eighteen in the case of boys. For those who desire it the Government has provided a special reserve at Balcarres, Saskatchewan, where a boy graduate of an industrial school is given eighty acres of land and help in starting to farm. If he makes good, another eighty acres, and in some cases more, is given him. Crop returns indicate that the experiment is successful. A female graduate may be given a sewing machine or household furniture.
Many graduates enter the general labour market and a few the professions. Field matrons are employed upon many of the reserves, their salaries being sometimes paid by the government, but usually by the church to which they belong. These, in addition to caring for the sick, instruct women in household duties. The Government provides medical attendance for the pupils in industrial schools and for nearly all the Indian people on large reserves or where a large number of smaller reserves can be reached by one physician. Hospitals are built and equipped sometimes by the Government and sometimes by the church interested, the Government usually rendering financial assistance to the latter.

The Department of Indian Affairs, established in 1873 under the Minister of the Interior, who is also Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, controls the educational movement and conducts it either directly or by assisting the efforts of the various churches. The spirit of cooperation between these churches—Roman Catholic, Anglican, Methodists, Presbyterian and Salvation Army—and the government in the work is admirable. It would probably be sufficiently close to the truth to say that the churches are the "School districts" or "Sections" that is, the local organization in Indian Education while the Government is the "Department". The Government pays a grant and certain amounts for capital expenditure, supervises the manner in which this grant is expended and insists upon properly qualified teachers, proper accommodation, equipment, recognized courses of study, in short sees that the education and care of the Indians measure up to a certain standard. In the case of "undenominational" schools the Government bears the whole cost and this is the only sense in which these schools may be said to be non-denominational; in the case of denominational schools, the church interested bears a portion of the expenditure. The churches on the other hand select the teachers in all the industrial and boarding schools and in most cases nominate the teachers in the day schools and carry on the work of education, and, in the cases of boarding and industrial schools, clothe and feed the Indian pupil throughout the year for eleven years. Appropriations by the Dominion Parliament for Indian Education in 1921 amounted to $1,112,410, of which $168,994 was expended on day schools, $601,969 on boarding schools and $269,249 on industrial schools, while $2,934 was expended
on ex pupils. Several bands of Indians assist in the work, and during the fiscal year 1921 the sum of $47,297 was available from this source, $13,485 of this being contributed by the Six Nations of Grand River.

A total number of 326 schools were in operation in 1921, comprising 255 day, 58 boarding and 15 industrial schools. Of the schools, 53 day and one industrial were undenominational; 87 day, 32 boarding and 8 industrial or 127 in all were under the direction of the Roman Catholic Church; 71 day, 16 boarding and 5 industrial or 90 in all, of the Church of England; 38 day, 5 boarding and 3 industrial, or 46 in all, of the Methodists; 3 day and 5 boarding, of the Presbyterians and 1 day school, of the Salvation Army. In these schools there were 12,558 pupils, 7,775 being in day schools, 3,156 in boarding schools and 1,627 in industrial schools. In addition to these about 100 are being educated in public and private residential schools throughout the Dominion besides a number attending high schools.

The Indian day schools in Ontario, Quebec, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island are inspected semi-annually by the provincial public and separate school inspectors. In New Brunswick and British Columbia Indian schools are inspected by officials appointed by the department. In Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and the North-west Territories the schools are inspected by the inspectors for the different Indian agencies, but inspection by Department of Education inspectors in the Prairie Provinces is now under consideration. In addition to the inspectors almost all the schools are under the supervision of the different Indian agents who are required to make monthly inspections and reports.

It has been already stated that in the literary training of Indian pupils the curriculum of the province in which they are situated is strictly followed. The statistics of the standing of these pupils at school are given by "Standards", Stand I corresponding to First Reader, Part I or Grade I; Standard II, to First Reader, Part II or Grade II; Standard III to Second Reader or Grades III and IV; Standard IV to Third Reader or Grades V and VI; Standard V to Fourth Reader or Grades VII and VII and Standard VI to Fifth Reader or Grades IX and X. Memorandum.

INDIAN EDUCATION

Recapitulation.

The Department of Indian Affairs had, during the past fiscal year, 326 schools in Canada, caring for the educational needs of 12,588 Indian children. 253 day schools situated on reserves had an enrolment of 7775 pupils, and there were in 73 residential schools 4783 of our wards. In addition, some 50 neglected Indian children have been placed in orphanages and about 120 promising pupils are receiving tuition in provincial public schools, colleges and in universities. The total expenditure from parliamentary appropriation was $1,112,409.65. Certain Indian bands in Ontario have contributed, during the same year, $47,296.53 towards the education of their children.

Cooperation with the various churches in Canada is the feature of our Indian educational work, and all residential schools and four fifths of the day schools are under the auspices of the Roman Catholic, Church of England, Methodist and Presbyterian churches. The expenditure for Indian Education is augmented, roughly 20% by these religious denominations. In addition, the wards of the Department receive a moral stimulus that undenominational schools would not impart.

The greater number of teachers engaged are professionally qualified and the work compares favourably with that in white schools similarly situated. The course of studies followed is that of the Department of Education for the province in which the school is located. The general plan is to have all classroom activities supervised by the Public and Separate School Inspectors.
INDIAN EDUCATION.

Maritime Provinces.

24 day schools, all under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, meet the educational requirements of the Indian children in the three Maritime Provinces. The enrolment for these schools is 552. Special instruction is being given in sewing, hygiene and sanitation. About 50 children are attending white schools or have been placed in orphanages. The total expenditure involved is $23,542.30.
ONTARIO & QUEBEC

Indian Education.

In Ontario and Quebec gardening and school fairs are emphasized in the 110 day schools under the Department of Indian Affairs. For these and the 11 residential schools in Ontario, there is a total enrolment of 4924. In addition, 106 Indian children are attending white schools, collegiates, or have been placed in orphanages. The expenditure for the last fiscal year was $264,814.32. Certain bands in Ontario augmented this by a contribution to education of $47,296.53.
PRAIRIE PROVINCES AND NORTHWEST TERRITORIES

Indian Education.

West of the Great Lakes the residential school has been more successful for our Indian wards than the day school on the reserve, due to the nomadic habits of the bands. There are in the Prairie Provinces 71 day and 44 residential schools, with a total enrolment of 4843. The Department has placed emphasis on farming, care of stock and domestic instruction. The expenditure for the past fiscal year was $498,241.41.
BRITISH COLUMBIA

Indian Education.

40 day and 17 residential schools care for the education of 2393 Indian children in British Columbia. The residential school is the more successful type and endeavours to teach a smattering of fruit farming and basketry, in addition to the regular vocational and domestic instruction. During the past fiscal year $318,042.58 was expended.
YUKON

Indian Education.

In the Yukon the Department has 4 day and 1 residential schools, catering to 146 Indian pupils. Another residential school at Dawson is coming under the auspices of the Department of Indian Affairs at the time of this writing. The total expenditure for the past fiscal year was $7769.02.

Sir:

I have yours of the 17th instant, in which you request certain information in connection with the operation of the Compulsory Education clause of the Indian Act.

In reply to your question - on how many reserves are compulsory school attendance laws enforced? - I beg to state that from time to time it has been found advisable to put this clause of the Act in force. Whenever day school activities are more or less abortive, due to non-attendance, this Department takes steps to insist upon the presence in the classroom of those Indian children who should attend. The agents employed are known as truant officers. We may appoint an Indian to this position, or, in extremities, a R.C.M.P. officer. When the good attendance warrants such action, the services of the truant officers are frequently dispensed with. Often the persuasive powers of an Indian agent are sufficient to enforce the Act, and you will see that it is quite impossible for me to intimate the number of reserves where compulsion has been used. Whenever school facilities are provided, and the attendance is poor, this Department is prepared to take steps to keep the classrooms full.

Your query concerning the denomination control interfering with the application of the Compulsory Attendance clause involves matters of policy which this Department is not prepared to discuss. I can inform you that, as a rule, the influence of the Church on the reserve is a power for good in connection with any departmental activity. You will understand that it is not possible for me to discuss this last matter at any length.

This Department would be grateful for a little more information concerning the nature of your thesis. If it is for publication, I feel that you should make an effort to get into personal touch with some of the officials of the Department. I will be personally pleased to see you at Brantford during the last few days of this week, and I feel that an hour of conversation would give you more information than a score of letters. If you would care to write to me, care of the Mohawk Institute, or telephone there on Thursday, Friday or Saturday (the 27th to 29th) I could give you an interview.

THE EDUCATION OF THE INDIANS OF CANADA
When Christopher Columbus landed in America, he was met by a group of astonished savages, whom he named Indians. Soon after, the news of the discovery of this new continent was spread broadcast throughout Europe. European adventurers began to filter into the continent at first by tens, and later by hundreds. These Europeans came from countries which had been enjoying the fruits of civilization for centuries. Savagery had been dethroned and in its place were to be found educational systems, improved agricultural methods, merchant marines, governments, improved weapons of warfare, epoch-making inventions, a high state of industrial development, a Christianity, a science, a literature. The savage Redmen fought fiercely to retain their hunting grounds, but slowly they were pushed to the frontiers. They were outnumbered, out-fought, and out-generalled by the superior Europeans. These brought with them their culture, art, and ideals. European civilization was no longer confined to Europe, but was extended to the newly discovered continent.

Industrial and social development was very rapid and a wilderness was transformed into productive farms, villages grew into towns, and towns into industrial cities, in an incredible short time. Had the Redmen been transferred directly to England or to France, their maladjustment would not have been much less. True, they still had the plains but they could not roam over them so freely. They still had the rivers, but steamers now glided up and down these streams. It was a conflict between savagery and civilization, and a decisive victory for civilization was inevitable.

Canada very early discerned the plight of the Redmen. They saw that they must be helped to adapt themselves to the changed and changing order of things. A laissez-faire policy may have been pursued and from this policy the fittest would have survived. How many would have survived is another question. Canada, however, saw fit to extend a helping hand.

At first Indian affairs were placed under the control of the Imperial military authorities. During the period of this military control (1763-1841) Canada was engaged in warfare and her people were scattered far and wide throughout the country. Canada naturally looked upon the Indians as potential allies or foes. Gradually, however, as settlement of the country increased and peace was once more restored, efforts to civilize, educate, and christianize, were substituted for the policy which was dictated by considerations of fear and self-interest. This gradual change of policy marked the second period of Indian affairs (1841-1867). The period from 1867 to the present time constitutes the period of control by the Dominion Government and since 1880 a Department of Indian affairs has had charge of problems relating to Indians.

The end toward which the Indians of Canada are being educated is full British citizenship. The Department of Indian Affairs has not wavered from this policy, although the method of executing this policy has been modified somewhat in adaptation to changing conditions. The problem is the citizenizing of the Indians in their settled communities or bands. The essential idea in full
citizenship is that of self-support. The Indians must progress from a position of dependency or of being wards, to a position of self-maintenance. They must learn, in addition, to cooperate in all legitimate activities, and to participate intelligently in the activities of the different institutions of the country. Psychologically, they must develop a social consciousness not opposed, but paralleling, the social consciousness of the assimilating group in order that they may become socially efficient.

The difficulties that lie in the way of the attainment of this goal of full citizenship are not a few and not insignificant. Discussion of some of the difficulties will lead to a proper appreciation of the task.

Right at the beginning the Government had to grapple with the problem of organization. In a large country like Canada, to organize a people unaccustomed in a great measure to co-operative action in time of peace, for purposes of control, protection, and education demanded patience, firmness, and tact. Finally, however, the Indians were settled in bands on lands set aside by the Government and known as "Indian Reserves". Just in this connection it may be stated that since 1763, the title of an individual Indian in fee simple to land reserved to band or tribe has not been recognized except in the case of enfranchised Indians. The Indians are educated on these closed reserves, and they are permitted to sell any surplus land only to the crown, as direct purchase by white persons is prohibited.

At present there are scattered throughout Canada from Nova Scotia to British Columbia over 630 bands comprising in all about 105,000 Indians. To oversee, protect and educate these scattered bands adequately is the Department's task. There is a geographical difficulty arising from the scattered positions of the bands. This geographical difficulty has been partly overcome by the appointment of Government agents who reside near the reserve or reserves. Travelling superintendents and inspectors supervise the work of these Indian agents. It is evident from the nature of the difficulty that a great responsibility is placed upon these Indian agents. The Indian Department makes known its wishes to the Indians through its agents and the Indians make known their wishes to the Department through the same medium. The Agent acts as the representative of the Indian Department. Although this system which has been adopted is effective, yet the handicap arising from this geographical difficulty remains.

If there were any uniformity among the bands, in the number of people who constitute the different bands, in their languages or dialects, in their religions or aboriginal beliefs, in the sizes of the reserves upon which they live, and in their stages of progress, the task would be greatly simplified. But the greatest diversity exists. Among the 630 bands supervised by 114 agents a large number of languages or dialects are spoken. The largest band has a membership of about 5,000 people and the smallest, 3 or 4. The areas of the reserves vary from a few hundred acres to thousands of acres. Some bands in the older sections of the country have reached a stage in their advancement equal to that attained by progressive white people. Other bands,
situated on the outposts of civilization still live in the same kind of tepees as their forefathers lived in, and still wear the same kind of clothing as their ancestors wore. Between the most advanced bands and the most backward are other bands in different stages of progress. In religion, many bands are composed wholly of Roman Catholics while others are predominantly Church of England. There are Presbyterians, Baptists, Methodists, and Congregationalists. Paganism in its many forms still exists even on the most progressive reserves. Probably no two bands could be found where circumstances and conditions were the same, and where problems called for identical methods for solution. Most comprehensive principles for guidance in the method of treatment are necessary amidst such great diversity of conditions.

But the centre of interest is the Indian himself. It is here that the real problem is found. His changed and changing environment has wrought transformation on his physical appearance, in his ways of thinking, in his attitude toward his fellow-men, and in his conception of religion. His skin is not so copper coloured now. His eyes may be blue and his hair may be quite fair. The full-blooded Indian is fast disappearing. Legally a man may be an Indian although he may have only a trace of native blood. So long as his descent has been through the male line he is, by law, an Indian. But an Indian woman, by marrying a white man, relinquishes her legal status as an Indian, and her children are white also. In dress, he is discarding the buckskin, beads, and feathers and is quite content to clothe himself like the white men.

But perhaps the most striking effect of his environment has been made upon his way of thinking, and upon his habits of doing. It is probably true that at least among the early Indian tribes who lived upon a physical plane rather than upon an intellectual plane, their modes of doing determined their ways of thinking, and as their intellectual life developed, their intellectual activities were coloured by their motor activities. The early tribes depended for their existence upon the chase and upon their success in warfare. The wild animals which they hunted moved from place to place according to their instincts. Climatic conditions, ever changing, attracted and repulsed these roving animals from place to place. Hunting expeditions never set out without ceremonial invocations to their gods for success. In warfare there was the same uncertainty, the same dependence upon pure chance. In sickness, they called upon their mysterious medicine man who, by magic, drove the evil spirits away. There was no attempt to get at the cause of things. Occurrences which they could not explain were at once set down as the works of supernatural beings. This ignorance of the laws of nature and their dependance upon the operation of these laws for their very existence bred in this aboriginal people a superstitious temper of mind which determined in a large measure their mode of living. Education is dispelling superstition and their mode of living is being governed more and more by their knowledge of cause and effect. They have learned, for instance, that sickness is caused by the improper functioning or loss of functioning
of some organ of the body and they call upon a doctor who is in the best position to determine the cause and the cure for the sickness. Medicine men are gradually retreating to the farthest reserves, and soon they will disappear altogether from the scene.

The Indian tribe in its primitive state pursued the path of least resistance. No determined or sustained effort was made to control circumstances or conditions. The behaviour of the tribe was largely determined by external conditions. True, the head chief exercised a certain amount of authority over the members of the tribe, but this authority was most evident, and most respected on hunting expeditions and in warfare, and the discipline within the tribe then was largely a discipline of fear, or a discipline arising from the instinctive desire for commendation. Social consciousness was an insignificant factor in this inculcation of discipline. When their food supply was ample, and their enemies were far away, idleness and festivals prevailed. If food became scarce on account of unproductive soil or scarcity of game, the remedy was migration to more favourable hunting grounds. Competition among the members, outside of competition for skill in the hunt, or for bravery in warfare or for wisdom and eloquence in council, was almost entirely absent. The food obtained was distributed throughout the tribe, and the soil of the whole continent was theirs. Accumulation of material wealth was unnecessary. Even large stores of food were unknown, for game was plentiful on the continent, and the tribes were virtually living from hand to mouth. Contentment prevailed if there was food for the immediate present, and the provision of food was left to the future. Necessity fell upon the tribe only when inveterate enemies were lurking near. Then, bravery, danger of death, grim determination and revenge, animated every member of the tribe to disciplined endeavour. Choice lay between discipline and annihilation and the instinct for self-preservation was strong. When they had defeated the enemy, or had attained safety by flight, inactivity once more prevailed in the tribe. In warfare the voice of necessity was insistent but in peace it was silent. Therefore discipline was lacking in the peaceful pursuits of the tribe. Nor could these conditions fail to be impressed upon the children. Disciplinary training of children was never attempted in a systematic way. The people of the forests and plains loved their freedom, and they were averse to deny that same freedom to their children. Corporal punishment was almost unknown. There were these conditions. A people, roving from place to place, living virtually from hand to mouth, and enjoying the freedom made possible by prolific nature, were comparatively free from the necessity of disciplinary training, except in the event of tribal warfare.

Some of the most difficult problems in connection with the education of the Indians toward full citizenship arise from the transmission of traits developed by primitive conditions from generation to generation. Compulsion in any form has terrors for the Indians. They resent it with vigor. Before a compulsory law can be made effective, and can be enforced without
much friction among Indians, they must understand that such compulsory law is absolutely necessary for the furtherance of their interests, and it is only fair to state that the bands in the older sections of the country have gone a long way towards recognizing the necessity for compulsory laws. But in some cases, resentment at trespass on traditional freedom has become so habitual that objection is made to compulsory laws mainly because they are compulsory. In the history of the development of societies, it has been found that compulsory laws are enacted by social communities where the need for such compulsory laws is felt by the majority of the members of this social community. In the meantime some harm may have resulted from the absence of these compulsory laws. Clearly Indian communities have had this advantage, that necessary compulsory laws have been enacted from without by a more highly developed community.

The Indian parents dislike compulsion from external sources, and they refrain as much as possible from using compulsion in the treatment of their children. An Indian missionary, who lived for over twenty years on a reserve, and had most favourable opportunities for observation, stated that in those twenty years of contact with Indians, he had yet to see an Indian parent chastising a child. Although this case is exceptional, let it be true that Indian parents are, as a rule quite lenient to their children. Former Deputy-Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Mr. J. A. Smart, stated, in speaking of Indian education, that "Indian children not only possess this (natural aversion to monotonous work and confinement in schools) in its strongest form, but receive much sympathy from their parents, who dislike to compel their inclinations and to subject them to discipline, and the possibility of what (at any rate as far as the boys are concerned) they regard as the great indignity of personal chastisement." If disciplinary training is not a strong characteristic of Indian home life, then the task devolves upon the schools. Improvement, however, is taking place in the matter of the disciplinary training of children in Indian homes, and indulgent influences in home life do not now wholly destroy the work of the schools.

There still exist in Canada a number of nomadic bands of Indians. It is quite evident that nomadic tribes are under most serious disadvantages. Agriculture as an occupation is impossible among them. Regular school attendance of children belonging to nomadic bands is out of the question unless the children are placed in boarding or in industrial schools. However, this nomadic habit is now confined mainly to hunting tribes in remote districts and to tribes which move to lumbering camps during the winter. There are some bands situated in more settled portions of the country, many of whose members move off the reserve to flax fields, or fruit regions, for one or two months during the summer. But it is encouraging to note that this wandering, roving habit is rapidly disappearing, and just as quickly as roving tribes recognize the disadvantages of this mode of living, and see from experience and by example, the advantages of a settled habitation, will they discard this mode of living. The change has been gradual and will probably
continue to be gradual.

It is not surprising, indeed it is to be expected, that a roving, freedom-loving people should lack an important requisite for success in modern society—steadiness. It seems to be altogether against an Indian's inclinations to remain in one place or at one occupation for any length of time. Periodic changes in environment and in occupation come naturally to a people whose parents or grandparents or great-grandparents roamed the forests and plains of a whole continent in freedom. Whatever physical strength the Indian may possess, and whatever skill he may have for use in employment, is largely counteracted by this traditional feeling—unsteadiness. Whether they are working for another, or whether they are working for themselves, they yield to their inclinations. Even at the present time, it may be stated that unsteadiness is an Indian failing, but to say that all Indians can be so characterized would be far from the truth. Gradual and continuous improvement can be noted in steadiness as education becomes more and more general among the bands.

Love of freedom, resentment of compulsion, lack of disciplinary training, and unsteadiness do not exhaust the list of traits handed down from generation to generation. Truly primitive habits of thought and actions developed under primitive conditions have been transmitted with lavish hand. Their forefathers, numbered at approximately one half of a million, lived on a continent which now supports upwards of one hundred and twenty millions. Vegetation and animal life provided perpetual supplies of food for the roving aborigines, who therefore felt no necessity for provisions for the future. This lack of foresight for future needs still persists. Earnings of months are sometimes squandered in a few days. As soon as they have earned a sum of money, they discontinue work to spend. However, bank accounts are increasing, and their behaviour is marked by patient foresight concerning future needs. Of two alternatives, one providing cash almost immediately, the other necessitating patience for months before financial benefits are derived therefrom, Indians will very often choose the first even though the reward is smaller. But as stated above the Indians are improving in the matter of provision for future needs. If an Indian experiences discomfort for failure to look ahead, and sees comfort among those who are exercising foresight, the tendency is to adopt the more beneficial mode of living.

The Indians in their camps often surprised by sudden attacks from enemy tribes. In these attacks wholesale torture and massacre of men, women, and children took place, although usually the women and children were adopted into the tribe, or kept as ransom. Unsuspected by the tribe, enemy spies had lurked around the camp for days and nights and had ascertained their number. Perhaps these spies had gone about the camp openly, unrecognized by the tribe. The news had been carried back to the hostile tribe and a surprise attack had been planned. Naturally, the Indians became very suspicious. After the discovery of America unscrupulous traders and settlers practised all forms of deceit to obtain fertile land cheaply,
to foment internal strife, or to befriend hostile tribes. Promises were made which were never carried out. Such condition of affairs did not at all tend to mitigate the already suspicious nature of the Indian. To-day, suspicion is a trait which has to be reckoned with in the management of Indian affairs. Well-intentioned purposes, unless supported by persuasive power, may fall by the wayside, discarded and forgotten because of suspicion.

Other problems arising from the Indian's primitive or aboriginal habits present themselves. These will simply be mentioned but the brevity of the discussion must not be construed to mean that these problems are unimportant. As a matter of fact success in citizenizing the Indians of Canada depends in large measure upon an adequate method of solving the problems now to be mentioned. One of these problems is that of transforming the Indians into an agricultural class. Another is the christianizing of the Indians. As to the extent to which success has crowned the efforts of the churches and the Department in the solution of these vital problems, mention is reserved for a later section.

There are two later developments, psychological in character which must be mentioned at this point. One of these is the habit, especially prominent in older Indians, of looking back to former times. Pauline Johnson had that type in mind when she wrote in "The Cattle Thief":

"When you pay for the land you live in, we'll pay for the meat we eat.
Give back our land and our country, give back our herds of game;
Give back the furs and the forests that were ours before you came;
Give back the peace and the plenty. Then come with your new belief,
And blame, if you dare, the hunger that drove him to be a thief."

The problem here is the substitution of forward-mindedness for this habit of mind so inimical to progress. Each succeeding generation, however, looks more to the future as the time when realization of their destined end is to be found.

But the more pernicious of these later psychological developments in the Indian's character is that of expecting help from the Government. The origin of this development is not hard to locate. So deep-seated, or habitual has this way of thinking become that, in some cases, withholding of expected help is considered an infringement of rights. Such a temper of mind is bound to interfere with the exercise of initiative on the part of the Indians, and the sooner they learn to depend upon their own efforts, the more rapidly will they develop their native capacities in a direction that will make them self-supporting and useful citizens of Canada.

As to the moral problems we cannot do better than to quote former Deputy-Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Mr. J. A. Smart, who stated as follows in his Report for the fiscal year 1896, "The enactment of special legislation recognizes the fact that the Indians require exceptional protection from their own natural fondness for strong drink, as well as from having temptation put in their way by unscrupulous miscreants whose lust of gain would outweigh every consideration of morality and humanity. While of course there are many exceptions, it may be said of the great majority of the Indians, that despite their natural proclivities, they would not go in quest of liquor if only left alone." Since the sale of intoxicating liquors to Indians has been illegal, and infractions of the law have been punished. That there have been difficulties in the enforcement of the law may be gathered from the following statement of Mr. J. A. Smart in the Report for 1899, "Every effort is made to discover and punish the miscreants who supply the Indians with intoxicants, but, as the Indians who receive the liquor are as a rule the only witnesses of such transactions and to give information would cut them off from all hope of procuring further supplies, it is next to impossible to extract any from them. Under such circumstances the only other course left is to punish the Indian, but here another difficulty presents itself; because the chances are that his circumstances are such that whether he be fined or imprisoned the result is to render his family destitute; and the duty of affording relief falls upon the Funds, if possessed of funds to devote to such purpose, and, if not, upon the Government." Conditions are continually improving, however, and, at least among Indians living on reserves which are surrounded by communities where prohibitory laws are also in force, an intoxicated Indian is indeed a rare occurrence.

Mr. J. A. Smart, speaking of other aspects of the moral problem stated; "As to other aspects of morality, and more particularly with regard to the true nature and obligations of the marriage tie, tribal customs and pagan views have to be overcome, and this has to a large extent been done, and every day is being further accomplished by contact with civilization, increasing familiarity with its views and customs, education of the young in the schools, but above all, by the earnest and faithful efforts of the missionaries of the various denominations."

"The Indians are beyond dispute a law respecting people, and when occasionally some serious crime is committed by one of their number, it attracts the more attention from its rarity, and causes alarm if of a character to suggest that racial antagonism may still be slumbering."

A circular issued by the Indian Department tells the whole story of Indian marriages and divorces in Canada: "A marriage between Indians or between Indians and others solemnized or contracted in accordance with provincial or territorial law is valid."

"The validity of marriages between Indians contracted in accordance with the customs of their tribes has been established by the courts, notably in the case of 'Comolly vs. Woolwich, and others', in 1867; nor does the fact that one or both of the contracting parties may profess adherence to christianity affect the matter."
"It is particularly deserving of notice that the validity of Indian divorces has never been affirmed in Canada, and Indian marriages, if valid, cannot be dissolved according to the Indian customs, but only in such manner as other marriages may be dissolved."

"If an Indian is validly married to one woman and has gone through a form of marriage with another which would make her his wife but for the fact that he was already married, he is guilty of bigamy and liable to the penalties for that crime (Section 308, Criminal Code, R. S. C., 1906), and the Department of Justice has expressed the opinion that, even if there has been no valid marriage but the Indian intended by complying with the customs of the band relating to marriage to make more than the first married his wife or wives, or if, even without such intention, he has complied in the case of two or more women with the requirements of the tribal customs, he may be successfully prosecuted under section 310 of the Criminal Code."

"With reference to a more or less prevalent idea that a man or woman can legally contract a fresh alliance if he or she in good faith and on reasonable grounds believes his wife or her husband to be dead or if his wife or her husband has been continually absent for seven years then last past and he or she is not proved to have known that his wife or her husband was alive at any time during those seven years, it has to be pointed out that, while such conditions would furnish a good defense against a charge of bigamy, they would not serve to legalize the second alliance in case of its being shown that both parties to the first marriage contract were alive at the time of the second purported marriage."

The ethical standard of the aborigines differed in important respects from the standard of Christian ethics. The process of approximation to the standard of Christian ethics has been gradual, as indeed has been the whole process of assimilation. The various religious denominations have laboured indefatigably in this process of adjustment in moral standard and their work has borne fruit in the gradual and continuous improvement that can be noted in this adjustment.

The most serious difficulties of the problem have now been indicated. While it would be utterly absurd and untrue to say that all Indians possess these traits of character, yet it has seemed that the number of Indians who can be so characterized is sufficiently large to justify an observer to place these serious defects at the door of the Indian people. It will be noted that such characteristics are labelled "serious defects". Now, if the Indian had remained savage and were to remain savage, these characteristics would not have been so serious. But under a changed social environment where certain characteristics are absolutely necessary for advancement, such characteristics must be so named. The fact cannot be emphasized too strongly that the Indian problem is the result of the great gulf which has developed between the Indian's adaptive powers on the one hand
and the rapid change in his environment on the other. Had the Indian been able to keep pace with this abrupt environmental change, such ability would have been fittingly termed miraculous. It is well to remember that for centuries (how many will remain a mystery) these characteristics were being brought into the character of the Indians by continual exercise and were being transmitted from generation to generation with such persistency and regularity as to be called hereditary. It is now only about two hundred years ago since the process of assimilation began on a general scale.

Before we begin to examine the instruments, organized and unorganized, used by the Department, it is necessary to mention the close connection existing between the various religious denominations and the Indian schools. The religious denominations concerned are the Roman Catholic, Church of England, Methodist, Presbyterian, and Salvation Army. Before the bands were organized and settled on their respective reserves zealous missionaries were at work educating and christianizing the Indians, and the churches have continued their efforts to the present day. The Department frankly acknowledges the debt it owes to these missionaries, and almost all Canadian Indian schools are conducted under a joint agreement between the denominations concerned and the Department as to system and finances. This system of union between church and state is quite in contrast with the system adopted by the United States where the churches have no such direct connection with the schools. Commenting on the Canadian system, Frederick H. Abbott, secretary of the Board of Indian Commissioners which was appointed to make an investigation into the administration of Indian affairs in Canada, has made the following statement, "The difference between Canada and the United States as respects the attitude toward the churches which have engaged in educational and missionary work among Indians is, that Canada from the beginning has frankly recognized her debt to the churches and her need of their continued help, whereas the United States Government, by raising the fetish of Church separation has weakened the effectiveness of missionary work among Indians and has come near to depriving the Indian youth of really beneficial religious instruction in the schools. The Indians of Canada provided that the chief or chiefs of any band in council may, subject to the confirmation by the governor in council, make rules and regulations as to the religious denomination to which the teacher of the school established on the reserve shall belong. If the majority of the band belong to any one religious denomination, the teacher of the school established on the reserve shall belong to the same denomination. The Protestant or Catholic minority of any band, may with the approval of, and under regulations made by the governor in council have a separate school established on the reserve. Thus Canada has expressed in law her belief in religious education in the Indian schools and has protected her Indians from the dangers of skepticism and confusion in religious thought, which inevitably attend the system in the United States, where Catholic teachers may by chance be employed to instruct Protestant children and vice versa."
Versa, and where Protestant and Catholic children thrown in schools together are exposed to the petty gossip and friction which too often finds place among missionaries and employees of different religious denominations in the same government boarding schools." Commenting upon the homelike atmosphere surrounding the Canadian Indian schools, Mr. Abbott states "My judgment is that the main cause of this home atmosphere is to be found in the government's frank encouragement of religious instruction which makes the teachers feel responsible for every phase of the pupil's development, spiritual and physical, mental and moral." There can be no doubt whatever that benefits have been derived from this union between the churches and the Department. Had the union between the churches and the Department been less close, the christianization of the Indians of Canada would have been retarded.

That there has been in the past no serious friction sometimes attending the operations of different denominations in the same fields, has, no doubt, been partly due to the attitude of the Department indicated above and partly to the attitude of the denominations towards one another. All the denominations felt that the Indians were ready for christianization. This one purpose, christianization, deliverance from aboriginal religious beliefs, actuated all denominations with a zeal and tolerance which left little room for friction. That there has been no serious objection from the Indians themselves is due to several reasons. The transition from pagan beliefs to christian beliefs is slow and gradual. There is a new allegiance and new ceremonials and the Indian is very intently occupied accustoming himself to the new beliefs. The new religion is not yet wholly his, he is just in the transition stage, but when the transformation has been completed he will defend the tenets of his religion with fervour and conviction. In many bands, all the members belong exclusively to one religion. In other bands they are so divided in the matter of religious beliefs that separate schools are conveniently provided. But in many bands the minorities are so few in numbers that provision of separate schools for these few would be expensive, to say the least. The children of the minority therefore are obliged to attend schools which are only passively sympathetic to their religion if they desire an education. Strong objections would probably be made if the children of the minority were compelled by law to attend schools taught, attended, and governed by persons belonging to another denomination. The situation is further alleviated by the fact that no taxes are paid by Indians living on reserves for any purpose, and, therefore, no money paid by the minority are diverted to the support of these denominational schools. It is significant that the bands which defray some of the expenses of their schools from the funds of the band are those whose schools are undenominational, or whose members belong to one denomination, or where the denominations have provided separate schools for the education of their adherents and members. Under ordinary circumstances, enforcement of compulsory attendance laws is, and will be, extremely difficult, presupposing as it does an intelligent appreciation at the place of the school in a community.
in a province, and in a democratic country. An adjustment of existing conditions will probably be necessary in many bands before compulsory attendance laws can be effectively enforced without violating individual rights in the matter of religion.

Too much praise cannot be given to those missionaries who made and are making great sacrifices that through their labors, the Indians of Canada might become christianized. Nor have they labored in vain. Four hundred and thirty years ago, every Indian in the territory now included under Canada, was a pagan. In 1890 there were 15,621 Indians professing aboriginal beliefs. In 1921, there were still 8,414 pagans. The number professing Roman Catholic religion, 43,966 in 1921, gives a remarkable record of the results of indefatigable work on the part of the Jesuit missionaries and their successors. Similarly, the 20,182 Indians in 1921 professing Church of England religion, were won from pagan beliefs by John Eliot and by the New England Company, which grew out of the labors of John Eliot. 12,820 Methodists, 2,155 Presbyterians, 1,297 Baptists, 1,426 professing other christian beliefs, together with the fore mentioned figures, show the extent to which christianity has been accepted by the Indians.
