It is safe to say that such results could not have been attained, if the churches and the government of Canada had not co-operated in the work.

There is great danger that in a system depending largely upon voluntary effort salaries will be low. Enthusiastic missionaries and teachers are willing to accept comparatively small remuneration for the privilege and opportunity of working among Indians. The supply of that stamp of people is not equal to the demand. A consequent lowering of standards and requirements usually takes place under the circumstances, instead of increasing the attractive power of the work by further inducements. Under present conditions, the employment of properly qualified people is very difficult of attainment and it may be stated emphatically and unreservedly that before teachers with proper qualifications can be engaged in greater numbers in Indian schools, greater financial inducements must be offered.
Competition between communities in securing efficient teachers is keen and the supply of such teachers is not at all sufficient to fill all schools in white communities let alone the Indian schools. But the point raised here is that this close union between the Department and the churches has probably had a tendency to keep salaries low, and comparatively low salaries always bring with them attendant evils. The remedy, of course, is larger salaries. The right solution appears to lie in the direction of greater self-activity and self-help on the part of the bands and not so much upon larger grants from the Department.

With this preliminary discussion of the close connection between the churches and the Department in the management of schools we shall now proceed to the examination of the organized and unorganized forces brought to bear upon the Indians with a view to their citizenization. The organized forces are: the Department itself, the churches, and the schools. These of course very often overlap. The Department and the churches, although very often working directly with the Indians, do their work mainly through the schools. The unorganized forces at work are those which call into exercise the Indians' initiative and selective power. The manner of the Indians' external surroundings in adapting him of himself to conditions in the lower stages of progress at least, the most potent factor leading the Indians to adaptation to modern conditions appears to be that of their external surroundings. Where the schools have failed in endeavor to make an impression, external surroundings, the persistence of their influences lead and impel the Indians along right paths of progress. While the list below does not pretend to exhaust the list of the external forces, they will at least give an idea of the unorganized forces: Trade and other dealings with white men; newspapers, travel, influence of well kept farms in the immediate neighborhood; social and commercial intercourse among themselves; social and physical isolation on reserves.

There are three types of schools; day schools, boarding schools, and industrial schools. In day schools, the pupils attend during the school hours, but go home after school hours. They correspond to the elementary rural schools among white communities. In boarding and industrial schools, the pupils receive instruction on the subjects of the course of study and are taken care of by the school after school hours. That is, they live in the school. Hitherto, the distinction between boarding schools and industrial schools was that some industrial arts, such as carpentry, painting and cooking, were taught in industrial schools, but this distinction has now practically disappeared, and boarding schools now attempt to teach as many of the industrial arts as possible. These industrial arts are taught in addition to the subjects of the course of study.

What are the causes of this irregular attendance at the day schools? Clearly the most important reason for this condition is that the Indians have not yet realized the importance of education. Isolated on their reserves where a comparative simplicity and crudity of social and commercial life prevails, they have not yet felt the need of adequate preparation for the activities of life. In 1900 Mr. J. A. Smart, in his report to the Minister of the Interior on the condition of Indian education in Canada stated: "So long as the Indians remain a distinct people and live as separate communities, their attitude toward education will in all likelihood remain much as it is today, which means that they will not be anxious for further education for their children than will serve as a convenience and protection with regard to such dealings as they have with the white populations."

"In the younger provinces the same motives actuate the Indians who are in contact with settlement, and the interest taken in education on the reserves bears a distinct relation to the extent of their intercourse with the outside world, and consequently is increasing." Mr. Frank Pedley, Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs in 1908 stated in his report to the Minister of the Interior for that year. "Education is naturally followed by Indians as by most others rather as a..."

means to an end than as an end in itself, and is appreciated in proportion as its material advantages are apparent to them and this bears a distinct relation to the comparative crudity of their social relations and commercial enterprises."

"Until the Indians amalgamate in a manner they have not so far done with other classes of the community, it need not be expected that beyond the rare exceptions occasionally met with, they will manifest any desire for higher education. In so far, however, as concerns direct material benefit, increasing contact with civilization extends their appreciation of a certain standard of instruction."

Other causes, some of them bearing close relation to the basic cause mentioned above operate against regular attendance at day schools. The migratory habits of some bands in outlying districts do not conduce toward regular attendance. This instinct of migration is still strong among many present day Indians who are not yet far advanced from their former state, and this is only another instance where their former mode of living interferes with their adaptation to modern social conditions. Hunting, fishing, lumbering, agricultural operations especially in fruit regions entice many Indian families away from the reserves. Efforts have been made to adapt the school year in such a way that the holidays occur during the period when the families are away.

It is quite evident that people, who do not feel the need of education for themselves and for their children, will either keep their children at home, or will indulge their varying whims which in most cases means irregularity in attendance. Just as soon as a boy or girl is old enough to become useful in the work around the home, which usually takes place at the age of 13 or 14, their education by the day school is very often discontinued. Disinclination to attend on the part of the children for any cause or causes in may cases does not call forth words of encouragement or of compulsion from parents.

Other causes are poverty, lack of suitable clothing, sickness, inclement weather, bad roads, and long distances from school. The ways in which these factors prevent regular attendance are quite evident. It may be mentioned in passing that irregular attendance through inclement weather, bad roads, and long distances, is more frequent among schools situated in remote and unsettled districts.

While in the main the attitude of Indians toward schools is that of passive indifference rather than energetic reaction thereto, still there are instances where the attitude is entirely and unmistakably hostile. This hostility is based on the belief that children who have received a different education from their parents will be separated from their parents in the great hereafter. As is to be expected, hostility from this reason is confined mainly to pagans. Mr. J. A. Smart, quoted elsewhere in his report for 1869, stated in this connection, "In the first stage, before instruction or education can be commenced, a great deal has to be done in the way of eradication..."
of superstition and prejudice, and in overcoming fear not unnaturally entertained by the parents that education will not only destroy sympathy between them and their offspring in this life, but through the inoculation of religion separate them in a future state of existence." Mr. Frank Pedley in his Report for 1903 stated in the same connection: "Pagans outside the sphere of civilization are disposed to regard education as an attempt to erect a barrier between them and their children". Needless to say, hostility to education is decreasing and the irregular attendance due to this cause is now comparatively insignificant.

The question may now be asked, what measures are taken to promote regular attendance at day schools? The most important means and measures used to promote regularity of attendance are as follows:- provision of noon day meals to the pupils; conveyance to and from school when weather is unfavourable and where distances to school are great; distribution of prizes for regular attendance; distribution of clothing, appointment of truant officers. It would be extremely interesting to examine how these measures have affected the attendance at schools where they have been tried, and fortunately some statistical information, although not by any means exhaustive, is obtainable. It would not be fair to say that the greater regularity in attendance was wholly due to the provision of mid-day meals and to conveyance, as other factors, such as the influence of an energetic teacher, and enforcement of compulsory clause, may have promoted the noticeable improvement. Much of the improvement, however, must be placed to the credit of these measures.

The cost of the conveyance of pupils is provided for by the Department of Indian Affairs, as is in most cases the cost of the mid-day meals. Very often the products of the school gardens are used to supply these mid-day meals. Most of the schools providing such meals have special equipment, and accommodation such as suitable kitchens, dining rooms, for such purpose, and a matron usually has charge, thus leaving the day school teacher free to attend to his numerous duties.

The prizes given take various forms, such as money, clothing, books, medals and so forth. It is clear that prizes do not constitute a potent factor in promoting regular attendance. The Indians live in the present and not in the future. A reward in any form a year in the future has very little attraction for the majority of Indian children. The important thing with them is present satisfaction. Furthermore, it has been found that a few zealous pupils will try to attend school regularly in spite of sickness in order that they might win the reward. For a great many pupils, the prizes lose their appeal early in the school year because of repeated or continued absence from school for various reasons, and all chances of winning have been forfeited.

In 1906 regulations relating to the education of Indian children were passed, and the substance of the regulations was to make attendance at school compulsory. Some of the clauses are as follows:— "All Indian children between the ages of 6 and 15 shall attend a day school on the reserve on which they reside for the full term during which the school is open each year, unless excused for the reasons hereinafter mentioned."

No parent, guardian or other person shall be liable to any of the penalties of these Regulations in respect of any child.

(a) If the child is under efficient instruction.
(b) If the child is unable to attend school by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause.
(c) If there is no school within two miles, measured by the nearest road from such child's residence, if such child is under ten years of age, or within 3 miles, if over this age;
(d) If the child has been excused as hereinafter provided, from attending school;

(e) If the child has passed the entrance examination for high schools."

Provision is made for the relief of any child from attendance at school for any period not exceeding two weeks during each of the four school terms or quarters if "the services of such child are required in husbandry, or in urgent and necessary household duties, or for the necessary maintenance of such child, or of some Indian dependent upon such child." "Indian agents may appoint one or more persons to act as truant officers on each reserve for the enforcement of these Regulations."

The penalty for neglect or refusal to send a child to school is a fine of not more than two dollars or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ten days or both.

The enforcement of these regulations is attended with a great deal of difficulty, as many bands, especially those in remote parts of the country, have not yet reached a stage in their advancement when such laws are fully appreciated, and when the social feeling favourable to compulsion in educational matters is so predominant that the operation of such regulations is made easy, and delinquent parents are brought into line through pressure from the dominant social feeling. It is reasonable to suppose that the Department has been reluctant to enforce these Regulations rigidly in the case of bands which are not far advanced. But in the case of more advanced bands in well settled parts of the country, a firm enforcement would no doubt be attended with beneficial results. Future improvement in attendance hinges on the manner in which these compulsory regulations are enforced, and the situation, although perhaps not so serious as statistics seem to indicate, undoubtedly calls for a somewhat rigid enforcement.

The number of families who realize the importance of regular attendance is fortunately very large. Sacrifices are made and inconveniences are suffered willingly and happily by very many parents in order that their children might receive an education, and such parents are sources of inspiration for all those engaged in Indian work.

But unfortunately there are always a few delinquent parents whose children, by the great irregularity of their attendance, seriously affect the average attendance of the schools they attend. It is very probable, that the great irregularity of attendance shown by statistics appears greater than it actually is.

That these percentages do not show the situation on the Six Nations Reserve correctly is beyond doubt. A number of families usually move from one school section to another during the year. Their children attend two or three months at one school when they move away and attend another school for the remainder of the year. Their names are kept on the register of two schools. Let us now examine the courses of study which have been followed in Indian schools. At the present time the studies prescribed for Indian schools is the same as that used in the provincial schools of the province in which the Indian schools are located. Previous to the adoption of provincial curricula, "the programme of studies" which was followed was that prepared by the Department for use in Indian schools. The change to provincial curricula has been gradual and has been spread over the last five years. The change was made mainly to utilize the school inspectors of the various provinces in the supervision of Indian schools and also to obtain the required textbooks more readily.

A copy of the programme of studies which Indian schools were obliged to follow before the change was made, is shown herewith.* Detailed comparison between this course of study and the courses of study of the various provinces would be interesting, but only general comparisons will be noted here. That there are differences both in the subjects and in the contents of the subjects is quite evident. Subjects present in some provincial curricula are not included in the list of subjects in the programme of studies for Indian schools, and

Some subjects which appear in the curriculum for Indian schools do not appear in provincial curricula, although the same results may be obtained in an indirect way. For instance, under the subject of general knowledge, the Indian pupils obtain certain information which white pupils obtain in another subject or in other subjects. However, it is in the contents of the subjects that the most significant differences occur. This programme of studies prescribed for Indian schools is not a composite of the provincial courses of study. Whether or not Indian children in the schools would have done as far as their public school education was concerned is a matter of opinion. An examination of the course of study shows that a pupil in an Indian day school has not advanced as far in certain subjects, such as arithmetic for instance, at the completion of his public school education, as the white pupil who has followed, let us say, the Ontario course of study. It appears that the course of study was made simple and constructed differently to accommodate Indian pupils. The advantages that were gained from a simplified programme of studies were probably not so great as to disfavour the adoption of provincial courses of study. Needful subjects such as ethics and religious instruction, if considered necessary, might have been added. While the efficacy of a course of study must be judged by its developmental and content factors, and not so much by the closeness of its connection and co-ordination to the courses of study in higher institutions, yet it is clear that an advantage would have accrued to clever Indian pupils had provincial courses of study been adopted from the first, in that these pupils would have found entrance to high schools and collegiate institutes less difficult. Other things being equal, this consideration alone is sufficient argument for the adoption of provincial courses of study. The Department of Indian Affairs by making the change has recognized the extrinsic, if not the intrinsic, superiority of provincial courses of study.

Normal school graduates, trained with a view to teaching in provincial schools, or having had experience in such schools, will now find adaptation to similar conditions in Indian schools comparatively easy.

Sewing, knitting, fancy work, cooking, house work, and manual training are taught in many schools. School gardens are cultivated also in many schools. Special efforts have been made by the Department to promote school gardens in schools and their efforts are attended with a great measure of success. These arts seem to have quite an appeal to the Indian pupils, as they are closely related to their predominant interests. It is to be expected that a people whose ideas of the purpose of education are largely utilitarian, whose life is lived largely in the realm of the physical and who are concrete minded, should find sewing, knitting, fancy work, cooking, housework, manual training, and school gardening very interesting. Indeed the logical approach to abstract ideas contained in a course of study is best made through concrete materials, especially so in the case of Indian children. In the first stage at least, the nature and characteristics of Indian pupils seems to demand a close correlation between everyday activities and common objects,
and the subjects of the course of study. Indian languages or dialects are characterized by the abundance of the words denoting physical activities and objects, and by the scarcity of words denoting abstract ideas. The average attendance at schools where at least three of these arts are taught is usually greater than the average. Fifteen day schools in the provinces of New Brunswick, Quebec, Ontario, Manitoba and Saskatchewan, taught at least three of these arts during the year 1916, as far as can be ascertained from the Report of Indian Affairs for that year. The average attendance at these schools for that year was 56.2% of the total enrolment. The average attendance at all Indian day schools for the same year was 49.7% of the total enrolment. The difference was 7.5%. At least one of the causes of this difference must have been the attraction of these arts for Indian pupils.

In order to obtain some idea of the status of the teachers who teach in Indian day schools in Ontario a questionnaire was sent to each Public School Inspector who inspects these schools. Information was collected regarding 36 teachers. It was thought that the qualifications of teachers in Ontario Indian day schools would give a fair idea of the qualifications of teachers in Indian schools throughout Canada; Ontario is one of the most populated, and well settled provinces in Canada. At least, it is reasonable to expect that the average for Ontario, would not be below the average for the other provinces. Of the 36 teachers regarding whose qualifications information was received, 16 possessed professional qualifications. Of these 16 properly qualified teachers, 9 possessed Second Class professional qualifications, and the remaining 7 possessed Third Class professional certificates. The majority of the 20 teachers who possessed no professional qualifications had, however, certain academic qualifications. One had only a public school education, two possessed a commercial diploma, two possessed Entrance to Normal certificates, one Junior Matriculation and the remainder had High School education, the number of years spent in High School work averaging from one year to five years. The average age of the qualified teachers was 44 and the average of the non-qualified was 32. Of the 36 teachers, 14 were males. The following statement taken from the Department's Report for 1921 sums up the situation in a general way:

"Certified teachers with professional training are engaged wherever it is possible to obtain them. In the older settled portions of the different provinces, the greater number of teachers are so qualified. In the schools situated in the more remote reserves, it is difficult to secure teachers with certificates. Many of our teachers who have not professional qualifications have, however, long experience and are meeting with a great measure of success in Indian school work." The aim of course, is to have qualified teachers with professional training in 100% of the schools, and while it is unreasonable to look for such perfection for some time to come, yet it would be quite fair to hope for a certain approximation to the condition in rural schools among white communities in Ontario.
Taking the figures given above as the basis it is found that only 44.4% of the 36 teachers have proper qualifications. In Ontario among white communities in 1919-1920, of 6149 teachers teaching in rural schools 5625 teachers, or 91.4%, had certificates qualifying them to teach in Ontario schools. The difference between 91.4% and 44.4% is too large even at this stage. The situation undoubtedly demands careful attention.

The question must now be asked; What are the reasons for the difficulty of procuring qualified teachers, and of keeping such teachers as are obtained, in Indian day schools? Ten Public school Inspectors answered these above questions placed on the questionnaire which was sent to them in the autumn of 1921. Eight of the ten inspectors gave low salaries as the reason. Five mentioned physical and social isolation. Other causes
mentioned are the irregular attendance of pupils, the unattractive nature of the work, the difficulty of securing suitable boarding places, and the unsympathetic attitude of parents toward education.

Unfortunately, information concerning the salaries paid to Indian day school teachers is lacking. The salaries paid to teachers depend on the qualifications they possess, and according to latest information, the salary scale ranges from $500.00 to $800.00 per annum, plus a bonus of $150.00 during the last four fiscal years. In Ontario the average salary in public elementary schools is $1348.00 per annum for men teachers, and $117.00 for women teachers. Salaries are however increasing and in some Indian schools, the salaries paid exceed those paid in neighbouring white communities.

They would be compelled, for the sake of convenience, to live among a people who speak a different language, and who have different customs and ideals. This unattractive prospect of social and physical isolation will probably operate against the employment of properly qualified white teachers for some time to come unless the salaries offered are sufficient to overcome this disadvantage. However, the difficulty of securing qualified white teachers due to this cause does not appear to be altogether hopeless. Settlement of the country is continually progressing and the extension of railways, both steam and electric, and building of good roads are continually overcoming physical isolation. As far as social isolation is concerned, that will gradually become less and less as Indian bands assimilate more and more the languages, customs, and ideals of the white people. No doubt the provision of teacher's residences have tended to mitigate social isolation, and to prolong the tenure of office of the teachers. The difficulty of securing suitable boarding houses is also thereby removed. Extension of this residence idea to more schools has not yet been attempted but therein lies the hope not only of Indian day schools, but of the rural schools of Canada in general. Difficulties would no doubt be encountered of the same kind as are encountered among white communities and, in addition, there would be the difficulties of adjustment inevitable in denominational control of schools. There are, however, a number of reserves where schools might be consolidated without the necessity of adjustment between the religious denominations. The Six Nations reserve may be mentioned as one reserve where consolidation of schools would be attended with beneficial results. The point here, however, is that gradual consolidation of schools would, in addition to many other advantages, provide social intercourse between teachers and would remove much of the unattractiveness of the work to some teachers.

Discouragement often assails a teacher because of the irregularity of attendance and because of the unsympathetic attitude of some parents. Diligent and painstaking work shows comparatively poor results in the face of irregularity of attendance. All that can be said about the unsympathetic and
unappreciative attitude toward teachers' work not only in some Indian schools but in other schools as well is that such a thing is disappearing. One of the important qualifications that a teacher carries into the teaching profession is that of vicariousness.

It is quite clear that there is a great disproportion in the distribution of the pupils in day schools, especially so in standard I and standard II, and it is also clear that the improvement in distribution during the 21 year period is very slight. It simply means that a large number of pupils in Indian day schools go out into the world equipped with no more than the education provided in the course of study in the first two standards. A large number never get out of standard I.

There must be reasons for such a disproportionate distribution and it is to a consideration of these reasons that we now turn.

One reason which is self-evident is that of the irregularity of attendance through which pupils are not able to do the work of a standard in one year. Irregularity of attendance seems to occur most markedly in standard I. When pupils fail to make the next grade on account of their spasmodic attendance, they probably lose interest, especially so when the subject matter of instruction is really intended for pupils younger than themselves. While statistics relating to age-grade or age-standard distribution are not obtainable, and therefore comparisons cannot be made with age grade distribution in white schools, yet it is certain that there are differences. That is, the average age of Indian pupils in the different standards is certainly higher than the average age of white pupils in corresponding grades.

One other reason which causes this disproportionate distribution, and which in some bands is even more important than irregular attendance is that of the difference in language. The language of instruction is in the majority of schools, either English or French, which differs altogether from the native languages of the children. Consequently, instruction in the subject matter of the course of study is really impossible until the child has become able to express and understand ideas through the medium of English words and sentences. This disadvantage is most felt at the entrance of the pupils into a school, especially so when their parents use the native language exclusively. The influence of the child's environment on his progress in school is quite evident here. An Indian child who is in an English language environment from its birth learns to speak the English language, and not a trace of Indian accent can be noted in its pronunciation of English words.

These two reasons, irregularity of attendance, and differences in the native language of the pupils and the language of instruction, appear to be the two most important reasons regulating the distribution of pupils in the standards. And it is significant that both these reasons are closely related to the extent of the Indians' intercourse with white people. As has already been stated, the Indians' appreciation for an adequate education depends upon the benefits they derive therefrom in their commercial and trade dealings with white people.
The obvious remedy is the increase in the frequency of contact between the Indian people and the population of the assimilating group along all social lines. Such increase in the frequency of contact will not only improve irregular attendance, and make the English language more commonly spoken in Indian schools, but will generally accelerate the whole process of assimilation. In fact, the hope for an adequate solution of the Indian problem appears to be in that direction. However, this matter will be treated more fully later on.

Other causes of the disproportionate distribution will now be enumerated:

1. The number of pupils who are late in beginning school.
2. The number of small children who commence before six and discontinue during the winter.
3. Inefficiency (including inexperience) on the part of the teacher.
4. Early school leaving age.
5. Frequent change of teachers.

The Boarding and Industrial schools remain to be considered and they will be considered together as much as possible. As early as 1890 the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs stated in his Report, "The Indian youth, to enable him to cope successfully with his brother of white origin, must be dissociated free from the prejudicial influences by which he is surrounded on the reserve of his band. And the necessity for the establishment more generally of institutions, wherein Indian children, besides being instructed in the usual branches of education, will be lodged, fed, clothed, kept separate from home influences, taught trades and instructed in Agriculture, is becoming every year more apparent". Again in the Report of 1890 the following statement is found, "It would be highly desirable, if it were practicable, to obtain entire possession of all Indian children after they attain the age of seven or eight years and keep them at schools of the industrial type until they have had a thorough course of instruction, not only in the ordinary subjects taught at public schools but in some useful and profitable trade, or in agriculture, as the aptitude of the pupil might indicate he was best fitted for."

These quotations from the Reports of the Department of Indian Affairs indicate the considerations which led to the establishment of industrial schools. These industrial schools were, however, located at widely separated places and Indian pupils who were enrolled at these institutions, were separated from their parents for months at a time, if these pupils came from remote reserves. Naturally there was a certain reluctance on the part of the parents to allow their children to go to these institutions involving separation for months or even years. To overcome this difficulty, boarding schools
were established near many reserves where parents may see their children as often as convenient. At first, boarding schools did not attempt to teach any industrial arts in the way that they were taught in industrial schools. The relation between industrial and boarding schools is indicated in the following statement taken from the 1900 Report. "There is, however, no doubt that in so far as obtaining pupils is concerned, the industrial schools are suffering somewhat at the hands of the boarding schools, which, instead of fulfilling the intended purpose of acting as feeders for the former, are to some extent supplanting them. Naturally, parents prefer to keep their children in the schools nearest their homes, and equally natural is it for the teachers of boarding schools to desire to retain their pupils instead of drafting them to higher institutions."

Provision is made in the "Regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children" for the placing of children in an industrial or boarding school if it is shown that the parents are negligent in the matter of education. The clause states "An Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace on requisition from the Department of Indian Affairs or from one of its authorized officers on being satisfied that any Indian child between six and fifteen years of age is not being properly cared for or educated, and that the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child is unfit or unwilling to provide for the child's education, may issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child and place it in an industrial or boarding school in which there may be a vacancy for such child, and a child so placed in an industrial or boarding school may be retained until the age of eighteen years is reached; but no child shall be committed to any industrial or boarding school before the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child is notified orally or in writing, by a Justice of the Peace, Indian Agent or Truant Officer of the intention to commit the child, and four days shall be allowed to lapse between the giving of such notice and the committal of the child." The parent, guardian or other person has the opportunity of showing that provision is being made or will be made for the child's care and education and under those circumstances the child remains in the custody of the parent, guardian or other person.

The relation between the Department and the churches as to finances and system is best shown by the following quotation from Mr. Abbott's Report already mentioned. "The churches receive from $80.00 up to $125.00 per pupil and they keep pupils..."
the year round, educate, clothe, and subsist them. If this grant from the government proves insufficient, the church organization makes up the deficit. Where only $80.00 is paid by the government, the government furnishes the building, and keeps up all repairs. When from $100.00 to $125.00 is paid, the church furnishes the buildings but the government keeps up repairs. The church selects the teachers in all the industrial and boarding schools operated by it and in most cases nominates the day school teachers. The Indian Agent makes a monthly inspection of the schools and reports the conditions to the Ottawa office. In two of the eastern provinces there is an additional inspection by the school inspector of the provinces, who also reports to the Indian Department. The contract between the churches and the Government provide that the teachers furnished by the church shall measure up to the standards required by the government; that the rations furnished shall be sufficient and come up to certain definite specifications; that the course of study followed shall be in close conformity to the course of study in the province where the school is situated; and that the church shall have the pupil for a period of eleven years.

The remedy of the government, should the church fail to live up to any of the requirements is found in a revocation of the contract."

A brief account of the equipment and operation of the industrial and boarding schools will be given. There are of course, certain variations chiefly in the adequacy of the equipment. The method and the subject matter of instruction vary little in the different schools. Variations occur principally in the range and completeness of the instruction in the industrial arts. The half-day plan of academic instruction alternating with a half day of industrial training is the general rule. The number of pupils enrolled in these schools varies. Some have over 100 pupils and some have less than 100. In the larger schools, teachers, and instructors are engaged, and the principal or superintendent supervises and controls the operation of the institution. Some of these institutions work 1,000 acres. The boys do the work of sowing, planting and harvesting. Very often an institution is able to pay expenses of operation and maintenance from the per capita grant from the Government and from the proceeds of the produce of the soil, and still have a surplus left over. Extensive barns for the storage of crops, and for the raising and care of live stock, principally cattle and horses, usually form part of industrial schools.

Information concerning the qualifications, salaries, and tenure of office, of teachers in boarding and industrial schools, is not available, and therefore comparisons cannot be made. This much is certain, however, that conditions as to social intercourse and board and room, are generally more favourable in the residential schools than among day schools. It is therefore reasonable to expect that teachers who have inclinations toward work among Indians would probably be attracted more toward residential schools where social isolation, and in most cases, physical isolation, are reduced to a minimum.

The question may now be asked: What measure of success attends ex-pupils of Indian schools? Have the schools fulfilled the hope that was placed in them? There have evidently been doubts in the minds of Government officials as to the effectiveness of the system of schools among Indians. The Deputy-Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs reported in 1904, "The questions have been raised repeatedly as to whether the existing method of education by day, boarding, and industrial schools as at present distributed and conducted is the best that can be devised for the education of the Indian youth, and again as to whether the potentialities of these schools are being exhausted." Again in 1906 he reports, "The justification for the maintenance of industrial as compared with boarding schools depends mainly under existing circumstances upon an experimental solution of the question whether graduates who return to their reserves will retrograde under or elevate the conditions of their environment." In the Report for 1909 he stated "The future of graduates from boarding and industrial schools also appear to demand close attention."

"An effort will be made to secure conditions which will make the most important event in a pupil's life, viz., graduation, a guarantee of fitness to assume its duties and responsibilities, and assistance financial and other will be provided to start the graduates at suitable occupations and in a fitting environment."

As has been already mentioned, the two principal ad-
Diagram 9 - Showing proportion of pupils enrolled in the different kinds of schools for the years 1901, 1905, 1910, 1915, and 1921.
vantages of boarding and industrial schools over day schools are the removal of pupils from retrogressive influences in the home and on the reserve, and the regularity of attendance made possible by the residence of pupils in these schools. So strong, however, are family ties, that graduates of these schools very often drift back to the reserves. There is no doubt that these graduates exert an elevating influence on the reserves not only on the contemporary generation, but the effect of the training received in these schools is also shown in the children of these graduates. But so powerful is the influence of environment, that very often graduates slip back to the ways and customs of their people living on these reserves. Methods of preventing this reversion to aboriginal ways have been considered, and probably the most interesting and significant is that of the establishment of a colony for ex-pupils at File Hills in the province of Saskatchewan. While this ex-pupil colony is still in the experimental stage, yet enough has been shown by results to warrant the expectation that the experiment is destined to be a successful one as far as the social adjustment of the Indian ex-pupil is concerned.

In 1901, 18,000 acres subdivided in 50-acre lots were set aside at File Hills in the province of Saskatchewan for the purpose of establishing a colony of the ex-pupils of File Hills Boarding School, and Qu'Appelle Industrial School. This colony, separate from any Indian reserve, is therefore free from any retrogressive influences that may be exerted by the parents of ex-pupils, or by the people of the reserves in general. In 1907 there were 20 families resident on this colony, and a total of 55 counting men, women, and children. A special report dealing with the File Hills ex-pupil colony was prepared in 1907 by Mr. W. M. Graham, Inspector of Indian Agencies. He reported in part as follows: "I am happy to say that not only has the colony proved a success, but it has demonstrated, beyond doubt, that if the same methods were adopted in other parts of these territories, in twenty-five years the Indian population could be converted into thrifty and industrious people."

"Although the colony has been in existence only six years, the results obtained have been phenomenal, to my mind. I shall instance cases of young men leaving school seven years ago, at the age of eighteen, who are today settled in comfortable homes, married and have children, who are brought up as white children are, not even knowing the Indian tongue."

The special report then goes on to give the cases of the successes of ex-pupils. One case will suffice here. "I shall next deal with the case of Mark Ward. This young man, after leaving the Qu'Appelle school, engaged with me as teamster and interpreter, and always drove me on my frequent trips to the colony. Seeing what was being accomplished, he became inspired with the desire to become a farmer here, and to my surprise asked me to be relieved of his position, which was worth $500.00 a year to him, so that he might go down and
make a home for himself. I persuaded the lad to remain in his position, for at least another year, and in the meantime to hire a man to drive his team, which he had bought with his earnings, and break land on the farm I allotted to him. In 1905 he went to the colony to reside."

"I visited this man's place the other day. He has a fine frame dwelling, two storeys high, containing five rooms and having a verandah round the front and side. It is plastered throughout and the kitchen is wainscotted (the house is worth $1500 at least). He has a large stable and four good horses, a complete outfit of farm machinery, consisting of a wagon, binder, seeder, walking and gang ploughs, sleighs, etc., besides the supply of tools usually found on a farm. He has an avenue of trees from the main road to his house. His barnyard presented quite a farm-like scene, there being in it pigs, poultry, calves and colts."

"Last year this man thrashed 2700 bushels of grain. This year his area for crop has been considerably increased over that of last year, as he had two outfits breaking new land all last summer. He will have over 150 acres in crop this summer."

"This man was brought to the Qu'Appelle industrial school from Poorman's reserve [Lougheed agency], and I am satisfied that, had he been sent back to that reserve at the time he left school, he would have fallen back to long hair and painted face and Indian customs as other Indian graduates have done who returned to that reserve about that time."

"Ward is now twenty-six years of age and is married to Margaret Duwent, who was for a number of years a servant in my house, and they have now a family of three small children, who are kept scrupulously clean and who cannot talk a word of Indian, which shows that that language is not spoken among these graduates in their homes."

This special report stated that there had been no infringements of the Indian Act in this colony, that these ex-pupils were strong supporters of the churches they now attend. It appears also that the remarkable progress made by these ex-pupils is not the result of spasmodic outbursts of initiative and industry, but that the progress is continuous and sustained.

These statements are found in various annual Reports on the colony since 1910. "One of the most pleasing features of this colony is that it is practically out of debt. The whole guaranteed indebtedness to merchants at the time of writing this Report does not amount to $275.00." The population of the colony then was 134. "Fully two-thirds of the doctor's visits to this colony are paid for by the Indians themselves." "The parents evince a keen desire to have their children educated, and there is no need to canvass for them, as they are sent to school when of age without question."

Results already appear to indicate that one of the most powerful factors in retardation or in progress as far as full citizenization is concerned is the social, physical, moral, intellectual, and spiritual environment. This experiment seems to show conclusively that environment and not heredity is the important controlling factor in the development of the Indians' native capacities in the direction of full citizenship. In a somewhat stagnant environment progress is slow, but in an environment where a spirit of industry and ambition prevail progress is rapid. It is fortunate that such is the case, as environment is subject to organized control, while hereditary transmission of characteristics is difficult to direct.

Before leaving the subject of the care of ex-pupils of boarding and industrial schools, it may be stated that at graduation pupils are sometimes given some material and practical help to start them on a career of usefulness and independence.

For the fiscal year 1921, $2,933.64 were spent in financial help for ex-pupils. The ex-pupils usually succeed to wipe out the debt in two or three years.

The industrial arts taught at industrial schools include carpentry, shoe-making, black-smithing, baking, and painting. The girls are usually taught sewing, general housework, in fact the branches of domestic science and economy which would be most useful to them. In some schools music is taught. The basic industry which is taught, however, is agriculture. The pupils are instructed in the care of live-stock, and in the growing and cropping of grains, fruits, and vegetables.

The Department has engaged instructors for the purpose of providing instruction and advice to Indian farmers on different reserves. Nurses are also engaged who travel from place to place rendering help and advice where opportunity offers. The Department has also from time to time issued circulars and pamphlets, written in a simple language, dealing with
such questions as the prevention of tuberculosis and the care of children.

Some information is available as to the improvement in housing conditions. It is evident that even in the matter of shelter the Indians have had to adapt themselves to changing conditions. A roving people and a fixed abode are entirely contrary. Superstition has also prevented more rapid adjustment in the matter of shelter as can be gathered from the following words in the Report for 1899: "In this as in almost all directions something has been undone before anything can be accomplished, for so long as the superstition which keeps an Indian from inhabiting a house in which a death has occurred prevails, he is not likely to go to much expense or trouble to erect what he feels he may have at any time to pull down or abandon." Where conditions are most adverse, the Indians are evincing an increasing readiness to den themselves in other directions in order to purchase lumber and shingles, and there are few if any reserves where in the course of a year one or two houses are not erected, and they are almost without exception, an improvement on those which they replace."

During the same year (1899) a special inspection was made of the dwellings of the Indians on the Blood Reserve in what was at that time the North West Territories. In all 160 houses were inspected, over 100 of these houses had turf roofs, 44 had only the natural clay floors. In the Report of 1900, these statements are found. "Varied as are the circumstances and surroundings of the Indians scattered over the Dominion, their dwellings range from the primitive one-roomed cabin built of logs, unheated, and roofed with mud to a class of residence, while inferior to some, are yet superior to many occupied by many white residents in the country."

The best houses are to be found among the farming com-
munities of Ontario, and in the villages in Quebec and British Columbia, a large proportion being excellent frame structures of modern pattern."

The influence of environment in the matter of dwelling houses as in other matters is again evident here. The Deputy Superintendent General reported as follows in 1922. "The steady advancement of such of the Indians as live in contact with the whites and have adopted industrial methods, is clearly evidenced by improvement in their houses and other buildings."

"In the older provinces, where the Indians have through the long course of years become largely imbued with the sentiments, manners, and customs of surrounding communities, their houses, generally speaking, are, in proportion to their means, as good as those of their neighbours and meet the requirements of their circumstances."

Here again in the matter of health environment had a powerful influence. Diseases disappear from among bands in proportion as these bands acquire the hygienic habits of the white people. Disease is evidently intimately related to the problem of housing. It is to be expected that, generally speaking, the healthier bands would be those which are contiguous to progressive districts. Dr. Bryce in his Report for 1912 stated, "It would appear as before remarked that we have within the work of the Indian Department itself a practical example of how its most difficult problem is to be solved. In this it has been shown that agricultural progress has gone hand in hand with social advancement and both along with a steadily increasing and high degree of health."

There are unmistakable evidences that Indian languages or dialects are disappearing, and the English, and the French languages being substituted therefor. Here again the influence of environment is beyond doubt the important factor in this substitution. It is not rare to find Indian children in bands of well settled parts of the country unable to speak or even understand a word of the native language of their parents. Even in homes where the parents converse in their native language, the children are gradually forgetting the Indian language. To ascertain the extent to which the school children of the Six Nations are discarding their native language, a questionnaire was sent to each teacher on the Six Nations reserve in 1919. Returns were received regarding 330 school children. Of the 330 school children 132 or 40% could not speak their native language fluently and many of these could not even understand a statement in the Indian language. 317 of these 330 school children, or 96% could speak English fluently. Only 13 could not speak English fluently. It is significant that in one of the largest bands in Canada where the number of people would tend to preserve the native language, such a large percentage of the rising generation are no longer able to use the language of their fathers and forefathers, freely. In smaller bands where the frequency of contact with white people would be greater this process of substitution would be more rapid.

There are several reasons for this situation and only the more important reasons will be indicated here. In the first place the language of instruction in schools is the English or the French. In the great majority of cases the teachers cannot speak or understand a word of the Indian language. Even if the teacher is able to speak Indian, it is used only to elucidate the meaning of English words or sentences. In the second place a knowledge of English is absolutely necessary in commercial and trade dealings with white people. In the third place the English language is superior to the Indian language for the expression of ideas. Furthermore, the Indian language has not kept pace with the progress of knowledge. Consequently, the range of the Indian vocabulary does not at all compare with the range of the English vocabulary. For instance, there are no Indian words for telephone, automobile, aeroplane, electricity. Practically, the only books written in Indian languages are the translations of portions of the Bible. As far as can be ascertained, there is not an Indian grammar in existence. From a consideration of the reasons for their substitution, it would seem safe to predict that the Indian languages would eventually disappear.

The expenditures for relief, medical attendance, and medical supplies, and supplies for destitutes from parliamentary appropriations have increased since 1903 although not steadily. Expenditures increased steadily from 1903 to 1907 and since 1907 the increase has been gradual. Diagram 1 shows the steady rise in such expenditures for all Canada, for Manitoba, Saskatchewan, and for New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, Quebec, Ontario and Nova Scotia. There is a drop in the curve for 1907 as the expenditure for that fiscal year was for 9 months only. There is also a downward trend for 1917, and 1918, when the Government of Canada decided to cut down expenses on account of the heavy war expenses. Just when the curve will turn downward is hard to say, but there are indications that that time is not far distant. It may be stated that one important cause of the upward trend is the increasing number of Indians who are being brought under well organized control. From a consideration of these amounts expended on Indians, and from other considerations also, one is tempted to venture a suspicion that the Government of Canada has perhaps erred on the side of liberality and indulgence in the treatment of the Indians of Canada. Now is the suspicion confined to people living outside of reserves, but it shared also by observant and educated Indians living on reserves. Treaty moneys distributed annually to Indians sometimes prove a curse. Full development of native capacities under such circumstances...
is bound to be retarded and sometimes even prevented.

Probably one of the most difficult problems in connection with Indian Affairs is the task of persuading the Indians to take on the full responsibilities of citizenship. There is no doubt at all that there are individual Indians and even bands especially in the older provinces, who are ready to assume such responsibilities. Yet it has been found that instead of desiring the privileges of full citizenship, Indians as a rule prefer to remain as they are. It is probable that the years of Government protection which have had some influence in inculcating this attitude toward citizenship. It is extremely unfortunate that the appeal of this privilege to Indians is so weak.

Prior to 1920 the clauses in the Indian Act which related to enfranchisement required a tutelage of six years before an Indian could be enfranchised. These clauses have been on the statutes since 1857 and only 102 persons have been enfranchised under these clauses during the period of 63 years.

In 1918 Parliament passed an amendment to the Indian Act with regard to enfranchisement enabling the Governor General-in-Council to enfranchise, on application, all Indians who have no land on reserves and who are willing to adopt their share of the funds of the band and to give up any title to the lands on the reserve. Under this clause 441 Indians of the Six Nations had been enfranchised up to March 25, 1923. While the clause applies to the Indians in any part of Canada the number of Indians in other parts of Canada who have been enfranchised under this section is only a fraction of the 441 Six Nation Indians enfranchised. Up to 1920 the total number of Indians enfranchised since Confederation was 360.

At the session of 1920 Parliament passed new sections relating to enfranchisement, giving the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs power to make inquiry and report from time to time as to the fitness of any Indian or Indians for enfranchisement. The Governor General-in-Council acting on these reports was given authority by these sections, to enfranchise an Indian and his wife and minor unmarried children forthwith. These clauses have never yet been put into operation. It may be mentioned that at the time of reading of the bill strenuous objections were made thereto by Indians, claiming that it was compulsory and that it meant the dissolution of reserves.

While it would be exceedingly interesting to examine more minutely and comprehensively the influence of environment upon the Indians' progress or upon his retardation in the process of racial and social assimilation, still sufficient has been shown to warrant the statement that such process bears a distinct relation to the frequency of contact with the assimilating group. Adoption of agriculture is most rapid among bands in well settled parts of Canada. Appreciation of the value of education is greater among bands where commercial and trade dealings with the white people are most frequent, and the substitution of the English language for the Indian
language is affected more speedily also in such bands. Ex-pupils of boarding and industrial schools revert back to aboriginal customs if they return to reserves, but retain their advantage if placed in a suitable environment. Housing conditions, birth rate, and death rate, degree of self independence all are closely related to proximity of, and intercourse with, a more highly developed community. There is no doubt at all that the physical isolation resulting from segregation on reserves, and social isolation resulting from differences in customs and languages have in the past operated to retard normal social change. There is danger that under such conditions Indian societies may become static and stagnation prevail. Yet in spite of these disadvantages, the progress of the Indians toward usefulness and efficiency appears to have been rapid.

Finally we must give a brief account of the part played by the Indians of Canada in the Great War. Over 4,000 Indians, or approximately 35% of the Indian male population of military age in the nine provinces enlisted for active service in the Canadian Expeditionary Forces. On some reserves only the old men and women and children were left to care for the work of the homes. The total contribution of the Indians of Canada to patriotic and other war funds amounted to $44,546.46. Red Cross societies and Patriotic leagues were formed on many reserves by Indian women. Innumerable various comforts for the soldiers, knitted socks, sweaters and mufflers, were made. The services of the Indians were absolutely voluntary, as they were exempted especially from the operation of the Military Service Act. Like their comrades, they also did acts of heroism, daring, and self-sacrifice. Quite a number did not return, as they found their resting places among their comrades from Canada, or from Britain.

Those who have returned to the reserves are exerting a beneficial influence on the life of the reserve. Returned Indian soldiers brought back with them, a measure of the discipline of army life, an appreciation of the necessity of organization, a broad-mindedness, and a culture resulting from travel in European countries, towns and villages. In France they were Indian Canadians and their badge was the Maple Leaf. The range of their thinking is no longer confined to the boundaries of their reserves or even to the boundaries of Canada, but their minds turn quite often to Britain, France, Belgium, and Germany and especially to the grave-yards where rest those of their number who made the sacrifice. There is now a link connecting them to these countries of Europe. Indian fathers, mothers, brothers, sisters, and relatives feel this same bond. An education of incalculable value has been derived from the Great War.

The Indian Department soon after the war took the responsibility of administering the Soldier Settlement Act among returned Indian soldiers on the reserves. The Report for 1921 states, "Since this work was undertaken by the Department, 330 applications for loans have been received and 184 granted. The total amount expended to date amounts to $321,269.51."
"The Indians have met their payments in a very satisfactory manner and the Department looks forward to much larger repayments next year. So far a large number have not yet fallen due, but the total repayment to date of $18,496 is very creditable. In fact very few Indians have failed to meet their payments, while a considerable number on all reserves, have repaid more than called upon to do."

The destiny of the Indians of Canada appears to be fairly well defined. Their identity as full blooded Indians is being lost. Among the Six Nations Indians not one can be found who has preserved his or her native blood from intermixture with white blood and this intermixture of white blood is going on throughout Canada. Consequently the copper colour is disappearing and brown and black eyes, and black hair, are giving place to blue eyes and fair hair. Beads, feathers and buckskin have practically been wholly discarded. Hunting and trapping as means of livelihood are now confined mainly to bands living on the outskirts of settlement, and agriculture, the trades, and the professions are claiming increasing numbers of the Indians. Paganism has been displaced from supremacy in spiritual matters by Christianity. Sometimes a language is forgotten in one generation, and each succeeding generation continues to substitute the English or the French language for the native languages. Social customs are conforming more and more to the social customs of the white race. It seems to be only a question of time when the Indians will have completely disappeared from Canada by racial, and social assimilation, and museums will provide the only material evidences of the existence of a former race. We must leave to future historians the writing of the account of the contribution of the Indians of Canada to Canadian life. However, long after the Indians of Canada will have disappeared, the Indian names which have been woven into the geography of Canada will remain, and it may be well to preserve the English equivalents of these place names while there is opportunity.

Dear Mr. Jamieson:

If you are going to prepare a more exhaustive treatment, I believe you would be well advised to spend some time visiting Indian schools, both day and residential, in the various parts of our Dominion. The problem divides itself, geographically, as follows: Maritime Provinces, Quebec, Ontario, Prairie Provinces, Northern Schools (Ontario, Prairie Provinces, North West Territories & Yukon) and British Columbia. I have found in my travels that there is a distinct child psychology and a different attitude towards constituted authority.

Your thesis, as far as an understanding of the Indian problem is concerned, has really an Eastern flavour and is sometimes not fair, particularly to the prairie Province Indian. On the other hand, the Maritime Indian presents a more sordid picture than you have painted, so I feel that if you are to prepare a further writing, you would be well advised to get into more personal touch with either the work itself or with Indian gentlemen from the various parts of the Dominion, who can give you an insight into the local native philosophy.

My letter -

I am convinced you should have put more time on the establishing of a definite continuity. A thesis of this length should, I believe, not only carry with it a table of contents but the pages should be numbered and each main division of the writing should be clearly connected with the whole. I believe it is not sufficient in a lengthy article to take for granted that coherence will look after itself. Each portion bears a relationship to the whole - why not establish it? It might have been well to have divided your work into chapters, in view of its length.

I make this criticism in a kindly way, and I wish to assure you that it is my sole aim to be of service to you. May the Department keep this copy that we now have? If so, both Mr. Scott and myself would be extremely grateful. In a later communication, I will be pleased to discuss with you three or four points in your thesis at which we are at variance. These are details but may form subject matter for profitable discussion.

May I wish you the Compliments of the approaching season.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

If it is practically possible a determination of the intelligence of the Indians by means of some non-language test in the case of Indians who cannot speak or read the English language fully, and by some other intelligence test in the case of those who speak and read English will be attempted in the future investigations. A study of this kind, so far as my knowledge serves me, carried out in either Canada or the United States, general ideas as to the nature and weakness of the Indians are not sufficient. However, we are unable to determine whether or not registers are being properly kept from day to day. Registers should be entered regularly; if the column mentioned above is to give correct information; but it is only when an officer visits the school that we have any assurance that a daily tally is placed on the registers provided for the purpose.

I agree with you that the quarterly returns will not give accurate information unless registers are kept. It is possible, however, that some principals of residential schools, where there is a regular routine of manual work and classroom instruction, fill in the column in our quarterly return with the number of school days for the quarter. Principals realize that the contiguous column, showing the number of days the pupil was in residence, is the important one on the return, inasmuch as per capita earnings are computed from the facts contained therein. The column showing classroom attendance should also receive meticulous care in the preparation thereof, and it may be necessary to direct communications to the principals of our residential schools if we find that the information is being supplied in a careless fashion and apparently without reference to classroom registers.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. FORKE: Mr. Chairman, in referring to the Indians of Manitoba I do not suppose I am likely to say anything that the hon. minister does not already know, but I think it well to make a statement as to their condition. I live near a reserve, and some twenty miles distant, near Brandon, we have a small large reserve. The condition of the Indians on those reserves is deplorable; there is no denying that fact. While I was at home at Easter I received a deputation of eight or ten Indians who came in a very ill and indigent manner, the story of the conditions that exist upon the reserves. We hear a great deal about the hard times among the farmers in Ontario, Canada, men who have not been acquainted with the sort of work, who come down from generations of farmers, yet are hardly able to make a living. I found Indians on the reserve without stock, without implements, without anything with which they could make a living; yet they have been existing. It seems to me that we are slowly starving these people to death. It is a very hard thing to talk about the Indians and his characteristics, their lack of ability to take care of himself under modern conditions, but that is perhaps a rather hard-hearted way of looking at things. I have been into the north and taken the places of these Indians, people who have been used to a nomadic life, who from generation to generation have lived the life of the hunter, knowing nothing of modern conditions. They are put in a reserve and told to make their living.

I remember a statement made to me by the late Glen Campbell, at one time a member of this House. He was commissioner of Indian police with jurisdiction over the Indians from the Great Lakes to the foot of the Rockies. I once had the pleasure of going with him over the Sarcee Indian reserve at Calgary, a splendid reserve, with good grazing, being capable of taking care of a great many cattle and stock of all kinds. I remember while admiring the reserve and the desirable place the Indians had there, that he mentioned the Indians to me were not for the red tape at Ottawa he could make all these Indians rich. I wonder if there was any truth in that statement? I do not know, but that is what he said. Possibly the Indians are ruled a little too much by red tape, without the application of any great knowledge of the conditions that prevail on the reserves. I am satisfied that it is no use to supply the Indians with anything except stock and seed and implements and then expect them to take care of their stock and make a good living for themselves. As long as these reserves are managed and operated from an office the business is run which is characterized by nothing more than red tape and accurate book-
keeping, we are going to have a continuance of the present conditions.

Remember, I am not finding fault with any of the officials, nor am I directing any special criticism against the reserve itself; but it is not the proper system. The agent on a reserve should be something more to the Indians than an official; he should be their adviser, their friend, even more than that, he should almost be a father to them by giving his advice and assistance in all matters pertaining to their work. As those who know them say, the Indians have an almost childlike temperament. I do not say they are deficient in intellect; in fact, in intellectual ability they will compare with the white man. But they lack the white man's assistance, his stick-to-it-ness, his care about his work day after day and carrying out his agricultural activities. I also know that if the agent on a reserve has the confidence of the Indians they will all come to him for advice, and until the government appoint agents who will be something more than officials, who will do something more than carry out simply what the minister tells them to do, so long will the condition respecting the Indian continue as it is in Manitoba.

I think it is a disgrace that Canada should allow its Indians to be in such a condition that they are in at the present time. It was almost pathetic to listen to the stories of some of these men. They went back many years and told me of the arrangements made whereby they became the wards of the government. They told me of how loyal they had been; that when the war broke out they sent their young men over to the front some of whom had done good service in Canada. Those who returned went back on the reserve; they have made a bad mess of it; they are unable to make a living and it is no exaggeration to say that there are starving Indians who live near them know the facts. At my own place we often feed the Indians because we know they are really hungry and need something more than they alone. Now I want the government to get acquainted with the facts; to look into the conditions that exists on the reserve; and when the inspector goes around, let him do a little more than enter the agent's office and see that the books are properly kept. I would like to see him get in contact with the Indians, find out what their complaints are, some of the actual conditions under which they are living, and whether something cannot be done to make life a little more pleasant for them. In the harvest time the Indians will go out and work well for a month or six weeks, and get big wages, but when they get a little money they go into the town and buy all the canned goods they can get hold of. They are improvident.

II p.m., there is no use denying that, and therefore, someone to take care of them. I have no doubt that the minister is aware of these facts and is anxious to do something to help the Indians. I want to make this appeal on behalf of the Indians; I know them that the country do a little more for them; that something be done to help them to help themselves; to get them on the way to making a fairly decent living and not actually starve as they are doing at present on the reserve.
