Being an account of what some "Good Indians" are doing on the land.

By JAS. A. DONAGHY

A QUESTION often asked is: "Is it worth while spending so much money upon the Indians in an attempt to make self-supporting farmers out of them?"

There are a great many who answer in the negative, declaring it to be a waste of funds. They say we are trying to make the square hole, which cannot be done. While there may be a grain of truth in the peg-and-hole idea, yet, the majority of these who give expression to that opinion are far out of the way, or are wandering in a strange land about which they have read but little. Perhaps the present system is not perfect, but that is true with most business systems; they are continually being improved. There may be some truth in the statement that the Indian is a round peg, and our mode of living is the square hole, and it may be necessary to make some rearrangement in the pegs. That situation appears to be found in the words of an Indian Missionary across the line. "Too much money and time are being wasted trying to make white men out of the Indians instead of making good Indians out of them."

That great strides have been taken cannot be denied, and looking over the changes that have taken place in two or three generations we ought to feel proud on our part, and are being justified. On the other hand we must remember there are sections and some of our cities in which the white people are lacking in progress financially, socially or spiritually. The opportunity has been at their door for many years. Not very long ago the Indians were millionaires, and naturally did not feel the necessity of working. No provision in that past was made. Food and clothing for travel and clothing abounded on all sides, they simply had to go out and bring it in as required, like casing a chestnut. But the bark broke, and the huge supply of food disappeared, the Indians also almost exterminated by the whites. Like many bankrupt millionaires of today in Florida, they must work or go hungry. With the old-times work being hard, but the Indian Department and the churches working together take the young children before they have felt the influence of their environment to any extent, and place them where they are fed mentally and physically to face them to face an attempt at Indian work. All is not discarded, but the leaven is at work, and a glance over some of our big reserves will astonish those who are not acquainted with the scene. A few days ago I used to pass a few large farms known as "Bonanza Farms," owned by white men, but the body seemed to be too large for the brain, and they were short-lived. But the young Indians in some of the big reserves in Alberta are doing no nothing short of "Bonanza farming," and they are "making it go." Their acreage is enormous, and their methods are scientific.

These people working upon a large or small scale, are guided by an overseer known as a Farm Instructor, whose duty it is to arrange all farming operations. His efforts are well rewarded. Seed is selected subject to his approval. He supervises the preparation of the land, and sowing of the crop. In fact, he is to the Indian farmer what The North-West Farmer is to the white people—a source of information upon all farms from setting a hen, upwards. They are prevented from setting a hen, upwards. They are prevented by this system from making the blunders so often found among white farmers, for they are kept from making rash deals for articles they have no real use for. And also, to prevent the consumption merely from unsupecting useless articles upon these unsuspecting people, no one of the great leaks is thus closed. And finally, as stated in the eyes of the law, any such deal put through without the sanction of the Board of Supervisors is a deal that cannot be very well collected.

As the Government is his guardian, naturally it handles his money. All grain tickets pass into the hands of the Indian Department, who does the purchasing and advances money as he requires it during the winter. It will be seen that this system works to the best of all concerned. The Indian has the backing of the Government, and at the same time does not know that the bill will be paid out of the man's crop as far as it will go. A white man may decide to pay off his mortgage and hold back until the Indian's debts are paid in full if he has the means to his credit. So, while he cannot be sued for the debt, he is much safer than many white men. But all his business is not so complicated. He makes a good living raising sheep, digging out wolf pups in the spring, for which he receives a bounty of two dollars per head. If he knows how to hire a man to put in his crop while he went "digging wolves," and in three weeks' time has a fine crop, and produce outside of farming operations is in their own control, and is used in payment of what is called the "loan of honor," contracted without the sanction of the Department, and though they may sometimes be in arrears, yet they are absolutely sure. Indian honesty still stands.

On the Swan Lake reserve the visitor will see as fine work horses on the farms as Chief Matosse, Chas. Tanner, John Cameron, Mr. Telford, and others see on the average white man's farm. Last year Chas. Tanner had a good yield of very fine oats, and Mr. Cameron, who now considers himself to be on "Easy Street." The other men have also done well. They raise a good variety of poultry, including ducks and geese, and also fish are in the gardens.

With an ordinary desire to pay, and education provided free, school taxes are unknown, the reader may think I am doing more than my share. It is well, for the Indian it is, if he has any ambition at all. We are giving these people the greatest opportunity ever given and a real square deal, although frequently we hear that we are not doing so.

The occupiers of the reserve have a large steam thrasher outfit owned by the Indians operating it on the Swan Lake reserve. They were working the farms at that time without a supervising Farm Instructor to direct them, but they understand the work quite well themselves. They have grasped the new idea necessary to overcome the lack of hunting and trading privileges, and the old mode of living has undergone quite a change, and they are gradually conforming to the white habit. We may expect them to fit accurately in the near future. It may be necessary for us to remember that they think of the Indians, and have their own national songs, dances, and traditions, and it may be necessary to cut off some of the sharp corners of the square hole a bit, and not demand that they become exactly like white men, but that they fill their place better by becoming "good Indians." Not the "dead" kind we used to hear about, but Indians whose crops will require many trains to carry them out of the country.

But they still hang on to regard for their old traditions and certain dances. Can they be blamed? Perhaps we will have to preserve their national customs that are fast dying out, and at the same time make "good Indians" of the people. We must be careful to judge them by the wandering element we meet with occasionally as it is to judge the race who tour the country on the bumpy night train. Give the Indian fair chance, and he will prove that it is a return for the interest you have tak'en him.

Are Our Indians Being Cared For?

To the Editor of The New Outlook:

Dear Sir—The newspapers have given quite a little publicity to stories of sickness and suffering among our northern Indians, and as I have lived among these people for the last thirty-five years and have some knowledge of the conditions under which they live, I would like to try and give the public at least one side-light on the situation.

Some criticism has been expressed as to the sickness among these northern Indians.

Now, from the standpoint of a physician, I have never adverse criticism of the Department of Indian Affairs, because we, who represent the Churches, cannot take any better care of these isolated, wandering bands. Indians from a spiritual standpoint than the Department of Indian Affairs does from a physical one.

The isolated, scattered condition of these people makes the matter of caring for them almost an impossibility. Many a time I have thought that trying to reach these Indians was like the search of King Saul for the missing David "as a partridge among the mountains."

My experience has made me of the opinion that the Department of Indian Affairs takes a very forefront of our federal and provincial departments in caring for their sick ones. Observing settlers, fishermen, and others I have often remarked, "The Indians are the best-cared-for people in the whole country." Wherever the Indians are accessible they are well-cared for. Where they are inaccessible and uncared for it is not the fault of the State or the Churches.

One special note about the matter of the care of the Indians I would like to write about and that is the part that mission workers under all the Churches have played. During the best part of the past one hundred years mission workers have been attending to the physical as well as to the spiritual life of the Indians. Before "Treaty" was made with the Indians there were on the job doing what they could and at their own expense. Since "Treaty" was entered into, the Department of Indian Affairs has supplied remedies and the mission workers have dispensed them. Many and interesting tales could be told of isolated mission workers doing wonderful things among the bands which visit bands of Indians. Equally wonderful and appealing stories could be told of how needless work came to an end, broken bones were amputated, made and so forth. Besides all this the steady work day by day of dispensing remedies, extracting teeth, caring for the women and teaching the children by daily example and precept upon precept, the laws of life and clean living, and of how to prevent sickness and if it came how to cure for it.

The question is ofttimes asked, "Do Indian Missions pay?" We who know something of the knowledge that the lowest factor in the civilization, and general care and control of our Indians has been the work done by the Missions among them.

Koostatah, Man.

F. G. STEVENS.

Dear Sir:

Re: Bird Banding.

In connection with the Official Canadian Record of Bird Banding Returns, kept at this office, it has been suggested that many more banding returns would be reported by Indians if they understood the purpose of identification bands and the importance of reporting details concerning the recovery of each banded bird. Accordingly, I am asking you to help in this work by familiarizing the Indians with the purpose and results of bird banding.

The information that it is desired to give the Indians is as follows:

Through the voluntary efforts of persons throughout Canada and the United States, aluminum bands or rings are being placed on the legs of wild birds in an endeavour to obtain information concerning the migration and life histories of our native birds.

To avoid confusion, only one set of bands is being used in the two countries, and these bands are issued by the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, at Washington, D.C. They bear the inscription "Biol. Surv., Wash.D.C." and a number, or a letter and number.

It is important that any Indian, who finds a bird wearing one of these bands report the fact to the Indian Agent, who will then report all details to this branch. He should give the kind of bird, band number, date and locality of recovery, and information as to whether the bird was found dead, was killed, or was released alive still wearing its band.

To each Indian or Eskimo, reporting the recovery of a banded bird, the Government of Canada donates a bronze medallion. These tokens bear the inscription "From the Government of Canada" and are finished off in bright colours, that for the Indians showing a Canada Jay, and the one for the Eskimos a Polar Bear.

Those who
Those who report returns, help to establish very interesting and useful information concerning the wanderings of the birds of which very much is being learned in this way. Every report of a banded bird helps. Many interesting returns have already been furnished through the cooperation of Indians, and we hope for a great many more.

It is hoped that the Indians have begun to realize that the protection, which is afforded to migratory birds by the treaty which exists between Canada and the United States, is resulting in the increase of our ducks and geese, so that the Indians will have much better hunting in the open season. It is also hoped that they have learned that spring shooting is very detrimental to the cause of bird protection in general and that they will cease to carry out this practice.

The geese and ducks from Canada go to the United States and spend the winter there. Years ago the people in the United States, where the birds winter, used to shoot them for market. There were no bag limits and in many places there was no closed season. Then when the birds were on their northward flight they were shot wherever they stopped to feed. In many of the States of the United States this was true, and even in parts of Canada.

Now, since Canada and the United States have come to an understanding, because the birds were getting so scarce, things have changed. There is an open season of the same length in all parts of Canada and the United States. In no part of each of those countries are the birds shot for longer than three and one half months. In the whole of the United States there is no shooting after the end of January. In the whole of the United States where our birds are in winter, there is no sale of birds allowed. Fines amounting to thousands of dollars each year have had to be paid by persons who broke the law, and long jail sentences have been given persons who shot ducks or geese for sale. As there is no shooting after the end of January, the birds are not bothered when they are mating before coming north to Canada to breed. If Canada and the United States had not agreed by this treaty to give the birds more care, by now there would be very few ducks and geese coming North, in the spring, for they would have nearly all been shot to be sold. Since the treaty between Canada and the United States, the sale of birds has stopped, and spring shooting has stopped. The treaty made it possible for the United States to set aside big reserves where the ducks and the geese are not shot at all at any time of year. It is because of this treaty that ducks and geese come North now in bigger numbers than they did a few years ago.

Indians should remember that if the treaty had not been adopted, there would be hardly any birds left to come North.

All Canadians.
All Canadians should do their share
to see that birds are not shot in spring before they
nest, to see that no birds are wasted, because they
mean so much to our people, and to see that all banded
birds are reported to the National Parks of Canada
Branch, so that we may have more knowledge of the birds'
migrations and habits and so be in a position to enact
laws for the protection of these birds which are a
national asset.

Indian Agents and other persons, reporting
banded birds, will be informed promptly respecting

THE SATURDAY EVENING POST

By Ray Lyman Wilbur

Secretary of the Interior

As Told to William Atherton Du Puy

The Red Man in a White Man's World

THE American Indian should be made self-sustaining, should be brought to full responsibility for himself, should be freed of his present wardship, should be merged into the industrial life of the nation. The administration of his affairs should be decentralized, the manner of his education revised, the Indian agent, with his abnormal powers, should cease to exist. The Indian schools will become but one of three agencies of Government which will steadily become less important, and in twenty-five years it practically should have ceased to exist.

The assimilation of the Indian has been a policy of the Government for a hundred years. Despite that policy, the Indian has remained a people apart, close to the old life, languishing into periods as he former hunting grounds have disappeared. Yet the Indian stock is of excellent quality and can readily merge with that of the nation.

To bring about this result it will be necessary to revise the educational program both of practical and vocational character and to mature plans for the absorption of the Indian into the industrial life of the nation. The Indian boy and girl will be given the normal educations of our American boys and girls. Indian schools shall in no respect partake of the nature of reform schools. He shall not be prepared for dependent wardship but upstanding and independent manhood.

He shall be prepared for a place in the everyday world and then that place shall be found for him.

The Indian, obviously, constitutes a racial group quite different from the masses of the population. The United States has had a vast experience with racial and national groups. Italians, Scandinavians, Germans, have come to these shores, lived for a while as peoples apart, been absorbed into the mass. But the red man has remained a comparatively small racial group that has been relatively unaffected by the movement toward the melting pot. The white American is today the least American element in the population. He remains unassimilated because he has been isolated, held apart on his reservation, prevented from entering the great stream of American life.

There is plenty of evidence indicating the possession by the Indian of abundant intelligence to become a productive citizen of the United States capable of giving a good account of himself. The psychologists have tested Indian children and have found them to be on an average grade of white children. The white children, they say, grade 14 per cent above the Indians. There is much question, however, if this advantage is not due to the stimulation they have had in their homes, the greater familiarity with the language of the schools rather than to any innate superiority.

There are many experiences in which Indian children have gone into the public schools and taken their places beside white children. They have passed through the primary grades and gone on to high schools with those children. In some cases they have afterward gone to college. In running this gamut of education the Indian child has made a record that seems quite normal. He has shown an adequate capacity to acquire these various degrees of education.

The Indian is dexterous with his hands. He sees accurately. He is probably superior to the average white man.
in learning manual tasks. He can learn to be a carpenter, a bricklayer, a machinist, as readily as any white man. He is an excellent employee in the railway shops of the West. There are one hundred and fifty Indians employed in these shops at Winslow, Arizona, many of them drawing the pay of skilled machinists. This manual skill appears in the industries of the Indian woman, in basket weaving, in blacksmithing, in shoemaking. The man is of an even temperament. The women fit well into domestic service. They make excellent trained nurses. They are competent as clerks and stenographers. It has been adequately demonstrated that there is, in fact, no bar against the Indian becoming of full social standing and as a member of a civilized community by an opportunity.

The world of activity that is America is wide open to the Indian. When he has finished that schooling which provides for most of his kind, there are two avenues open to him. He may go back to the reservation or he may try to find himself a place in the white man's occupation. At this turning point in his career his fate is largely in the hands of those who control the Government who administer the Indian Service. They can send him back to the reservation to return to the ways of his ancestors and maintain the Indian status as a race apart or they can send him out into the active life of the nation.

The Choice

FROM now on every effort will be made to accomplish the following:

Senator Curtis, who, as a boy, lived as a blanket Indian on the reservation, tells of his experiences as a boy and, at the age of fifteen, again going up with the Indians to return to the reservation. His Indian grandmother waked him in the night, showed him that road led to the life of a reservation Indian and the other to that of the white man, and, though she loved him dearly, put him on the road which led him to the latter. Just this problem faces every young Indian who returns from school. Proper placement would lead most of them into lives among the whites and to assimilation.

The educated Indian usually goes back to the reservation, experience has shown, usually goes back to poverty, to the life of the aborigine. His veneer of civilization is soon lost and he becomes as were his fathers. The people of the reservation are likely to be prejudiced against all that is not Indian. The old prejudices of the young man may have learned in school, beat him down, drive him back.

Among the Indians there is great reverence for the old people, an apparent virtue, but one which here has barred progress. The white people dominate. There is no use against them. Because of the former theory of returning the young educated Indian to the reservation that he might exert an elevating influence comes to naught. The old order wins out. Boarding-school education is stripped from the young Indian upon his return to the reservation as might be a cloak.

The young Indian coming out of school does not want to go back to the reservation. A return to the crude life of it is particularly repugnant to the young girls. It usually happens, after they have gone back to their homes, that they come to the Indian agent and plead with him to find an avenue of employment for them. They beg for work. But in the remote regions in which the reservations are located there is no work. They can do nothing else than to subsist on the rations provided for them.

There should be no great difficulty in finding places in the industrial life of the nation for these young Indians. They could be placed anywhere and it is not hard to direct into the proper channels. Their numbers are not so great as materially to affect any labor market. They are scattered West where, for example, domestic help is scarce. Every girl who wants it could find a place in a white home. Their employment in the tourist hotels would be a highly attractive atmosphere. Many of them have had special training in sewing, which has its possibilities. Places could be readily found for those who have got some training in photography. There is unlimited call outdoor-door for the boys on the farms, in the orchards, in railway building and maintenance.

They are too often chained doggedly to one idea which, on the face of it, seems a correct one, but which has failed through the decades in actual practice. It has held that the Indian of the modern epoch was better fitted to farming than any other occupation. They had land. Above all else, they should be taught to farm. They have been so taught and then they have gone back to the reservation and applied what they have learned. Their opportunities have been many, but few have taken advantage of them. Farming on the reservations is largely a failure. The Indians lease their good lands to white farmers, who succeed on them, while the Indians fail.

As a matter of fact, the owner operation of a farm is a quite complicated business. Many white men with a thousand years of experience fail to operate successfully. It requires foresight, fixity of purpose, business sense, capacity for management, certain scientific knowledge—a combination of many things. It is almost impossible for one other than the exceptional aborigine. The development of the Indian into a farmer has largely failed and should cease to be the favorite theme of educationalists. The simplest method of self-support for an inexperienced and backward individual, the new policy should hold, is that of work for pay, preferably outside. The Indian's first step toward taking his place among the general population should be that of getting a simple job, doing it faithfully, and thereby gaining experience in the new manner of life. Securing this sort of work for him is the most practical step that can be taken toward his assimilation.

It is to the advantage of the Indians who remain on the reservation that their contact with their white neighbors be increased. Whatever possible, the reservations should be opened up in part to white settlers. White men should be mixed with the Indians. This would break down Indian isolation, give them an opportunity to absorb white civilization.

The experience of the Kiowa Indians, in Oklahoma, is a fine example of the result of such intermingling of the races. A generation ago lands were allotted to the Kiowas, who were unlettered red men, few of whom knew anything of English. Instead of allotting them lands which were in a solid block, they were given alternate tracts with white farms. The white settlers went about their farming, built their schools, carried on a normal community life. The Indian farmers observed their neighbors, came in contact with them, grew to imitate them, sent their children to the white...
schools. Those children of the present generation are in no way members of a race apart. They are average members of the community.

Even the Indians who grew up under the old order have come to live like white men now. A single generation has worked the miracle. Conditions approximating these would cause the dissolution of any of these reservations.

Much might be done for the aboriginal adults of the isolated reservations who are now living in idleness and poverty. The West is changing, which ought to be doing. During the past decade half a million Mexicans have crossed the line, seeking and finding work in the United States. More of them have come than there are Indians in all the United States. They have tended to congregate in such cities as Los Angeles and San Antonio, where new quids for the nation to digest. The excuse for allowing them to come in has been the need of them to perform rough labor yet needed by our national industry.

Their blood is little different from that of their cousins across the line. They have been brought into our country as a new problem while our own Indians have languished in idleness and want on their isolated reservations.

Provision for securing employment for our own Indians should have resulted in their getting many of the jobs rather than those introduced by Mexico. It should have got them away from the reservations, given them an opportunity to learn, carried them far toward civilization. There are certain reservations which get money from the sale of timber. The White Mountain Apaches, in Arizona, for instance, the last of the wilder Indians, have been away from the reservation and have made as much as four hundred thousand dollars in a single year. It was said of them that they spent it all, but they did not go back to the reservation. The answer to this is that they gained an experience in handling money which will be of value when next they have opportunity to earn any.

Off the Reservation

There is one employment activity of the Indians, however, that I would discourage. I do not believe that the reservation in shape manner is beneficial to them. The influences that surround circus life, for example, are likely to prove a rather serious test on the moral fiber of any such development. There have already been too many cases in which shows have been stranded and the Government has been called upon to take Indians who were a part of them back to their homes.

Employment will be found for the reservation Indians. It is in the interest of most of them that, when they get away from the reservations, they be encouraged to stay away. Gradually they would find themselves, establishing permanent homes among the general population, taking their places among the mass of us.

There are a few of the reservations on which the productive arts and industries have developed. The blanket weaving of the Navajos, the baskets and silver ornaments of the Pueblos, are typical of them. These should be encouraged to the utmost. They should be helped, particularly in marketing their output. The existence of these reservations is a few reservations, however, should not lead to the false impression that they offer a general opportunity to the Indians of the nations on all reservations. On many of the reservations there is little opportunity for the Indians to earn livelihoods through their native arts and industries.

The Right Sort of Help

In so far as is possible, there should be continued allotment of Indian lands with full ownership rights. Provision should be made for disposing of the surplus rights of absentee Indians. The advantages of contact with the whites develop when members of that race are allowed to enter the reservations. The timber should be distributed among the Indians. The Indians, whether they stay on the reservations or leave them, should be fully provided with their property rights. There are many ways in which this could be done. An Indian reservation, for example, might be created in which a valuable forest of spruce might be created which would own this timber. The Indians of the tribe would be stockholders in the corporation. It could be arranged to give the best possible returns from the timber. Members of the tribe, whether they stayed on the reservation or moved away, would receive what was due them. This would be better for them than that they should be bound to the reservation by property rights which they were forced to acquire if they wished to move.

Under these influences Indians would tend steadily to get away from the reservations. Those remaining in the order would graduate off. Those who remained on the reservations would have normal educations and would assume the roles of normal citizens. The government would then vanish. In a generation there would remain but a few small groups that would be different from the generality of the population. Indian administration virtually would have ceased to exist.
Shall We Send Our Indians to the Cities?

Joseph A. Gschwend, S.J.
Editor of Jesuit Missions.

During the month of July, a Senate Investigation Committee has been at work on the Indian Reservations. The writer does not question the Committee's sincerity or hard work. However, not being endowed with an all-seeing eye and an all-comprehending mind such as enabled the Senate Committee to "study" the Indian situation in a vast territory of some 15,000 square miles in two or three days, the writer found that three weeks were scarcely sufficient to give him anything like a complete idea of the Indian problem on the Sioux Reservations of South Dakota.

The writer, long before his trip to South Dakota, had made something of a study of the American Indians. He had read up on the subject and had discussed the Indian and his problems and his mode of life with men who had given years to the work of evangelizing and civilizing the Red Man of the Dakota prairies. From these men he learned to know the Indian as he is in reality, in daily life at school, and off in his tent or tepee or log cabin or small house out on the plain. The men who had been burned brown by exposure in the cause of Indian welfare had not drawn their knowledge from beautiful illustrations that one may find in magazines or books, nor yet from heroic Indian figures that adorn our art galleries and museums, or are stamped on our coins.

After many conversations held with old missionaries on the Reservation, and after personal observations made at the schools and among the Indians themselves, one feels rather convinced that the problem of training the Indian along lines of white civilization and industry is a slow and painful process. One understands, too, the danger involved in following out in practice the suggestion of certain poorly informed investigators, that the Indian should be sent into the city and made to shift for himself.

The Indian on the Reservation is only slowly emerging from the nomadic life of his ancestors. He has not yet entirely overcome his lazitude, his old-time aversion to strenuous work. Put him into competition with the white man of the city, and, most likely, it would be only a matter of weeks or months till the Red Man would find himself established for life in the slums of our cities. That he is not ready to compete with the white man in the latter's industries, is evident from the experience right out on the prairie where the white settler soon outstrips his Indian neighbor, and where even the well-trained Indian, who has been through some eastern school or other, soon lapses again into his old ways.

Handicapped in this sphere, the Indian has yet another weakness which would make him a losing player in the game of life in our cities. That weakness is the Indian's ignorance of the value of money. He simply has not yet learned its value, and consequently still needs the guiding and helping hand of the Indian Agency and the missionary to teach him to provide for a rainy day. Left

In ten years, enrolment has increased 28% and attendance, 48%. The percentage of attendance has increased approximately 10%. Not only are more children attending, but they are attending more regularly. This has had an interesting effect on the academic standing of pupils. In 1918-19, 878 Indian children were studying in Grade 5 and higher. Last year, 2228 were in the higher grades.

All this is very gratifying, but there is much to be desired yet as far as day school attendance is concerned. Every energy is being bent to make instruction at these schools attractive. Better qualified teachers, more interesting texts and teachers' aids, more playground and outdoor activities and better correlation with the Indian home environment are the
aims. In Part II of this report will be found a tabular statement, showing the location and indicating the enrolment at all Indian schools.

Compared with the previous year, there was an increase of one residential school. New institutions were opened at St. Phillips, Sask., and Sioux Lookout, Ont. The first is under the management of the Oblate Fathers and the second is conducted by the Missionary Society of the Church of England. The Old Sun School in Alberta, was destroyed by fire and, at the time of this writing, is being rebuilt. During the year, three day schools were closed on account of poor attendance, and in three communities the Department is associated with a local school district in the conduct of new combined Indian and public schools.

The work at residential schools was particularly encouraging. The churches that are associated with the Department in the conduct of these institutions have been more careful in the selection of principals and other officers. As before, vocational training has been emphasized. Special funds are now available for this phase of the work in the province of British Columbia and all residential schools there are now well equipped for manual training and related instruction. In Ontario and the Prairie Provinces, emphasis is placed on farming, gardening and the care of stock. 7075 pupils were enrolled at residential schools during the year. Compare this with 4,640, the number maintained and trained in boarding schools ten years ago, and the increasing importance of this part of the Department's educational programme is apparent.

All Indian schools were inspected frequently by officers of the Department. In addition, public and separate school inspectors visited all classrooms, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, where there were special Indian School Inspectors. More thorough inspection has resulted in a higher standard of instruction. Classroom activity in Indian schools is now comparable to the work in white schools of the same localities. It is the practice at Indian schools to follow provincial curricula and to engage fully qualified teachers.

The health of Indian children studying in boarding schools has been given special attention. Medical and dental supervision and treatment have been arranged. Travelling nurses spent part of their time at these institutions. There was considerable expenditure for the removal of adenoids and
Diseased tonsils and for the correction of defective vision. There has been a special effort during the year to vaccinate every Indian school pupil. Improvements have been made in the children's diet and in the playground activities. Milk herds have been tested and special attention has been given to water supply and sewage disposal systems.

New main buildings were commenced during the year at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, near Kenora, Ont., and the Alert Bay Institution, in British Columbia. In addition, the Department secured a suitable farm and building site and commenced the erection of the necessary buildings for a large boarding school at Shubenacadie, N. S. This last named institution will provide an academic and vocational training as well as maintenance for orphans and other neglected Indian children in the Maritime Provinces. The boys' wing at the Kamloops Indian Residential School, in British Columbia, was completed during the year. At nine day schools, new classrooms or teacher's residences were erected.

One hundred and sixty graduates of Indian schools, who showed academic promise, received grants for the purpose of continuing their studies at high schools, universities and business colleges. The policy is to make grants to the most promising, physically fit graduates of our own schools. If church and department representatives consider a graduate worthy, a grant is allowed when the bona fide intention of the pupil is evident and provided proper supervision can be secured for the period of advanced study. These tuition grants are continued only when satisfactory reports are received. Last year, besides those taking advanced work, there were approximately 225 Indian children attending white schools and orphanages. All these are in addition to the enrolment at Indian schools as shown in the tabular statements. The expenditure from parliamentary appropriation on behalf of these special students amounted to $39,000 during the year. The practice of assisting selected ex-pupils of residential schools to start farming and housekeeping has been continued.

In the past, the funds of certain Indian bands have been used to meet some of the costs of conducting day schools on their reserves. The year under review is the first that all expenditure for education has been provided by Parliamentary Appropriation. The programme of free education is now extended to all Indians in Canada. On the 19th ultimo, I wrote to you, briefly indicating the nature of Indian educational activity in Canada. You now ask regarding the character of the educational work of a residential school and of the reserve schools.

Indian residential schools are for the Indian child who is underprivileged from an educational standpoint, i.e., no school close to his home, orphan or neglected. The activity at a residential school is both academic and vocational. Girls are taught the domestic arts, practical nursing, etc., and boys are prepared for whatever vocations are common on their particular reserves. All older pupils spend half of each day in one of the vocational departments and the other half in a classroom. The academic work is as prescribed for white schools by the Provincial Departments of Education. In certain parts of Canada, where the Indian lives by the chase, his habits are too nomadic for the operation of day schools on reserves. In these localities, the residential school is the main factor in the programme of the Department and of the churches that are associated.

The Indian day schools on reserves are comparable in every way to the ordinary rural school. Provincial courses of study are followed, emphasis being placed on agriculture and manual training. An effort is made to correlate classroom activity with home life on the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Education and Welfare Work for Native Alaskans

Schools, Hospitals, Orphanages, and Cooperative Business Enterprises Conducted Under Great Difficulties by Men and Women Imbued With True Missionary Spirit. Some Stations Reached Only Once or Twice a Year

By WILLIAM HAMILTON
Acting Chief Alaska Division, Bureau of Education

The story of relief work carried on during the summer months on the coast of Labrador has crowded many lecture halls and has deservedly drawn from the benevolently disposed thousands of dollars toward its support. Few people realize that in Alaska, more remote and inaccessible, the Bureau of Education is carrying on, all the year round, a far greater work in behalf of the aboriginal races of that northern Territory.

For the native Alaskan the Bureau of Education provides teachers, physicians, and nurses—trained workers who have at heart the welfare of their charges. It maintains schools, hospitals, and orphanages, relieves destitution, trades, organizes cooperative business enterprises, establishes colonies, and controls the reindeer industry.

To Overcome Distances the Greatest Problem

The work is of vast extent, and it is carried on under great difficulties arising principally from the remoteness of most of the villages, the enormous distances between them, the meager means of communication, and the severity of the climate. The 27,000 natives are scattered along thousands of miles of coast and on the great rivers in villages ranging from 30 souls to 200 or 400 persons. The work would extend to the utmost limits of the United States in terms of distance with schools in Maine, California, Georgia, and Minnesota. One of the school districts is twice the size of the State of Illinois. Many of the settlements in which the bureau's work is located are far beyond the limits of regular transportation and mail service. Some of the villages on remote islands or beside the frozen ocean are brought into touch with the outside world only once or twice a year, when they are visited by the United States Coast Guard steamer on its annual cruise or by the supply vessel sent by the Bureau of Education. During eight months of the year all of the native villages in Alaska, with the exception of those near the coast and a few near the Alaska Railroad, are reached only by trails over the snow-covered land or frozen rivers.

One of the greatest problems has been the securing of transportation of appointees and supplies from Seattle to the remotest settlements. In compliance with the requests for a vessel suitable for use by the bureau in its Alaskan work, the Navy Department transferred to the Interior Department the U.S.S. Bozer, a wooden vessel, with a carrying capacity of 500 tons, formerly used as a training ship for naval cadets. During the season of 1916 the Bozer made two voyages, the first to the Bering Sea region and the second to points on the shore of the Arctic Ocean as far as Point Barrow. On its southern voyage she took teachers whose terms of service had expired and carried from northern Alaska reindeer meat which Eskimo herders wished to sell in the States. During the winter months she was used in the work of southeastern Alaska as a school of navigation and seamanship for young native men.

In the Alaskan native community the school is the center of all social, industrial, and civic life. The teacher is guide, leader, and everything else the community may demand. To be "teacher" in the narrow schoolroom sense is the least of the teacher's duties.
School Savings Successful In Small Community

That the school savings system works as well in small communities as in the cities is demonstrated by the schools of Gilbert, Minn. Within 10 weeks from the day the first savings were deposited, $1,950 out of the 2,066 pupils enrolled opened school accounts.

Detail work of the system within the schools is in charge of W. A. Pike, head of the commercial department. Within two months more he expects that every child will have his book open. Weekly and monthly reports showing the percentage standings of all the rooms are sent to every room in the district. It has been provided that as soon as every pupil in a school opens an account, the entire school gets a holiday.

Mexican Indians Surrender Homes to Establish Schools

The Department of Education, Mexico, is sending as many rural teachers as possible to the State of Chihuahua to meet the call for education among the Tarahumara Indians, according to the Bulletin of the Pacific School Union. These Indians formerly fled to the mountains at the sight of a white man, but were won over through an educational campaign conducted by the Mexican Government.

So strong was the Indian's conviction that one of them offered his hut as the first "People's House," leaving only a tree as shelter for himself and his family. Six other Tarahumaras followed his example. These "people's houses" are made centers of activity against drunkenness and other vices.

Prompt Action Demanded of School Nurses

Foreign Bodies in the Eye Frequently Cause Trouble. Bites of Insects and Minor Injuries Require Attention

By ELLA D. FLEMING
Junior Specialist in School Hygiene, Bureau of Education

In the course of the school nurse's duty she often will be called upon to give a child medical treatment; but emergencies often call forth her ability to do small things quickly and adeptly.

Some of the most frequent ones are:

Removing a foreign body from the eye, irrigating a child's ear, care of a fainted child, treating insect bites.

Removing a foreign body from the eye may be accomplished by drawing the upper lid down over the eye, and causing the child to blow the nose forward at the same time. If the particle is under the upper lid, instruct the child to look down and inward, turn the lid back over a small pencil or match, and with the corner of a clean handkerchief or cloth, wipe off the inside of the lid. If the particle is under the lower lid, draw the lid down against the cheekbone and instruct the child to look up. If the body is imbedded in the eye-ball, do not touch it but have an oculist see the eye at once.

Suggestions of Practical Methods

In irrigating a child's ear when the doctor wishes it done and for any reason it can not be done at home, lay the child down, draw the tip of the ear upward and backward, and syringe the ear gently with warm water. Be very careful not to poke into the ear or direct the stream of solution forcibly against the drum of the ear.

If a child has fainted, lower his head, give him fresh air in abundance and apply cold compresses to his head and chest. An attack may be averted by having a child rest on his hands and knees.

For an insect bite such as from a bee or wasp, soak the area affected in a solution of ammonia or baking-soda.

To Emphasize Local History

"A museum in every high school" is a new slogan in Kansas. Local history and the botany and geology of the respective localities are the subjects to be emphasized. The collections are to be made by the pupils to stimulate interest in their studies. Many high schools have found value.

Natural Resources

Educating Our Indians Is An Important Task

New School In The Maritimes

Department of Indian Affairs

Conducts Day and Residential Schools Throughout Canada.

One of the very important functions of the Department of Indian Affairs is the providing of educational facilities for Indian children throughout the Dominion. Day schools are conducted on reserves in every province and where conditions necessitate it, residential schools are also operate. In order to provide academic instruction and vocational training for those Indian children in the Maritime Provinces whose needs are not met by the twenty-two day schools conducted in that part of Canada by the Department, a residential school has been erected at Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia. There are six such institutions in the vicinity of the Great Lakes in Ontario and many in Western Canada but the one lately erected at Shubenacadie is the only one in the Maritimes.

The new school, which will house 125 pupils and the necessary teaching staff and provide accommodation for class-room and domestic instruction will be opened about the middle of September. In due time there will be erected barns, workshops, and the other equipment necessary for the vocational courses.

Of the day schools conduct by the Department of Indian Affairs in the Maritime Provinces, eleven are located on reserves in Nova Scotia, ten in New Brunswick, and one on Prince Edward Island. These schools solve the ordinary problem of educating the children residing in close proximity to the schools. There remains the necessity of providing for orphans, neglected children, and those who live too far from the day schools to be regular attendants. It is for these under-privileged children that the residential school has been established.

From the establishment of the first industrial school nearly one hundred years ago, there has been cooperation between the Dominion Government and the various religious denominations interested in missionary work among the Indians. In following this well-established policy the Shubenacadie school will be conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church as the Indian bands in the Maritimes are all adherents of that faith.

Rev. Father J. P. MacKey has been appointed principal and is now installed in the school. Under the Department's direction he will have general charge of the institution. The Sisters of Charity, who will conduct the domestic and classroom activities, will move into their quarters about the middle of August. The teachers and other instructors will be fully qualified and educational activities will be academic and vocational. The class-room work will be comparable to that in the public schools of the province. At the Department's request the school will be inspected by officers of the Provincial Department of Education. The vocational training will include for the girls, domestic science; and for the boys, farming, gardening, care of stock and possibly manual training, thus placing graduates from this school in a position to become self-supporting and independent.

The St. Thomas Local Council of Women wishes to express its commendation of the present system now in operation in Institutes for the education of the Indian girl and boy.

After consulting former pupils and making a careful study of the habits and inclinations of the North American Indian, we fear that a change from the present scheme to bring it into conformity with our Ontario Public School system would prove a handicap rather than an advantage in fitting them for a place in our National life.

The part-time academic and practical education qualifies them so that when they leave school they can at once be placed at gainful employment. Otherwise, the average Indian child, handicapped by the lack of finance is not prepared to further his academic education, and thus have a tendency to revert to his tribal custom of living.

During the past 9 years, definite efforts have been made to improve and expand the educational activity among the youth of our Indian wards. The present Superintendent General of Indian Affairs has taken a lively interest in this work and has asked Parliament for larger appropriations, so that improvements could be made in the Indian school service. Buildings have been reconstructed or enlarged and better and more varied equipment has been supplied. Higher salaries and grants have attracted better qualified teachers and instructors.

In connection with residential schools, which are a very important factor in the programme, 27 new main buildings have been erected or are now under construction.

Since 1921, the number of Indian schools has not materially increased. Added accommodation and better and more attractive instruction have contributed largely to the remarkable increase in enrolment and attendance. The enrolment has increased from 12,558 in 1921 to 15,347 last year. During the same period, the average daily attendance has increased from 8,074 to 11,258. Not only are more children attending, but they are attending more regularly. This has had an interesting effect on the academic standing of the older pupils. Nine years ago, 929 Indian children were in Grade 5 or higher. Last year, 2,228 were in the higher grades.

The cost of educating Indian children in some parts of Canada was definitely imposed on the Federal Government by treaties. Elsewhere, the State had accepted this obligation. However, up to last year, certain bands in Ontario and Quebec still paid from their own funds part of the expenses of conducting their schools. The Government has now extended the system of free education so as to include all Indian children.
Special efforts have been made to extend and improve the vocational training in residential schools. Larger grants to the churches that are associated with the Department in the conduct of these institutions have made this possible. Departmental officers make frequent inspections, with a view to preparing the Indian boys and girls for lives of economic independence after graduation.

The curricula and textbooks at Indian schools have been made to conform to the standards of the various provinces. The inspection of Indian schools by the provincial public and separate school inspectors has been extended to the three prairie provinces. Wherever this arrangement is possible, classroom instructors in Indian schools benefit greatly by the constructive criticism of men who are familiar with the best pedagogical methods in use in white schools.
An Indian Training Ground

The following letter is from Rev. W. A. Hendry, Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba. The work of the school throughout the year has been carried on in all its branches. The attendance, as usual, has been equal to the capacity of the plant. For the last ten years more children have wished to enter than we could accommodate. The parents realize that the school serves a purpose which seems to bring something worth while to them and they want their children to take advantage of it.

The farm, on which we look for good things always and consider our greatest asset as a training ground for the future of the school, was all but a failure this past harvest of the lack of rain. We had only four hours' rain in this district from spring until fall. No matter how it looked as though it would rain it did not seem to be able to rain, and many crops were sown twice, but all alike were burned up.

Our chief source of supply is the Long Flat Reserve which is sixteen miles to the west of the school. More than half of our pupils come from this reserve. The Indians of the Sioux village are being moved to it, which will make it the largest reserve in southern Manitoba.

In many ways great progress has been achieved with the Indians in the three prairie provinces during the last forty years. There are few Indians today who cannot speak the English language and more than half the population in the prairie provinces have been through the day or residential school. They know how to read and many of them have received an excellent training in agriculture in some one of the residential schools, and others have worked for many years with the farmers of the plains. They have received very generous and sympathetic help from the government in the way of support and guidance through the aid of a farm instructor, and they have good land free from taxation of any kind. The Indian is not lacking in knowledge as to how to proceed to farm, but, unless they do so by their own initiative and assume responsibility, they will never learn what it means to stand on their own feet. The task from now on, for a while at least, is a difficult one, as it requires a thorough knowledge of the problem, and an education of a practical kind that requires tact, patience, and perhaps a little audacity to perform the work of transferring the load on to the Indian himself.

If we continue giving to him, ever giving, we may be working toward an ever-fading objective, and at the same time wasting in the Indians what is often called "the latent energy." On the other hand, if he is taught to stand on his own feet, he will be inspired to construct on his own characteristics and to develop his own leadership. It will tend to help him to work out himself his programmes of education, health, economics and community welfare. In the final analysis the only permanent foundation for progress must come from within the Indian himself.

Mr. SIMPSON: Can the minister give any information as to the intention of the government with respect to the erection of a new building to replace the old Shingwauk Home building?

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): I am sorry my reply is not with me at this moment, but I may say that we are as quickly as possible replacing old buildings with new and modern ones, and erecting new buildings where they seem to be required for Indian educational work. My deputy will be here in a few minutes.

Mr. SIMPSON: They are carrying on at present in a building that has been in existence for a period of upwards of fifty years. It is not modern at all.

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): I have it in mind, I cannot say whether it is in the program for this year or not.

Mr. MANION: I would like to refer to the question of the fire extending from the Indian reserve at Fort William into the park. Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): I am familiar with the report the hon. member has brought up. It is one upon which we have not reached decision. Mr. MANION: I think in this case the minister's deputy is a little too economical for the department and he should let down the votes in justice to the parks board of Fort William.

Mr. BENNETT: I should like to say a few words about this item. Last year taken for granted, I believe, the minister voted a degree point out to the minister that during the last few months, in fact during the last year, I have received very serious complaints regarding the administration of the Indian department in western Canada. The fault does not rest with the officer immediately in charge. Political patronage has played a large part in the matter, in which the deputy head is wholly without authority. For instance there
have been cases of machinery bought merely for the purpose of providing business for friends and which lies outdoors unused. In one instance a man employed on a farm instructed to the Indians an undischarged bankrupt, and in another case a man who is addicted to the use of liquor to too large an extent was put in a position of authority with the result that at times he gets under the weather with injurious consequences to the Indians.

There is a vast sum of money being expended for the Indians, and this talk of the minister about his desire to help these wards of the nation would somehow bring me to give some little expression to that sentiment in concrete form in a proper expenditure of the money voted for the purpose, and with less exercise of political patronage on the part of appointments to the Civil Service Commission, which makes appointments in some cases should make them in all. It is not simply one case but six or three cases in particular. Why is it that the rear relations of a member of parliament is taken from Portage la Prairie and put on a reserve? Did the Civil Service Commission approve of it?

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): Yes.

Mr. BENNETT: Under what circumstances?

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): I cannot tell my hon. friend.

Mr. BENNETT: I think the minister could be he took the trouble to. The people in that locality at all events think so. In one instance the Indians were moved off one reserve—

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): Where was that?

Mr. BENNETT: Not far from Portage, and they are supposed to have removed to other places. I do not know whether they have been or not. This is the report that was made by a gentleman who went through the country, not with any political bias at all, but with the one object of seeing how the aborigines were treated. He inquired why farm machinery should be left lying around unused, and why the power for farming purposes unused. He also saw this reserve that I mention. In fairness to all concerned I am leaving out the names of the particular individuals, the matter having been an opportunity to investigate these matters, lest it be said that injury is being done to any particular person.

Some years ago the idea was started that the Indians were raising very large crops. For instance, in my own province of Alberta there were the exigencies of—shall I say?—the demands of friends, the reserves should be leased near Medicine; then reserves were created; then the sale of the lands of a reserve east of Calgary; and when you go into Saskatchewan you find difficulties of the same sort, especially in the northern parts of the province, and still in Manitoba. The result is that although it is said that the Indians are producing large quantities of grain, in the main it will be found that we are not getting the increase they should for the moneys that are expended, and part of the moneys we are expending belong to the Indians. There is a vast sum of this money that belongs to the Indians; for when lands are sold which the Indians own the proceeds from the sale of these lands goes into a trust fund, and the income therefrom is available for the maintenance of the Indians.

I have referred to three reserves in Alberta. I refer to a reserve in Saskatchewan. There is also a reserve in Manitoba called Long Plain reserve, which I mentioned a little while ago. The Indians I referred to are the Indians who were removed from Portage to the Long Plain reserve. I do not go into the numbers in detail, but I think it is sufficient for my purpose to indicate them lest it be said that we have approved of this vast expenditure; and I say again, though it may be small in itself, it is a relatively small sum of money, actually it is a very substantial sum. You have $2,500,000 out of $5,000,000 being used for Indian education, including the construction of schools, buildings which would be desirable, if not now, that we should have a complete statement from the minister as to just what work is being done and what the results are. Possibly the hearers of the ear of the nation would be ready for something to go into the matter in detail, but I should like the minister to know that there are those deeply interested in these questions who are steadily watching them from outside observation and they believe that the results obtained are not all in keeping with what could be secured from the expenditures made. A tendency is manifesting itself to expend money on the purchase of facilities for farming which are not used for farming, with resultant idleness on the part of the Indians. The question of the Indians in this direction is well known to all—with the unfortunate result that instead of the Indian becoming more self-respecting he becomes more dependent on the government as they do very excellent areas of land of high agricultural value, we know that there are not wanting those who are always endeavouring to see that these lands are sold.
and purchased by someone else. The minister has had a good deal of experience in that regard in various sections of the country. He knows the means that are taken to have the Indians made to believe that it is desirable for them to sell and that they do not find their resources gone and the lands sold; the result is that you have a worse condition than you had before. The minister knows the difficulties which sometimes have been pointed out in connection therewith, I fancy many others besides myself.

Without taking the minister's time or the time of the committee we go into a great deal of detail which I have under my hand, and which I had expected would be useful at this session of the house, representing accumulated detail extending over several years. I do suggest, however, that whatever little time he may have at his disposal for Indian affairs might be utilized in having the closest possible inspection made of the farms now in the hands of the Indians, and the inspectors' reports. Unfortunately I have seen some of them and have checked them up. I know the difficulties in connection with farm instructors and the difficulties and difficulties which the minister has to experience with those who think that they are fitted by a kindly Providence better to discharge the duties of farming among the Indians than Indians than any other people in the world. But if we are to get some value for the money that we are expending and make the Indians as well as possible self-supporting, more self-reliant and less dependent and improve his position in the community by encouraging him to engage in agricultural pursuits and the raising of crops, done at one time in connection with two reserves in Alberta, we shall have to adopt different means from those which are now in vogue.

There is no doubt that there is an opportunity to which attention I attach a great deal of importance is strongly of the opinion that there has been a steady deterioration in recent years in the management of the affairs of the reserves. That is not wholly attributable to my hon. friend's administration, of course, but it is attributable to causes which the government might, it seems to me, by very strong action prevent. I confine myself with pointing out these matters, without taking time to read a vast quantity of evidence which I have dealing with the subject, if the minister to ensure that he shall I say?—observation and action on the ground, and not departmental action from Ottawa, that better results are obtained for the money expended than those which we have heretofore realized; for some of the education that we have given the Indians has only resulted in the poor unfortunate becoming the easier the victim of the tendencies of modern civilization. I think the minister knows what I refer to in that respect. Despite all efforts that are made to prevent the Indian becoming the victim of the drink, very often his improved education has the effect readily made him a victim of alcohol. I see nothing wrong. All these things are matters that I regard as of great importance from the standpoint of the treatment of our aborigine, and I earnestly hope that steps will be taken to improve the conditions I have mentioned.

Mr. STIKWART (Edmonton): There are reserves in western Canada—I presume my hon. friend is peaking of those reserves—where the Indians are left out of doors. But that is the case on almost every farm in western Canada. On the whole I think we have more facilities on the Indian reserve for securing implements and tools than will be found on ordinary farms in any given locality in the western country. As fast as we can get money—because after all it is a question of money—behind us providing facilities for covering these implements at or near the agent's quarters on the reserve. The appointment of agents is made by the Civil Service Commission, usually after a competitive examination.

Mr. BENNETT: It was not agents that I mentioned.

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): Farm instructors are appointed by the commissioner at Regina. The hon. member refers to him, forgetting that Mr. Edwards, who, he says, was an undischarged bankrupt when he received his appointment. I did not know anything about that at the time. After the period of probation he did not prove to have the necessary qualifications for the work and he is no longer in the employ of the department. My hon. friend says that the Indians are making no improvement in the way of farming. May I direct his attention to the Blood reserve at Macleod? They had well over one hundred thousand bushels of grain on that reserve last year. The Indians on the Blackfoot reserve are also making progress. As to the sale of Indian land, I agree with everything that hon. member said. Usually the reserve covers the best land in any given locality, and there is a desire on the part of the people who surround it to secure that land and they try every means in their power to get possession. The Blackfoot reserve was sold long before I became Superintendent...
General of Indian Affairs, and we have had a good deal of trouble in getting collections of the money from the Indians, but we have succeeded in strengthening out the difficulty. It is not the policy of the department to sell any land required now or that may be required in the future in the province of western Canada if it can be utilized by them for grazing, agriculture or any other purpose.

With respect to the education of the Indians, when I took charge of the department I found the various churches of the country, the Roman Catholic under the Oblate Fathers, the Anglicans, the Presbyterians, the Methodists—of course the Anglicans and the Catholics were engaged in missionary work to a much greater extent than the Presbyterians and the Methodists—I found that these churches had constructed buildings and had become responsible for the maintenance of the Indians in their institutions, and they were levying upon their adherents to secure money necessary to carry on their educational work. These churches had gone into the country in missionary spirit to educate and christianize the young Indians, and I did not think it was fair to have them carrying that heavy financial burden. Therefore I immediately took steps to purchase from them the institutions that were considered to be useful for a number of years to come and to replace as far as possible the structures that had fallen into disrepair. The Roman Catholic churches carried on their work under much better conditions than they did when I became minister of the department.

With 105,000 Indians scattered over the Dominion from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and away up in the Arctic, it would seem strange if some of our officers did not go wrong once in a while. But may I say to the hon. leader of the opposition that I will not tolerate an officer on an Indian reserve who has anything to do with liquor—and I am not a prohibitionist.

Mr. BENNETT: Hear, hear.

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): That is one very strong resolution I have made in this regard, and I intend to carry it out. So far as I know, we try to keep the staff engaged in Indian affairs as honest as possible. I do not say that we will not have difficulties now and again; anyone who has to administer this department is bound to have difficulties, but I say we are making progress, and I think perhaps I should be glad to inform the house of the lines along which we are making splendid progress in Indian affairs.

[Mr. C. A. Stewart.]

Mr. BRADY: I want to bring home to the Minister of the Interior a few facts that are vital in connection with this question. I will admit, without hesitation, that the money we are spending on the education of Indians in Canada has not resulted in making the Indians of our country educated. No hon. member of this house who has studied the Indian problem can dare tell me that beneficial results have accrued from this large expenditure. If we compare the condition of the Indians in Canada with that of the Maoris in New Zealand, we find a striking contrast. The Maoris in New Zealand have entered almost every branch of life you can even find them in the legislative halls of that dominion. Unfortunately we cannot point to a similar advance among the Indians in our own country. I say that the minister has honestly endeavored to the best of his ability to solve the problem of educating the Indian, but he has not succeeded. The Indian on the reserve is given tools with the most valuable land in the country at his disposal, is not doing for himself what he should do when we take into account what happens to his education? What is the position of the Indians today? I grant that the Indian schools are doing good work? There is the Coqualeetza school, the school at Fort Simpson, Athabasca Telegraph Station, and Whitehorse Island school, all are doing very good work. We must admit that they are not solving the problem of getting the full value of these 105,000 Indians who have been taken from their natural habitat in our modern methods, and to whom we are trying to give a modern education. We have succeeded only in giving them a veneer of education, and we have not brought the education of those Indians to its legitimate end. In their education I suggest that we should strive to teach those Indian children to be part of the modern life in which they find themselves. Are the Indian schools doing that? I desire that when we spend so much money on Indian education we shall see to it that the Indians shall have good teachers, and teachers who are well paid. Furthermore those children should be taught technical work in which pursuit the Indian is an expert.

Without taking more time of the committee I wish to say that by instinct the Indians are very artistic. We in this house would do well to take note of the work they have done with wood carving in western Canada; they are efficient in painting and basket weaving. What have we done to fit the Indian for the vocation to which he is entitled? We
should direct our attention to the study of the Indians. We have more Indians than we are doing today and I hope that during the coming year a great and concerted effort will be made to make those Indians part and parcel of our modern civilization a part which they do not hold at the present time.

Mr. KEDDLE: I have a long letter concerning the dismissal without notice of Mr. W. Edwards. Is the minister in a position to make a statement as to why this man was dismissed?

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): I believe my department received a letter from my hon. friend. I made inquiries, and as a result I find that there statements were made to the effect that there was an undischarged bankrupt. The claim was made that the Indians owed him money, which claim I believe has been satisfied. The principal however was that the man was not fit and capable to carry out his duties, and for that reason was not employed longer.

BUSINESS OF THE HOUSE

SITTING THIS DAY AFTER ELEVEN O'CLOCK—

SITTING ON ASCENSION DAY

Right Hon. W. L. MACKENZIE KING (Prime Minister): I wish to move that this house do not adjourn at eleven o'clock to night.

Mr. BENNETT: We should have a definite statement as to when the house will rise. We had difficulty on one occasion in connection with that matter and it is better to have a definite statement at the place of eleven o'clock rather than to proceed immediately and then have difficulty.

Mr. MACKENZIE KING: My hon. friend and other members of the house are no doubt aware of the importance of Ascension day, and that in the past it has not been customary for this house to sit on that day. It has not been customary either for the last May As it has been sitting since that day and are now doing our utmost to get through with the business of parliament as rapidly as possible. It might be convenient if all of us were present only for two sittings tomorrow instead of three as we are doing at present. In that way we would leave the morning free to meet at some afternoon. Mr. FANSHER (Late Member): I want to bring to the attention of the minister the matter of some Indian accounts. In some instances in the province of Saskatchewan Indians submit their claims to the farmers and purchased seed grain, feed oats hay for horses and in some instances cattle. In some cases these people have received full pay, but in others they have not received anything. I brought this matter to the attention of the minister last year, and my remarks are recorded at pages 380 and 380s of unrecorded Hansards. Among other things the minister said:

In every case where he is able to prove such an order we are prepared to settle, and in some cases where the evidence is clear that the transaction actually took place and that the minister is prepared to pay the claim, we will try to make an adjustment.

It seems to me that some provision should be made by legislation or parliament to pay these accounts when the agents get seed grain or feed from farmers. I hope the minister will see that these accounts are paid this summer.

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): All I can say is that we do recognize the orders of the agents, but we do not pretend to recognize trading done with Indians unless by the
authority of the agents. We have had a great deal of difficulty in settling up old accounts which have dragged on for many years; many of the obligations in this respect occurred during and just after the war. I think, however, with the exception of just one or two at Tisdale, where we have paid most of these accounts, and the crop on the Blood reserve this year will no doubt clear up a very heavy indebtedness which exists there. Mr. FANSHER (Last Mountain): Am I to understand that it is not the intention of the department to take care of these accounts at all until such time as the money comes from crops belonging to the Indians themselves?

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): No, that is not what I want my hon. friend to understand. As far as possible we want to avoid taking money from our Indian account for purposes of paying these amounts. In the case of the Blood Indians there is about $50,000 owing, a very large amount, and I am informed that this year their crop will clear up these accounts. In some cases we have had accounts long overdue and he had to vote the money to pay for them. Mr. FANSHER (Last Mountain): I should like the minister to understand also that it has not been his task for these men to carry these accounts for many decades and some of them for very large amounts. The farmer, thinking he was going to get his pay in the near future, let go of a valuable liquid asset and so has not received his money. We cannot now afford to make a loan to the department which would enable these legitimate accounts to be paid. They should be paid and it would not take a great deal of money and it would relieve a great deal of hardship among the farmers who have been carrying these accounts for a long time.

I may say frankly, if Anglo-Saxons wish to rent the land they would certainly have the privilege, but I do not know that they should have the ground and I would absolutely refuse to lease lands to orientals unless that were a general policy in British Columbia and then, of course, we would acquiesce in it. Mr. McQUARRIE: The minister says that the orientals take good care of the land. Perhaps the minister does not know. As a matter of fact the orientals do just the opposite; they use up the land. fess we are not anxious to sell Indian lands,

them and they are of any particular
value for agricultural purposes, they are
usually sold or put under leasehold. Use is
being made of them in some cases, but the
Indians of course receive the benefit of the
receipts from the leases, and in this way we
are assisted in carrying on the Indians.

Indian lands; we believe there is little enough land

Mr. STEWART (Edmonton): What we are doing—and we are trying to extend it—is to provide a suitable remedy to build extensions to these institutions, and they are operated as Indian annexes.
