WHAT WILL YOU DO WITHOUT HIM?

FRANCIS RIDLEY HAVergal.

I could not do without Him!
Jesus is more to me
Than all the richest, fairest gifts
Of earthly life can be.
But the more I find Him precious,
And the more I find Him true,
The more I long to find
What He can be to you.

Why will you do without Him?
Is He not your Guide?
Did He not die to save you?
Is He not all you need?
Do you not want your Master?
Do you not want a Friend?
One who will love you faithfully,
And know you to the end?

What will you do without Him
When death is drawing near,
With His own deathless love,
That casts out every fear?
When the shadow-valley opens
Its gloomy, silent door,
And the terrors of its darkness
Must all be passed o'er?

What will you do without Him
When He has shut the door,
And you are left outside because
You came too late before?
When it is no use knocking,
No use to stand and wait;
For the words He spoke to your heart
Then terrible "Too late!"
You cannot do without Him!
There is no substitute,
By which you ever can be saved,
No hope, no cheer,
Without Him there is no way
Of love and life and joy.
Without Him there is nothing woeful
And everlasting night.

Why should you do without Him?
It is not too late;
He has not closed the day of grace,
He has not shut the gate.
He calls you by His name,
He calls you!
He would not have you go
Another step without Him,
Because He loves you so.

What will you do without Him?
When the great white throne is set,
And the Lord Himself can mistake
And never can forget—
The Judge whom you have never here,
As Friends of God's dear Son,
Shall summon you to give account
Of every word and thought.
You need not do without Him,
For life is just by Him,
He is ready to be gracious,
Only waiting for your cry.
He is anxious to receive you—
To make you His own—
Why will you do without Him?
And wander on alone?

"I am not the sparrow sold for two farthings and no one of them is forgotten before God; but every hair of your head is all numbered. Fear ye not therefore; ye are of more value than many sparrows." (Luke xii. 6, 7.)

I'm only a little sparrow,
A bird of low degree;
My life is of little value,
But the dear Lord cares for me.

He gives me a coat of feathers—
It is very plain I know,
But it is a special crown
For it is not made for show.

But it keeps me warm in winter,
And shields me from the rain;
Were it bordered with gold and purple,
Perhaps it would make me vain.

And when the spring time cometh,
And the sun doth rise and set,
With many a chirp of pleasure,
In the spot I love the best.

I have no barn or storehouse,
Nor any place of rest;
God gives me a sparrow's portion,
And never a seed to keep.

If my meal is sometimes scanty,
Close feeding makes me sweet;
I have always enough to feed me,
And life is more than meat.

WAITING FOR JESUS

Waiting for Jesus, and loving while waiting,
Loving to speak for His honour and praise;
Loving to sit at His feet and adore Him,
Loving to ponder His words and His ways.

Waiting for Jesus, and praying while waiting,
E'er in communion with Him I adore;
E'er at the footstool of mercy imploring
Showers of blessing on all from above.

Waiting for Jesus, and serving while waiting,
Serving—and oh! what a Master to serve!
Helping, rewarding, and cheering in labor;
Oh that my heart from Him never may swerve!

Waiting for Jesus, and praising while waiting,
Praising in action, in word, and in song;
Oh! it is sweet to be ever rehearsing
Strains which eternity will but prolong.

Waiting for Jesus, and daily expecting,
Gazing to catch the first beams in the sky;
Oh what a moment 'tis quickly approaching,
Moment of triumph, of rapture, and joy!

We hear and read a great deal of discussion, today, about the proper and most helpful observance of the Sabbath in our homes. We have moved from the old-time severity of the Puritans toward a lack of regard for the Sabbath—a lack of regard and respect for the day that is really a serious matter. While it is possible to say that the religion of the Puritans was hard and unattractive to children and young people, it is nevertheless true that their disciplinary effect was good, for in those days children grew up to become God-fearing and God-fearing citizens. Some of their remedies would be of necessity be impractical now, but may we not strive to make a happy medium in the observance of the Sabbath, that will somewhat harmonize with changed conditions, and yet help our youth to understand that it is God's Day?

Let us make it a day when the intimacies of the family circle are the sweetest and most precious, when the help and inspiration of the sanctified are most needed, hampered by thoughts of the toil of yesterday or fear of the coming tomorrow; when the best books are read, and the most holy deeds performed. The centenary of one of our most important schools falls during the coming year, and, as a matter of historical interest in connection with the development of the work of Indian education, the following short history of the Mohawk Institute has been prepared by the Superintendent of Indian Education:

THE MOHAWK INSTITUTE
During the year, 78 residential schools and 272 day schools were in operation, a total of 350 centres of Indian educational activity. The total enrolment was 15,743 and the average attendance, 11,579 - a percentage of attendance of 73.55. The enrolment for the year is the largest and the attendance the highest yet reached. Ten years ago, the average attendance was 7,649, and it is gratifying to note that the increase since that time is over 50%. In Part II of this report will be found a tabular statement, showing the location and indicating the attendance at all Indian schools.

The same number of residential schools were in operation last year and the results have been very encouraging. Vocational training is possible at these boarding schools and the Department continues to emphasize this important phase of the work. Mention should be made of the rapid development of technical education in British Columbia - made possible by special funds which have been provided for the purpose. In Ontario and the Prairie Provinces, emphasis is placed on farming, gardening and the care of stock.

The co-operation of the churches in the management of these residential schools was as follows:

Two new day schools were established where there was promise of real usefulness. On many reserves, the Indian schools now secure as good attendance and results as rural white schools. Provincial curricula for public and separate schools are followed and fully qualified teachers are engaged.

All Indian schools were regularly inspected by officers of the Department. Particular attention is paid to the general management, condition and care of property, vocational training and the health of the pupils. In addition, provincial school inspectors visited all classrooms and reported on the academic work, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, where there were special Indian school inspectors.

It is with much regret that the Department reports the death of the Sister Superior and 12 children when fire destroyed the main building at the Cross Lake Indian Residential School, in northern Manitoba. Renewed efforts have been made in the matter of fire prevention and protection and all principals of residential schools
have again been instructed to examine fire fighting equipment and escapes and to practise fire drill regularly. Fireproof construction is now being used in all new buildings where there are children's dormitories and at all schools the Department has provided adequate fire fighting equipment and escape facilities.

New main buildings were commenced during the year at four residential schools - Brandon, Man., (Brandon); Punnichy, Sask., (Gordon's); Gleichen, Alta., (Old Sun's); Grouard, Alta., (St. Bruno's). In addition, the Department assisted the respective church authorities with the reconstruction of new buildings at Beauval, Sask., Wabasca, Alta., and Providence, N.W.T. The new buildings at Alert Bay, B.C., and Kenora, Ont., (Cecilia Jeffrey), were completed and furnished during the year.

The buildings for the new Maritime Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie, N.S., have also been completed and furnished. This institution is for orphan and neglected children and for those who are unable, for one reason or other, to obtain an education at the reserve day schools. It already gives promise of much usefulness to the Indians of the Maritime Provinces. At 8 Indian day schools in Canada, new classrooms or teachers' residences were erected.

The practice of assisting the most promising and industrious graduates of Indian schools was continued. Approximately 160 young Indian men and women were helped to continue their studies or to establish homes. Except in those Indian communities where successful farming is found, the school graduate presents a problem which is very difficult of solution. The Department and the churches interested are trying new schemes and searching for better methods of helping the young people to establish themselves.

In the past, the funds of certain Indian bands were used to meet some of the costs of conducting day schools on their reserves. The year under review is the second that all expenditure has been provided by Parliamentary Appropriation. The programme of free education is now extended to all Indians in Canada. The Place of the Day School in Indian Education

By F. Earl Anfield, Principal Inian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C.

It was the writer's privilege recently to pay a visit to several of the more northern villages from which our children are drawn to this residential school, and most gratifying indeed were the impressions gained. A tremendous improvement is to be noted in type and condition of homes, and in every case by one Indian people, although perhaps there is a tendency to build on rather too pretentious a scale. However, such is a good fault. The villages visited were well informed and clean, and although the fishermen had not had an too prosperous a year, there was noticeable a feeling and sense of well-being. Through the good-will of the Indian Department and an earnest desire on the part of the people of our northern villages are now equipped with satisfactory water supplies, and if the large washings displayed on the clothes line were any sign those supplies were being well used.

As seems so usual in our Indian village life, the attraction of many seemed to centre around the Church, and there was strongly evident a desire on the part of the Indian people to make of their Church a real centre to the corporate and spiritual life of the village. In one centre, Bella Bella, the Indians, the people who are largely engaged in building a Church Hall, all the lumber and labour being freely and cheerfully donated by the people. The Village Council arranged for the necessary materials for the workers, and it was pleasing indeed to see them working together after a hard morning's work, and to hear them discuss how they were going to use the work of their creation after its completion.

Talking of Village Councils, it would be well in my opinion if this movement were extended to more villages and also if the power of the Council were made a little more concrete. In one village the writer passed at the Council's Notice Board, and read therein an earnest request from the Council that better attendance take place in the day school; on another a notice stating that the curfew law was to be enforced, all with the signature of the Chief Councillor. There is need indeed of more of enforcing such orders by the Council themselves.

This brings me to the chief subject of this little article. The Indian Day Schools visited were, without exception, well built, well equipped, and, best of all, in the hands of quite willing and enthusiastic teachers. I wish most strongly to stress the fact that by these noble workers, often in the loneliest and most disheartening places, is being performed a task that is heroic to a degree. In the latest report we find that the total enrolment of the day schools of this province is 1,267, whilst the average attendance is only 604, whilst the Residential Schools, with a total of 1,585, have an average of 1,375. In the former case less than 50 per cent, and the latter almost 88 per cent. Is it any wonder that the day school teachers get discouraged; can we not see why it is so difficult to get pupils to go into the schools and discouraging conditions? And then, to crown it all, along comes the Residential Schools and take away the best of the children to the larger centres. As one teacher put it, "We want the children to try and attend regularly, and they are the ones you come and take just as we are getting them somewhere." Or, to quote another—"The children feel that they do not need to attend regularly as some of them think that as soon as they get to ten or eleven years of age they are off to the Residential School in any case." This attitude was found in the minds of the parents in every centre visited, and it is a fatal weakness among the Indians at any rate if the day school is to be made the power it should be in village life. The parents must be educated to the all-important fact that continued success and an increasing standard, is contingent upon the facilities offered by the Day Schools of our Indian villages. I tried to impress on them the fact that if the Day Schools were properly supported by the parents, there would be no need for the removal of children from our residential schools, with a consequent increase of scope for the pupils, as the money and teachers at present used in primary work could be diverted to other classes, and further that if the day schools were successful, then the number of problem cases in the large schools would be greatly lessened, as the day school will have shown the defects so often remedial if caught in time. Neither should be forgotten the value of the day school in an attempt in introducing of Indian children to the routine and life of the larger schools. To sum up briefly, the following points must be emphasized greatly if the Indian Day School is to come into its proper and most valuable sphere:

(1) An educational propaganda must be carried on extensively among the parents to convince them of the value of their day schools, as the foundation schools for the education of their children.

(2) A far more rigid enforcement of the Indian Act with regard to school attendance must be carried out.

(3) The curriculum of the Day School must be adapted to allow of more specialization in primary work.

(4) A move in the right direction would be that the residential schools should demand from the parents a pass certificate from primary to Grade I, with a satisfactory attendance record at an Indian Day School, before applications will be accepted.

In closing let us give honour to those faithful teachers who, in face of real difficulties and often harshship and neglect are holding the line of Indian education. God bless them, cheer them, and comfort them, in the realization that their labour is not in vain.
The today and tomorrow of the Indian Child.

Education-

The Educational and Civic training system of the Dept of Indian Affairs working in conjunction with the several Churches is today rapidly approaching perfection.

The magnificent new residential schools finished, under construction and in contemplation will, in the course of a few years, complete homes of early and adolescent training covering every sphere of education from moral to technical and in which every child between the ages of 10 and 16, who passes the doctors medical examination, will have access.

These large commodious residential schools are a wonder and a source of jealousy to the white population. Many times when one has been busied showing a visitor over the school, the conversation winds up with the words "this is marvellous, I wish my child could be an Indian for 10 years of his or her life." The Department of Indian Affairs has indeed a reason to be proud of their late accomplishments, and the Churches have indeed a reason to be thankful to the Department at Ottawa for its keen foresight, sympathy and adherence for and to a policy even surpassing dreams of ten years ago. The Churches now are obliged to put forth every effort to keep faith with the Fathers who have realized in their outlook that, first suitable and modern buildings must be provided which should be the foundation institutions of future learning for generations of their wards. Then cheerfully with the spirit of highest faith handed over the keys to the Churches expecting these institutions to be religious as well as technical training to the young Indian life of British Columbia.

Everywhere in beautiful settings and surroundings these institutions must breed in the child a system of character building comparative only with the pureness of the natural beauty and grandeur generated and created by a God of Love who is seen in and throughout yet immanent in all the child's eye beholds and should hear of from those in charge and to whom the Department of Indian Affairs have so nobly almost without reserve handed over to care for and in which to bring up in the way they should go, those who are their dependants.

With this generosity goes every sympathy, intertwined with an expectancy of such development that will eventually absorb the Indian race into the body politic and thus cultivate independent citizens who will prove worthy of the expenditure and the unwavering foresight of the Department together with the faithful and patient work of the Churches through their workers are so nobly moulding upright, fair and honorable lives in those younger Indian people.

The New Schools open up many advantages of training. While the class room covers the entire Provincial Curriculum and a child has the option of advancing side by side with his white brother even to matriculation standard. On the other hand the child is trained in first aid, care of babies, elementary nursing, manual training developing into full fledged journey men's engine work essential today for every boy to know, general agriculture on a scientific basis, whereas excepting for the larger centres, the white child is obliged to resort to Red Cross and other philanthropic societies as well as instructors salaried by the government to give whatever routine instruction can be given under existing circumstances.

Truly the Indian Child is a favored individual and sometimes one wonders whether the race on the whole appreciates what is being done, but those only who are workers in the field can vouch for that spirit as exhibited in the return of the fruit of their labors as they sojourn among those who have been through their hands. The advancing strides have been a marvel and the present system of education in vogue, this advance should hereafter be more visible and convincing as the years go by.

The child is growing in mind and maturing in physique. He shows marked ability and in not a few cases this is shown extraordinary aptitude in every Dept. of his training especially in the technical work so lately established. In some cases one finds themselves forced by the brightness of mind and anxiety exhibited by the
child, to carry on into advanced work. Students are asking for high school education some looking forward to scientific training. This spirit must not be discouraged as it is a self-centered force having in itself tendency towards the rapid growth and wider advance of the race as a whole. One finds individual parental interest in their offspring and also an individual reserve claiming the glory of a child's advance, developing into Band accepting or Iau reis. The Indian as a rule is docile and Stoical retaining his expressions of delight only exhibiting same in close intimacy bordering secrecy. The old Boys and Girls are becoming more outspoken regarding their children's advance and welfare.

Let me say a word for the Indian Day School. The work in this branch of the Department's system of education is largely a preparatory course for entrance to the Residential Schools. Feeders one might term them. The idea is a very good one and the policy every where should be to have properly certificated teachers specialized in Language and Kindergarten work.

While a great sacrifice is made by teachers in the main, it would seem that everything is not brought to bare on the Indian parent in the necessity of regular attendance as the average is very low and such is not conducive to good work by the teacher nor is the child properly fitted to enter the Residential School. I have found that children entering at having five years experience in day schools are not good grade two pupils. Others have come registering grade four and were obliged to be taken back to grade two. This factor cannot be placed on the teacher but rather on the reticence of the parent in keeping his child in regular attendance. In comparing the average attendance of the Day School with that of the Residential one finds a great difference showing that something should be done together more regular attendance if they are to play the part the Department expects of them; else the first three or four years of the child's educational life is lost. This the child cannot afford for he has to begin with in the majority of cases a two year language handicap to overcome before anything can be done in grade work.

As mentioned above there are a number of children forcing the schools for higher education and are asking to be fitted for special training. While I do not advocate a wholesale advance I cannot discourage the child who has the ability, self-foresight and cohesiveness, as these must be taken on and for the time being will have to be absorbed by the Department in the different Sub-Departmental positions to which they may qualify. A Boy may wish to take Medicine and in case he makes good his qualifications, work for him can be found among his own people. The same applying to the Nurse or Teacher or in Agricultural pursuits. This condition is rapidly approaching and provision will have to be made for it.

This brings me to the to-morrow of the child. I have endeavored to describe the system of modern training now in vogue among our Indians but of what use is all this? Some ask, Will the child follow up his or her training or they revert? This depends upon a number of vital questions, some of which has to be proven by the Indian child now grown up, and some will depend upon the policy adopted for his absorption.

The growing tendency of the Indian towards responsibility is fast becoming his asset and is leading him to a state of independence. Here-tofore he was classed as a thriftless, irresponsible species of manhood. This trait is born in him and it is not an easy task for him to cast away inheritance. He is beginning to realize that his own making or breaking lies within himself and that to depend on outside assistance alone will soon drive him into vagrancy becoming a fit subject for the grasp of the law. He is fast realizing that he cannot anymore roam the hills to search for game and to kill without reserve, nor can he fish the streams without restriction and is applying himself to responsibility in labor. He sees that he must be prepared to shoulder the burden of responsibility a position of labor will place upon him. No more can he work when he likes and lazily lie around for a period. He also finds that with responsibility comes a peaceful un-
disturbed life, a respectable home and family and steady employment. This tendency is more marked in those who have been through the schools where responsibility is taught and driven home in every way. Once he has grasped this spirit of responsibility and has shown aptness in application he is rated as one of the best by his employers. I have heard railway men say that the Indian when he will take care makes the best Section Foremen they have on the D.C. lines. Road Masters say that the best kept sections are now under Indians, which statement augurs well for the future of the race. I believe that given his opportunity this will apply to any class of employment.

Technical training now working factor in our schools will give the boy a feeling that when he graduates he will be equipped to take some responsibility which will in turn give him independence. Mechanical training in every line appeals to him. He is quick, apt and efficient with tools and will use his head to accomplish. He delights in being given an opportunity of exercising his own creative ability. He sees his own production and it results in him a something latent leading him on to greater activity and efficiency.

Efficiency and rapidity are watchwords today among employers and in Unions. The keen competition in the trades per force calls for efficiency and responsibility and that irrespective of race or creed. If therefore we can assure these requirements in our Indians, as I believe we can, and they measure up if given their opportunity, the Department of Indian Affairs will in the course of a few years be amply rewarded for the expenditure wrapped up in these schools and the Churches will rejoice in having expended work and patience in the years of training. Our work, God's work, rewarded in independent, law-abiding God-fearing people.

Protection from himself in his rapid advance, is something that must be taken care of by those in authority. The Indian is an adopted child and has realized and accepted protection, asking for it, cases where it should not be given. With the present day unrest and unemployment comes the tendency for Governments to protect and sustain, wherever possible, in employment those who to some degree return to them in taxation part of what is given to the taxable citizen, the Indian being a more or less free agent objects even to paying the poll tax. He asks for protection against same and gets it, which fact I think is not good for it carries with it the possibility of no employment when perhaps he could get it being at least a small donation to the public treasury. It also deprives him to a degree of the responsibility in his equipment.

This would also lead us to the Enfranchise which education and responsible Citizenship will give him. There are a great number of our Indians who are not in such a position as to be intelligent voters. In a few years time all will come under this recognition by our Governments. It would increase national interest and have a tendency to quicken his ability to cast off his Ward garments.

In absorption the utmost care should be exercised by those in charge of the educational problem of these people not to educate them away from themselves. The present half-breed situation—Indian and white—is not good. The half-breed children in the field are in constant contact with an appalling situation, not only in illiteracy but also in the fact that this inter class are neither whites nor Indians and are claimed by no one and in general useless and irresponsible. Care therefore should be taken to secure so this condition is still possible. This can be done by educating the two sexes on an equality. The natural tendency of humanity is to link up with his own standard in education. A Doctor will marry a nurse or a teacher, and so it runs throughout. Very rare is the occasion for one in either sex to marry illiteracy or lower his or her educational standards. The Indian is quite human in this respect. This difficulty therefore can be cured for by those in responsible for the upbringing of these school children and a great social difficulty in time eradicated.

The Indian mode of living and in most cases at the present has been and is a source creating a feeling of class distinction and it was only in the main a very low class of white man who would lower himself to live with an Indian woman. The consequence is that the last state is worse than the first, leaving behind
The Indian in his early life was a Nomad, he travelled, hunted man and beast, finding himself "Lord of all he surveyed". If he cared to own little on the land which was all his, very good but if not very good, however, the loss in the interior of B.C., he was and in a man of the land so it must be the policy of the authorities to see that he developed agriculturally. To-day this development is not very far from the primitive, only in its infancy and greater thought and greater strides will have to be taken and taken in this important regard.

British Columbia is a mixed farming province and if properly handled a family can make a good living on thirty acres of land, especially in the irrigated sections.

Following a scientific training, which in all Schools should be given, and which when a boy is graduated from the School, he will be able to carry on at his graduation in the same manner as he was taught in the School. He may be left behind with his knowledge and at his hand to work against the natural tendency of all life to hate and a boy under the control of his early teaching takes unto himself a wife whom he hopes to care for as a husband; he has been taught when a child to earn for the necessities of family difficulties of production and provision become greater, the boy finds that his little store is not sufficient well equipped nor is he capable in his primitive way to keep himself, his house, clothes and food.

Driven to the work he must find another or war in which to provide and very often he forced to become a soldier or is found by the law trying to make an unlawful living for himself and family using his education to further his interests. A man will into the hands of the law and as seven years term might be a period of his husband's forced separation the idea and desire to live in morality in order to take care of that child which is a blessing to any man or woman who in God's name have been joined to another. It is to prevent this catastrophe, the government should be made before him for the above mentioned, a community system should be advocated the Community System wherever possible. Graduates of the Schools should be given an opportunity to attend high schools, where they may catch up again to that they could before and carry on where they left off at the end of their School days.

Government on a Community basis where a number of families could be supervised as one unit, this would give the Board of Education a better opportunity to follow up their boys and girls. The Department would also be able to give closer and more intelligent supervision. The church also would find it much less difficult to continue in every way the early instruction spiritually of the child. In a word it would make possible the Departments policy and success would be attained by working in conjunction with the several Churches.

The early environment of the "potlatch" is still a source of annoyance and children will vacate the Schools without leave in order to attend these modified old time gatherings. These are carried on at the time of death and again at the time of renovating their cemetery.

With the community system a hall could be built and used to offset this evil. It would also serve for community games and meetings. Competition should be fostered in games among communities. Recreation of all kinds could be supervised and many evils thereby taken care of.

Competition could be applied in agriculture with suitable prizes issued. Calf clubs could be organized. Judging classes carried on. Senior and junior herd sire sires could be kept and a general continued supervision having for its object the stabilization of the young population who are now wards of the Department.
Farms should be made interesting to the boy. Half-hearted or haphazard agricultural training should not be tolerated in the schools nor on the reserve. Scientific and intense training should be the slogan so far as it is possible to enter upon that training an international competition calls for thorough and intelligent work those who are going to make a success of any industry.

Science in an industry makes it interesting. No boy will take an interest in that which does not interest him; he will become its slave instead. The school therefore must foster, mould, and develop interest in the pupil and he must be taught to adapt himself to immediate and sectional surroundings.

Methods maintained and successful in the dry belt are not adapted in wet areas; methods adaptable in the interior are not a success at or in the coast schools. Judgment must be carefully meted out and the child brought up to conform with the development of the province in which he is to live and make a livelihood.

The tendency of the Indian today is to become an eight hour day man and get into the mechanical line. This tendency must be cultivated on the coast as it seems a workable and feasible proposition there because of the unlimited mechanical development but in the interior care must be taken to keep our Indians at home and in their proper environment industrially as well as physically. One would therefore advocate for the coast Indian a thorough mechanical training and for the interior Indian an intensive agricultural training his mechanical training materially helping him in the work.

Now this system of Community plantation would entail a great deal of thought and a fairly large expenditure. The situation of land would have to be considered in the beginning as the irrigation problem is one not easy to overcome and good judgment in choice would have to be exercised.

Considering the expenditure I would not advocate giving this modernly built and equipped community over to the Indian Boys without some reserve. They should be made responsible for the investment the investment and also make a small payment each year on the principle which would return in time the initial expense. A boy after being given a trial and found wanting should be changed for more showing of responsibility. The Boys thus placed should not be given complete control of their individual property except in so far as it is his upon which to make a success and when it is considered he has made payment equal to the expenditure the property would become his so long as he used it to the satisfaction of those in supervision. It would be his but he would be unable to rent or sell and would be property to be perpetuated to generations.

I have had long talks with Boys and Girls already graduated and who have stated that they would be glad to enter upon any contract reasonable feeling that they could make good, maintaining that at present they could not get a start and the initial handicap was of life long duration.

I have no hesitancy in saying that this plan of settlement would soon become a source of joy to all concerned. The average Indian Boy and Girl realizes what responsibility is and will take it when given.

It is true there are still many who know nothing only to live a thriftless irresponsible life, living in the main upon a horse's back, gambling away his best friend—his horse—saddle and saddle blanket when meeting another of the same calibre, yet even this could be corrected by the close supervision available on the Reserve in community system, or leaving such to their own fate would soon bring them back to lead a responsible life adopting the plan mapped out for them.

I would like very much to see a plan of this type tried out and would be glad to offer suggestions or assist in any way. It has been a source of careful thought to me. I am interested in the children and also interested in the relation the Department holds to them and would like to see some plan worked out so that graduates of these interior Schools would become in the course of time, the length of time depending upon the individual Boy and his ability to make a success, independent citizens holding and
maintaining the same rights and privileges of any prosperous citizen of the Dominion. I feel an investment of that sort would avail much and would be a concrete proposition. It would return in time money well spent initially with no maintenance other than official supervision which largely could be done by those already in the field through condensation of work brought about by its introduction, instead of being spread over wide areas as it is at the present time.

The system would eradicate many old evils and traditions by segregation of the young placing among them some of the older Indians who are anxiously looking forward to the time when their affliction of tradition, thriftlessness and irresponsibility will be a story for perpetuation instead of a reality still existing in a small but determined way.

There still exists many handicaps but these would be a minus quantity in a short time. The present hand-to-mouth existence is not conducive to results in a manner calling for a rapid turnover, but given a working opportunity the Indian Boy and Girl of today will quickly adapt themselves to new spurs onwards, new possibilities and would accept an opening which would allow them to carry on according to the teaching given in the Residential Schools. The pupils themselves would see a future ahead and the worker, especially the heads of these institutions would feel that although the children were leaving their childhood home they would not be lost directly they passed out of the School door at graduation.

The Indian Residential School of today is only a first step towards stabilization; the work in them must be followed up close till and money are lost. Results accomplished in them would otherwise be of no avail with no return for expenditure.

I could enlarge upon the many evils which surround the Child at his graduation but sufficient it would seem to plan away of escape and materialize same so that the beginning of escape so well established in the Schools will not be lost by having the child return to his former foes.

The Residential Schools should be the hub around which the present and future life of the Indian child is moulded. His future depending upon himself in ability and responsibility and also upon the opportunity he's given to exercise his early childhood and adolescent training.

I trust that the above will be of some benefit towards the future Educational life and civil establishing of the Indian Child.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith Indian Agent Gordon's report on the Norway House Agency for the month of August.

After reading this report, and from what I know after having visited the reserve, I am satisfied in my own mind that the Indians are going to have a hard time of it. The problem at Norway House, Berens River, and in fact all the reserves bordering on the Lake, is a very difficult one to solve. At best, these Indians only eke out a hand to mouth existence, and now that there is only a limited amount of fishing carried on, what is there left for them to do? We have had extensive fires and the game is disappearing, and we cannot raise stock nor grain, so that the only solution is to feed these Indians or else move the younger Indians out to the prairies after they graduate from school. This is one reason why I have always thought the Department should give consideration to the matter of bringing the children from those northern points out to the schools on the prairies, and after they graduated many of them would not return to the north. I think it is a great mistake building large schools up in the north; to take a child at seven years of age and keep him in school until he is eighteen, means that he is unfit to carry on a life of hunting, even if there were anything to hunt. The problem is one that should receive very serious consideration. A number of pupils have been brought out from the north to the schools at Brandon and Teckum, and have since found their places on the prairies and are doing very well indeed. Many of the girls are married to white men, are raising families and sending their children to school. They are living like prosperous white people. Whereas had they remained in the north they would be living in a state of near starvation, which I think goes to show that the proper thing to do is to educate them out on the prairies, which gives them a chance to assimilate with white people or to settle on reserves where they can make a living.

Education of Indians

The report to hand of the provisions for education of Indian children who are wards of the Dominion Government, indicates that so far as the buildings and staff are concerned Canada is not saving money at the expense of the "papoosees." There are now 78 residential, and 276 day schools with nearly 16,000 pupils in attendance. The residential schools the report states are conducted by the Anglican, Roman Catholic, Presbyterian, and United churches, while the public ones provided by the Government and in this connection it should be noted that Manitoba has now two new ones, one already erected at Brandon and one in process of building at Birtle. The amount spent on Indian education in the fiscal year ending March 31, 1929, was $2,215,412.

Side by side, however, with these handsome residences there is arising at least some volume of criticism, not as to the amount of money Canada is spending on these children, nor as to the amount of effort being put forward by the schools, but as to the ultimate results. Canada is making an effort to pay her debt to her first settlers, but are the results at all commensurate with that effort? In other words are large, modern, electrically-machine-equipped schools ideal or even sensible educational plants for children whose tradition and mode of life are far removed from such accessories?

There is a body of opinion which claims that not only is this education not an advantage, but that it is a detriment and since this opinion comes from persons in close touch with the situation and the "gooseies," perhaps it might be well for those in charge of Indian education to become aware of it. It is claimed that these children brought up in these residences go back to their reserves where the conditions are so vastly different from those of the school, that handicapped already by a nature which does not lend itself to over-exertion and by the hopeless breach of environment, they rapidly sink back and in a year or so have successfully eradicated all the veneer which the white man's well-intentioned efforts have conferred upon them. But the years learning these things to forget have not taught them the things which they might have learned in their own tradition of life.

Supporting this contention are the reports of the tuberculosis organizations which point to the fact that the tuberculosis among Indians as one of the causative factors of the high death rate. If the Indians could be made to realize as they are supposed hopefully to do, to keep a sanitary house and to eat rather than that go to forward the cause of health, there would be a better record, or at least a record more liable to suppose that there would be.

On the other side, however, is the report of the Census authorities which goes forth that during the past decade the area of land under cultivation by the people increased from 172,195 to 322,751 acres, and that the total income has jumped up from $1,000,000 to $9,745,576. A fairly encouraging record when it is remembered that the population is practically stationary.

However desirable it might be the Indians cannot go back to the ways of his ancestors. He must live, if he is to survive, within reasonable distance of the white man's standards. Canada has a good record of her treatment of these people. Her records are still good so that good intentions go. But there does seem to be some room for opinion that the type of approval of the results of the education which is being provided, not with regard to whether it is such provision but that if necessary it may be better adapted to the pupil and to the life from which he came and to which he will return.
FRANCIS H. GISBORNE
K.C.150.D.C.L.

The Education of the Indians in Canada

Great advancement has been made in Canada, particularly of late years, in providing our Indian population with a high standard of education and vocational training. Increased appropriations by Parliament have made possible the construction of new modern schools and the enlargement of existing buildings which have attracted more highly qualified teachers.

There are now 350 centres of Indian education, attended by over 15,000 pupils, ample evidence of the success of the work in preparing Indian children to become independent and self-supporting citizens of the Dominion.

In its work for the education of the Indians the Department of Indian Affairs has had close cooperation of religious denominations, which well-established policy has demonstrated beyond all question of doubt the effectiveness of the system.

The latest addition to the residential schools for Indians is the one opened in September, Manitoba last summer, which is the first of its kind in Canada. It is provided with dormitories, class rooms, study rooms, recreation rooms, sunroom, hospital ward and laundry. Adjacent to the school are a number of fine farm buildings. These residential schools are required owing to the scattered locations of the reserves and also because the occupations of the Indians take them away from their homes.

The curriculum provides academic instruction equivalent to the second year in high school. In addition, the girls are given a thorough course in domestic science and the boys a course in agriculture together with an elementary training in carpentry and such other trades as will be of use to them when they leave school.

While every possible effort is made to impart a sound academic and industrial education, special attention is given to the health of the students to assist in the building up of a robust constitution.

Under the care and tutelage of the Department of Indian Affairs the practical Indians now have a successful agriculturist. Official records for 1928 show that 65,104 acres in the Prairie Provinces were sown to grain from which were garnered millions of bushels. In addition thousands of bushels of root crops, hay and other fodder were produced.
The wireless operator on board the Alice Lacey only tuned in the National transmitter. A hideous creaking jarred on ear and mind, his wife, and through it, the Voice emerged in the middle of a sentence.

"I have one S.O.S."

The wireless operator listened idly. The floor of the little cabin rose and fell monotonously as the trawler Alice Lacey fought her way through the restless sea. The cabin was a maze of net, full of bewildered and indignant fish. "Will James Andrews — A.N.R.E.T. — be able to reach the trawler Alice Lacey, at present fishing somewhere in the North Sea, please inform me once more how well his wife is?" And the voice sank to nothing under a fresh onslaught of squall and a violent sea weather. The message was not repeated.

A little switch clicked under the wireless operator's hand. He slipped off the headphones.

Heavy feet stamped overhead. "Andrews—what a coincidence!" He went up the darkened ladder. Bert, in slippers, was coming down the stairway. The wireless operator called, "Bert!"

"Bert, I've just picked up a call—S.O.S—for Jim Andrews. He's got to go home at speed. His wife is—and there's something else. The rest of the message had been smothered under atmospheric interference. 'Get hold of him,' said the Voice."

The man rebuttoned the neck of his slacks and ran up the stairway. His wet back glistened in the lamplight. The wireless operator took off the headphones. The bows of the Alice Lacey thundered into the roar of waves as he burst them into clouds of breath-catching spray which drenched the man's neck and drenched his soul, all at once. "Where's Andrews? Where's hell's Andrews? Wanted, here..."

And presently, Andrews came in. He drew up in the little wireless cabin to get confirmation of the words bawled into the air by the Voice. He was listening to the results of the day's play in the League matches.

"Aye," said Grandfather Bill. "A very awful groan was wrung from him. Then a huge hand on his shoulder shook him roughly and the headphones slipped over his face.

"Hello, Andrews..." This is good ten." Tom Chedder, just beginning to catch it. Something about your wife..."

"Mary..."

"I didn't hear the end of the message. But—well—" he dropped his eyes before the steady and rather stupid glare of the lamp. "You know those S.O.S.—generally sent when dangerously ill, don't they? I'm sorry old man..."

"Mary..."

Andrews seemed to have rather thickened his receptive powers. Then, "Dangerously ill? What do you mean?"

"The S.O.S on the wireless, man!" The wireless operator's voice sounded impatient, though he looked curiously at Andrews.

"Aye, of course." Andrews put out his hand. "What made you come home so sudden?"

"Someone sent for me on—"

"And right in the middle of that sentence he stopped speaking. For all his mannerisms, with extraordinary vivacity, the wireless operator of the Alice Lacey was speaking again those half-heeded words.

"Mary..."

"Mary..."

Andrews sank into a chair, and covered his face with his hands. All that he had gone through—the shocking news, the night race with its hope and fear, misery and death—now this did surprise; all he had gone through overcame and overwhelmed him, and his spirit gave way.

The woman came a few paces towards him, and stood looking at him. "Jim," she said, faintly. "I didn't know you were here."

He looked up. He still could not believe that it was his wife, alive and well, standing there, back-forth because of the tears in his eyes. He began to struggle with his feelings because he could not trust himself to speak just yet. As he did so, he saw the partly-packed suitcase lying open on the floor; his clothes were laid out over the back of a chair—ready. The woman closed her eyes. He put away his hand slowly.

"What's this, Mary?"

Only her eyelids tightened away, Mary?"

Dear Brother Francis:

I have given your letter of recent date considerable thought, so that I would know how I could best assist you in the preparation of your thesis on the Indian Schools of Alberta. The first suggestion that came to my mind was that you should examine the reports of this Department for the period 1975 - 1905, but I am unable to find that they have ever been sent to either the University of Alberta or to the Library at the Legislature. I therefore propose to give you some information in this letter. From this, suggestions will come to you, regarding the next step you should pursue.

At the present time, there are being conducted in Alberta 20 Indian residential schools, as shown on page 85 of our latest report, a copy of which is enclosed. One is missing from the list, and at the present time, it has been changed to day school activity, pending the completion of the new residential school main building. I refer to the Old Sun's institution, on the Blackfoot reserve, which is conducted by the Department and the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada. On page 81 you will note that in addition to the Sarcee Indian Day School, there is also one shown at Morley, but this is really an adjunct of the residential school there and need not be considered independently. Briefly, there are 20 Indian residential schools and one day school operating in the province. Strictly speaking, there are three other day schools which are really in Alberta, although we list them under Saskatchewan because they are in the Onion Lake agency. I refer to the schools at Cold Lake, Frog Lake and Long Lake. You will find these also on page 81. So that you will have a general understanding of the work that is being done, you might read the literary matter on page 13. This part of our latest report is rather brief, as I wanted some special room for the story of the Mohawk Institute, which commences on page 15. Day schools were conducted by the various churches in Alberta for some years before the Government gave any assistance. In some cases, they took a few pupils in residence. At the time of Confederation, there was practically no government organization or control of Indian schools in Alberta. Such as existed were supported for the most part by Missionary Societies, Religious Orders and the Indian Bands themselves.

About 1885, the Federal Government came to the rescue of the churches doing the work and gave to residential schools a per capita grant for current expenses. This grant has been increased from time to time and, at the present time, amounts to an average of about $170 per child per year, based on the actual average attendance. During the last 10 years, the Department has tried to undertake, not only the current expenses at Indian schools, but practically all of the capital expense as well. Before 1920, certain schools were assisted with their capital expense and other schools were erected entirely by the Government, but considerable church and missionary money was being used for the purpose. In the northern part of the province, this obtains to this day. The Roman Catholic and the Anglican Churches still have the major equity in the physical equipment. From Edmonton south, however, where there are situated the largest schools, the Government owns practically all the properties.

There is additional literary matter extracted from the reports of the various schools to be found on page 167. The expenditure will be found on page H56 (Auditor General's Report 1915-16) and the residential schools for Alberta, on page 47 for the industrial schools and page 49 for the boarding schools. I may state, at this time, that we no longer distinguish between boarding and industrial schools. They are all known as residential schools. Originally, there was a distinction. The Government established the industrial schools and the Church owned and conducted buildings were known as the boarding schools. Today, this distinction has disappeared, and the type of instruction in all residential schools is quite uniform.

Dear Father Langlois:

I have your letter of the 17th ultimo, with reference to the population of Indians in western Canada and the hope for their future. Generally speaking, the rapid decline in Indian population in Canada as a whole ended about 100 years ago. It is estimated that there were approximately 115,000 Indians in Canada in 1830. There was a slow decrease until the beginning of the 20th century, when the population was known to be roughly 105,000. During the past 30 years, the number of Indians has slightly increased. The best figures available at present are 108,000. In a few months, the results of the decennial census will be known and a very accurate figure can be given.

With particular reference to the Indians of western Canada, concerning whom your comments have occasioned surprise, for your information I compare the figures of 1912 and 1929.

|                | 1912   | 1929   |
|----------------|--------|--------|
| Manitoba       | 10,373 | 12,263 |
| Saskatchewan   | 9,545  | 10,784 |
| Alberta        | 8,113  | 9,846  |
| Northwest Territories | 5,262 | 4,615  |
| British Columbia | 24,781 | 25,107 |

These figures show that the Indians of the West have, to some degree, won an immunity from the white man's diseases that at first contact created such havoc. So, there is certainly considerable truth to your remarks.

As far as industry is concerned, there is no doubt that great strides have been made in the last 20 years in western Canada.

EDUCATION.

The educational work of the Department is increasingly important. There were in operation during the year 80 residential and 272 day schools; or 2 more residential schools than the previous year, and the same number of day schools. The enrolment increased from 15,743 to 16,415, and the average attendance, which is the important figure, from 11,579 to 12,231, an increase in one year of 5.63%. Further, pupils were more regular in attendance during 1930-31, the figure being 74.51% of the enrolment as compared with 73.55% for the previous year.

It may be of interest to briefly review the progress in Indian education during the past 50 years. The following table, with percentage increases for each decennial period, indicates the increasing importance of the work and shows that a very satisfactory step forward has been taken during the past 10 years.

Particularly gratifying is the improvement in the attendance regularity during the past decade. From 64.29% to 74.51% shows a remarkable awakening on the part of Indian communities and parents. In 1920, compulsory education of Indian children was provided by statute, and the Act is enforced, particularly when supported by the opinion of the most progressive Indians on a reserve. However, the main reason for improvement in attendance at Indian schools is a growing conviction on the part of our wards that their children must be better fitted for the future. Fewer and fewer natives are finding it possible to live by the chase and they are turning towards education to prepare themselves for encroaching civilization.

Those somewhat familiar with the educational work of the Department and the Churches may argue that the rapid increase in residential school attendance, which is naturally quite regular, is largely responsible for this improvement. It should be stated that
the residential school percentages of attendance have always been good and that practically the entire credit is with the pupils of day schools, who come so largely under the influence of their parents. The following tables show the residential and day schools separately for the past 40 years. Earlier figures distinguishing between the two types of school are not available and are not so valuable for purposes of comparison, as the work was hardly well established. As far as the residential schools are concerned, the figures for 1901 are really the first that should be considered. It will be noted that the percentage of attendance at residential schools has been quite constant for 30 years and that the improvement lies entirely with the day schools. In fact, for the past 10 years, the percentage of attendance for day schools has increased from 50.56 to 61.90—a greater improvement than that of all schools taken together.

During the year, there was a change made in the compulsory education clause in the Indian Act. It is now possible to compel the attendance of every physically fit Indian child between the full ages of 7 and 16 years, and, in very special cases, the Superintendent General may direct that a pupil be kept in school until he has reached the full age of 18 years. Of course, the usual practice at Indian residential schools is to encourage pupils to remain until they are 17 or 18.

In Part II of this report will be found tabular statements, showing the location, naming those in charge and indicating the enrolment and attendance at all Indian schools. Day schools on reserves, where our wards are permanently settled, quite properly are becoming increasingly important. Special efforts have been made during the year to increase the efficiency at those day schools where there is a large average attendance. Better qualified teachers are being engaged and modern texts and other instruments of instruction are being placed in their hands.

Generally speaking, residential schools enjoyed a particularly successful year. At these institutions, emphasis is placed on vocational training, religious instruction and the care of health. The various churches, as shown hereunder, cooperate

Indian schools follow the provincial curricula, but special emphasis is placed on language, reading, domestic science, manual training and agriculture. Frequent inspections are made by officers of the Department. In addition, public and separate school inspectors visit all classrooms, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, where there are special Indian School Inspectors.

During the year, new main buildings were completed at four residential schools - Brandon, Man. (Brandon); Punnichy, Sask. (Gordon's); Gleichen, Alta. (Old Suns); and Grouard, Alta. (St. Bruns). The buildings at the Birtle Indian Residential School in Manitoba; the Muscowequan Indian Residential School in Saskatchewan; and the Blue Quills Indian Residential School in Alberta had outlived their usefulness, and reconstruction was commenced during the year. There was also started a new main building at the Beauval Indian Residential School in Saskatchewan, which had been destroyed by fire in 1927. Grants were given to the church authorities towards the cost of important improvements at the Albany Indian Residential School, on James Bay, and the Providence Indian Residential School, in the North West Territories. Minor improvements were undertaken at several other residential schools and new classrooms were erected at a few day schools, where the work was well established.

The practice of assisting the most promising and industrious graduates of Indian schools was continued. Approximately 260 young Indian men and women were helped to continue their studies or to establish homes. Except in those Indian communities where successful farming is found, the school graduate presents a problem which is very difficult of solution. The Department and the churches interested are trying new schemes and searching for better methods of helping the young people to establish themselves.

CULTIVATING INDIAN IDEAS

There is a growing desire in the United States Indian department to follow the trend of the native mind in various essentials. It is being better realized that more latitude in the red man's home and economic life gives a better cultural showing, than to force upon him the white man's ways.

This has long been the Canadian point of view. Our Indian guardians have consistently followed the course of preserving the native atmosphere on the various Indian reserves, while useful educational instruction has not deprived our Indians of certain individual and traditional tendencies of value.

Indian boarding schools across the line are now recognizing craft schools, as a matter of conservation of native craft and artisanship of value. Boarding schools are being restricted to Indian pupils of more advanced age. There is a distinct attempt to revive knowledge of native arts and crafts by drawing on all of the schools. Native teachers are being encouraged.

This recognition of the Indian point of view arises out of the efforts of many devoted white men and women, who have been able to see the "other side" of so-called "Indian problems."
"The purpose of education for any indigenous peoples at the present day is to help these peoples, both as groups and as individuals, to adjust themselves to modern life, protecting and preserving as much of their own way of living as possible and capitalizing their economic and cultural resources for their own benefit and their contribution to modern civilization. The effort should begin with the Indian people in their own environment or in some comparable environment, in which they can develop their own resources. The Indian educational problem is to work over from a more or less conventional institution conception of education to one that is local and individual. Boarding schools should be for special purposes, at least partly vocational.

Utilize Indian arts and crafts wherever these exist or can be revived. Grasp opportunities to put Indian children into local public schools rather than into government boarding schools.

In the United States, they have appointed visiting teachers, who are really field matrons, for the purpose of coordinating home and school. (R.T.F.'s note - This language "Visiting teacher" suggests another type of employee, one who has been really successful and who has a broad viewpoint should be employed to supplement the work of the public and separate school inspectors. Such a worker would really be a junior Inspector of Indian Schools). In the States, State curricula are suggested for the Indian service as guides but are not slavishly followed.

"It is estimated that the same sum of money that is required for 100 children of elementary school age in a boarding school will provide an adequate educational programme, including necessary food, clothing and follow-up service, for at least half as many more if expended in the local community - and with better ultimate results. It is both better economy and better education to leave the children in their own homes. That the Indians themselves should be consulted regarding these and other plans for education of their children is axiomatic. We welcome signs of initiative on the part of Indians to work themselves free from dependence and take an interest in their own educational affairs."

In the United States, they are substituting the lure of good facilities, good personnel and need of education for the dragging-in method of enrolment.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

The latest census shows that there are 23,290 Indian children of school age. 16,400 are attending Indian schools and an additional 300 are being educated in white schools—a total of 16,700, or 71.7% of the total number of school age.

In the northern parts of Canada, there are approximately 3,835 Indian children of school age whose parents live by the chase, and schools for these would be very difficult to undertake, nor is it desirable that such children receive a white man's education at the present time. The present generation of these hunting and nomadic Indians of the North are better off if left alone. Their contact with whites is negligible.

Approximately 7½% of the Indian children of school age, numbering about 1,630, have no school facilities. It is timely now to consider extending our programme to embrace these, although there is no particular pressure being brought to bear upon the Department from the Indians themselves or from any other sources. Approximately 2½% of the Indian children of school age are delinquents. School facilities are available, but, for one reason or another, attendance has not been compelled in their case. This group is rapidly diminishing. The remainder, approximately 3½%, are physically or mentally unfit for an education.

To recapitulate:

- 71.7% - in school.
- 16.4% - school facilities not now desirable.
- 7½% - additional school facilities should be considered.
- 2½% - delinquents
- 3½% - unfit.

THE FIRST CANADIANS.

The impending resignation of Dr. Duncan Campbell Scott from the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa will create a vacancy in the highest important post. The distinguished poet has filled a key position in the Department for more than half a century. To select a successor for such an outstanding State servant would be a matter of nation-wide concern, and it is one which is of even more importance now. For it has become increasingly apparent in the past few years that Canada's whole relationship toward the Indians should be reviewed.

It is quite possible that the retirement of Dr. Scott will expedite an opportunity for reorganizing the Department and realigning the whole work of Indian welfare, on a scale inexpedient at other times.

The recent interviews and letters in The Globe from Mr. John Butterfield, a responsible and respected prospector in Northern Ontario, have at last drawn attention to the gravity of the allegations of Canadian officials against his charges. For if Mr. Butterfield's charges are true, Indians are not only living in an appalling state of semi-famine. They are not only suffering from the scourges of deadly disease. But they are also being subjected to destruction and physical affliction because—to use a blunt term—they have been "double-crossed" by His Majesty's Government in the Dominion of Canada.

If Mr. Butterfield's charges are true, the Indians are not getting the medical attention to which they are entitled, not only under the laws of common decency or humanity, but under the very letter of the supposedly solemn treaties which they were induced to sign.

If Mr. Butterfield were but one observer making rather sensational charges the tendency might be to brush them aside as isolated and but one lapse away from a mere local condition. But the fact is that Mr. Butterfield's charges are but substantiations of reports made by no less a noted public servant than Captain Roy Maxwell, Commissioner of the Department of Ontario. A few years ago Captain Maxwell had occasion to make an emergency flight into the Far North on a mission of mercy. He brought back a story of sickness and disaster tragic enough to stir the hardest hearts.

The essential point is that the Indians surrendered properties of enormous value for certain considerations. Money payments—small in comparison with the real value of the land—played their part. But the Canadian representatives of the King also promised the Indians certain services—medical attention and supplies.

Are these treaties being honored? Or are they being flouted like nine-tenths of all other treaties have been flouted by white men in their dealings with North American Indians?

Perhaps Tecumseh was right when he made those speeches as eloquent as any that ever came from the lips of Lincoln or Laurier. The great Indian chieftain convinced the confederacy which he bound together by sheer force of his own marvellous personality that the last hope of the American Indians lay in the union of all of the tribes. Thus Through Yet Tecumseh himself lived to pour scorn on the British General who failed to honor his own King's agreement with the Indian leader and whose cowardice was partly responsible for Tecumseh's death.

The history of the century following Tecumseh's death is not such as to shed lustre on Canada's treatment of the Indians. Indian relations became the sole responsibility of the National Government after the days of Confederation. Yet Governments of all parties came and went, and the Department of Indian Affairs was regarded, by whatever party happened to be in power, as just another necessary function.

If there is any censure to be levied as a result of this state of affairs, it should not be placed on the Departmental officials. If the true story could be told it would probably be found that the politicians—politically or unpolitically—forge the Indians as much as possible—because the Indians have no votes.

The degeneration and decay of a great race is a tragic thing. Is it inevitable? How many Canadians know that the Indians, who are not supposed to be able to adapt themselves to modern civilization, make the best structural steel workers available—virtually monopolizing that hazardous occupation in some cities?

Canada's relations with the Indians afford a striking contrast with those between New Zealand and the Maoris. Perhaps the reason why New Zealanders put Canada to shame is because the Maori representatives have always been permitted to speak for their own people on the floor of Parliament.

If the Bennett Government is willing to make a start toward atonement for a sorry chapter in Canadian administration by having some small, competent body make a survey of actual conditions of Indian life in Canada.

If Canadians as a whole could be given an authentic clear picture of Indian life—after the manner of the Royal Commission on social welfare in Ontario—a real start might be made toward redressing Indian wrongs.

A Canada-First Government should not be indifferent to the plight of the First Canadians.
Ottawa, June 11, 1932.

At the present time, Indian schools adopt the provincial curricula but place special emphasis on language, reading, domestic science, manual training and agriculture. It is hoped to prescribe, in the near future, a complete course of studies for Indian schools in Canada. In the junior grades, at least, there will be a departure from the provincial courses, which are not altogether suitable in either scope or content for Indian children. All Indian schools are regularly inspected by officers of the Department. In addition, public and separate school inspectors visit all classrooms, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, where there are special Indian school inspectors. Fully qualified teachers are engaged whenever possible.

The health of Indian children studying in boarding schools continues to receive special attention.

- Good medical
Good medical supervision has been arranged and much thought is given to physical education, proper diet and sanitation. During the year, extraordinary care was taken to prevent the loss of life by fire. In the schools where the hazard is serious, night watchmen are employed and at all schools fire drill is practised regularly.

The practice of assisting the most promising and industrious graduates of Indian schools was continued. Approximately 250 young Indian men and women were helped to continue their studies or to establish homes. Except in those Indian communities where successful farming is found, the school graduate presents a problem which is very difficult of solution. To the Editor of The Globe: There have been two articles in The Globe recently which have so stirred me that I must speak through the medium of your paper.

One is the letter from John Burdick of Fort Macleod regarding the actually cruel treatment, through neglect, of Indians at the Patricia School.

The other was a special article headed "Discipline" which dealt with the atrocities committed against Indians in reserve for the purpose of enforcing discipline.

Now, I am forced to write because, as it happens, I know considerable about the subject and can make a little similar to the general treatment of Indians, the nature of which I have heard and knowledge.

Some people will still persist in the idea that the white man is a dead one. They think that the race is passing away and that it is only a question of time before they will be extinct.

I believe that God has put it in my power to do something for Indians and only because of that reason do I write now.

I have seen representatives of law and order drinking at a party where Indians were present. I have seen them have been a good example to the Indians. I've known an individual who had never been convicted of a single Indian for being drunk or in county jail for being drunk. This same man was fined on the supposition that he had been drinking when he swore that he had not.

Then as to the doctor. I was at a house in a small village last night when a man (Indian) came anxiously calling for his wife. She was ill, his wife, who was soon to be a mother. The doctor came, but it was too late and the baby died.

The home was broken up. The father is now in prison. His wife and daughter is being cared for by people on the reserve who are wanting the money they get for selling their goods. Another is in an institution.

There is another boy in my school with sore eyes. I sent him to the clinic the doctor here Friday. The case was considered something unusual. But I saw his eyes becoming worse. So I wrote to Ottawa and arrived a new doctor, who really cares for the Indians. He found that my little pupil had tuberculosis. And on the advice of the doctor we found three others with it at school.

As regards discipline at school. At first glance one would consider that to be a teacher of Indians must be a hard task, since that discipline would be easy. I know that Indian children can be educated by appealing to their good qualities (which are not lacking) rather than force. They can be ruled by love, but to be forced by fear simply brings forth their unkindness.

Government agents who are to rule schools for Indians should take a study course in child psychology and school management and learn the fact that the Indians whose pupils had to be hurt physically to be made to behave, are not Indians. There are many young Indians tell of the futility of strapping in their school clothes. Physical punishment does not really mean much to an Indian. But appeal to their better nature, which is highest and you will get lasting results. I know whereof I speak.

Where is the feeling from headquarters against the Indians speaking? Why do they not stand up? What good do they do? What right has any one to take their language away from them by force?

It's very interesting to me to know that there are some teachers of the pupils from one of these schools who have been punished for using these terms, or something similar to this:

"We have a man teacher, who is awfully cross. He keeps us all running out in the yard when we're playing games or doing our work in the classroom. If he keeps on being so cross we're all going to quit school at Christmas."

This is a case of lack of humor, but it is the attitude of the pupils in these schools which is most contrary to one who loves and understands child nature that even in their play they must keep their language away without fear of punishment in the form of a beating or a whipping.

Now, I think I've said sufficient to show that there are two sides to this question. We must see Indians treated as human beings, not dogs. They must be allowed to think and speak for themselves they are trodden under foot by indifferent men who think that their own every helplessness has been their greatest appeal.

I trust that this may serve to interest someone who may realize how to give Indians understanding and love instead of the mockery of old children's food, which only keeps their bodies and leave their souls to starve.

Toronto One Who Loves Indians.

EDUCATION OF INDIANS.

Further Progress is Anticipated Under the New Administration.

To the Editor of The Nation:

Not many persons realize that the Federal Government administers one Federal program of education, namely that of the Indian Bureau, which has the responsibility for the education of thousands of Indian children scattered throughout the width and breadth of the United States.

For many years this Federal education project was devoted to giving Indian children an education as white children, in spite of the racial and cultural differences between them and, on the whole, these differences possibilities and different kinds of opportunities open to them in adult life.

As a result of those interested both in education and Indian welfare this situation has been changed and a progressive educator, Dr. Carson Ryan, placed in charge of the government Indian schools, to bring their program into line with modern progressive thought in educational administration. This involves the development of a system of education adapted to the specific needs of the Indian child and the preservation of the best elements of his native culture.

The first step was the abolition of the Indian boarding schools, which were unnecessarily costly and in many cases failed to provide education of a high standard. Some of these have been closed, but much of the whole program still remains to be put in operation. All those interested in the progressive education experiment which has been undertaken can only hope that it will be continued as vigorously and on the same scale as hitherto under the new Commissioner of Indian Affairs, to be appointed by the new President.

MARIA ROGERS.
New York, March 4, 1933.
