TAP-DANCING compares most favourably with many forms of sport, as an exercise for developing certain deportments. Through this exercise the child's muscles and limbs are strengthened and an upright carriage gained.

Parents should do well to note the love of the young generation for musical exercises. Those who have given their children this form of exercise have been well repaid by the noticeable improvement shown in the health and deportment of the children in later years.

There are many forms of Tap-Dancing, but perhaps the most popular and the easiest to follow, is the original dance of the North American Indians which is known as "The Red River Jig". The step for this dance is easy at all stages to learn. Throughout the foot makes three beats - the first only slightly accented - the second a slur, while the third is forcibly accented, because it receives the weight of the body, while the other foot takes up the step.

As the Old-Time Fiddlers play, one can easily recognize the triple beat running through the music. Thus it is almost an impulse that one dances the Red River Jig in accordance with the music quite naturally when accompanied with rhythmical music.

A child who is musically inclined may soon develop the flexibility that will enable him to do the triple tap. To practise this he should stand on his toes, keeping body erect, with the right foot the toe pointing downwards, straighten the leg bringing foot smartly on to the floor in front of him, then draw it back in line with the left foot.

The left foot will require more exercise, and this is obtained by raising the weight on the toes of the right foot and swinging the left foot backwards and forwards. This exercise will be more enjoyable performed and with greater exertion if the piano music of "The Tapatoe" is played. It will accustom the child to the rhythm.

Once the triple tap is mastered, and the child can do it, no matter how slowly, his muscles begin to tremble and his bones to grow stronger due to the splendid erect position of the body. The music of "The Tapatoe" can be played very slowly at first, then faster as the child becomes fully acquainted with the dance. With a fast musical exercise, such as this, a most beneficial development is obtained in a short time.

The world over, nations have portrayed the tempo of life, and to remedy the different modes of dancing, yet it has been left to the Canadians to inspire this triple tempo, in rhythm with the triple tap action; and this tempo is the fundamental basis of the dance, perfect symmetry between the music and the dance.

These two dances, "The Red River Jig" and "The Tapatoe" for which there are many steps are numbered to assist the parent or teacher with these two musical exercises.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR DANCING TAPATOE

The National Canadian Tap Dance

The Tapatoe is danced like the Military Schottische, commencing with a shuffle—lady with the right foot forward with the right foot, repeat a shuffle, with the left foot forward for three times and a turn by alternate shuffles. This is just as graceful a dance to watch as the waltz and as easy to learn.

A Shuffle—Stand with weight on left foot, holding the right foot off the floor, with knee slightly bent. Swing the right foot forward, sounding a tap on the floor with the ball of the foot and finishing with right foot forward, holding the right foot off the floor. Now bring ball of right foot to floor, with knee straight, sounding a second tap. This movement is done as though to slap floor sounding two taps. On the second tap the weight is carried over to the right foot.

Ladys' Step (Tap taps only):

Slap right Count 1
Slap left Count 2
Slap right Count 3
Slap right Count 4

Repeat all that starting left. Gentleman's step is the same only commencing with the left foot, and beginning the repeat with the right foot.

The Turn—Couple are in waltzing position. Turn clockwise lady commencing left, Gentleman right. Gentleman step is:

Slap left Count 1
Hop left Count 2
Slap right Count 3
Hop right Count 4

Repeat all that.

Recommended for accuracy in tap dancing and for physical development.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR DANCING THE RED RIVER JIG

This dance is, we believe, derived from the Pow Wow of the North American Indian, the early inhabitants of the Red River Valley, and was continued by the early settlers.

Two dancers face one another six feet apart; stand perfectly erect, and their movements commence by doing a shuffle by the right foot, followed by one shuffle with the left; every third shuffle or tap raise the foot backward sufficiently to miss one beat of the music. Perfect shuffle and tap—shuffle and tap of step is beat perfect time to the music with ones toes, with as little body movement as possible, is easily accomplished.

The dancers change side by crossing over with the shuffle step, a hand clap, and continue to dance about six feet apart until tired, or until other dancers take their place.

There were 80 residential schools and 260 day schools in operation during the year—a total of 340 Indian schools. In addition, the Department assisted in the maintenance of 9 combined white and Indian schools. The total enrolment was 17,425 and the average attendance 13,487. Education of Indian Children

By K. M. H.

The Department of Indian Affairs has issued a report on the education of Indian children. The emphasis placed on domestic science and manual training and agriculture is that emphasis placed in relation to the facilities which the pupils will have when they attempt to put theory into practice at home, on the reserves, or that emphasis—whether the best intentions—directed by the best of practice among white people.

The same life on the reserves is not an overburdened affair. If the criticism is justified, and it is too general and well informed to be a matter of much doubt, that, for example, the domestic science is taught to the Indians girls, the aid of electrically run washing machines and electrically powered bread mixers, it is not going to be much help at the home lodge. The same is true of agricultural and of animal training. The Indians do not need steady work at any time, and to suggest that he will take enthusiastically to seed selection, the cultivation of crops, and the care of animals is merely an extremist. It should be remembered that his history, and pretty recent history, is that, is to find his food by the hand of the white man—wheat and cattle culture done by the same. Therefore, elaborate teaching in agriculture is simply endured by the Indian students, and to judge by the few years of results, is generally and most effectively forgotten.

Over the years education of the Indians has not been a success. It has not lowered the death rate, especially from tuberculosis, which disease is fostered by poor housing, and unsuitable diet. It has not raised the status of Indian life on the reserve. It has not increased the number of Indians who have taken their places in the life of the Country.

In the few places where progress has been made among the Indians there has been based on observations directed by an agent who had knowledge of Indian character and of the possibilities, economic and human, with which he had to work.

Canada has spent millions on Indian education, and is still spending, and that ungrudgingly. The gesture apparently satisfied the white citizen's conscience that he owed something to the red man and is determined to pay it. But it is too easy a way which contents itself with handing over money.

There should be intelligent plans. It is always very difficult to fit civilizations so alien in ideals as the Indian and the white, but where there is respect and goodwill on both sides, as there is in this case, the task should not be an impossible one.
2nd December, 1933.

I have heard a rumour that your dept contemplate abandoning the system of residential schools for Indians and depending only on day schools, retaining one or two residential schools for orphans.

I trust it is not correct. After living on this coast for 42 years during 10 or all years of which I was Indian Agent for the whole West Coast I am in a position to judge the effect of the two systems.

When I was first Indian Agent, both systems were in use in this Agency and I had the best of chances to see the results.

The Boarding schools did good work hampered by the then antagonism of the Indians who did not like to part with their children. Now the Indians are anxious to send them to the residential schools as they see the benefit.

I used to tell the Indians that if they did not wish to be forced to send their children to the boarding schools, they should make a point of seeing that they attended the day schools which were then held on several of the principal reserves. The exceptional child or the child of exceptional parents did fairly well but the vast majority were no better. It was always left entirely to the choice or whim of the child as to whether he should go to school or not and you can guess the attendance. Apart from that the Indians move about so much according to the season and the opportunities of fishing that their children could not have attended well if they had wanted to.

I have seen children with an ostensible attendance of 4 or 5 years at day school and they did not know the elements of reading or writing.

The results of the boarding schools were very different and are now a credit to the Dept. I feel strongly on this as I would hate to see the Dept adopt a policy that would be bound to undo so much that they achieved in the past. In ten or fifteen years time the education of the Indians would be back where it was 20 years ago.

I would be much obliged if you would advise me by return mail as I would like to get it before I leave home, on the following points:

1st Has the dept such a change of policy in mind?

2nd Can I have a copy of the treaty or at least that portion of it dealing with education which was made some time shortly after Confederation, made between the Indians of the 3 Prairie Provinces as we now know them and her Majesty Queen Victoria. I think it was made in her name after an investigation by a Royal Commission.
House of Commons
Canada

3rd, A copy of an agreement or a blue book containing it, made a few years ago between your dept and the Indians of B.C. They had been agitating for treaty rights claiming that no definite treaty had ever been made with them and claiming that therefore all B.C belonged to them.

An arrangement was made to take the place of a treaty and I have a firm impression that it contained a clause guaranteeing the existence and I think the extension of the boarding or residential system of schools.

I may be quite wrong but I think the first named treaty and certainly the last named agreement contained promises of education facilities being given the Indians and owing to their nomadic mode of life I submit that this will not be afforded by a system of day schools on the reserves.

I question even if it would be much economy if that is the idea. There would have to be so many day schools in out of the way places to accommodate small and remote bands. These Indians are not like those on the Prairies. There may be only 25 or 50 in a band and they may be 20 miles from any other band or even if nearer, be entirely cut off by impassible woods or a sea trip too tough to negotiate half the time.

I trust you may oblige by sending me the data asked for as soon as possible. I do not want the whole treaty merely the part dealing with education.

Yours faithfully,

A.M. Neill

January 4, 1934.

Dear Mr. Neill:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to continuing the system of residential schools conducted for the benefit of Indian children.

The Department has given no consideration to the abandonment of the present system of residential schools and is not contemplating any change in its present policy. At present, however, it is not proposed to extend the residential school system. It is considered, in a case where further school facilities may be necessary, that the day school would meet requirements. The Department endeavours, in so far as funds permit, to keep school buildings and equipment in good repair.

I am forwarding, under separate cover, a copy of Indian Treaty No. 4. This is similar in all respects to the other treaties made with the Indians of the Prairie provinces. You will observe that it was agreed by the Treaty to maintain a school on each reserve whenever the Indians of the reserve should desire it.

I also forward a copy of the report of the special Committee of the Senate and House of Commons regarding the enquiry into the claims of the Allied Tribes of British Columbia.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

The above is a partial list of residential schools in connection with which the Department pays a per capita grant. In these cases the Department did not build the schools and does not exercise the rights of ownership. It is noted that the last seven in the above list are in one agency, i.e. the Grouard Agency.

In a number of these cases the Department is being asked to assume financial responsibility and to pay grants towards the capital costs of the buildings, besides making additional grants for additions, repairs and maintenance. In at least some instances there are undertakings on the part of the Department to furnish certain financial assistance. Many of the arrangements made in the past in this connection have been verbal in nature and the terms are not of definite record. It would seem clear, however, that in some, if not
all cases the Department is obligated to some degree at least, but the lack of written records and agreements makes it very difficult to determine the nature and extent of this responsibility.

The fact that the Department has undertaken the payment of per capita grants implies a certain responsibility for the up-keep of the buildings, if not for the capital costs.

In my opinion it is necessary that the Department adopt a general policy for the purpose of dealing with these difficulties and I would respectfully offer the following suggestions for your consideration:

(1) That the Department of Indian Affairs undertake the payment of per capita grants and any financial aid towards the cost of building only when the prior authority of the Department has been granted. This authority should cover such matters as site, size and nature of school buildings.

(2) That such authority in all cases be set out in a formal and definitely worded agreement for the guidance of Departmental officials, as a matter of record and for the purpose of avoiding future misunderstandings.

(3) That the schools now operating by authority of the Department as recognized by the payment of per capita grants be assisted from time to time as circumstances warrant and financial conditions permit.

(4) That the various missionary societies be notified that in future building projects undertaken without the sanction of the Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs will not be considered as a later date for authority and recognition.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

Can the Indian of B.C. be raised to a standard of citizenship wherein he would be obliged to be responsible for his own responsibility, rather than full enfranchisement.

Because of depression necessitating economy men are forced to think in terms of saving expenses. But how many have really thought of the new operating construction of the economic world? It affects everyone as individuals because of this it naturally extends to wider relative fields; from families to communities, from communities to governments, covering in its scope governments or committees which govern industries, commodity circulation, governments municipal and federal. It matters not what business one adheres to economy has to be practised. In governments of countries, departments are affected; during the past two years estimates have been returned for paring at every session of parliament. The common dollar is not in circulation and therefore could not be had in taxation direct or indirect, hence the department of Indian Affairs as all other departments, is obliged to exercise the utmost economy and now feels as though the bottom is about to drop out, finding itself with thousands of dependants on its hands, what is to be done? We in B.C. have felt the pinch; grants have been cut temporary, but when will this reduction be returned? While departments for the time being have been laid aside, what then can be done? Can we carry on with these cuts? Can we, as members of departments efficiently carry our load with such handicap? Reconstruction, what does it mean and where are we to begin? Thoughts take one back to the early days and for a brief moment we must dwell on conditions leading up to the present situation. There are one or two outstanding thoughts which should command our attention.

(1) The Indian in Canada is in his Fatherland; this is his home. He cannot, like the Chinese or Japanese, be repatriated, for he is in the land of his birth. He is therefore not a foreigner and much more so than his white brother has he a right to his just living. He is the aboriginal and must be absorbed into the body politic.

(2) This absorption must be done as quickly as possible for it will relieve the populous general of a large amount of taxation. The Indian is human in every sense of the word; like every other aboriginal tribe he was found with social relations built about a sense of religion. This religion had with it a centralized deity which was greater than himself and must be taken into consideration at all times and in all places. His worshipful instincts were easily appealed to and he was quickly led to citizenship of the Kingdom of God. This citizenship holds within itself the one thing which breeds loyalty, patriotism and independence.

In order to best see the working of this change one must of necessity see the beginning. We find the Indian in his original state knowing no responsibility. He lived upon the animal, vegetable and fish wealth of the land over which he roamed in freedom. He ambushed and scalped his tribal enemies. His system of hygiene was worked out in his nomadic nature; he wandered and in that wandering, while unaware of it himself, he was able to keep himself fairly healthy and at all times fit for the chase. He left behind him as he roamed, his refuse and nature did the cleansing work. As a result then our early white migration came into touch with a race healthy in its own crude mode and manner of living. His system of eugenics was linked up in a great many ways with his mode of warfare; fighting in ambush he annihilated if possible, but in some cases, saved the daughters of his enemies to become the mother of his own sons, children in this way keeping high a standard of breeding.
He spurned cowardice. Brave became a brave by enduring extreme torture or by roaming in isolation sometimes for long periods of time, gaining his keep from nature's inanimate and animate life. Stoical in the face of danger he faced death because he expected it to come at a certain time and very often in a certain manner.

The Indian's folk lore and ceremony were wonderful and beautiful and to himself real, becoming a part of his life.

His one big responsibility in life was to keep his bodily appetite appeased. He ate when he was hungry and hunted when his larder was empty. Seasonally he preserved by his own methods the fruit and roots of the wild, while the fish was put through a process of sun drying. These served him for winter food together with the meat of the chase. He understood nature and utilized her for his own essential bodily sustenance.

He was not without superstitions. Conformity to his traditions was a marked characteristic and with his superstitions they had a great deal to do in governing his life and forming his habits and mode of living.

The white man then coming into the land found a people unique who at first showed a placid mind but soon was induced to smoke the pipe of peace. There followed barter and fire-water. The Indian was sadly exploited, finding himself out his weaknesses the white man took advantage of him, seeing Madam Clotchet's weakness for gaudy colors the Gentleman Indian paid dearly with his life to satisfy this weakness. Values being unknown to him the Indian was induced to pile barrel high the old Hudson Bay basket in order that he might become the proud possessor of the white man's weapon of killing.

Then follows the prospector of every blood and land, who again in their turn took advantage in many other ways, worst of all morally, for the Indian came into contact with, in the main, a very low type of white man who brought disease. Following this, settlements and the rounding of the Indians into reserves and forcing upon him the white man's mode of living, blocking nature's work and making possible the spread of disease and the development and spread of tuberculosis, were the conditions into which the Indian was rudely precipitated, resulting in the fact that until late years he has been a dying race. To-day we can safely say that he survives, the records for statistics show that he is increasing again numerically.

The country for a time, through its own lack of forethought in its system of development and seeking for gold, practically forgot that it owed a dying race a helping hand; yet whatever induced her, she turned her eyes to look into the cause of the Indian and she found a situation which called for rapid and timely attention. The condition was such that it would demand years of patient and constant care. Canada also realized that the co-operation of Christian principles was necessary in the reconditioning of the race. She therefore asked the help of the churches in her undertaking and we now find the church and country working hand in hand accomplishing slowly but surely a gigantic Canadian task, which extends itself in its appeal to all true Canadians who realize the existence of a common brotherhood.

Absorption in itself means or presents to the casual thinker, perhaps only one thing, that is inter-marriage between the whites and the Indians. In looking into this part of the work, men who have made a study of the situation find a great deal of other blood, principally white, and where this is so it has not always been good. Very many times we find the mixture has been much for the worse. The halfbreed who is recognized as neither Indian nor white man is a curse to the
country and a menace to the uplift of the Indian. Absorption by mixture of blood in inter-marriage cannot be advocated. It must be applied only to a status of Dominion citizenship; that is keep the Indian separate, letting him live as a race within the land but see to it that the system of absorption will raise him to a higher standard of citizenship, making him a citizen of whom we can and will be proud.

We have hereto for expended large sums of money and energy but what has been done? Nothing but to create Indians who parade under the name of Indian and hang to the apron strings of the Department of Indian Affairs, so to speak. The work is terribly disjointed and needs some welding and amalgamation. In order therefore to carry on economically and for the best of all concerned a minute study of the problem sectionally would have to be made together with the Indian's general relation to the population as a whole, taking into consideration the weakness of the Indian and his easy fall to many temptations.

Conditions and occupations at the coast are much different than in the Southern Interior of the Province and likewise the North differ widely from the South; sectional study involves the necessary industry and therefore occupation. In the Southern Interior of B.C. you have an extensive fruit growing and mixed farming occupation while on the Coast the occupations vary from mechanical work to lumbering and fishing. In the North you have fur trading and lumbering. In order therefore to make a success of the Provincial Indian situation it has to be studied sectionally.

It follows then that the Indian must be taught to adapt himself, first to his environment, secondly to take care of his own physical needs in such a way as to become a responsible citizen wholly manning and maintaining his own Canoe of Life. He, on the coast, must be given a liberal and useful education in the art of building, ways and means of fishing, the art of boat building, the care of and how to handle gas engines, the care of and how to handle cannery machinery. He, in the Southern Interior of B.C. must be taught agriculture in all its phases, cattle husbandry, dairying, fruit and vegetable growing, how to lay out and build his irrigation ditches and to irrigate, how to cultivate, spray and prune his orchards. He, in Northern B.C. must be taught how to farm where it is possible, fur farming should appeal to him and he could be taught to grow fur in his own backyard and also the art of conservation of fur on his trap lines, and he should be taught lumbering and conservation of timber which should be realized in this industry.

How then is this to be done efficiently and with the least possible expenditure? Simply and solely through a system of education beginning in the day or residential school and at the age of seven years and by a definite and concrete following-up scheme.

A definite academic education must be provided and in all cases and stages using the provincial curriculum, setting at least an average standard of high school entrance for every child. This is not an impossible task if ages are adhered to and a constant attendance enforced. The Indian child shows considerable aptitude in absorbing and retaining academic subjects as they are taught to-day. Mentally, except for a language handicap of one year, he progresses equally with the white child. Intelligence tests given and I.Q.'s taken show some to be as much as a year and a half older in intelligence than they are physically. Since then we have a mind which can be readily developed, it can also be taught to control technically the physical faculties. Here again more than average aptitude is shown and it leads one to believe that secondary advanced education would be a very ideal educational development to follow, leading up to trades and industries
best suited and adapted sectionally for whatever part of the Province
the child is expected to live in after school life.

The residential schools for the past, in some cases sixty years,
has been very great factor in the uplift of the Indian and is still
one would think, the ideal of all modes of education. It is centralized.
It overcomes also a difficulty in the Indian make-up, that of irresponsibility,
for his child when in the residential school is controlled by those
whose only concern is the advance of the Indian to common citizenship.
While the Indian is aware of the responsibility demanded of him yet his
utter indifference to things essential to future welfare hinges entirely
upon the native peculiarity of being sensitive only to the needs of the
day. He therefore applies himself and works all his dependants into this
unfortunate trait. The residential school takes away a great many
difficulties and makes education more thorough, but are they altogether
the best? Are the difficulties which they dissolve after all insurmountable
if handled in other ways? In the beginning the residential school is an
institution which belongs to times of prosperity. Only governments can
carry them on. Indian Residential Schools are worked today. They are
expensive financially and are again expensive stumbling blocks to the
rapid and thorough absorption of these people. As they are provided for
today they take away from the Indian that very responsibility which they
themselves are trying to instill. These institutions feed, clothe and
educate an Indian's children during the most expensive period of his child's
life. A Graduate becomes a father and is blessed with a family for
which during school days he is taught to take the responsibility, then the
school turns around and takes the instilled responsibility out of his hands.
Surely this is defeating its own aims. The Indian must be made responsible
for his own responsibility else it will take a thousand years to bring
him to that position wherein he will take that responsibility. Give him
the responsibility of his family and you have him on the rapid road to
citizenship. One might say make him pay a set sum towards the education
of his child, in other words tax him and listen to his appeal. It would
take a regiment of soldiers to extricate this money for he never has any
when it comes to helping to take care of his child in one of the resident-
ial schools. Follow their system up and we find that when non graduates
and lines that father had no responsibility in his rearing, the son
declined to take any responsibility of his parent when in the age. Stories
have been told by responsible persons, who know what they are saying,
about boys who are graduates of these institutions, sitting by the fire-
side in comfort when his grey-haired father shoulders his shovel and rocker
and heads for the river to wash gold in order that he might live and keep
his communistic son. The residential school, while it is not retarding
yet it is not conducive to the rapid uplift of the Indian, which could be
set going and maintained by a system of day schools with the residential
schools to-day utilized as institutions wherein higher secondary educat-
ion, academic and technical could be taught on the same basis and along
the same lines as junior high schools are carried on but with a somewhat
wider opportunity for technical and industrial education. This wider
opportunity would be one great step in the right direction. As stated
above it would make the Indian responsible for the care of his own family
at a time when it most needs his care and instead of releasing him of his
responsibility it lays it where it belongs.

Through the day school system, educational expense to the
Department of Indian Affairs would be cut in three or four. The average
number of children cared for by one teacher in a residential school is
about nine, this varies a little but runs between eight and ten; while
a day school teacher would take care of from twenty to forty or an average
of thirty, taking the province on a whole.
By cutting down the educational expense greater medical care could be given in the way of placing a nurse on each reserve or with each school teacher and where necessary, an extra officer who could be termed truant officer. This officer being in touch with the school or schools always could also be of some help to the Indian from the point of view of sectional occupation.

The Indian would by this scheme be obliged to feed and clothe his children and thereby he would be made to bear the burden of his own responsibility instead of, as stated above, the residential school taking this responsibility provided for by the Department and assisted by the church or denomination of whatever professed Christian religion the Indian happens to belong. The residential school makes responsibility much too easy for the Indian, as for example, an Indian who is a steady worker on the railway section, much to his credit, with a family numbering ten, have all but one been through a residential school, spending anywhere from seven to ten years in the institution. Two girls married shortly after graduation; two boys today are working on the railway with the father and son-in-law. They have, between the three, an earning capacity of five dollars per diem and therefore, even though he is able, is not obliged to carry his own responsibility. It would seem that there is, under these conditions, no fostering of the growth of responsible citizenship but is rather retarding that growth. Anyone would be very foolish not to avail themselves of such opportunities if allowed. Why should he make any effort to raise himself to any prescribed status of citizenship?

It is true this would work a hardship in some cases, perhaps not a few, but when a man is thrown on his own resources it is remarkable what difficulties he will meet and surmount with a little help and encouragement. Again it would open avenues to the Department when not only the children but the whole race could be helped.

In these days of economy and cutting down of departmental revenues head of departments look for ways of escape. It is common knowledge to those connected with the Department of Indian Affairs that its present educational scheme is absorbing all its available revenue. It is obliged even to cut to the core the relief so many of these older Indians need. There is a cry for equality of recognition between the whites and the Indians. This is justifiable for the Indians has as great a right for the same relief and pension recognition. This could easily be accomplished without added expense if a change could be made.

The Indian in the Interior of B.C. could easily take care of more responsibility if given in a proper way and it would make him a much better man and citizen. It would be interesting to make a study of the Coast section in this regard. Surely some scheme could be found wherein a sectional scheme could be put into action which would deal relatively and with equal effect.

As stated above, the expenditure involved in the residential school cannot be cast aside and must be utilized to the very best advantage in making them advanced secondary educational institutions wherein a child could be developed according to ability and mentality. He would graduate from the day school as grade seven pupil and at the maximum age of fourteen. He would be able to take care of himself and also be in a position mentally and physically to be advanced in such an institution of advanced general education.

Parents object to sending their children away from home at the early age of seven years fearing that the child will be obliged to do work which cannot physically do. These would have no hesitation, if asked, to send them to a day school and on the other hand, would have no hesitancy in sending them at the age of thirteen or fourteen to a school such as a residential school could be made.

In cases where it could be afforded parents should be obliged
to pay a yearly fee of $50.00 to $100.00 so that the responsibility of his own making would not entirely be taken away from him when the time came for his child or children to attend this higher educational school. Attendance to these schools should be made compulsory up to the age of eighteen years, and in every case possible giving the child an average of four years residential school life. While reducing the cost of education it would also increase the numbers eligible for that higher essential education, reaching in turn a greater number and again the Department of Indian Affairs and churches would reap a greater benefit by turning out these greater numbers. To give real justice to a child's education in a residential school an increase of per capita grant is necessary. The child is obliged to do too much manual labor. Actual labor should only take place during periods of demonstration and should be of short duration. Residential schools cannot afford to hire labor to do the work, especially is this so where agriculture has to be taught.

It has been abundantly demonstrated that the Indian child today can take an advanced education. Schools are every year now graduating children who have attained a high school standard, not a few of these advancing to matriculation or university entrance standards. Academically a few should be taken on and in so far as it is possible the Department of Indian Affairs should be ready to absorb them as teachers, stenographers and instructors. Wherever possible graduates should be employed whenever a boy shows aptitude and a tendency to responsibility, positions should be given him; to this aim the Department through its agents should work. Appeals should be made to the Province to utilize the Indian rather than any foreigner. Employers of trade should be approached, railways asked to employ Indians wherever possible on the sections. It is rather sad feature of regular employment to find every nationality, Chinese, Japanese, Swedes, immigrants from Norway and the Balkan States given preference over the heads of young Indians who are anxious to make good, and given an opportunity would undoubtedly arise to the occasion.

The establishment of day schools, perhaps consolidation of reserves to accomplish this, making a two or more roamed school would be advantageous to the children as well as to the teacher employed. It would give an opportunity for a partially graded school and therefore more individual class attention. If a bus should be necessary, the driver could act as truant officer, as well as instructor in school gardening and general supervision of the Indian work on the reserve or reserves, by making a study of this and wherever possible a school could be erected. This should be done with a view to taking care of educationally not only the children but the parents as well.
It is true there are a number of day schools in the province situated, in some cases, very remote places. One, two and three in an agency with, in some cases, unqualified teachers, and on top of that, a very poor average attendance throughout. They are too scattered and insufficient in number to place a truant officer in the district so duty is placed on the agent or assistant. Each of these officials, unless it is on the beaten track, makes no attempt to visit the homes unless demanded by the Department.

The Department appoints as inspector of schools a man who is conscious of his position and in the choice of teachers allows the agent or church or some sympathetic reason to have a teacher continue in the school who is not worth his board, without taking into consideration the monthly he receives. What use is a dog if he is not able to hunt, or assist in driving sheep or cattle, without these qualities he becomes an ornamental animal. Officials become paid ornaments if their advice is not taken, in cases at least of glaring academic inefficiency and at this time when teachers are so numerous and are clamouring for work. A mistake in choice is sometimes made by the best of men but that mistake can never be one hundred percent in every case. What business has the church or Department men in the field who interfere with the inspector of schools when the inspector knows his work and is doing his best to raise the standard of general education. There are too many wheels within wheels. Every possible assistance should be given a man who wishes to give his best but the hanger-on should have no place at all whether his inability comes through insufficient training, or because he is a good fellow who has been so long in the work and who has perhaps in many other ways done a great deal for the Indian. The education of the future generation must not be jeopardized. If more day schools were established then more regular attendance would be forthcoming, and the decrease in expenditure would warrant a full time truant officer.

Great care should be taken that the children are not educated away from themselves. Separate schools should be established so that in them the sexes could be educated along the same lines, reaching the same standard, numerically equalizing as much as possible. Human tendency is to link up with alike standards in education and society. This is applicable to the Indian and it should be the business of the system to see that no distinction is made but that each and every child should be given an equal opportunity to fit him or herself into the race as a race but not by blood absorption or inter-marriage. Unfortunately there are always those among the white race who will stoop to the lowest and in satisfying fleshly desires take advantage of the Indian girl, making her his slave. Indian parents also will sacrifice their girl's character to get a white connection, though the connection as a rule happens to be with the lowest element, hence the last state is worse than the first. By all means keep the race together by giving them an opportunity to get satisfaction educationally and socially within themselves, so taking away a great evil which has heretofore exhibited itself in the half-breed situation which is a menace to the advance of the Indian himself.

I can now hear the churches crying out in holy horror but surely the churches can rise to an occasion which is for the good of the land, holding themselves to make allowances, and by some arrangement provide for the situation. If on the other hand strict adherence to church denomination is sought, then leave church division as it is. Let Anglican be Anglican but shift children from the Coast to the Interior or vice versa, establishing one or more residential schools to take care of advanced learning and one to take care of the destitutes, applying this method to the Roman Catholics and non-Conformists alike. These schools are already in existence and would not now be an additional expense in the scheme. Pride and prejudice must be a nonentity even as the Department would have to drop
playing politics if this arrangement were to be carried out. Citizens of the Kingdom of God cannot be made unless fairness is shown. Fairness cannot be shown if we are going to lower ourselves to allow politics to play a part in the lifting-up of these people.

Since the Indian has taken the first step in citizenship, that of being responsible for his own family and therefore has approached to a standard of citizenship, the great question arises, what are these children going to do to maintain this first step? The parent has been made responsible in the first stage which naturally follows the child and therefore a following-up scheme must be forthcoming. A definite concrete following-up scheme must be ready for graduates. They are, in the schools, mentally equipped and during this period are shown how they can maintain themselves. Let me say here that an honourable discharge certificate and a mentally alert child is not sufficient to keep the child going in the way wherein he has been so carefully taught while in the school. Principals and teachers alike are not giving just service to society if their business is anything other than to equip and advance the children who come within their charge. They should guide them as far as they reasonably can towards self-maintenance and independence. It can then be truly said that the very definite lesson that first and always occupy the mind of every church or government institution and every teacher in these institutions is self-reliance and responsibility. Any individual institution which for any purpose seeks to hold up the success of these children is misusing God-given opportunities. Since this is the case let me ask the question, what is being done by the Department to nurture and maintain this spirit of responsibility? Let me answer the question by giving a picture of what under the present abstract system might easily happen. A boy is graduated from a school wherein he has been studied and has been led to follow farming. He has shown an interest in all phases of agriculture. The boy graduates, going back to the reserve which he now calls going back home, and finds there a few acres of land on which he is expected to carry out that which he has been taught. After years of living within a school where his meals were regular and good, clothing warm and sufficient, baths regular, and a good clean bed wherein to sleep nine hours a day, the boy finds himself at the age of eighteen saying my mind will work but my hands are tied. I have no house, I have no machinery, I have nothing, only an education which now I would be better without for I would, in my ignorance, not have known anything different. Again the natural instinct tells him he must mate and perhaps take unto himself a wife, who also has been through a school, increasing step by step the responsibility. Then, through the blessings of God, a child makes its appearance, the boy with a wife and child to care for, will if he is able, use his education honestly and in an honest way take care of himself and his dependants. If he cannot then he will use some other means, it makes no difference as long as he can get enough of this world's goods to supply his needs and the needs of his wife and child. He falls into the hands of the law and is sentenced for supplying, stealing, or cattle rustling, and is branded a criminal in carrying out his duty as a father and a husband in caring for his legalized wife and child. With all good intentions, perhaps driven to the wall, when a little thoughtful help at his graduation would have made him a desirable citizen. No one of an official capacity visits him or takes an interest and one more Indian has come to be watched criminally in all that is officially recognized. He at least lives in close proximity to the clutches of the law, not an honourable citizen as he was taught he must be, but one that becomes a liability. Again there are always white men who will stoop to use an Indian for his (the white man's) criminal advantage. This is in so many cases unfortunate but true.
In not a few of these cases an Indian gets work, and on the strength of this runs a bill at the local store and pays up as the weeks go by. When his work finishes he never thinks of his bill and leaves an honestly contracted debt unpaid. Work again comes his way but he goes off to another store, and so on. Here let me ask would it not be much better for the Department to allow some means of collection in this regard? Yet a just debt remains unpaid because the Department's agent says keep off the reserve, you cannot take his horse or his cow or his beans, nor can you take his money. Again Indians who are to a great extent making good, by having been given help initially from the Department, can purchase a car, which is in almost every case his ruination, and can if he wishes run this car over the bank or can ruin it mechanically, and the dealer has no comeback as the Indian simply says take your car back I am finished with it whereas if he knew that his beans or horse or cow could be taken for part payment of a just debt he would not be in a hurry to purchase his ruination.

It is said that dealers have no business selling to an Indian as he knows he cannot collect, while another says do not worry the dealer made the Indian pay enough initially for the car and has been well paid for it, is this the proper viewpoint to take? Does not it likewise instill in both the minds of the Indian and the dealer dishonesty? Surely it does, for if the dealer knew he could get his own, as he can out of every other citizen he would be more inclined to deal honestly. The Indian also knowing that he would have to make his regular payments would not, in the first place, be inclined to risk more than he was able to pay. It is true in cases among the whites there is no sense of honour and dealers are obliged to take great risks and for these risks the faithful generally have to make payment. One never sees an opportunity for wholesale daylight robbery, as it were, as is the case with the Indian; almost all of them by the fact that they are not liable to pay bills are in that fact liable to be made dishonest citizens, men for whom no one has respect. The church and schools can teach until doomday and their combined efforts cannot avail for the gross wrong that is being done to the Indian at the present moment. He parades under the name Indian avails himself of his privileges, and laughs under the skin at his own weakness and inability to get what he wants and cheat without restriction almost. The railways running through our province do more for the uplift of the Indian than the Department, for where an Indian earns his living off the reserve, the Department places him in the same category with the white laborer, hence his monthly wage is liable to guarantee by his debtor. If he allows this to happen a second time he finds himself without a job. This I am sure is teaching responsibility and just what is needed to make an honest citizen. This could easily be done and profitably extended to every Indian on the reserves by utilizing the agent or his assistant to carry out just and fair collection of fairly contracted debts.

Interested enquiry into the assistance given by local agents to local business men show that, in so many cases, the agent and his office does not mean a thing to them in the way of assistance to collect debts. There are cases where local business men have been of material assistance to the agent and if this was co-operatively utilized its reflection on the Indian would be of great benefit to his uplift. Not all business men are out to exploit the Indian, some are ready to help in every way possible. These men should be given every support but they are, in so many cases, fighting a lone battle. An Indian is allowed to run a bill, through the kindness of the merchant, and pledges in good faith an amount of his monthly wage, his bean crop, or his apple crop, or his fur harvest, or his fish harvest but when bills fall due and he is approached, he leaves and goes to the Chinese store next door. Here the Indian can buy or gamble as he sees fit, and is exploited, robbed of his character as well as his money. One finds that the Indian will do his business on Sunday through the back door of a
Chinese joint rather than a week day, through fear that the honest merchant
to whom he is indebted, will see him. This situation is a reflection on
Provincial authority for not enforcing the law and it is also a reflection
on the agent who should interest himself enough to see that his Indians
were morally and Christianly protected. Many a time it is asked what the
church is doing. The church does a great deal for the Indian in his youth
but what can it do but condemn the Indian together with the prescribed
indeficient process of Indian uplift.

In the Thompson and Fraser Valleys there are many Indians who are
self-supporting and many more could be made self-supporting if made to
realize that their debts should be attended to before potlatching and pow-
wowing, spending everything overnight when they should have plenty to keep
them over the season. Conditions of this sort need not arise if the
proper supervision is given and a check made by keeping in touch with local
business places, especially Chinatown stores. Local business men should
be able to co-operate with the agent in being able to go to him for action
in cases where fairly contracted bills should be paid. Allowing the Indian
to fall into dishonesty is the very opposite to that which he is taught
during his school life.

Indians who are steady workers have also been helped by the agents
to evade Poll Tax, which is a direct evasion of responsibility.

Under the present working conditions with such meandering arrangements
it is no wonder that some of the Departmental officers who have the uplift
of the Indian at heart, cry out in disgust at the way the work is carried
on and especially when politics are allowed to govern. The principals of
schools without exception, must dread the day when their boys and girls
have reached the age when they slip over the threshold of the school no more
to return as a pupil. The task is not impossible if all were in the work
for the work's sake and the above loop-holes were covered.

The following-up scheme should be carefully considered and as the
foundation for this scheme should be well and truly laid during the child's
period of school life it would only remain for the department to enlarge or
build upon that foundation. No one can gainsay the fact that foundations
for citizenship are laid in any educational system. The Indian work then
should be carefully fostered and nurtured in its growth.

For the Interior of B.C. the community system of settlement would
undoubtedly be the ideal as it would well take the place of the reserve and
so called rancherie. Indians are fond of social life and if this fondness
can be guided in the proper channels then we have gone a great way in our
upward progress. Thirty acres of land is sufficient to take care of a man
and his family, and with intense cultivation such as that which should be
taught in the schools, an Indian would become self-supporting in a very
short time; providing appointed officials were capable of doing their work
and interested themselves in the Indian and his welfare.

The Interior on the whole could easily be organized. The water
question being the big problem in the community system. Church, school,
and Departmental supervision could more easily be carried on and maintained
and an immediate status of citizenship established. Situation of reserves
should be chosen with a view for easy marketing conditions, some of the
reserves now set apart are ideally placed and should be utilized. There
should be no difficulty with co-operation between the Province and the
Dominion in setting apart new reserves if necessary, for in the cause of the
Indian, it is a common one to all.

The Interior of B.C. is ideal and presents many opportunities for
mixed farming by which a farmer can readily provide for his needs. Purchases
he would be obliged to make, over and above his own productions could easily
be provided for with a few tons of potatoes or a few tons of hay. Car lots
could always be made up in a community whereas individually it would be much
harder and almost impossible. The Indian does not need big holdings but
with a number a great deal of successful concentrated work could be done.
If the Indians of the southern Interior of B.C. were taken care of in this manner, it would in turn care for one-third of the Indian population, which in itself would be of some material benefit to the Department. This scheme of community settlement would demand a means of regulation. Initial expenditure by the Department would have to be made and therefore an investment, in advance, to the community. Boys placed in their settlement should be obliged to pay interest charges and a small portion each year on the principal, so that over a period of years full return would be made to the Department. This would place some responsibility on the holder, which in itself would make him fit into effect that which he had been taught.

The land so distributed, when paid for, should be ceded to him as his property, not to be sold or traded, but for perpetuation by will to his next of kin, male or female; or dealt with in like manner and according to Canadian Law relating to any other citizen of the land.

Old time Indians who value their property by the number of dogs and horses they have should not be allowed near such a community settlement. The younger Indians of today are crying out against such, stating that they are a hold-up to their advance. While one man has to be careful in accepting this statement, coming as it does from boys who have been through school, for very often these lads feel their status in education and become agitators of a kind. Nevertheless it shows the desire to get away and to cast off, wherever possible, prejudices of this kind.

The Coast situation would represent a difficulty, the fishing industry taking the Indians from place to place, but by careful study a great and substantial change could be made and a successful scheme evolved. On Vancouver Island there is an opportunity for agricultural development which should in every way be fostered, and the Indians induced to stay on the land.

In this manner work officially would take upon it a concrete nature giving those in charge a better opportunity for getting away from forced abstractness. As mentioned above, a sectional study should be made and should cover every aspect of the work, from the school teacher to the commissioner. What good would an agent be if he were unable to look into the agricultural pursuits of the school graduates in an essentially agricultural area or agency, especially if the child was taught agriculture because sectionally it was his only pursuit? One sees an advertisement hanging in the local post office wanting a man for constable who has at least a practical knowledge of agriculture. The Department realizes the necessity for this end an appointment is made, after a great deal of political pull, of a man who does not know the difference between a Holstein cow and a Durham, or a variety of wheat from a variety of oats. The thing is absurd, yet in some cases, is a reality. Agents likewise have been appointed, so great care should be taken, especially in regard to agents and their assistant. It matters not what race or age within that race is being dealt with, if the official is unable to advise and keep occupied the people under him, then he is only an expense to the Department and shortly becomes a hanger-on and is moved from place to place and is, to use a common proverbial phrase, a round peg in a square hole.

Occupation is the secret of success in any line of work. If a teacher is unable to keep his children occupied, he has chaos instead of order in his classroom. This applies to every class of work. An official should be able to make an intelligent survey of his work, and if at all interested, he will do so without delay on his appointment. He will call a meeting of his Indians, ascertain their ideas and be prepared to make recommendations. A bluffer, delinquent, or incapable person has no business to be in the work, and the Department of Indian Affairs should not have to endure dictation politically. It should have no sympathy whatever for inaggressiveness of a man who expects to do a day's work beginning between 10 o'clock and noon and finishes at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. The work itself demands a full day's work. Equilibrium of service is a studied
necessity; delinquency gives the Indian a chance to come back. Reasonable aggressiveness with good judgment, sympathy for the Indian, and patience is our need in the field. No sympathy should be given to men whose habits are not ideal; slothfulness, drunkenness, immorality or even indifference should not be for a moment tolerated.

It is universally known that the church, no matter what branch, sets ideals of measurement in moral and social life. Every official therefore should be ready to set a church example and attend his own services with regularity and frequency. While this is a highly commended virtue it also excites conscientious scruples which in every person genders to efficiency, regularity of habits, and temperance in all things. Choice of fit men is not a mere position filling act but the use of retrospective individuality as well as possible recognized ability to conscientiously and efficiently carry on the work so far as it is physically and reasonably possible, is required.

An official's work is not to toast his feet at the fireside, reading a novel and waiting for the work to come to him but rather, by studying his problems he can see possible complications or necessities and is ready to meet them. Emergencies arise in every sort of life but the man who is obliged to treat everything as an emergency is short of individual energy and therefore a men to whatever part of life's realities he has contact. How real these things become in the work and responsibility one has undertaken in playing his part in bringing these aboriginal peoples up to a standard of citizenship wherein they would become entirely self-supporting.

The Church truly plays its part in this great work but it is not always successful in every sense because representatives of the Department find it hard work with the church personnel, rightly so in cases. Again the church personnel find church sympathy very lean within the hearts of Departmental officials, especially where there is no example of church consciousness nominal church men as a rule find it hard to co-operate. Real churchmen as a rule understand the reality of living in Divine touch with their God and fellowmen.

An official should not think in terms of money but in terms of Indian citizenship. It is true we all expect a living wage but when the higher things are thrown away for the less essentials or material things, we are missing the mark. Again if an official always is crying over being underpaid or he finds it hard to make ends meet or worse still allows bills to run, what kind of an example can he be to the Indian? He is a specimen of not much worth to himself, to the work, and to the Department.

Agent's assistants and agents themselves centre their activities in laying off and arresting when they would be much better occupied in how they are going to occupy their Indians, and bring their law-breaking minds into profitable occupation. The constable forgets that his appointment hinged upon a knowledge of agriculture, fur farming, lumbering, fishing or mechanic.

Enfranchisement is one thing and a standard of citizenship is another. To be raised to full enfranchisement would perhaps necessitate the Indian's removal from the reserve or doing away with the reserve system. While to raise him to a standard of citizenship wherein he would be responsible for his own responsibility would leave him on the reserve, keeping the reserve system in vogue as it is today. The present system gives the Indian an opportunity and protects him in that opportunity of parading under the name "Indian". He gets what benefits he can, in most cases not a few, some of which have already been mentioned, and glories in his own ability of being able to hang on to the apron strings of the Department. Take away that protection wherein he is able to say: "you can't sue me"; "you cannot take my cow, nor horse"; "you cannot collect my produce money", or in his own mind the statement, "I am not obliged to pay my just debts if I don't want to"; "you white man, you owe me a living anyway and why should I not get it",
and you will see how quickly his attitude will change. Observe how careful he will be when he knows that through the agent or other authority he will be obliged to pay his way. Again by the day school system, he would be obliged in so far as he was able, to take care of his own family thereby making him entirely responsible for his own responsibility.

A step of this character taken would automatically put out of commission agitators, Indian and white, making the work pleasant as well as interesting. It is sad to say there are white men who exploit the Indian and are constantly advising him behind the scenes. The Department has had plenty of proof of this as letters are constantly received which indicate agitators are at work. In some cases however these parasites venture to display their individualized ignorance of the Indian situation and are a worse menace than knowing agitators; for the public is ready to accept anything on an agitative nature. Wrong impressions are thereby made, and falsified pictures are drawn of a work which should in no way be tampered with, especially by ignorance and amateurs.

There is a tendency for men in the field to lower themselves to the same standard as the Indians because the Indian is casual and unstable especially in regard to time. Punctuality is foreign to his make-up unless taught, but by careful teaching sometimes drastic to himself, he will in time respond. Church and Department alike should be always ready to maintain an equalized schedule. The Indian is no slouch, while he says nothing, he thinks a lot and his thoughts are demonstrated in his actions. He will drop one whom he knows will misplace his appointments, he will scorn one who is not as good as his word and that by this modernized Indian, who is not what his father was, will say one thing and never think of carrying it into effect.

There are a great many weaknesses in the present day system which are foreign to a general stipulated cohesiveness that in itself has a tendency to create a spirit of doubtfulness in the Indian which in his original make-up was really not there. We are too fond of transferring obligations where possible, or shelving responsibility. This particular bit of work is not my business; it belongs to the Educational Department. I therefore put into effect what the principal to the school says: he wants your boy or girl and therefore he must have him. Instead of putting it the other and better way - the Department says your boy must go to school and since there is whom I must have him. Agents should know their agencies and should be able to say I have so many children of school age, how many are you graduating so that I may know what to do. Families should be considered and good judgment meted out regarding those who first should go to school; simple but concrete co-operation. How many times principals are confronted with the story of how "you forced me to come to school" when if the agent and his assistant were really interested this would not be the case. Directly a shelving of responsibility is exhibited there is something wrong. There is no place for any but men who see and will take their responsibility of their own position and help others in their positions, for God knows the work needs us all with every faculty alert and every pulse vibrating with the call of duty. No one should be afraid of the responsibility of their position, fear undoes so quickly that which has taken years to build.

There are a great many Indians who have no scruples whatever and there are a great many white men who are ready to fraternize with these. There are also white men, sometimes those in authority, who will stoop to trappings for the Indian and will in good faith fraternize with him just for the purpose of getting the society which goes with laid information, when a case is brought up against the Indian. Cases have also been known where whites in authority have stooped to giving parties to make good fellows of themselves and claim for themselves a good-fellow place in the eyes of the Indian so that they might afterwards make use of the Indian and in being by the men who have the work at heart, brought up for hearing, have bribed or coerced the Indian into taking a false
oath. Trouble of this kind arises in Provincial and Dominion relations, game wardens and provincial constables who are not square have no more right to have anything to do with the Indian than has a man in the Dominion employ who is of equal calibre. There are flagrant cases of men who under provincial law are freed from crimes which should put them behind bars for years.

One then would question the authority given provincial men by the Indian Act. One also would question the mealy given informants as a possible source of wrong in encouragement to cater to the Indian's weaknesses for material gains. It would seem impossible to separate the Indian from the grasp of Provincial authority yet one feel that less opportunities be given to Provincial field authorities and more power of authority invested in the hands of the Dominion men, with a decent salary attached, so that he could not be confronted with the temptation to stoop to things of low calibre. Provincial authorities lie in wait to take advantage of the Indian when such should not be allowable. This weakens the hands of those who wish to do what is right and is also very discouraging, not to say anything of its degrading morals.

Regarding enfranchisement, the Indian Act is careful to state that enfranchisement shall not be forthcoming to an Indian without his consent and the consent of the band. This has been amended to read that a committee appointed may make choice of Indians who may be given the franchise with a proviso that no violation of any agreements made between them and the crown will take place. Enfranchisement would affect only a very few Indians for all of them have interest, more or less vital, in the reserve which has been set apart for their possession. Any Indian would be very foolish to ask for enfranchisement since he can enjoy so many privileges, shelving his responsibility in so many ways. He makes it a business to see that he receives attention, demanding it in excess.

The Act also reads that, "in case of any Indian given the franchise shall be given letters patent to all property which he has heretofore held in the reserve, providing he pay for such property and shall be classed as a citizen of good standing in the Dominion, possessing and enjoying the same legal powers, rights, and privileges as his Majesty's other subjects and shall no longer be deemed to be Indian within the meaning of any laws relating to Indians." This cannot be done without his removal from the reserve and if it should so happen he should be taken at far away from the reserve, his friends and kinfolk, as it is possible for him to be removed, so that in no way would he be able to exercise these new rights and privileges on his own people. To leave him on the reserve would simply mean chaos and would undo everything which has been done. Think of the untold harm one man, with practically unrestricted access to liquor stores would do; though he may not be an offender in excess drinking himself, yet he could ruin a whole reserve in a very short time. It is also a well known feature among the Indians that they will all gather around their fellows and wouldn't they have a great time enjoying the white man's privileges suddenly thrown upon one in their midst? Jail the criminal yes but would it not be better for him to still be an Indian and to a degree at least would take care of himself, even while he is constantly in jail, the country would have to be wholly responsible for him.

As a citizen who would have sole right over his own property he could sell and presently one would find a Chinese vegetable garden in the middle of a reserve which would be a wholesale menace, with arms reaching to complete destruction of reserve, health, and everything else deemed a benefit. The Chinese menace is bad enough with restrictions but with no letters it would simply be left havoc and the Department would reap accordingly. By all means let us give the full franchise to those few who are eligible and who are to-day living, in every sense taking the responsibility of the country's making, and who are not living on the reserve, and who earn their own living, in every sense of the word.
To those who are living on the reserve but earning their living off the reserve, e.g., laborers on the sections, farmers, etc., greater care must be taken. Beginning with this man comes the standard of citizenship which has been heretofore explained. He must be made to accept in every way the responsibility beginning with the care of his own family. This can only be done by the day school system followed by the higher secondary school education wherein he would be obliged to take care of at least part of the expense entailed. Then by a following-up scheme which can easily and readily become a very efficient means of caring for not only the few but would reach out to all. One sees a big initial expenditure in the offing but what are a few thousand dollars in making a recovery of millions over a very short period of years. It would also be a real beginning in the permanent uplift of these people.

It must also be remembered that the initiative must be taken by the Department and through its men in the field it can only be made a success. It therefore is important that men must be prepared to begin with what they now have on hand; a people who are in the middle of an educational transition period. The status now is worse than it was in the beginning. Education has been the salvation of many as it has been pointed out, but need not be if a regulation were made whereby those educated would be obliged to make proper use of their education rather than to use their development of brain to beat the law or get out of paying his just debts. Give his victim an opportunity to collect; take away protection of a wrong nature and protect him by making him work and pay as he goes. I am firmly convinced that in the course of a very few years the Indian work of B.C. could be so reconstructed that it would not only show a great reduction in expenditure but would also find the greater percentage ready to be given enfranchisement and to take it and use it as any other citizen of the Dominion.

In studying the Act one notes that a chief and a council are duly elected under the supervision of the Department, any member of which being subject to recall for certain stipulated crimes. This should be almost scrupulously observed; a chief who is immoral, dishonest, intemperate or incompetent should be removed at once and likewise with a councillor. This is one place where an agent can bring into play a real weapon that can be utilized so wonderfully for the uplift of the Indian but it is so very often neglected that it is more or less farcical to them. The Indian is very fond of position, so deprivation of honour as a rule hits them hard. Indians of the old school of thought, i.e., who tolerate potlatching, old time burial ceremonies or Indian practitioners in medicine should never hold a position as chief or councillor. Men who have risen above these things through Christian teaching and secular education properly used should fill these positions. What encouragement can one of the old school give to those who have gone through a modern school and what help would he be to the Indian agent? Every possible use should be made of the chief and the council, making sure that they realize their worth and that they are working in accordance to the Act. They should be regularly called together, their duties defined, and reports made on their fulfillment of duty, and minutes of these meetings should be taken and kept. Officials visiting reserves could very quickly ascertain what the Indians of the agency expected and were doing in the way of uplift. Another duty could be added to those already stipulated: "To keep all undesirables off the reserve, whites and halfbreeds alike." There is great need of more strict observance of the halfbreed situation. There are many who are neither white nor Indian but who should have some designation. It is a marvel how these men, here and there, come to our notice; some who are receiving reserve privileges and reserve protection which, taken away, would be a severe hardship on these men, their dependants, and their own or their wife's parents. These men should be given Indian status and handled accordingly. A survey of this situation should be made by each agent and an unbiased decision made. The situation calls for a line to be drawn where a district
district separation is forthcoming. Fish cannot be made of one, and flesh of another, clean up and begin anew.

The tendency is to take everything out of the hands of the Indian which is not in accordance to the Act. One common aim should be set throughout. If franchise, then let us get busy and make those who are eligible take it as other citizens. If a standard of citizenship which will reach all is the aim, then let us together evolve a scheme, whether by getting opinions from selected individuals or by meeting on block. Whatever is to be done should be done at once. There is no time to waste in generalities or waiting to shelve responsibility. Ask one of the officials now in office in the province to make a survey and to see that it is thoroughly and intelligently made. Let it be done by one individual who will not stuff the job off or to someone else which is sometimes so carefully and unscrupulous; done in so many cases in government positions. Time should be taken to be thorough so that the situation could be fairly studied and presented. Perhaps a workable programme could be drawn up by which the official could be guided. Whatever is done should be done by one person and he should make it his business to see every worker, departmental and church alike. He should present the scheme to the Indians and get their opinions, and also to the councils where a great deal of information should be forthcoming, if these are being used by the agent, and would be if he were alert and interested in his Indians. On the other hand if the agent is not able to conduct a meeting (which by the way is not impossible) an official will not be able to make much of an Indian council interview.

There is in B.C. a very important position to be filled and if politics are kept out of it and a man appointed from the ranks, if possible, but if not, the man chosen should make his work an interest and study. There is a great opportunity awaiting such a man and the appointment is keenly awaited by all, especially the men who are interested workers because the filling of that position means much to the Indian work of B.C.

App. 1. The educational standards of officials should be a real consideration. If at all possible men who have a college degree should fill all positions. No constables should be appointed who have had at least Senior Matriculation Certificates. All other officials should have higher standards. A constable with only a matriculation certificate must not expect promotion unless a very outstanding man in the work and has amply proven his interest and worth.

Dr. McGill,
