Indian Schools Roll Increased To New Records

Churches Are Actively Co-Operating Along Educational Lines

Ottawa (C.P.)—A total of 340 Indian schools were in operation in Canada during the past fiscal year, according to reports issued by the Department of Indian Affairs. Of these, 80 were residential and 260 day schools. In addition, the department assisted in the maintenance of nine combined white and Indian schools.

The total enrolment was 17,425 and the average attendance 14,887. This was an increase in enrolment over that of the preceding year of 302 and an increase in attendance of 380. A more regular attendance was maintained at the day schools during the year, the average being 65.73 as compared with 63.69 for the previous year. The percentage of attendance at the schools was 77.4, a record for the work.

Efforts were continued during the year to improve conditions in both day and residential schools. Many fully qualified teachers and instructors were engaged and equipment was maintained to standard. The residential school activity was particularly encouraging. All the schools had an enrolment of pupils to full capacity. Under present conditions, the Indian parents are anxious to place their children in the schools did this become possible.

Several of the churches are actively engaged in the management of Indian day and residential schools. This co-operation of the churches in the case of residential schools is as follows: Roman Catholic, 44; Church of England, 21; United Church, 13; Presbyterian Church, 2; making a total of 80.

In addition to the regular academic work taught in Indian schools, there is the very important vocational training at the residential schools. Farming, gardening, raising of stock, manual training, and domestic instruction are being given more attention than ever before. Although at day schools is most difficult, but progress is gradually being made.

Dialysis is used in many of the classrooms, except those in the more northern schools. Under arrangement with the provincial departments of Education, the services of regular inspectors and separate school inspectors are utilized, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and Newfoundland where there are special Indian school inspectors. In addition, there is a medical inspection service which gives constant supervision to the vocational training.

Computing and high school work is taught at several of the day and residential schools. The more advanced pupils in those institutions schools that are situated close to universities or colleges are assisted by secondary teachers in competition with white children. There were 120 half-time Indian students not shown in the tabular statements, attending public schools, high schools, and universities in Canada.

The department, in the case of most of these assists with a grant from parliament for the purpose.

No new building operations were undertaken during the year, only were carried out in order to keep buildings in a good state of repair.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has frequently been requested, in the past, to assume financial responsibility towards the capital cost in erection of residential school buildings in which it does not exercise the right of ownership, also make grants towards cost of additions, repairs and maintenance, after the work has been completed, without plans and estimate of cost having first been submitted for departmental approval. This also applies in the case of purchase of equipment and furnishings. In some instances, undertakings have been made on the part of the Department to furnish certain financial assistance, but many of the arrangements made in this connection have been verbal in nature and the terms are not of definite record. It would seem, however, that, in some, if not all, cases, the Department is obligated to some degree, but the lack of written records and agreements makes it difficult to determine the nature and extent of this responsibility.

The fact that the Department has undertaken the payment of per capita grants implies a certain responsibility for the upkeep of the buildings and equipment, if not for the capital cost. For the purpose of dealing with these difficulties in future, the Department has decided to adopt the following policy:

1. The Department of Indian Affairs will undertake the payment of per capita grants and any financial aid towards the cost of buildings and equipment only when the prior authority of the Department has been granted. This authority should cover such matters as site, size, and nature of school buildings, particulars regarding equipment and furnishings and cost involved.

2. Such authority in all cases to be set out in a formal and definitely worded agreement between the Department and the church authorities interested, for the guidance of both, as a matter of record, and for the purpose of avoiding future misunderstandings.

3. That the schools now operated by authority of the Department, as recognized by the payment of per capita grants, be assisted from time to time as circumstances warrant and financial conditions permit.

I wish to emphasize that, unless authority is first obtained, the Department cannot in future assume any responsibility for reimbursing church authorities or principals of schools towards any part of cost of work undertaken by them in the erection of school buildings, the making of additions and repairs, or the purchase of equipment and furnishings.

I would request that the above rulings receive your careful attention.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

October 16 1922

Dear Canon Gould:

I have to inform you that there has been an amendment of the definition of the words "Protestant Child" and "Roman Catholic child" as they appear in subsection 1 of section 10 of the Indian Act. It is my request that you substitute the present communication for that of June 5th, last, and govern yourself accordingly.

The concluding part of subsection 1 of section 10 of the Indian Act, as enacted by 10-11 Geo.V., Chap. 50, Section 1, provides as follows:

"... No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic School, or a School conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

The opinion of the Department of Justice is that a Protestant child is one born of Protestant parents, or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices. A Roman Catholic child is one born of Catholic parents or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Roman Catholic school, or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices. In other words, the father has a right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child should be brought up, and his wishes must be regarded unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them.

In accordance with this view, if a Protestant parent wishes his child placed in a Roman Catholic school and brought up in the Roman Catholic religion, or a Roman Catholic parent his child in a Protestant school and brought up in the Protestant religion, he may do so; but for the protection of the Department, we demand in such cases an affidavit to that effect by the father. Such affidavit must be made before a justice of the peace. Indian agent, or other person authorized to take affidavits, and the person who takes such affidavit must certify that the statements set forth in the affidavit were read over or interpreted and explained to the deponent who thoroughly understood the same. In cases of Bona fide adoption, the religion and wishes of the foster father will be recognized by the Department.

As intimated in my earlier communications, I do not wish this ruling to be the occasion of requests that children be transferred from one school to another on the grounds of the present decision. I believe that a child, that has been resident in a school and may have imbibed religious opinions, should remain in that school for the full tuition period.
Yours very truly,

(sgd) Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General

Dear Mr. Scott:

Your letter dated June 5th, "concerning the religion of applicants for admission to Indian Schools", received, and considered by the Executive Committee of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada at its meeting held on Monday of this week.

The Executive Committee adopted, unanimously, the following resolution:

WHEREAS;

The Executive Committee of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada has before it the letter dated June 5th, of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs stating, in part, as follows:

"I have to refer to my letter of December 24th last concerning the religion of applicants for admission to Indian residential schools.

The concluding part of Subsection 1 of Section 10 of the Indian Act, as enacted by 10-11 Geo.V, Chap.50, Section 1, provides as follows:

".... No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic School, or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices".

The interpretation, which the Department had placed upon this part of the Section, having been criticized by certain officials interested in the education of our Indian wards, the matter was referred to the Deputy Minister of Justice, whose opinion is that a Protestant child means a child of parents who are Protestant; and a Roman Catholic child is one who has been baptized as a Roman Catholic or is born of Catholic parents; but the father has a right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child shall be brought up, and that his wishes must be regarded unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them".
THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED;
That the said interpretation is wholly unacceptable to
the Church of England in Canada, which demands an
interpretation governing in the same terms "applicants
for admission to Indian residential schools", in
relation to the Church of England and in relation to
the Roman Catholic Church; that the official withdrawal,
forthwith of the interpretation be respectfully but
most firmly requested and demanded; and that a copy of
this resolution be sent to the Right Honourable the
Prime Minister of Canada, and to the Honourable the
Minister of the Interior as the Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs".

The foregoing resolution is so explicit that I do not
think that I can add much by way of comment, save to say;

1. That by the words "governing in the same terms", we
mean that the form of words, that is the tests,
used to determine the religion of an applicant in
relation to the Roman Catholic Church must apply
also, under similar circumstances, to determine
the religion of an applicant in relation to the
Church of England in Canada. The interpretation
of the Act as given by the Deputy Minister of
Justice, quoted in the above resolution lays down
the definition that "a Protestant child means a
child of parents who are Protestants; and a Roman
Catholic child is one who has been baptized as a
Roman Catholic or is born of Catholic parents".
In other words two tests (1) baptism, (2) parent-
age, are applied to determine the religion of an
applicant in relation to the Roman Catholic Church,
and one only, parentage, in relation to the Church
of England.

2. That the interpretation under discussion is, in the
respect described, wholly and absolutely unaccept-
able to the Church of England in Canada. The inter-
pretation gives the Roman Catholic Church except-
ional consideration and, in consequence, directly
invades and contravenes the basal principle of
religious equality.

3. That I should be remiss in my duty if I failed to
emphasize in the strongest possible manner the fact
that the interpretation is wholly and absolutely
unacceptable to the Church of England in Canada;
which Church very respectfully, but most firmly,
requests and demands that it be withdrawn, forth-
with, in the same official manner in which it has
been announced; and that failing such withdrawal,
in the manner described, the Church of England in
Canada will, while definitely and publicly ref-
using to accept or to recognize the interpretation,
most strenuously resist and oppose the application
of the same by any and every means in its power.

In accordance with the instructions of the Executive
Committee I am sending a copy of this letter, including the resolution,
to the Right Honourable the Prime Minister and to the Honourable the
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

General Secretary.

LAUDS WORK OF INDIAN SCHOOLS

Dr. T.B.R. Westlake Says Indian an Asset Canada May Be Proud of

Winnipeg, April 28.—Canada has every reason to be proud of the fine type of citizen now being developed in the Indian residential schools throughout the country, according to Dr. T.B.R. Westgate, field secretary of the Church of England in Canada, who has just returned from a tour of Indian schools under the jurisdiction of his society.

Many Canadian crops of grain and vegetables which even stretch into locations within the Arctic circle, after convincing proof the Indian is an asset Canada might well be proud of, he said.

Dr. Westgate's tour took him from Moose Jaw, on James Bay in northern Ontario, to Alert Bay, Vancouver Island, thence over the historic trail of the fur traders in the north. The return journey was made down the Athabasca and Slave rivers to Hay River, Ontario Lake, Petzam, Elkhorn and on to Winnipeg.

Many pictures were taken at the various schools visited, including a photograph of an Indian plowing with a team of huskies supplying the power. Another picture was taken near Akhlavik, in the estuary of the Mackenzie. A grain elevator was owned and operated by Indians at one reserve visited, Sir. Westgate said.

There were 79 residential schools in operation during the year, with a total enrolment of 8,596 and an average of 7,760 - the percentage being 90.27. 256 day schools were also conducted, with an enrolment of 8,683 and an average attendance of 5,468, giving a percentage of 63.19.

As shown in the above paragraph, 335 schools were conducted by the Department, and, in addition, assistance was granted to 10 combined white and Indian schools. The total enrolment of Indian children at all schools was 17,448, with an average attendance of 13,362, giving a percentage of attendance of 76.52. The tabular statement, showing the location and indicating the enrolment and other facts in the case of each school, will be found in Part 2 of this report.

Every effort was made during the year to improve the efficiency in both residential and day schools. Qualified teachers and instructors were employed and equipment was maintained.

The Mackay Indian Residential School, which has been conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, was destroyed by fire on March 19th, 1933, and has not been rebuilt. During the year, the Department recognised a residential school conducted under the auspices of the Church of England at Fort George, Quahsee. In addition to the regular academic work at all Indian residential schools, farming, gardening, care of stock, manual training, and domestic instruction are being given more and more attention each year.

In the province of New Brunswick and in the province of British Columbia, the Department employs an Indian School Inspector. In the other provinces, arrangements have been made with the Provincial Departments of Education for the services of the regular public and separate school inspectors. Consequently, all classrooms
except those in the more northern schools are regularly visited by qualified inspectors. All pupils receive medical inspection at regular intervals.

Continuation and high school work is taught at several of the day and residential schools. The more advanced pupils in these residential schools situated close to municipal colleges are able to receive secondary education in competition with white children. There are approximately 200 Indian students who are not shown in the regular statement but who are attending public schools, high schools and colleges in Canada. In the case of most of these, the Department assists with a grant from Parliamentary Appropriation. Every possible effort is made to assist only those who will likely benefit from secondary education.

No new building operations were undertaken but all buildings were kept in a good state of repair. The expenditure for Indian Education for the year shows a decrease of $52,063.21, as compared with the previous year. Additional consideration has been given to the selection of suitable texts in order to provide books that would adequately meet the requirements of our schools. School inspectors and teachers have commented favourably on our efforts in this regard.

Gentlemen:

In connection with a study I am making of the relationship of the Government of the Dominion of Canada to education, I am anxious to secure authoritative information respecting the policy and program and legal provisions for the education of the Indians.

Any documents you may be able to send me bearing upon this question would be of material help and the receipt of the same from you would be greatly appreciated. If there are any charges involved I shall be very glad to remit the amount necessary to cover the same.

I am especially interested in the laws passed dealing with the matter from the time of its first initiation and also whether or not, and the extent to which, the provincial departments of education have been associated with the Dominion Government in providing for the education of the Indians.

Any information or materials you may be able to send me will be sincerely appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

James C. Miller
Professor, Educational Administration

Ottawa, Sept. 25, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, requesting information respecting the policy, programme and legal provision for the education of the Indians in Canada.

In reply I have to say that, under authority of Sections 9-11 of the Indian Act, as amended, the Governor in Council is granted authority for the establishment of schools for Indian children. Under separate cover, you are being forwarded a copy of the Indian Act. Section 100 permits the Indian Bands in Council to make rules and regulations as to the religious denomination to which the school established on a reserve shall belong.

Indian education had its beginning in all parts of Canada in mission schools. Gradually, the Dominion has shouldered the burden and accepted the responsibility.

There are two classes of schools - day and residential. The day schools, situated on reserves, are comparable in every way to the ordinary rural school. Residential schools are for the Indian child who is underprivileged from an educational standpoint, i.e., no school close to his home, orphan, or neglected. The activity at a residential school is both academic and vocational. Girls are taught the domestic arts, practical nursing, etc., and boys are prepared for whatever vocations are common on their particular reserves. The

Indian schools are not part of the provincial system, but, at our request, they are visited by the Provincial Public and Separate School Inspectors. Teachers are engaged or dismissed by the Department of Indian Affairs, but they are expected to follow the advice of the Provincial Inspectors.

From the establishment of the first schools, nearly 100 years ago, there has been cooperation between the Dominion Government and the various religious denominations interested in missionary work among the Indians. The majority of our schools are conducted under the auspices of one or other of the religious denominations associated with the Department in the carrying out of its educational policy.

There are no special reports on the Department's educational programme. Our Annual Reports are the only current printed matter. You are being forwarded a copy of the Annual Reports of the Department for the years ending March 31, 1927, and 1933. The Provincial Departments of Education have no responsibility whatever for the education of Indian children. All expenditure for the purpose is provided by Parliamentary Appropriation. Dear Dr. McGill:

I am preparing a dissertation on Education in Canada for my doctorate from Toronto University and should be very happy if you could assist me with information regarding your system of education. I am gathering statistics to cover a period of years from all the Provinces of the Dominion. When these shall have been completed, I hope to have a comparative statement that will be useful as well as scientifically valuable.

The following data is my chief concern, or figures which will lead to such.

1. Aggregate days of attendance.
2. Total number of children of school age.
3. Per cent of school population attending school daily.
4. Average days attended by each child of school age.
5. Average number of days schools were kept open.
6. Total elementary school attendance.
7. Total High School attendance.
8. (a) Number of Boys -- High School.
    (b) Number of Girls -- High School.
9. Total yearly expenditure for education.
10. Average annual expenditure per child of school age.
11. Total number of teachers employed.
12. Expenditure per pupil for purposes other than teachers' salaries.
13. Total expenditure for salaries.
14. Total annual enrolment.
If feasible, I should like to get figures which go back to the inception of public education in your Province—at least as far back as possible.

Any information regarding teacher-training, Normal School, cost of equipment, curriculum, etc., etc., will also be gratefully received.

Please forward everything that you can, and cost of same.

Thanking you in advance for your kind cooperation.

I remain

Very sincerely yours,

Cecil O'Brien

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter requesting further information regarding Indian schools in Canada. The Department does not issue any syllabus for Indian schools, as these schools follow the same curriculum as is prescribed by the province in which the schools are located.

You are, no doubt, aware that education in Canada for white children is under the jurisdiction of the different provincial governments. The education of Indians is the only system of education controlled by the Dominion Government and we have, therefore, found it advisable to adopt the system of following the provincial curricula.

One special difficulty in Indian schools is that many of the children do not speak English when they come to school. In order to assist the teacher, we have found it useful to use a manual prepared by the Department of Education of Ontario. While this manual refers particularly to the teaching of English to French-speaking children, many of our teachers have applied it to advantage in Indian schools. We have, also, found it necessary to prepare a Pre-Primer designed especially for our schools. For your information, I enclose a copy of the manual referred to above, also a copy of our Pre-Primer and the Work Book which is used in connection with it.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

DR. MCGILL,-

Relative to the communication the Right Honourable the Prime Minister received from J. A. Canadian, an Indian of the Caughnawaga Band, I would say that this man is a rather aggressive and prolific letter writer. He, his wife and two children are at present on relief. Concerning the request of the Prime Minister, to be advised what is being done in connection with Indian education, I would say, briefly, there are 256 day schools, 79 residential schools and 10 combined white and Indian day schools in operation in Canada, with an enrolment of 17,448 pupils and an average attendance of 76.52%. The average attendance compares favourably with that in provincial rural schools.

The Department is associated with the various Church denominations in the carrying out of its educational policy, the greater number of schools being conducted under church auspices. Buildings and equipment are kept to maximum efficiency, as funds at our disposal permit. Teachers having professional qualifications are engaged and all schools, except in New Brunswick and British Columbia, are inspected by provincial public and separate school inspectors. In the two provinces named, we have our own inspectors. Textbooks and classroom studies are as prescribed for provincial white schools.

At all residential schools and a great number of the day schools, pupils can advance to the Ninth or Entrance Grade. An increasing number each year pass their Entrance to High School. At the residential schools and certain of the day schools, there are classes in manual training for the boys and domestic science for the girls. The boys are instructed in farming and the care of stock at residential schools and the girls receive training in general household duties. It would not be possible, without a large increased expenditure, to extend the work. Reports from public and separate school inspectors frequently make favourable comparison of the instruction being given in Indian schools with that in White schools in their inspectorates.

There are a large number of Indian pupils taking advanced educational courses at high schools, colleges, business colleges and universities. No part of the cost of the education of Indian children is charged to the Indians.
Indians or to their Band Funds - all expenses being paid from Parliamentary Appropriation.

With special reference to the Caughnawaga reserve, to which Mr. J. A. Canadian belongs, I would say there are three modern 4-roomed schools, one 2-roomed school, and three one-roomed schools, with a teaching staff of 19 fully qualified professional teachers. In addition, there is a qualified physical instructor. Besides the regular curriculum, domestic science is taught the older girls and there is a stenographic and bookkeeping course for both boys and girls.

There are approximately 540 children of school age on the reserve. Of this number, 496 attend the day schools on the reserve and 40 others are in attendance at Indian residential schools, technical schools, business colleges and universities.

The buildings, equipment and classroom instruction on this reserve would compare more than favourably with the schools in the towns and villages of Quebec. None of the Indians contribute one cent to the cost of the education of their children. It would be difficult to improve classroom instruction at these schools. I consider that Mr. Canadian has no cause for complaint in connection with Indian education, at least on the Caughnawaga reserve.

CANADA'S INDIANS ADVANCE IN EDUCATION

Continued Gratifying Progress in Academic and Vocational Training - New Schools Being Erected

Ottawa, Canada.—The continued growing interest of Canadian Indians in education is a matter of gratification to the Department of Indian Affairs, stated Honourable Thomas G. Murphy, Minister of the Interior and Superintendent General of Indian Affairs when interviewed recently on the progress of the Dominion's wards. Canada's treatment of her aboriginal inhabitants redounds to the credit of the administration, and the response of the Indians to the Department's efforts to advance them to a position of independence and self-support has been a major factor in the success of the work.

In nearly every year since the inauguration of day and residential schools among the Indians increases have been recorded both in the number of pupils enrolled and in the percentage of attendance. Ten years ago, in the school term of 1923-24, the total enrolment was 13,873 and the average attendance, 9,198. Last year the enrolment had risen to 17,446, a gain of 25.77 per cent, while the average attendance had advanced to 13,352, an increase of over 45 per cent.

During the fiscal year ended March 31, 1934, there were 256 day schools, 79 residential schools, and 10 combined White and Indian schools in operation, a total of 345. The residential schools are conducted by the Anglican, Roman Catholic, Presbyterian, and United Churches, and high tribute must be paid to the zeal and self-sacrifice of those engaged in the work. The department has had the close co-operation of these religious denominations in the education of the Indians, and this well established policy has demonstrated beyond all question of doubt the effectiveness of the system.

Two new Indian residential schools and an extension to an existing school are in course of erection this year. At Sault St. Marie, Ontario, the new Shingwauk school is under construction to replace present old buildings. This structure, which will accommodate 150 children, will be modern in every respect and fireproof. It is expected it will be ready for occupation by July 1. The school will as in the past be conducted by the Church of England in Canada.

At Lebret, in the Qu'Appelle valley, Saskatchewan, a building sufficiently large to accommodate 250 children is in course of erection to replace that destroyed by fire in November, 1932. It will be of re-enforced concrete construction and will be ready for occupation about next autumn. The school will continue to be conducted by the Roman Catholic Church.

To provide increased accommodation, an addition is being made to the Residential School near Morley, Alberta. This building is of frame construction and when the addition is completed the school will accommodate 100 pupils. This school is conducted by the United Church of Canada and is for the benefit of the children of the Stony tribe.

(Continued on sheet 269)
In these schools, as in the other Indian day and residential schools, the provincial curricula is followed, with special emphasis on language, reading, domestic science, manual training, and agriculture. For the older pupils, half the day is spent in the class room, and the remainder of the time is devoted to vocational training. There are farm lands in connection with each residential school and a member of the staff is a competent farmer. Under his guidance, the older boys carry out the farming operations and by this means they acquire a practical knowledge of farming and animal husbandry. The girls receive training in sewing, dress-making, cooking, bread-making, and other household duties.

Every possible effort is made to impart a sound academic and industrial education and special attention is given to the health of the pupils. During the years spent in the residential schools, medical and dental treatment is provided, which with a balanced diet and supervised recreation, assists in the building up of a robust constitution.

THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS CIRCLE TOUR

Ottawa, Canada.— Excellent motor highways traversing Banff, Kootenay, and Yoho National Parks form a picturesque motor loop of 260 miles. From the town of Banff the highway runs to Castle and here forks, one branch turning south via the Vermilion pass and Kootenay Park, the other proceeding west to Lake Louise and, via the Kicking Horse pass and Yoho Park, to Golden, British Columbia. Zuni Pueblo

Modern institutions are rapidly being adopted by the Indian population of the country, say Indian Bureau officials in a recently issued statement. In the past two months a majority of reservations have voted to accept the Indian Reorganization Act which allows them to set up a modern form of business and political organization. And now word comes from the Zunis of New Mexico of the adoption of the popular vote method of electing officials.

At Zuni villages the life of the Indians is very much as it has been in years past. They are self-contained, independent communities. Their lives pursue the ancient pattern in these days very much as they have in times past. Their dwellings are ancient, the same crops are raised in their fields, the same arts and crafts flourish. The white man's representatives are there in the form of the Superintendent, teachers, doctors, and so on. But side by side with these many of the old Zuni customs have remained.

One of these customs was the way of selecting the governor, he who would own the cane presented to the Zunis by President Lincoln as a symbol of office. In the past the choice of the governor has been made by the caciques or priests, a body of five older men whose decision bound the whole village. Once appointed by the caciques, the governor then remained in office until, by the same priestly judgment, he was replaced.

But recently there has been a trend toward popular government in the old pueblo. The young people and the more progressive old ones joined about a year ago in presenting a demand to the Indian Office for regular elections. The Indian Office left it up to them. When they finally decided that they wished to adopt the American institution of popular vote, white officials took no part in the actual election beyond seeing that order was maintained.

The first election under the new system was held recently and it passed off smoothly with an election of governor and village officers. The new men ran on a platform of supporting the present administration in its movement to fight erosion of tribal lands and to institute a program of range control. At the end of the day a village feast was held with the roasting of—appropriately enough—three buffalos.

Arts and Crafts

There is now an "Indian Trading Post" in the department store of R. H. Macy & Co., New York City, that harbors arts and crafts American Indians that are considered incredibly beautiful examples of contemporary art. The purpose of this "Post" is "to acquaint people in the East with the charms of these things to explode the fabulous legend that the Indians could make no Indian art at its best; to show that Indian rugs, pottery, paintings and weaving fit with contemporary interior decoration as deftly as anything concocted by the modern masters of design."

This ought to prove an effective outlet for the handiwork of the Indians. It was inspired by Mrs. Charles W. Collier.

Help Wanted!

The I. R. A. is urgently in need of funds to keep up its work without any loss of effectiveness. A formal appeal has just been sent to our members and friends, and we hope the response to it will be prompt and generous.

Death has taken a heavy toll from the ranks of our faithful supporters, and the depression has reduced the income of others, but if each one does a part as circumstances permit, the necessary funds will be forthcoming.

Thomas-Rogers Bill

Exploiting the Indians of the Five Civilized Tribes in Oklahoma has continued so long that it seems to be considered by a certain class of attorneys as a game that should not be interfered with. The matter was very well put by Senator Wheeler at a hearing of the Senate Sub-committee on January 8, 1929 (page 1190), when he remarked to a witness:

"There are only two classes of people down in Oklahoma, the Indians and those who live off the Indians; is not that right?"

"Mr. Selby—Yes; there are a lot of honest people down there, Senator. There are many of course who live off the Indians.

"Senator Wheeler—From listening to your testimony I have come to that conclusion."

The force of this statement is illustrated by the vicious attacks on the Thomas-Rogers bill, which aims to afford a larger measure of protection to the Indians of the Five Civilized Tribes—and, indeed, to all Indians in the State of Oklahoma. Senator Thomas and Representative Rogers, both of Oklahoma, and Chairmen of the respective Indian Committees, are to be commended for their courage in seeking to stop these abuses which have grown into customs. The need for such legislation is clearly shown by the determined opposition of those who are interested in the continuance of a system that has been so disastrous to the Indians of the Five Civilized Tribes.

Navajo Boundaries

The New Mexico Boundary Bill (H. R. 6542) would complete the task begun by the last Congress in
defining the exterior boundaries of the Navajo reservation in Arizona. The country occupied by the Navajo Indians is primarily valuable only for grazing purposes. It also requires large areas because of the sparseness of desert vegetation and water. Many Navajo Indians now have public domain allotments in the area within the proposed New Mexico boundary. The bill would make possible solidification of these areas by exchange or purchase and eliminate the friction due to the "checker-board" occupancy by Indian and white stockmen.

Indian Claims

Several bills have been introduced in the present Congress providing for setting up an Indian Claims Commission, or a Court of Indian Claims. Probably the companion bills (S. 2731, and H. R. 7837) are the best suited to the purpose desired. Settling up the mechanism for settling for all Indians and for all time their claims against the Government is urgently needed. The hope of securing large sums of money which will make all members of a given tribe wealthy, the disturbing influence of agitators seeking personal emolument, and the feeling of the Indians that justice is being denied them, stand in the way of an effective program of cooperation between the Government and the Indians. At the present rate of handling Indians' claims this procedure must go on indefinitely. The creation of such a Claims Commission as is proposed by this legislation should bring about the settlement of these matters within a reasonable period of time.

W-H Amendments

A bill (S. 2655, H. R. 7781) is pending in Congress to amend the Wheeler-Howard Act in two important sections. First, it provides that any elections under the Wheeler-Howard Act on the question of excluding a reservation from the application of the Act, on adopting a constitution and by-laws or amendments thereto, or on adopting a charter, the vote by a majority of those actually voting shall control the election, provided that the total vote cast shall not be less than 30% of those entitled to vote. Second, the time for elections as to whether the Act shall apply is extended for a year—until June 18, 1936. There are desirable amendments in view of the confusion that has resulted from the stipulation of the Wheeler-Howard Act that in order to exclude themselves from its provisions a majority of the tribe must vote against it, and the ruling that those not voting were counted as being in favor of it.

An Oklahoma Plum

A Joint Resolution (S. 109 and H. J. 264) has been introduced in Congress which aims to remove from the classified service the position of Superintendent of the Five Civilized Tribes in Oklahoma and make it a presidential appointment, subject to confirmation by the Senate. The Resolution provided "that such Superintendent shall be an Indian by blood, an enrolled member of one of the Five Civilized Tribes..."

There is no justification for adoption of this Joint Resolution except that it would put one more "plum" at the disposal of the Oklahoma politicians. If it is desired to appoint an Indian to the position, providing he had the qualifications though not a civil service status, he could be selected through a presidential exception.

When it is considered that the Superintendent of the Five Civilized Tribes Agency has the supervision of trust funds approximating 18 million dollars and restricted Indian property worth upwards of 80 million dollars, it is clear why it should not be subject to the blighting hand of political influence.

W-H Appropriations

The Interior Department Appropriation bill for the year beginning July 1, 1935, as passed by the House and Senate and reported out of Conference, contains the following items for carrying the Wheeler-Howard Act: Credit fund, $2,500,000 (although the W-H Act authorized $10,000,000); Land Purchases, $4,000,000 (one-half of the sum authorized); Student Educational loans, $175,000 ($75,000 less than the amount authorized), and for Tribal Organization, $150,000 (as against the $250,000 authorized). The Wheeler-Howard Act authorized appropriations of $12,500,000, and the present Congress is appropriating less than one-third of that amount. It looks like short-sightedness to build a good machine and expect it to run without fuel.

Montreal Conference

At the National Conference of Social Work, to be held at Montreal June 9-15, the Committee on the American Indian will hold two sessions: June 10th and June 11th, 11 A.M. to 12.30 P.M.

The topic for the first session (June 10) is "Governmental Policy in Indian Affairs." Commissioner Collier is expected to speak on "The Present Policy." A speaker (to be announced later) will discuss "The Relation of the Government to Indian Needs."

On June 11 the main topic will be "The Indian Community." The speakers on the program are: Samuel Gerson, Director of Social Service, Montana Relief Commission, and Mark L. Burns, Superintendent of the Consolidated Chippewa Indian Agency, Cass Lake, Minn. Lawrence E. Lindley, Washington Representative of the I.R.A., is Chairman of the Committee and is expected to preside at both sessions.

Philadelphia Indians

The Society of Neighborhood Indians of Philadelphia, with a membership of about 250, will hold an annual Carlisle-Haskell night on Friday, May 17, at 1234 Locust Street. "Old grads" from different parts of the East are expected to attend this event.

EDUCATION.

During the year 79 residential schools, 362 day schools and 10 combined Indian and white schools were in operation—a total of 352 centres of Indian educational activity. The total enrolment was 17,560 and the average attendance, 13,442—a percentage of attendance of 76.54. The enrolment for the year is the largest and the attendance the highest yet reached. In Part II of this report will be found a tabular statement showing the location and indicating the attendance at all Indian schools. The same number of residential schools were in operation last year and the results have been very encouraging.

Efforts were continued, during the year, to secure efficiency in both the residential and day schools. Many fully qualified teachers and instructors are engaged and equipment is maintained to standard. All residential schools had an enrolment of pupils to full capacity. The Indian parents more and more realise the benefits of education and are anxious to place their children in the residential schools.

The cooperation of the Churches in the management of the residential schools was as follows:

Six new day schools were established, where there was promise of real usefulness. On many of the reserves, the Indian day schools secure as good an attendance and results as rural white schools.

Provincial curricula for public and separate schools are followed and fully qualified teachers are engaged. In addition to the regular academic work at all Indian schools, there is the very important vocational training at the residential schools.

Under arrangement with the Provincial Departments of Education, the services of regular public and separate school inspectors are utilized, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, where there are special Indian School Inspectors. In addition, there is medical inspection and department officers give constant supervision.

Continuation and high school work is taught at several of the day and residential schools. The more advanced
advanced pupils in these residential schools that are situated close to municipal colleges are benefited by secondary training in competition with white children. There were approximately 200 Indian students, not shown in the tabular statements, attending public schools, high schools and colleges in Canada. The Department assists them with a grant from Parliamentary Appropriation.

The practice of assisting the most promising and industrious graduates of Indian schools was continued. Except in those Indian communities where successful farming is found, the school graduate presents a problem which is very difficult of solution. The Department and the Churches interested are continually trying and searching for better methods of helping the young people to establish themselves.

New main buildings were commenced during the year at two residential schools - Sault Ste. Marie, Ont. (Shingwauk Residential School); and Lebret, Sask. (Qu'Appelle Residential School). An addition is being erected to the residential school at Morley, Alberta, to provide increased accommodation. All school buildings and equipment were kept in repair as far as funds permitted.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, requesting information regarding Indian residential schools.

In this connection I have to say the Department has no published literature for distribution, other than the annual report of the Department. I am sending you a copy, under separate cover.

All Indian residential schools are conducted under the auspices of one or other of the religious denominations associated with the Department in the carrying out of its educational policy. The larger number of the residential schools are government-owned institutions, but there are also a number church-owned.

The Department provides a per capita grant for a stated number of pupils at each school. From this grant, the authorities in charge of the school are to provide the cost of food, clothing, salaries of staff and all incidental expenses, and the Department is responsible for the upkeep of buildings and major items of equipment.

The church-owned school buildings and equipment are, to a large extent, maintained by the church authorities. However, if funds are available, the Department may assist towards the cost of repairs and equipment. The church authorities engage the services of all members of the staff, but their appointment is subject to the approval of the Department. It is necessary that they are fully qualified for the positions to which they are appointed.

The work in the classrooms is inspected by the provincial school inspectors, except in the province of British Columbia, where we utilize the services of our own inspectors. Besides, the schools are frequently visited by the local Indian agents and departmental inspectors.

I am sending you, also, a copy of the Indian Act, and would refer you to Sections 9, 10 and 11. This comprises the law regarding the establishment of schools and the carrying out of the educational policy of the Department.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, requesting further information regarding the schools in northern Manitoba.

Replying to the second enquiry in your letter, I attach a list, in duplicate, giving the dates on which the various day school activities, as mentioned in your letter, were started and recognized by the Department of Indian Affairs. Our early records are somewhat incomplete. In nearly all cases, these schools were started as missionary enterprises; the church authorities interested, after the schools were conducted more or less intermittently, requested the Department to contribute a grant towards salaries and other expenses. Therefore, it is impossible, in some cases, to give the exact date on which the schools started.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL.

I note from your memorandum of the 14th instant that one of the representatives of the church missionary societies recently stated to the Honourable the Superintendent General that, when a child in a residential school is ill and unable to attend classes, payment of per capita grant is not allowed during the time missed from classes.

No such instructions have ever been issued by the Department.

As long as a pupil is in residence, with the Department's permission, grant is allowed even though such pupil is unable to attend classes owing to illness or other reason.

When a pupil is absent from a residential school for more than two or three days, either through illness or from some other cause, no per capita grant is allowed for the period of absence. I think you will agree that this is fair treatment, due to the following reasons:

(1) In the majority of cases of absence through illness the pupil is sent from the residential school to hospital, where the maintenance costs are paid by the Department.

(2) In the case of truancy or neglect of children to return promptly upon the expiry of their leave, the school is not required to maintain them, and, therefore, is not entitled to per capita grant for the period of their absence.

Dear Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, addressed to the former Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, requesting information regarding the work of educational type which is carried on among the Indians of Canada.

Some 17,560 Indian children are enrolled in the 350 day and residential schools. These schools are not under the control of the Departments of Education in the different provinces but are financed and managed jointly by the Department of Indian Affairs and the various churches engaged in the work. In each province, the Indian schools are inspected regularly by qualified school inspectors, and the work done by Indian pupils compares favourably with that of the white schools in the same localities. In the day schools, in addition to the regular curriculum, emphasis is placed on handiwork, gardening, hygiene and group games. The residential schools give still further teaching in the manual arts that will assist the pupil in later life. The boys are trained in farming, gardening and the care of stock; and the girls are systematically taught all household duties.

Parliament annually provides appropriations - amounting during the present fiscal year to two million dollars - from which the expenditures for the maintenance of the various schools are made. The churches which are cooperating provide further funds to finance them.

Special training or assistance is offered to the promising graduates of the day and residential schools. Approximately 300 young Indian men and women are attending high schools and colleges in Canada. Financial assistance and careful supervision for these special pupils are arranged for by the Department. Other energetic graduates are given grants for stock, implements, household equipment or building material.

In the residential schools - 79 in number - the staffs are nominated by the church authorities, and the activity is supervised by them and by the Department. The pupils in primary grades devote both morning and afternoon to classroom exercises, but the school day is divided for older pupils between academic instruction and vocational training.

RE THE ADMISSION OF CHILDREN TO RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

UPON FORMAL AFFIDAVIT BY THE FATHER.

The Department is guided by the following ruling.

If a Protestant parent wishes his child placed in a Roman Catholic school and brought up in the Roman Catholic religion, or a Roman Catholic parent his child in a Protestant school and brought up in the Protestant religion, he may do so; but, for the protection of the Department, we demand in such cases an affidavit to that effect by the father. Such declaration must be made in the presence of, and certified by, the Indian agent or other justice of the peace, as having been understood by the Indian parent and as embodying his wishes.

Dear Canon Gould:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 23rd instant, enclosing a copy of the Indian and Eskimo Commission's recommendation, in connection with the difficulties arising out of different religious beliefs when recruiting pupils for Indian residential schools.

I have noted the remarks of the Commission, and will be grateful for further enlightenment concerning two of their recommendations. Article No. 3 suggests that no Protestant child of one denomination be admitted to a school under the management of another Protestant denomination, without the consent of the authorities of the church to which the child belongs. In this connection, I wish to point out that in the past there has been practically no trouble between various Protestant denominations, and such a ruling, if put into effect by the Department of Indian Affairs, would cause considerable correspondence and give opportunity for endless trouble. As you know, the present effort is for the express purpose of minimizing difficulties, and I must confess that I am convinced that recommendation No. 3 of your Commission would lead to dissension among the interested Protestant institutions.

Again, I will be grateful for enlightenment concerning recommendation No. 8, which reads: "That the Department of Indian Affairs should be ready to consider applications in special cases where parents brought up in one faith desire their children to be brought up in another." Is it your wish that Roman Catholic parents be permitted, upon the signing of an affidavit, to place their children in a Protestant school? This has been the most irritating sore and might lead to wholesale proselytism. In addition, considerable trouble ensues in later years, when parents make the wonderful discovery that their children are being brought up in the wrong religious faith. I believe that, if parents brought up in one faith desire their children to be educated in another, they will themselves have undergone a bona fide change in belief. When the Department has reason to believe that such change on the part of the parents is in good faith and not for the express purpose of circumventing the Indian Act, children will be admitted to institutions conducted by the church with which the parents have become associated.

Dear Mr Scott:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of December 24th, in reference to difficulties arising in connection with religious belief when recruiting pupils for Indian Residential schools.

I wish to congratulate the Department for its attempt to solve a rather difficult question. However I must state that the Roman Catholic authorities cannot admit entirely the tentative decisions reached by the Department and I take the liberty of respectfully setting forth objections as also of suggesting a solution in some cases.

Paragraph 2 of your letter quotes a part of Section 10 of the Indian Act, as follows: "No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices." The words have been underlined by the undersigned with the object of showing that the conclusion of the Department, viz: "In the future, children from Protestant and Catholic homes will be considered eligible for admission, respectively, to Protestant and Roman Catholic schools only" does not conform to the word and spirit of the law as set forth in this Section 10 of the Indian Act, in which it is question of a Protestant child or a Catholic child and not the child from a Protestant or Catholic home.

Therefore do not see how the Department can alter this regulation. The Department can enforce law but has no authority to change it. Moreover, such a course would simply paralyze or discourage missionary efforts. And I wish to mention that I speak as much from a Protestant standpoint as from a Catholic one. The case has happened when Protestant parents have brought their children to a Catholic school stating clearly their intention of having said children baptized in the Catholic Faith (if they were not already) and educated in a Catholic school. A Catholic priest would act against his conscience and would not perform his duty and I dare say, would be in contradiction with himself in refusing such cases. Of course, prudence and respect for the Department's just regulations would dictate to him a procedure to safeguard his action and avoid possible trouble. Another instance is found in the case of children born of mixed marriages. Any Protestant wishing to be married to a Catholic party before the Catholic Church must sign a witnessed promise to give religious liberty to the catholic party and to have all children born of said marriage baptized and educated in the Catholic Religion. One will readily realize the difficulties arising in such cases from the ruling of the Department, specially when the father is a Protestant. Even in spite of the father's desires and solemn promises, and of the child's baptism the only school open to the latter would be the Protestant school. Under such circumstances the Department would go beyond its jurisdiction and its ruling would prove a manifest interference in the intimate rights and liberty of parents.
In Paragraph 3 the following principle of elementary natural law is set forth: "except under special circumstances, the father during his life, has a right to choose in what religion the children are to be brought up, even when the children are illegitimate." In my opinion the bringing in of this principle weakens the Department's reasons for the ruling given in Paragraph 2 and seems a contradiction, for, if the father's choice is admitted by the Department when the parents disagree why should not same choice be admitted and with far greater evidence when father and mother agree? A few words could be said relative to illegitimate children but this is not the proper place.

I have read over the Indian Act and copies of Correspondence and Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools and nowhere have I found that the Department was vested with the authority for dictating about the religion of an Indian, adult or child. Therefore the Department's ruling in the present instance could be considered ultra vires. The only concession possible would be in the case of difficulties arising from the choice, on the part of Protestant parents of a Catholic school for their children, or vice versa. Then the religion of the child (Section 10) is to be inquired into; that is the primary condition. In dubious cases the Department could be asked to give a decision. However, to safeguard all parties (the Department included) a declaration sworn to before a Magistrate and two witnesses could be made by the father or guardian declaring:

1. The religion of his child or his consent to the christening of the latter in another religion;
2. His free choice of the school conducted under the auspices of the child's religion.

This procedure has been practically followed by the Department in the past and I am pleased to state that difficulties have been rapidly smoothed by following such a course.

The Department can consider the above remarks as representing the Catholic view in the matter, and I have to substantiate and confirm my conclusions the approbation, under their own signature of the Rt Rev. Bishops, the Very Rev. Provincials and the Rev. Principals and Missionaries to whom I have forwarded a copy of the present letter. Such unanimity and precision of opinion from men attending to the spiritual care of the absolute majority of the Indians of Canada and identified with educational work in their behalf should carry a certain weight in the regulations of the Department on a subject of the importance of the one proposed.

Thanking you for asking our advice on the intended interpretation of the Indian Act and hoping that the Department will find agreeable to give its decision in the light of the principles referred to and deductions therefrom, I remain,

Yours respectfully,

Joseph Guy

Sir:

In the past, this Department has experienced some difficulty in the matter of paying accounts for equipment purchased for Indian residential schools. There are certain regulations governing the expenditure of public funds, and it will assist our officers if principals of Indian schools and church officials will remember the following instructions.

The Department's authority must be obtained for expenditures that are to be met other than from the school per capita grant. Requests should be forwarded through the office of the local Indian agent, so that his recommendation can be attached. It is quite in order for the principal to secure the assistance of the church authorities in the case of major expenditures, but the original request should come through the Department's officials in the field.

The requirements of the purchasing Commission must be kept in mind. If authority to purchase locally is granted, the principal or agent should secure competitive prices for all material over $15. If manufactured articles are desired, this Department will ask the purchasing Commission for the business houses that should be asked to quote. The principal, when requesting equipment, should intimate the type desired by referring to a price list or catalogue of some Canadian firm. The Purchasing Commission emphasizes the importance of buying, as far as possible, goods that are manufactured in Canada.

When the business has been awarded to a firm the bill should not be paid by the principal, unless it is his intention to finance the purchase out of per capita earnings. The account, in duplicate, should be given by the principal, not to a church representative, but to the Indian agent, or direct to the Department in the case of some residential schools not in Indian agencies. Our agent will certify the accounts if they are in order, and this Department will send a cheque to the firm that has supplied the equipment. When authority has been granted to purchase locally, a memo must be attached showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted, and whether the goods selected were manufactured in Canada or otherwise.

Your attention to the above requirements will assist this Department in its effort to administer the Vote for Indian Education in a satisfactory manner.

Deputy Superintendent General.

October 5, 1922.

I have to inform you that there has been an amendment of the definition of the words "Protestant child" and "Roman Catholic child" as they appear in Subsection 1 of Section 10 of the Indian Act. It is my request that you substitute the present communication for that of June 5th, last, and govern yourself accordingly.

The concluding part of Subsection 1 of Section 10 of the Indian Act, as enacted by 10-11 Geo. V, Chap. 50, Section 1, provides as follows:

"No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school, or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

The opinion of the Department of Justice is that a Protestant child is one born of Protestant parents, or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Protestant school, or a school conducted under Protestant auspices. A Roman Catholic child is one born of Catholic parents or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Roman Catholic school, or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices. In other words, the father has a right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child should be brought up, and his wishes must be regarded unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them.

In accordance with this view, if a Protestant parent wishes his child placed in a Roman Catholic school and brought up in the Roman Catholic religion, or a Roman Catholic parent his child in a Protestant school and brought up in the Protestant religion, he may do so; but for the protection of the Department, we demand in such cases an affidavit to that effect by the father. Such affidavit must be made before a justice of the peace, Indian agent or other person authorized to take affidavits, and the person who takes such affidavit must certify that the statements set forth in the affidavit were read over or interpreted and explained to the deponent who thoroughly understood the same. In cases of bona fide adoption, the religion and wishes of the foster father will be recognized by the Department.

As intimated in my earlier communications, I do not wish this ruling to be the occasion of requests that children be transferred from one school to another on the grounds of the present decision. I believe that a child, that has been resident in a school and may have imbibed religious opinions, should remain in that school for the full tuition period.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 8th instant, in which you request information regarding the assistance given to Indian pupils.

This Department has 73 residential and 260 day schools for the youth of our Indian wards in Canada. Residential facilities in Eastern Ontario and in Quebec are very limited, and lately this Department has made arrangements with several institutions conducted under Christian auspices for the care of some of the promising orphan or destitute Indian boys and girls.

The procedure adopted is to follow the recommendation of Indian agents, teachers and missionaries on the reserves. Representations are made to us from time to time concerning the ability of an Indian child who, for some reason or other, is unable to live at home and attend a departmental school on the reserve. Our representatives indicate the religion of the child and suggest a home or residential school where he or she can be provided for and educated. The Department makes a grant for this purpose to the institution chosen—the funds being provided from the Parliamentary appropriation for Indian Education. The individual merits of each case determine the Department's decision.

Further, we have assisted promising Indian boys and girls who have been in attendance at departmental schools. Parents are sometimes willing to provide a certain amount for the tuition of a child, and this Department has made a special grant for those fitted to undertake more advanced studies. Before providing for the tuition of an Indian boy or girl, this Department must be satisfied that the pupil in question is of the proper type and that careful supervision will be offered. Again, we look to our representatives for recommendations concerning each particular case.

Your obedient servant,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

OFFICE OF THE
DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL
OTTAWA

Ottawa, March 26, 1923.

Dear Mr. Kearns:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, requesting certain information regarding the Indian residential schools that are maintained or assisted by this Department.

You will find enclosed a list of government-owned schools, showing the religious denomination, the pupilage and per capita grant allowed. Church-owned schools are grouped under denominations and also show the pupilage and grant allowed. In explanation, I wish to state that the amount of per capita grant for boarding schools is determined on three bases: 1, ownership - government or church; 2, geographical situation - east, west and north; 3, type of building - well equipped and modern or otherwise. Two schools in the Yukon receive a higher grant than any others, because of the costs of food, clothing and other staple articles. Industrial schools each receive a per capita grant of $150, except in the province of Ontario, where they are classified in the same manner as boarding schools. In the industrial school class there are two exceptions to the general rule - the Mohawk Institute, in Ontario, and the Lytton Industrial School, in British Columbia, which are financed solely by this Department and without assistance from any missionary society or order. I am hopeful that these two institutions will be able to finance on per capita grants of $160 and $180, respectively, during the fiscal year 1923-24. The information contained in the attached list is for the fiscal year 1922-23.

From time to time, it is necessary to increase the pupilage at those residential schools where applications are numerous and when accommodation can be provided. The pupilage figures in each case are those that obtained at the close of the fiscal year 1922-23. Occasionally, when a school is accommodating its full quota of pupils, and the Department finds it necessary to admit orphan or destitute children, we allow supernumerary grant for them, until such time as vacancies occur among the regular grant-earning pupils.

Relative to the second paragraph of your letter, I have to state that the per capita grant is to enable the principal to meet current expenses; food, clothing and salaries are the major items in this connection. Equipment and equipment replacements, repairs to buildings, pupils' travelling expenses, medical and veterinary services and supplies, and postage are the chief expenses at residential schools.

W. Kearns, Esq.,
Assistant Auditor General,
Ottawa, Ont.
schools that are met by parliamentary appropriation, independent of the per capita grant. When funds are available, this Department meets expenses of every kind, with the possible exception of those incurred for food and clothing. The religious organization under whose auspices a school is operated may give grants to the principal, for salaries, to meet deficits and for any other purpose it sees fit.

There are some government-owned schools where church missionary societies or orders make special grants amounting to thousands of dollars per annum, in an effort to permit the school to give the type of instruction and residential care upon which we insist, and to keep the institution in a solvent condition.

Enc.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

ESTIMATES — 1921 - 22.

To provide a further amount for Indian Education...$100,000.00.

The above item represents a bonus at the rate of $20.00 per capita for the 5,000 pupils provided for in the Residential Indian Schools. This amount will increase the total estimate for Indian Education from $1,112,415.00 to $1,212,415.00.

A joint deputation representing the various religious denominations waited upon the Superintendent General a few days ago, and urged that this amount be granted as a bonus for the current year only. They are satisfied with the present per capita rate, which was increased by $10.00 in 1916 and by a further $10.00 in 1919. They state that while they have been able to conduct the schools on the government grants plus increased levies from their own funds, they have been unable to make good any repairs, carry out any improvements in their buildings, or to meet any incidental deficits from their current resources. Financial statements submitted to the Department show that during recent years the Churches have contributed approximately 25% of the cost of maintenance of these schools. It will thus be seen that the partnership existing between the Government and the Churches relieves the former of a large expenditure which would have to be met if a State system of Indian Education prevailed, and at the same time the State would lose the moral and civilizing influence of the Churches in its ultimate design of advancing the Indians towards full citizenship. The Churches confidently assert that if this bonus be granted for one year, they will be enabled during the following year to conduct the schools without any call upon the Government for maintenance beyond the authorized per capita grant.

It is interesting to compare the financial assistance given to our schools from Parliamentary Appropriations and like grants made to similar institutions in the United States from Appropriations by Congress.

In the United States the responsibility for Indian Education was some time ago assumed by the State. Previous to 1918 the per capita grant allowed by the United States Government for residential schools was $137.00. In 1918 this was increased to $200.00 for schools with a pupilage of one hundred or over, and $225.00 for schools with a pupilage below one hundred. During the fiscal year 1919-20 the average grant to Residential schools in Canada was approximately $137.00. During the year 1919-20 the average appropriation made by the United States Government for the education of Indian children in residential and day schools was $211.73 per capita, while in Canada for the same year the per capita appropriation was $141.37.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your No. 100 of the 5th ultimo, with general reference to the instruction offered in Indian residential schools in the Prairie Provinces. I have noted your criticism of the efforts made in these institutions to turn out young men who have a knowledge of the care of stock and of farming methods, and that you believe many of the principals are not qualified themselves in these matters.

I am aware that there is room for much improvement in the training the boys receive at residential schools, but it is only when you or one of our inspectors name the school, and, if possible, the member of the staff that is responsible, the Department can remedy conditions. If Parliament would vote twice the present appropriation for current expenses at Indian residential schools we could engage our own principals and staffs and supervise their activity. The present arrangement with the churches permits of the conduct of our institutions at a minimum of expense to the country, and, in addition, allows the youth of our wards to grow up in a Christian environment. And I must add that the missionary Societies and Orders have shown a pronounced willingness to co-operate with the Department in its effort to improve the instruction. If you or your officers can lay the blame for any inefficiency on the feet of a member or members of a school staff, the church authorities, at our request, will arrange for efficiency up to the limit of their resources.

You have referred to the academic instruction offered in our residential schools, and the need for drastic reform. I must draw your attention to the fact that we have lately engaged the services of public school instructors, and we have made arrangements in Manitoba and Saskatchewan for our teachers to attend local conferences and gatherings held by the officers of the Departments of Education. These are definite steps toward better teaching, and I look for decided improvement in this connection in the near future. The Superintendent of Indian Education assures me that every few days instructions are given to a principal or other church authority relative to changes on the various staffs. Your remark that "the schools of late have had a free hand in regard to the matter of employing teachers and instructors" is not in accordance with the facts. Our supervision has become, in the past year or two, more strict than ever before.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
If provincial school inspectors will report on inefficiency in the classroom, and the Department officers on those workers who are training our boys to be farmers, I am prepared to arrange with the proper church authorities for any necessary changes in personnel. We can continue these efforts until the missionary Societies protest that high salaried instructors are beyond their means; then, if such action is warranted because we are getting better results, the per capita grant may have to be increased.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Kearns:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the closing of the Dunbow (St. Joseph's) Indian Residential School during the fiscal year 1922-23. I have noted that you consider the financial wind-up of this school was not in strict accordance with the provisions of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act. I cannot agree that the funds and movable assets of a government owned Indian residential school which is managed, and has been managed for years, by church authorities are public moneys and property. The Church Missionary Society or Order supplements the per capita grant from year to year. Further, when the school management has made a futile effort to secure parliamentary appropriation for improvement to plant and equipment, church moneys are often used for the purpose. In other words, at a government owned Indian residential school, church authorities from time to time supplement parliamentary appropriation for both capital and current expenses.

I consider the bank account, crop, stock, food and clothing and all equipment belong to the State and the Church jointly. Inspector Murison, in the case of the Dunbow Indian Residential School, was directed to assist the church authorities in the closing so that our equity in movable assets would be safeguarded. Our officer was instructed to cooperate with the Rev. Principal and to see that all bills were paid. Any equipment of value to the other Indian residential schools managed by the same Order in the vicinity was distributed gratis. The remainder of the movable assets were sold and the school bills having been paid, the balance, $477.42, was deposited to Casual Revenue.

When Mr. Murison was paying the outstanding accounts, he telegraphed for permission to pay the arrears of salary. It developed later that these amounted to $5549.37. The Provincial of the Oblate Order at an earlier date had requested a total cash consideration of $16,589.98 for their equity in the property. In view of these facts I considered it advisable, before paying the arrears of salaries, to have Mr. Murison's audit and report before me. I therefore directed that the funds concerning which you have raised questions be deposited in a special account.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

W. Kearns, Esq.,
Assistant Auditor General,
Ottawa, Ont.
April 11, 1924.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

The attached letter from Mr. Commissioner Graham gives rise to certain general questions relative to the laundry and its equipment at Indian residential schools. The activity in the laundry serves a dual purpose—the washing for the institution is done and the older girls receive instruction.

In a modern institution of 100 pupils and staff, a sufficient number of labour-saving machines should be installed to permit the washing and sterilizing of the clothes to be done with enough dispatch to eliminate the irksomeness attendant upon too many days' labour per week. I believe that power machines for washing, extracting and drying are desirable in the larger institutions. The washer should be fitted with steam connections, so that the clothes may be sterilized. A small steam boiler also is therefore required. This equipment is used for the regular bi-weekly washing of bed clothing, under clothing, shirts, dresses, aprons, etc.

The officer in charge of the laundry regularly gives the girls instruction in the steps to be taken with an ordinary domestic washing. An assortment of articles to be washed is put through by hand for instructional purposes. Further, the girls will receive other experience as in an institution there are certain articles that can best be done by hand and frequently there is clothing to be boiled and washed at short notice. There is plenty of opportunity for instructing the laundry girls in ironing as this is all done by hand.

For the work that is being undertaken by hand the laundry should be equipped with a receptacle for boiling small quantities of clothes, flat irons, a box stove for heating them, stationary tubs and two or three hand wringers. Large wooden receptacles for soiled clothes and tables for ironing and sorting complete the equipment.

Supt. of Indian Education.
November 22, 1924.
