Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

At different times, representations have been made to the Department that it would be advisable to increase the annual vacation at Indian residential schools to six weeks. Of late years, Mr. Inspector Cairns has urged a longer holiday and Rev. Father Guy, on behalf of R.C. principals, has made a similar request.

The reasons advanced are as follows:

1. In extremely warm weather it is better for the health of the pupils if they are without classroom activity and without the restraint which is so irksome to the Indian child. (There is a general tendency to increase the duration of the summer vacation at educational institutions).

2. A certain number of the staff have to be on duty at Indian residential schools at all times. If the vacation of the pupils is limited to one month, some of the officers do not receive any more than two weeks' holiday.

3. One or two exceptions have been made and a holiday longer than 31 days is taken. Father Guy points out that some principals allow six weeks or more, without the permission of the Department, and have been doing it for many years.

I wish to recommend an annual vacation of 43 days instead of 31 days as formerly. This will be fully 6 weeks plus a Sunday at the end of the holiday. With your approval, I will draft a circular letter to the Church and Department workers interested. I propose to send a copy to two or three representative principals and to Commissioner Graham and Inspector Cairns, with the request that they make suggestions. Then a circular would be directed to all principals and agents, after having been approved by yourself.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, May 14, 1925.

To Church Authorities, Principals and Department Representatives:

The Department has decided to allow pupils at Indian residential schools annual leave with grant for any period up to 43 days. Holidays may be taken consecutively, at the discretion of the principal, during the September quarter. Other dates may be fixed only when specifically approved by the Department. The practice of giving pupils leave from Indian residential schools at Christmas is considered unwise, and, in future, grant will not be allowed if holidays at this season are given without permission. At no school should week-end holidays be granted.

Requests for special or emergency leave for pupils, who are urgently needed at home, should be made to the Indian agent, who will give approval only when he considers such leave absolutely necessary and after he has the concurrence of the principal, who should understand that grant will be discontinued. Special leave in the case of any pupil should be reported to the Department by the Indian agent. If the medical officer advises that a pupil be sent home for a period because of illness, the Indian agent should be informed and the principal, when preparing the quarterly return, should not apply for grant for those days the pupil was out of school.

Orphans and children of destitute parents should not be allowed summer holidays, unless satisfactory arrangements can be made for their care when away from school. Principals should not allow annual leave to children who have had to be brought in under escort upon the expiration of summer vacations and may refuse holidays to those pupils who have truanted during the academic year. Extreme care should be exercised in the case of pupils whose homes are distant from the school. Unless special safeguards concerning their return can be taken, holidays should not be granted.

When the September quarter return is being prepared, the dates of the annual leave should be clearly indicated and grant for the full quarter may be requested for all pupils who have been away from the school no longer than 45 days.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMO FOR FILE:

RE: Payments on the Per Capita Grant Basis.

P.C. 2810, dated 22nd October, 1892, was authority for changing the manner of financing Indian residential schools. This authority of His Excellency was secured with a view to more economical management, "when the whole cost of an institution is directly borne by the Government, the same economy by those in immediate charge is not used as would be employed under other conditions." It was considered that "the best way to effect the desired decrease (in expenditure) would be to place the schools under a per capita grant system similar to that" in operation at government established schools, which had been given to church authorities to manage.

This Order in Council reads in part as follows:
"The Minister therefore recommends that the following be applied to the industrial schools in operation in the Northwest Territories and to such other similar institutions as may hereafter be established as soon as, in the opinion of the Indian Department, such institutions are in proper running order, at rates to be fixed upon as being fair and just. . . . . . . . payment to be made only for children authorized by the Commissioner to be admitted and in accordance with the scale now governing payments to schools under the per capita system, which may be altered from time to time to suit circumstances. This Order in Council also contained clauses which had to do with the agreement to be entered into by the churches and it mentioned the per capita grant rate in the case of four specific schools.

On May 25, 1897, the Auditor General asked for a list of schools showing the amount of per capita grant to each, the authority for paying per capita grant and a statement concerning what expenses the per capita grant was to meet. On the 12th of June of that year, the Department forwarded a statement in answer to this letter from the Auditor General and mentioned that the authority in the case of all residential schools, other than the four specifically mentioned in the Order in Council, was "Parliamentary Grant." Two days later, the Auditor General asked to be informed what was meant by "Parliamentary Grant" as he did not find that these amounts had been voted to the different schools. He also pointed out that the Order in Council indicated $140 as the per capita grant to the Battleford institution and that it was now being paid at the rate of $145.
In connection with this last letter from the Auditor General, Duncan C. Scott prepared a memorandum for the file, which reads in part as follows: "The principle of such payment was fixed by the details of the General Estimates for Indian Schools. The separate items do not appear in the Supply Act. The authority to pay per capita grants to schools established after the date of the Order in Council was granted by the Order in Council (here quote). The division of expenses is made as strictly as possible upon the terms of the Order in Council."

The departmental reply to the Auditor General was dated June 26th and the words of Mr. Scott's memo were used. The quotation, however, omitted that portion of the Order in Council which reads as follows: " . . . . . . . . in accordance with the scale now governing payments to schools under the per capita system which may be altered from time to time to suit circumstances." I believe that, if these words had been included in the departmental letter, the Auditor General would not have replied on the 30th of July that it was necessary to have an Order in Council fixing the amount of the per capita grant to be paid to each school.

Mr. Scott then directed a memorandum to the Secretary, which reads in part as follows: "The wisdom of passing an Order in Council fixing these grants is doubtful and I do not see upon what ground the Auditor requires it. I suppose he has made the demand because he knows that in the case of the larger industrial schools we have obtained an Order in Council; but this Order was passed, not to fix the grants solely, but to place the schools upon a new footing - the per capita system - and it was thought advisable to make the change as authoritative as possible at the beginning. That order (22nd October, 1892) lays down the principles upon which these schools are conducted and provides that other schools may come under its terms. . . . . . . . . These per capita grants belong to such . . . . . . and distinct class of expenditure that, at first thought, it might be said that the demand for an Order in Council is reasonable; but it is just as unreasonable as it would be to demand the authority of His Excellency for any or all of our fixed charges. The allowances to schools are no more permanent. In the end, the Auditor may ask for full details of our Estimates, a matter with which he has nothing whatever to do."

Official letter of August 17, 1897, to the Auditor General states in part: "It is difficult to see why a payment of this kind should be fixed by Order in Council and I should be glad to know your reasons for thinking it necessary." The Auditor General replied on the 25th of August that Council, having fixed the rates in four cases and authorized these rates, has established a precedent which must be followed in authorizing the grants payable to other schools. The Department's reply, on the following day, was "that it is not possible for this Department to agree with your interpretation of Order in Council of 22nd October, 1892."
The Department's position at that time was that the O.C. established the principle of paying such per capita grants and it was therefore considered a sufficient warrant for the continuance and extension of the system. Following the Department's letter of the 27th of August, that it could not agree with the Auditor General's interpretation, the matter appears to have been dropped.

I consider that this memo is not complete without reference to correspondence which commenced with a letter from the Auditor General dated March 22nd, 1923. The Department was asked for a list of the residential schools, indicating the grant, pupilage, religious denomination, ownership, and was requested to send advice concerning any changes that might be made in the future. Mr. Learns also requested a statement showing what expenses were properly payable by the Government in addition to the per capita grant. I cannot overlook the possibility that the old question of the Department's authority to fix per capita grants was in the background at this time. I prepared a lengthy letter which was to go with the list requested and, as is usual when details of arrangements and agreements are given, the writing is not nearly as satisfactory as if general terms only are used. There are a thousand and one types of expenditure in connection with an Indian residential school and, no matter how careful one compiles a list of the expenses that should be met by the State, there are bound to be omissions and subsequent questions by the Audit Office. The more detail in definition the more limited is the application. The Deputy Minister, other officers of the Department and myself were at a loss to know how to reply. On December 28th of the same year, Mr. Learns asked for a reply to his earlier letter, and, on February 11th, 1924, a list of Indian residential schools showing ownership, religious denomination, pupilage and per capita grant as on April first, 1924, was submitted. Mr. Learns was informed that it is necessary to increase the pupilage at certain Indian residential schools from time to time. It might have been advisable to have added that adjustments in the per capita grant rate also were inevitable. The correspondence ended here, as the Auditor General did not insist on the information which the Department seemed reluctant to offer. Of course, our position was that some of his questions had reference to policy and administration and were outside the jurisdiction of any department but our own.

No authority, other than that of the Superintendent General, has been secured for the establishing of residential schools, for the fixing of the grant to be paid in each case, for the determination of the pupilage to be allowed, nor for an adjustment of the amount of the grant from time to time.
The grant in the case of a few schools has been increased when it was found necessary, and, when considered advisable, the Department has decreased the per capita grant in the case of a few schools. At the beginning of the fiscal year 1924-25, a flat $20 increase was made in the per capita grant payments, when the bonus of this amount - paid for the fiscal years 1921-22 to 1923-24 - was incorporated in the regular per capita grant. For the fiscal years 1919-20 and 1920-21, the per capita grant bonus was at the rate of $10. The Department is making an upward revision and a new classification of the residential schools at the present time.

An increase which averages $10 per child is being made in the case of some schools as from April first, 1926, and in the case of others, a year later. It is proposed to make a final adjustment at a later date, so that there will be some measure of relief to the financial situation in which the churches find their Indian educational work.

Russell T. Fettler,
Supt. of Indian Education.

The health of Indian children, particularly in residential schools, has been the subject for considerable thought and activity. A special effort is made in the matter of physical education and fairly comprehensive medical and dental supervision and treatment are provided. The Department is cooperating with the Canadian Junior Red Cross, with a view to better health for Indian children.

All the Indian schools are inspected frequently by department officials. In addition, public and separate school inspectors visit all classrooms, except in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, where there are special Indian school inspectors. More thorough inspection has resulted in a higher standard of instruction. Classroom activity in Indian schools is now comparable to the work in white schools of the same localities.

Indian schools follow the provincial curricula but place special emphasis on language, reading, domestic science, manual training and agriculture. In the junior grades, there is a departure from the provincial courses, which were found not altogether suitable in either scope or content for Indian children.

During the year, two modern, fireproof residential

The former building provides accommodation for 150 pupils and the latter, for 260. Seven day school buildings were erected, four of which provide living accommodation for the teacher. Funds to erect these buildings were provided under the Public Works Construction Act. School buildings and equipment were maintained in a good state of repair, as the funds provided for the purpose would permit.

Approximately 200 graduates of Indian schools, who showed academic promise, received grants for the purpose of continuing their studies at high schools, universities and business colleges. The policy is to make grants to the most promising, physically fit graduates of our own schools. If church and department representatives consider a graduate worthy, a grant is allowed when the bona fide intention of the pupil is evident and proper supervision can be secured for the period of advanced study. These tuition grants are continued only when satisfactory reports are received. Last year, besides those taking advanced work, there were approximately 180 Indian children attending white schools and orphanages. All these are in addition to the enrolment at Indian schools as shown in the tabular statements in Part 2 of this report. The expenditure from Parliamentary Appropriation on behalf of these special students amounted to $26,800.00 during the year.

The practice of assisting selected ex-pupils of residential schools to start farming and housekeeping has been continued. The expenditure for this purpose amounted to approximately $4,000.00.

EDUCATION

It may be of interest to briefly sketch Indian educational activities. All the early efforts with Indian children were wholly missionary in character - for nearly 200 years the work was carried on without financial assistance from the Governments. There is record of Recollet Fathers' schools for Indian children in New France as early as 1616; the Jesuits were active early in the 18th century; and settlers in the British colonies established little centres of Christianity at this period. These intermittent and only partly successful efforts were continued under British domination - prominence being given to instruction in religion. Even the education of white children received very little attention - in fact the first school in Upper Canada (1784) was for the Mohawk Indians who had settled on the shores of the Bay of Quinte and the first church to be erected in the province (1785) was for the Six Nations Indians of the Grand River Reserve, near Brantford.

Prior to Confederation, day schools were successfully conducted at Lorette, St. Regis, and Ferreville in Lower Canada. At Caughnawaga, educational work was made nearly impossible by local difficulties. However, there were interesting experiments at Chateauguay and Christieville, where Indian boys from Caughnawaga were taken into residence and given a training in the classroom and on the farm. All these school activities received grants from Lower Canada. The Seminary of St. Sulpice, at Oka, maintained a farm school, at which Indian boys were enrolled.

In Upper Canada, the Society for the propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts organized the earliest Indian school on the Tyendinaga Reserve (Bay of Quinte). The New England Company, an evangelical organization chartered in 1661 in the reign of Charles II, the Wesleyan Methodist Missionary Society and the Jesuits interested themselves in Indian educational work early in the 19th century. Approximately forty day schools were established in Upper Canada prior to Confederation, but there is record of only two of them receiving grants from the Governments of the day. Special institutions for the education of Indians were established at this time: the Mohawk Institute by the New England Company; the Alderville and Mount Elgin Boarding Schools by the Wesleyan Methodist Missionary Society, and the Wikwemikong Boarding School by the Jesuits. In addition, there was a community training centre established by the Governor of Upper Canada at Manitowaning, on Manitoulin Island. This enterprise was for the education of both young and old; but, as it did not appeal to the Indian temperament, it was abandoned in 1856, after twenty years of effort.

It should be recorded that in 1848 certain Indian bands in Upper Canada agreed to set apart for the purposes of education one-quarter of the amount received in compensation of their annual distribution of ammunition. This Indian school fund was used largely for the maintenance of the Alderville and Mount Elgin Boarding Schools, payments being made on a per capita grant basis - so much per child per year. Right at the outset of governmental association with Indian educational activity, we find two of the outstanding characteristics of the present system - church
co-operation in the work and per capita grant payments to residential schools.

Prior to Confederation there was practically no organization of Indian schools in other parts of Canada. Missionaries interested in the education of Indian children were opportunists - classes being conducted whenever and wherever the activity gave promise of even a little success. The New England Company experimented with foster homes for Indian children in New Brunswick even before it applied its energy and funds to the work among the Six Nations. A Church of England chaplain to the Hudson's Bay Company conducted a boarding school for Indian children on the Red River as early as 1822. A Roman Catholic priest tried an agricultural school for young Indians at Rainy Lake, near St. Boniface, Man., in 1833. There is record of day schools in various parts of the West, all conducted by Roman Catholic, Church of England and Methodist missionaries. In British Columbia the New England Company began work early in the 19th century from which developed the present Lytton Indian Residential School.

At Confederation Indian schools were supported for the most part by missionary societies, religious orders and the Indian bands - little financial assistance being given by the legislatures. Low salaries were paid and the attendance was irregular and, as a consequence, the schools were not effective. When the British North America Act placed the responsibility for the Indians of Canada with the federal Government, reports from Indian schools were forwarded to the Department of the Secretary of State, a branch of which was made the administrative office for Indian Affairs. In 1867 one residential school, the Mount Elgin Institute, with an enrolment of 52, and forty-nine day schools with a total of 1,664 pupils - all in Ontario and Quebec - were recognized by the Indian Office. There were several Indian schools, entirely missionary in character, that did not make return to the Government. The two most important of these were the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, supported by the New England Company, and the Roman Catholic boarding school at Wikwemikong.
New Indian Residential Schools Completed

Ottawa, Canada.—Marked progress has been made in Canada in recent years in the extension and improvement of facilities for the education and vocational training of the Dominion's Indian population. New schools buildings, modern in every respect, are replacing old structures and better qualified teachers and instructors are being attracted to the Indian schools. There are 79 residential schools, 262 day schools, and 10 combined Indian and white schools in operation under the supervision of Honourable T.A. Crerar, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and Minister of the Interior. Eighteen thousand Indian children in Canada are enrolled in the schools and of this number 8,900 are in residential schools.

Two of the most recent additions to the residential school system are those erected at Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, and Lebret, Saskatchewan. These, like other schools under the Department of Indian Affairs, are operated in co-operation with the various church authorities engaged in Indian work, a method of carrying on the education of Canada's Indian youth which has worked out most satisfactorily.

The Shingwauk Indian Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie is conducted by the Church of England in Canada. The new building was opened on October 3, 1935, under the principalship of the Reverend C.F. Hives. It replaces that built in 1875 and is one of the finest in Canada. The school has accommodation for 150 pupils and staff and is steam-heated and fireproof throughout. The new building is of steel construction, with reinforced concrete floors, tile partitions, steel stairs, and fireproof connecting doors. The outside walls are faced with brick and trimmed with stone. The main building is H-shaped, the centre portion being 80 feet long and the end wings 64 feet by 32 feet. The centre portion contains accommodation in the basement for dining rooms for the pupils and staff, boys and girls recreation
rooms, toilets, baths, wash rooms, shower baths, etc. There is a wing at the rear approximately 70 feet by 50 feet which contains the kitchen, store rooms, boiler room, laundry, and cold storage. On the ground floor are located the class rooms, sewing room, and staff living quarters, together with a spacious assembly hall. The first and second floors contain the dormitories, clothing stores, staff bed rooms, and a well planned infirmary for the boys and girls.

The Lebret Indian Residential school in the Qu'Appelle valley of Saskatchewan was officially opened on May 29, 1936, and is being conducted under Roman Catholic Church auspices. This school replaces that destroyed by fire in November, 1932, and provides accommodation for 250 pupils and the necessary staff. The building is of re-inforced concrete construction throughout. It has a frontage of 246 feet, with a rear extension of 115 feet deep. In the basement of the main portion of the building are located pupil and staff dining rooms, boys and girls recreation rooms, toilets, baths, shower baths, etc. The rear wing contains the kitchen, scullery, cold storage room, laundry, and boiler room. It is worthy of mention that the basement of all Indian residential schools is practically a ground floor as the level of the basement floor is only 12 inches below grade, thus providing a maximum amount of light and ventilation. On the ground floor are located the class rooms, sewing room, staff bed rooms, offices, and a large chapel. There is also a large room for the accommodation of Indian parents when visiting their children. The first floor contains principally the dormitories, the Sisters living quarters, and infirmaries for the boys and girls. The second floor is entirely devoted to dormitories and a few staff bed rooms for supervision. The building is heated by steam and the water supply and sewage disposal systems were also installed by the Department.

Mr. CRERAR: I confess that my knowledge of the whole Indian problem in Canada is not as intimate as I could wish, but I might say in a general way that the Indian population in Canada today is about 112,000, and is increasing. The fact that it is increasing makes the Indian problem deserving of the attention of public officials with a view to studying the best methods for bringing education to the Indians, making them self-supporting, and generally improving their situation. Unquestionably a very large number of Indians are on relief at the present time. I am speaking from memory, but I think I am correct when I say that about one-third of the Indians in Ontario and Quebec have been on relief for the last two or three years. The rather superficial study that I have been able to give the Indian problem since I took charge of the department has convinced me of the view that the administration is rather expensive; that it costs a considerable amount of money and probably could be improved in some respects. There are further problems in connection with education. In this connection we sometimes run into a rather delicate situation. It is frequently found that two or more denominations are carrying out their good work in one community, and this occasionally creates a problem. There is as well the question of the relations which are to discharge our obligations to the Indians in this connection, this matter will stand a very considerable amount of study. There is no problem of bringing the Indians to a better understanding of the methods of the white man and his way of living. At times I do not think we have acted wisely in this respect. In western Canada there in some parts of Ontario there are Indians who are making substantial progress towards becoming self-supporting. This is being achieved mainly through the cultivation of land. In more remote parts of the country trapping and fishing, the traditional occupations of the Indian, are practically his only means of support. Our Indians are scattered from Prince Rupert, Vancouver and from the international boundary to the Arctic circle and one realizes the magnitude of the problem when that vast area is considered. I may say however that the work has to do with measurements as to the position of stars, and the relation of those measurements to measurement of time. Communications by radio are maintained with other observatories, and as a result we are able to have very accurate time. For instance, in Ottawa we have six hundred electrical clocks, three of which are in this chamber. It is important to have the correct time, otherwise the hon. member for Nova Scotia might have some time in one of the speeches he makes to the house. Then the observatory studies sun spots and their effects on climate, commerce, and plant life. Recent theories of the physicists indicate that sun spots have a material bearing on mundane matters, and we in Canada wish to make our contribution to the study of these matters. Mr. BENNETT: The fact that the Indian population is increasing is in itself prima facie evidence that they are not being well looked after. Prior to a few years ago the Indian agents were not always medical men, nor are they yet; but an effort was made during the last report to provide that if possible they should have some medical training. The result is, I believe, that this is the first time a report has been made to the house of an increase in the Indian population. My memory is that it was several years ago; but during the last few years an effort has been made, whenever vacancies have occurred, to appoint as Indian agent, if possible, a medical man. As a result the children have received better care for, tuberculosis has been brought under control; disease has diminished, and the habits of life of the Indians have improved.

I cannot speak of the Indians in the maritimes provinces. The report I received with respect to them on one occasion was rather alarming, and a special effort was made to have some medical relief efforts made. They are in a rather bad way. In Quebec, apart from the large bands, there are small bands scattered over many sections of the province, and in Ontario, apart from the large reserves, there are numbers of bands of Indians. When we get into western Canada we find that usually they have excellent reserves. At Medicine Hat the Blackfoot have a very fine reserve which they receive substantial revenues. The Blackfoot Indians have sold large quantities of their land, sometimes by public auction and sometimes not, and considerable sums of

The Stony Indians west of Calgary, are in a bad way. They are hunters and fishermen and during the last few years have suffered acutely. A good deal of money has been expended in improving facilities at Morley, and perhaps they are better off than they were a while ago. So far as British Columbia is concerned, reports from there indicate that many of the Indians are in a pretty bad way, and a special effort was made to look after many of them.

I have been astounded at the enormous amount of money that has been spent to accomplish the results. The year before last the situation was very acute, and when you realize that $4,000,000 has been spent on about 112,000 Indians, who then did possess adequate resources in the way of reserves, I can only say that the closest supervision ought to be exercised over administration. I believe in many cases they are rations which they have treaty money distributed to them, under the terms of surrender they made to their interests in lands and the taking up of reserves. They have been paid sums in the way of treaty money, and then they are charged on their own funds. I understand that they utilize their own funds for the construction of buildings.

One of the most difficult problems is that connected with education. I believe it is the outstanding problem in that regard. My memory is that cost per head in connection with these Indians is not high, but is a very substantial part of the appropriation. I think the relief measures afforded them have been as nearly adequate as possible.

Canada, I believe, has discharged its obligations to its wards as fairly as has any country in the world, but during the last ten years there has been a decided increase in expenditures. The Indians have been receiving medical attention and care which they never had before, and with the rations they have received they have been in a much better position, very much better as a matter of fact than have other sections of our population. I believe that until within three years ago they administered their own educational system, but for some reason or another that privilege has been taken away from them. I have not been able to discover the reason. The department gave the excuse that they had appropriated the whole of the education of Indians in Canada and that because of that they must take away from the Indians the administration of their schools. In passing may I observe that the Indians built their own schools from their own funds, and prior to that time had contributed about half of the cost of their own education. They enjoy a reasonable amount of autonomy due to the fact that they elect their council, and it seems to me it was most unfortunate that the Indians were deprived of a degree of autonomy which, by virtue of their advancement, ought to encourage them to go further; it ought to give them more autonomy and more control over their affairs, in so far as they are able to manage them.
In that way we shall make good citizens of them.

Now the few moments I shall speak—and I shall not take too long—may I state that the Indians in the Six Nations reserve are in a somewhat different position from that of the average of the aborigines of Canada, because they compare very favorably with our United Empire Loyalists. An agreement was made between Captain Joseph Brant and the British government which he well extend his loyalty towards the Brits at the time of the American revolution. The loyalists were granted certain concessions if they would remain true to the British crown. They came to Canada and were granted a number of land extending six miles on either side of the Grand river from its mouth to its source. They did not need all that land, so for some reason they sold a portion of it. The money was set aside and was held in trust in Canada as a trust fund for the maintenance of the Indians. This was a good business proposition, and I believe we have every reason to commend the Indians for their astuteness in having a sound account, only wish the government had put a bank account or some other place where those Indians, because if that were so we would be in a much better position than we are in today. The matter in regard to which I am speaking has been perennial subject.

I believe my predecessor, Mr. Smoke, described conditions possibly better than I am in a position to do, because I know he has made a study of the subject, whereas at the time I am going through eighty-six pages of legal terminology. So far I have gone only about half way through, but it has been my endeavor to learn the history of the Six Nations Indians.

Mr. BENNETT: Read Mr. Smoke's speech and you will get the story.

Mr. WOOD: Yes, and I commend Mr. Smoke for his approach to the subject. Unfortunately I have not been able to get all the facts in the short time I have had at my disposal, but to the best of my ability I have endeavored to do so in my own way. For that reason I am not going into detail, because I do not want to misplace the another characters, or to put them in a wrong light.

It seems however, that about one hundred years ago a scheme known as the Grand river navigation project was devised, and was incorporated in 1832. Trustees were employed to enter upon the crown lands, or the lands belonging to the Six Nations Indians, after making compensation. The funds belonging to these Indians were at that time held by trustees. In 1832 the Hon. J. H. Dunn, then Receiver General of Upper Canada, had charge of the public moneys of the then province.

He was an active exponent of the policy of the company and held the office of president of the Welland Canal Company. The Grand River Navigation Company acted more or less as a subsidiary and was to supply the funds to the Welland canal. By virtue of that arrangement the two companies worked together.

Mr. Dunn filled the further position of trustee of the Six Nations Indians. He appears to have had an active part in their money affairs. On April 3, 1834, an order in council was passed stating the Indians ordered that the moneys invested in British funds should be transferred to Canada to be invested in provincial debentures or other government securities. I shall not go into detail regarding the ramifications of the charters or supplementary letters, nor view the various changes in the financial structure, but briefly I would state that they did get a charter from Sir John Colborne, the then Lieutenant Governor of Upper Canada, to assist them in an endeavour to form a company to permit trade in western Ontario via the Grand river. He was successful in getting sufficient interest among men who had money to invest to organize the company.

As time went on the Buffalo and Goderich line of business was such a change that took place in the transportation, and thus impairing the possibilities of the Grand River Navigation Company. The competition of the railway would also impair the possibilities of the canal. These men found that they were going to be left in a precarious position. For some reason, of which at the present time I am not aware, they wished to withhold their obligations and pledge to Sir John Colborne and, to make a long story short, those who were responsible substituted the Indian funds to purchase stock and put those funds into a precarious investment.

The association of the Receiver General with the Grand River Navigation Company placed the government in a very difficult position; for it meant that they were investing funds which they held in trust for the Indians in a company in which some of them were personally interested. You will see, Mr. Chairman, that the security of the funds of the Six Nations Indians was thus jeopardized, and the Indians in consequence feel that they have been wronged.

I believe that the result of this scheme of organizing a joint stock company and investing it in their funds which were held in trust for them by the government of the day. Whether the powers of a trust company had been defined at that time or not, it is
not lawful, as I understand the matter, for a minister to invest in a joint stock company funds which belong to the Indians.

It might be said that all this happened one hundred years ago and that we have no obligation today. While there may not be a legal obligation and I cannot speak as to that—undoubtedly there is a moral obligation, and that moral obligation was incurred through the fiduciary from the coffers of the government of the trusteeship of funds which belonged to the Six Nations. I do not say that this was done with dishonest intent; it might have been done with the intention of doing good. The only thing that is unfortunate point is that the money was held in trust for the Indians and the government had no right to invest it in a joint stock company.

Mr. CRERAR: When did that happen, may I ask?

Mr. WOOD: It happened somewhere around 1834, and thirteen instalment payments on the stock were called for down to August, 1841. About £25,000 had been paid from the Indian funds and the directors of the Bank whose in which the Indians' funds were invested at that particular time. All the interest on these Bank stocks which should have been paid to the Indians each year was absorbed in paying up these instalments on the stock as fast as the instalments were called for. The payment of the Indians' funds began in 1859. I might just quote from the order in council of January 16, 1840:

The council beg to state, for the information of Your Excellencies, that the trustees of the money of the Six Nations Indians, in the stock of the Grand River Navigation Company, took advantage of an order of St. John's, upon the recommendation of the trustees of the Six Nations.

And he was president of the Grand River Navigation Company. I leave the house to deduce the motive. The order in council continues:

Their Excellencies Sir Francis Head and Sir George Arthur alike objected to the investment, but owing to the assumption of the government by Sir Francis Head the trustees felt the money had been already invested, liable to forfeiture in case the further stock should not be paid in.

These Indians are advanced. They are conscientious, they are industrious, they take their funds, and I think they are quite within their rights in their demand. I live within two miles of these Indians; I know their habits and the manner in which many of them have advanced, and many of them can take their places among the citizens of this dominion in the various professions and other walks of life. Many of their young women are qualified school teachers, and many of their young boys and girls are attending secondary and high schools in the community.

I am speaking only of the Six Nations Indians because those are the ones I know, and I would urge upon the Department of Indian Affairs the granting to the Indians of more autonomy in keeping with the progress they have made.

I think a great mistake was made when control of their schools was taken away from them. This was a disservice to them. I do not know why the purpose was, but it happened somewhere around 1932. I know it is nauseating to the Indians who are interested in their own schools to have some school board hired from the outside come in and teach their children when they have young lady teachers of their own quite capable of performing those duties. As to the motive why I do not know, but to me it savours of a little bit of politics. There may have been some good friends who wanted certain things done.

I met recently the case of a young Indian just north of Brantford who asked for his enfranchisement. He had received a very good education and then became enfranchised, and by virtue of his enfranchisement he was assuming a position citizenship to all intents and purposes a white man. He was a good Conservative, and he was appointed to an Indian school. He had a splendid son, a brilliant student, who before he got his B.A. degree, and the son was engaged last summer to take one of the other schools. I believe it would be wise for us to give back to the Indians the right to administer their own schools. They do not take kindly to our administration of them. They are honest, industrious citizens, interested in their own welfare, and they do not take kindly to the government's method, particularly just because they happen to be of a certain political complexion, to come in and teach in their schools, particularly when they have people of their own who are qualified to teach in those schools.

In conclusion, I would ask the Department of Indian Affairs to give serious consideration to the claim of the Six Nations Indians to the sum of $100,000 of their funds that was taken away from them by the action of the Receiver General in a breach of trust. I believe the Indians will be very glad to receive the interest upon that sum, provided they assume greater obligations providing they are granted more autonomy and are given a more important voice in the administration of their own affairs.
Mr. CRERAR: I am afraid that the claim of the Six Nations Indians, a claim that originated over a hundred years ago, to $160,000, with accumulated interest, is one that the government could not possibly meet. I do not know the merits or demerits of the case, but the hon. member for Brant has put forward. Since this question originated 102 years ago or thereabouts, the federal government as we know it today would not be responsible for it.

If my memory of history is correct, this happened during the time when Upper Canada was still being governed as a crown colony.

The hon. member spoke to me only a little time ago about this question, but I have not had an opportunity of going into it. I am afraid I cannot hold out any hope that we will meet a claim, which originated over 100 years ago. Six Nations will interest me. I am afraid that a serious consideration of such a proposal would send my colleague, the Minister of Finance (Mr. Dunning) to the hospital.

There are some 6,000 Indians in the reserve to which my hon. friend refers. From information I have been able to obtain, I understand they have done remarkably well. There is a certain amount of the Indian work, which after all is the act under which matters pertaining to the Indian population of Canada are administered, comes into conflict with the suggestions made by the minister. I cannot pass any critical judgment on his statement. My information is that the majority of the teachers in the schools on the Brant reserve are of Indian origin. My hon. friend shook his head. Perhaps my statement is incorrect, but I understand that at any rate a number of the teachers have been trained from Indians who have been pupils in the years immediately past. It is the general rule that Indians should be made as independent as possible of outside assistance. No one would have greater pleasure than I do the day when the Indians of Canada could attain a position whereby they would be not only self-supporting but able to look after such matters as education and other things as their white brothers do.

Mr. CLARK (York-Sunbury): I am very much interested in the Six Nations reserve, and I was pleased to hear the minister sympathetic toward and so willing to investigate the Indian problem. I have known many Indians for many years, and at times I have been ashamed of their treatment by our Indian agents. More attention should be given to the employment of these agents. Only those who have a certain sympathy for the Indian, who would not have a disposition to exploit them, who would desire to help them, should be employed in this capacity. I recall having employed an Indian guide who was a fine type of man, but I found out that his relatives were being treated very unfairly by the Indian agent.

Mr. SENN: I listened with considerable interest to what the hon. member for Brant (Mr. Wood) had to say about the funds which were investigated in the Grand River Reserve. I agree with him. A part of this reservation is in my own county and I believe the Indians feel very strongly on the matter. I do not intend to carry this matter any further as the minister has given his answer. I was very interested in the allegation of the hon. member that politics were very much present in the appointment of teachers on the reservations. I have had many interviews with the Indians about this matter myself. Prior to the change which took place in 1852, as described by the hon. gentleman, there was considerable jealousy and quarrelling among the Indians as to who should teach in their schools. At times the appointments were made by the Indian council and it often became a matter of politics within the reservation. From time to time the personnel of the council would change, and teachers would change to suit the opinions of those newly elected. I believe this was one of the reasons why the change was made to the Indian department appointing the teachers.

Mr. WERMESINGER: What amount in this year will be used for the construction of dwellings? Will this cover repairs to dwellings and the construction of new buildings? What amount is to be spent in the village of Caughnawaga for this purpose? This village is situated from Quebec on the main highway to the United States by way of Malone and I think it is important that it should present a good appearance. I should like to know what amount is to be spent.

Mr. CRERAR: I have not the amount for Caughnawaga. The total amount for dwellings is $19,500, but the hon. member will bear in mind that that covers the whole vote.

Mr. BENNETT: The whole of Canada.

Mr. CRERAR: The whole of Canada. I am not at the moment in a position to say what portion of the vote will be applied to Caughnawaga.

Mr. BENNETT: That would be exclusive of band funds.
Mr. CRERAR: That is exclusive of band funds.

Mr. WERMENLINGER: Would that be for new dwellings?

Mr. POTTIER: How many Indians are there in Nova Scotia?

Mr. CRERAR: Approximately 2,000.

Mr. DUPUIS: The hon. member for Verdun spoke of the reserve at Caughnawaga.

Mr. LAPOINTE (Quebec East): The hon. member is no longer there.

Mr. DUPUIS: No; I was disfranchised by the present administration and forced to move eastward. Nevertheless I take an interest in Caughnawaga and I notice that the leader of the opposition has still a weakness for it, whereas he took his stand there in that reserve which is one of the largest in Quebec, the Indians have a territory of approximately 11,000 acres of good farm land which is practically all cultivated by white people who rent the farms. Very often we have requests from these white people, who are on the reserve with the permission of the Department of Indian Affairs, to investigate complaints they make against the Indians that they are not being well treated. In some instances these white men are barely tolerated on the reserve, and not being able to work they rely on relief. They have not the means of supporting themselves and they are in a peculiar position. Though they live on the reserve, the Department of Indian Affairs is not obliged to make provision for them. The provincial government, under the relief laws, is not bound to support them. They are therefore left without support.

It is a matter of importance for the department to come to the rescue of these white men in view of the fact that the department itself allows them to live there. A considerable quantity of land there could be abandoned, and I suggest to the government that it would be wise to look into the situation and see whether it would not be better to allow these Indians to sell this very important piece of land and use the proceeds otherwise. It is important inasmuch as it is near so large a centre as Montreal, and the Indians are not inclined to cultivate it. They are rather inclined to establish a hardware works or such employment in connection with the Dominion Bridge Company or other steel works. This is their only occupation, and if the Department of Indian Affairs were allowed to sell this large area the amount derived from its sale could be used for the benefit of the Indians themselves and would assist the department in the administration of the reserve. I make this suggestion to the department in good faith, hoping that they will take action. As the hon. member for Brant stated, the Indians of Caughnawaga generally speaking are likely to attain the same level as the so-called Indians who are living there if they were given more freedom, if they could inspire the government with a little more confidence and were allowed to sell their land on certain terms, within a few years this large area of good land could be disposed of, one farm after another, so that the people in the surrounding district might use it for farming purposes.

Mr. BENNETT: How many Indians are there?

Mr. DUPUIS: Around 3,800.

Mr. CRERAR: Less than that; a little under 3,000.

Mr. DUPUIS: As matters stand now, it would cost the Department of Indians Affairs a considerable sum to take care of these Indians properly from the point of view of education and hygiene. For the most part the village is built on rocks, and the construction of a sewer and water system would cost a great deal; the department would have to spend too much. For this reason, indicated by the hon. member for Brant, I investigated the matter; the inhabitants are unable to follow the rules of hygiene, and the doctors themselves say that in Caughnawaga some of the diseases that are prevalent on the reserve are undermining the health of the population. I believe the population of this particular reserve is diminishing, owing to the fact that the present department is unable to give the Indians the legitimate attention they should receive.

If the government would accept this suggestion and allow the Indians to sell their farms, retaining the proceeds at their disposal, the majority of the Indians would follow the ordinary pursuits of life, while those who preferred to retain their status could be more easily dealt with.

Another aspect of the question which interests me is hospitalization. If it is as it was when I was member for Laurier-Naperville, then there is no building for their hospital which is far too small for the needs of the reserve. If the department were to spend the amount required for that purpose the cost would be considerable, because I think it would have to erect a new building.
do not want to embarrass the minister. I make this suggestion only with the hope that the department will study the necessity of applying this policy. Mr. CRERAR: So far as disposing of a part of the reserve for farming purposes to white men is concerned, my suggestion is concerned, it is necessary in all cases to get the approval of the band to the surrender of any of their property. I am not entirely familiar with the difficulties attending such surrender in Quebec, but I understand that the point arises that if a surrender is made it has to be made to the crown.

Mr. DUPUIS: I think the provincial government, if the question were treated seriously, could make a decision whether if the land is to be abandoned by the Department of Indian Affairs it would not revert to the crown as regarded by the provincial government, but the Quebec government might make an agreement allowing the Department of Indian Affairs to sell that land. I know this question involved some difficulties which were not solved in the past, but I discussed this matter with the provincial government some years ago, and if my memory serves me aright, I believe a solution of the problem can be found.

Mr. CRERAR: The consent of the Indians would be required anyway, in case of that kind. With regard to the other point raised by my hon. friend mentioned, namely, the presence of white people on the reserves, that presents another different problem. It has occasionally happeneded that a white man has married an Indian woman of the reserve. He may die, and then the Indian woman, who has taken the status of a white man, may have children return to the reserve. Under the Indian Act they are no longer Indians, but of course they are living on the Indian reserve, and the province has interfered, has been called upon to intervene with relief when that happens. This is one of the problems that arise perhaps inevitably in the administration of Indian affairs. I shall be very glad to keep in mind the observations made by my hon. friend. Mr. SENN: Referring again to the question of money that was invested by the crown some years ago in the Grand River Navigation Company and which belonged to the Sault Ste. Marie Indians, I discussed this matter at one time with a former Minister of the Interior, the Hon. Charles Stewart. Is that item of ten thousand dollars included in this item?

Mr. CRERAR: I am sorry that at the moment I cannot give a definite answer to Mr. Dupuis's question. My deputy tells me that some special grant has been given to this reserve. Whether or not one is given consideration of a claim which they believe they have against the crown, and to which the hon. member for Brant has referred, I cannot say.

Mr. SENN: I should not like the minister to have the impression that I said "in consideration of this claim"; the amount was other than as a satisfaction in lieu of the claim itself. I know this money has been expended, and very well expended, on the reservation for the past few years in the building of roads, and that the roads are not nearly completed, and I suggest to the minister that the grant should be continued if possible.

Mr. LOCKHART: Do I understand the minister to say that compulsory education is definitely established on the Indian reserves as well as in other public school systems in Ontario or the dominion? I did not catch his answer because of interruptions. I am referring to compulsory education.

Mr. CRERAR: According to the information I have, it was intended under the Indian Act that educational facilities should be made available to Indian children as far as possible, and that when they were available the Indian children should take advantage of them. Finds Indian Race In Canada Growing

(Canadian Press)

SUMMERSIDE, P.E.I., Aug. 6 — The Indian race in Canada is increasing rapidly," J. D. Sutherland of Ottawa, superintendent of Indians, said today. He is visiting the island province in the interest of his department.

"Great progress has been made in recent years in the education of our Indian population, the literature indicates," he said. "Due to the care now given Indian mothers at childbirth and because of the better care given in Indian schools on child welfare, infant mortality was no longer a problem as it had been."

"There are about 19,000 Indian pupils attending the 265 day schools and residential schools," Mr. Sutherland said. "Canada's farthest north Indian school is at Fort Davis. The newest addition to the reservation schools are at Sault Ste. Marie and Fort Chapel. Indian Race Grows Swiftly

Health of Natives Has Improved Greatly, Superintendent Reports.

SUMMERSIDE, P.E.I., Aug. 6—The Indian race in Prince Edward Island is increasing rapidly, J. D. Sutherland, Ottawa superintendent of Indian Affairs, told the delegates attending the island province in the interest of his department.

"Great progress has been made in recent years in the education of our aboriginal population," the superintendent continued.

Due to the care now given Indian children, the death rate and the number of instruction given at Indian schools and child welfare, infant mortality was considerably lower than it had been.

"There are about 19,000 Indian pupils attending the 265 day schools and 80 residential schools," Mr. Sutherland said.

Canada's farthest North Indian School was at Aklakivik. The newest school buildings were being erected there at Sault Ste. Marie and Fort Chipewyan.

Indians were sent to the residential school in New Brunswick, Mr. Sutherland pointed out.

"In former years, the death rate was heaviest from birth until seven years. Education and proper care of infants had greatly reduced the rate," Mr. Sutherland stated.

The following is a summary of the expenditures for Indian Education, in regard to Buildings and Repairs; Equipment and Furnishings; Materials and Supplies; and the method by which the work in this connection is dealt with by Department officials.

The expenditure incurred for the above purposes during the fiscal year 1935-36 was as follows:-

1. EQUIPMENT - Purchase - $85,609.76
2. EQUIPMENT - Maintenance & Repairs - 3,941.96
3. BUILDINGS and WORKS (New Construction) - 114,620.52
4. BUILDINGS and WORKS (Repairs and Alterations) - 54,702.17

1. EQUIPMENT - Purchase:

This consists of Beds and Bedding; Kitchen and Dining Room, Laundry, Bakery, Cold Storage Lighting Plants; Stationary Engines; Classroom Desks; Farm Machinery and Stock; and various miscellaneous equipment.

When a new residential school building is completed, the Architect decides what furnishings are to be supplied. For the greater part of this equipment, the purchase is made through the Purchasing Branch of the Department.

Regarding renewals of equipment, the greater part is purchased locally, by the Indian Agents, who receive authority through the Schools Branch. The Agents are furnished with the names of the firms from whom to
whom to obtain quotations. In some cases, they are instructed to make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price, and, in other cases, where the purchase involves considerable money, they are required to submit the quotations to the Department and receive authority before placing the order. The Purchasing Agent arranges certain purchases renewing equipment, such as laundry machines, fire fighting appliances, engines and batteries for lighting plants. I would consider the amount of purchases in renewing equipment is made, approximately, one-third by the Purchasing Agent, at the request of the Schools Branch, and two-thirds by the Agents, locally, also upon instructions of the Schools Branch.

2. EQUIPMENT (Maintenance and Repairs):

The Schools Branch carry out all correspondence and arrange for the maintenance and repair of all equipment.

3. BUILDINGS and WORKS (New Construction):

When it has been decided to erect a new residential or day school building or teacher's residence and the funds have been provided, all action being taken by the Schools Branch, the actual erection of the buildings, the preparation of the plans and awarding the contract are carried out through the office of the Architect of the Department, who supervises all this work, and, after the building is completed, the officers of the Schools Branch are responsible for its future maintenance and management.

4. BUILDINGS and WORKS (Repairs and Alterations)

All minor repairs and alterations are carried out by the Schools Branch, who give the necessary instructions to the local Indian Agents.

Major repairs and alterations to buildings, repairs to water systems and sewage disposal systems are handled by the Architect. However, the greater part of all repairs is carried out directly through the Schools Branch.

5. MATERIALS and SUPPLIES (Classroom Texts, Stationery, etc.)

All text books, library books, stationery, etc., are ordered, upon requisition, through the

- Government
Government Stationery Office. The Schools Branch informs the Stationery Office of the number of the various textbooks, scribblers, exercise books, pencils and other classroom equipment that will likely be required. The Stationery Office then stocks the equipment. When the teachers requisition for supplies, an order is forwarded to the Government Stationery Office, who send the classroom equipment required to the teachers and render accounts to the Department for the cost. The purchase of Biscuits for midday meals, to the amount of approximately $6,500.00, is made by the Purchasing Branch.

All other purchases under this heading and the large correspondence in connection therewith is handled through the Schools Branch.

WELFARE AND TRAINING

The Welfare and Training division is one of the three new administrative units for which provision has been made in the Department of Mines and Resources.

The reorganization of the Department was completed and the personnel of the staff announced on December first, 1936.

It is recognized, in the creation of this division, that a worthwhile welfare programme must be basically educational in character; that education is not something injected into a child during his sojourn at school but a process that should continue throughout life. It is difficult to think of educational effort in a realistic sense, in terms other than those which emphasize the welfare and progress of the entire Indian population. The activities of the division, therefore, are interdependent and complementary, directed toward clearly defined objectives. These objectives, for a generation or two at least, will be the training of pupils to make the most of their available resources, with talents consecrated to the service of the bands to which they belong, and an adult Indian population proud of their racial origin and cultural heritage, adjusted to modern life, progressive, resourceful and self-supporting.

The Welfare programme organized toward the end of the fiscal year consists in the main of the creation and cultivation of subsistence gardens and the extension of agricultural operations; the purchase of livestock and equipment; encouragement of arts and crafts and sale of handicraft products; the survey and development of territory suitable for the propagation of muskrats and other furbearing animals; purchase of traplines and leasing of timber limits, housing construction, administration of relief and the care of the aged and physically incapacitated.

It is estimated that during the year one-third of the Indian population were dependent, in whole or in part, on relief allowances. It is apparent, therefore, that we are confronted with the spectacle of vast natural resources awaiting legitimate exploitation, on the one hand, and an impoverished Indian population on the other.

The Indians of Canada have suffered acutely in recent years; unemployment, drought in agricultural areas, inadequate returns from steadily diminishing fur and game resources have contributed to the demoralization and disintegration of their economic and social life. Relief allowances are, at best, a palliative. Direct relief, unless wisely administered, tends increasingly to destroy initiative and to rob the recipient of that wholesome sense of satisfaction that ever follows the accomplishment of a worthwhile task.

The present Welfare programme is designed to encourage the Indian to support and sustain himself. It is sufficiently comprehensive, when supported with the parliamentary appropriations necessary, to enable him, whether he be farmer, trapper or fisherman, to obtain and utilize the tools necessary to sustain himself and those dependent upon him.

An attempt has been made during the year to bring the educational policy of the Department into closer conformity with the actual life needs of Indian children. Steadily increasing emphasis has been placed on the importance of manual training. Material has been supplied, in an attempt to encourage gardening and carpentry work among boys, and dressmaking, crochet work and elementary domestic science among girls. Plans have been prepared for the construction of day schools, equipped to provide an educational programme designed to meet the needs peculiar to the reserves on which such schools are established. It is not too much to hope that these schools will become the focal points in community life - centres to which children and adults will turn for guidance, instruction and inspiration.

An encouraging feature of educational effort during the year was discovered in the multiplying demands for
agricultural and homemaking short courses and in the tendency
and willingness of the Indians to recognize the value and
distinctiveness of their arts and crafts. Consideration has
been given to ways and means whereby the Indian population
might be encouraged to still further conserve their ancient
values and skills and thus contribute to the cultural life
of the nation.

Dear Sir,

In my study of the relations of the National Government to Education in Canada—aimed after over two years of total disability on my part—I am in need of further information regarding provisions for the education of the Indians. May I make the following inquiries:

1. In accordance with the provisions of sub-section (a) of section 90 of "The Dominion Lands Act" (1872) an Order in Council was passed in September of 1873 providing for the support of Indian schools at certain points of Section 16, Township 44, Range 2, west of the third meridian.

Has this Order in Council been made effective? How many acres of land has thus far been made available for the support of Indian schools? What has been the income that has come from such reserved lands each year since the inception of the plan up to and including 1881?

2. Section II of 17-58 Vict., c. 32, s. 11 (1874) added section 128 to the Indian Act in which the Governor-in-Council was authorized to establish residential industrial schools—as I understand—distinctly from the reserve schools provided by the churches and would be maintained by the Government. Could you give me the names and locations of the first school established under this provision? Would it be possible to let me have a list of the residential industrial schools for Indians founded under this provision and wholly supported by the Government and those that are known as branch schools under the Government?

Any comments you may be able to extend to me on subjects of this import will be deeply appreciated.

I am sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. You may have an old friend corresponding between us. I am the Jane E. White who is Chief of Educational Administration at the University of Pennsylvania who wrote & sent a few years ago, June 11th (1935). I have been about on such leave. I hope to return to duty early 1936. Meanwhile while convalescing I am trying to pick up the threads and complete the study.

J.E.W.
Minister's Office

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have a letter from Mr. R. J. Davidson, Inspector of Schools at Balcarres, Sask., saying that he is writing to you in connection with information for a study of Indian education in Canada.

You probably have a number of requests of this kind, and unless you know the persons making the requests, it must be difficult to distinguish those that are worth taking seriously. It is for this reason I write to tell you that I have met Mr. Davidson on several occasions in the last few years, and have talked with him at length about the selection of a topic for his doctoral thesis. It was really at my suggestion that he decided two years ago to explore the possibility of writing the story of Indian education in Canada. I suggested it to him by reason of the fact that the lack of a comprehensive record of the education of the native population has always seemed to me a shortcoming in Canadian educational documentation.

During the last two years Mr. Davidson has studied a good number of volumes on native education in other countries to give him a background against which to view the work in Canada, but you would need to have no fear of him using the privileges you might extend to him to develop earning criticism. He is not that kind of person.

Moreover, he is not interested in rushing off a piece of work in a few months just to meet thesis require-
ments. What he would like in order to make a job of it, I believe, would be to have permission to work in Ottawa for a summer or two in collaboration with your Department, where he might have the guidance of your officials and access to such records as would be useful in presenting the story of Indian education as a connected whole, over the years.

If you could see your way clear to help him to this end, I am sure the result would make for a more general and more intelligent interest in the education of the Indian people.

REGINA, SASK., July 4, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that on Monday, June 20th, I had a conference with Bishop Burd and Archdeacon Paul at Prince Albert, with regard to school affairs.

In our conversation we covered selection of teachers; religious instruction for the schools; extension of the work into the homes through using married men as teachers, having their wives teach sewing, knitting, etc., to the children, and organize the women of the Reserves into Homemakers' Clubs or similar organizations; and the necessity of closer co-operation between all engaged in Indian work.

During our conversation I asked the Bishop how we could overcome the objection of the Roman Catholics to sending their children to lay schools under Church of England auspices. He suggested that the Priest be allowed to use the school during certain hours for giving his children religious instruction, and that all the children who did not wish to attend be allowed to retire. I asked him if he did not think it would be better to make the teacher strictly responsible to see that when religious instruction was being given the children by a clergyman of any denomination, the children of the other denomination be required to leave the room, in this way removing suspicion of the school being used for the purpose of inducing the children to change from one denomination to another. The Bishop replied that he saw my point and agreed.

He asked what my stand was on the employment of clergymen as teachers. I replied that I could see no objection to it, provided they possessed the necessary qualifications, on Reserves where the Indians were all of one denomination, but that I thought it would be a great mistake to employ them on the Reserves where the Indians were mixed Roman Catholics and Protestants, as there would be an objection on the part of the people of both churches to sending their children to be educated under a clergyman of another denomination. He replied that this could be taken care of.

He also asked .......
He also asked my stand on the selection of teachers. My reply was that, as we were in accord on the policy that should be followed as to the qualifications the teachers should possess, I could not see that any benefit would be derived by making any change in the present procedure.

The Indian teachers and workers of the Prince Albert Diocese will meet in Prince Albert some time in August, and the Bishop has asked me to be present at this meeting. This I will arrange to do.

I was well pleased with the conference, and feel that we can work together without any friction.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

ANNUAL REPORT
Welfare and Training Division
For the Fiscal Year ending March 31, 1938.

TRAINING

Indian Day Schools were constructed during the year at the following Reserves:

- Christian Island, Ontario
- Restigouche, Quebec
- Port Simpson, British Columbia
- Kinistino, Saskatchewan
- Bloodvein, Manitoba

These schools, with the exception of Kinistino where a school was established for the first time, were built to replace buildings which, in recent years, had become wholly unsuitable for educational purposes.

It is estimated that the increase now taking place in the Indian School population will necessitate the construction of at least ten one-room Day Schools annually, or five Day Schools and one Residential School with accommodation for one hundred and fifty pupils, if the present policy of making provision for pupils in Day and Residential Schools is continued.

Steadily increasing emphasis has been placed throughout the year on the importance to the pupil of manual training and vocational instruction. Residential Schools are now equipped to provide worth while instruction in agriculture, gardening, carpentry work, boat building, tailoring, dressmaking, cooking, hand loom weaving and physical culture. These studies are combined with the regular courses of study supplied by the Provincial Departments of Education. In the cases of Indian pupils, however, and particularly those pupils who intend to establish themselves on Reserves, the tendency at present is to provide a practical course of study with less emphasis on academic subjects.

The one-room, ungraded rural school is, in most cases, a poorly equipped educational unit. In the absence of basement accommodation it is almost impossible to promote a programme of vocational instruction. It is the policy of the
Department, however, to provide basement accommodation suitable for vocational instruction at all Day Schools constructed in the future. The fact that there are difficulties to be overcome in the case of the older schools does not mean that at these schools vocational instruction is wholly neglected. Indian Day School teachers frequently, at their own request, are supplied regularly with dressmaking material, yarn, tools for gardening, garden seeds and lumber for wood working projects. The fact that requests for these supplies have been multiplying during the year is an indication of one of the most encouraging tendencies in educational effort among our Indian population.

WELFARE

A special welfare programme was organized by the officials of the Welfare Division early in the year. This programme was designed to re-establish Indians, and particularly Indians in receipt of relief allowances, on a self-supporting basis.

The sum of $150,000.00 was set apart from the regular Welfare appropriation voted by Parliament for the promotion of projects and the purchase of supplies. An attempt was made by the field officials to give particular attention to Reserves where unemployment was most in evidence and where relief expenditures appeared to be increasing. The most urgent needs of the Indian population on each Reserve determined almost wholly the scope and details of the programme. Under the direction and supervision of Indian Inspectors and Agents live stock, farm machinery and tractors were purchased and supplied to Indians. A number of the unemployed were engaged in cutting pulp wood, cleaning land, boat building and in the construction of root houses.

Twelve tractors were purchased during the year. These tractors remain the property of the Department but are placed at the disposal of Indian Bands and are operated under the personal supervision of our farm instructors.

A number of surveys have been undertaken and completed in the northern regions of the Prairie Provinces with the object of securing from the Provincial Governments areas of land suitable for the propagation of muskrat and other fur-bearing animals. An area has been secured from the Government of Quebec which will enable the Department to proceed with the development of an area suitable for beaver in the territory lying south and east of James Bay.

It is gratifying to state that despite the crop failure of the Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta the results of the special programme have been satisfactory and
encouraging. It must be borne in mind, however, that the rehabilitation of the Indian population calls for the exercise of patience and perseverance and is a process that cannot be unduly hurried. It is significant that the majority of young Indians are at this time anxious to establish themselves on Reserves. It is the policy of the Department to encourage this tendency and to make life on the Reserves as attractive and as satisfying as it is possible to make it.
