Indian Day Schools were constructed during the year at the following Reserves:

- Christian Island, Ontario
- Restigouche, Quebec
- Port Simpson, British Columbia
- Kinistino, Saskatchewan
- Bloodvein, Manitoba.

These schools, with the exception of Kinistino where a school was established for the first time, were built to replace buildings which, in recent years, had become wholly unsuitable for educational purposes.

It is estimated that the increase now taking place in the Indian School population will necessitate the construction of at least ten one-room Day Schools annually, or five Day Schools and one Residential School with accommodation for one hundred and fifty pupils, if the present policy of making provision for pupils in Day and Residential Schools is continued.

Steadily increasing emphasis has been placed throughout the year on the importance to the pupil of manual training and vocational -
vocational instruction. Residential Schools are now equipped to provide worthwhile instruction in agriculture, gardening, carpentry work, boat building, tailoring, dressmaking, cooking, hand loom weaving and physical culture. These studies are combined with the regular courses of study supplied by the Provincial Departments of Education. In the cases of Indian pupils, however, and particularly those pupils who intend to establish themselves on Reserves, the tendency at present is to provide a practical course of study with less emphasis on academic subjects.

The one-room, ungraded rural school is, in most cases, a poorly equipped educational unit. In the absence of basement accommodation it is almost impossible to promote a programme of vocational instruction. It is the policy of the Department, however, to provide basement accommodation suitable for vocational instruction at all Day Schools constructed in the future. The fact that there are difficulties to be overcome in the case of the older schools does not mean that at these schools vocational instruction is wholly neglected. Indian Day School teachers frequently, at their own request, are supplied regularly with dressmaking material, yarn, tools for gardening, garden seeds and lumber for wood working projects. The fact that requests for these supplies have been multiplying during the year is an indication of one of the most encouraging tendencies in educational effort among our Indian population.
WELFARE:

A special welfare programme was organized by the officials of the Welfare Division early in the year. This programme was designed to re-establish Indians, and particularly Indians in receipt of relief allowances, on a self-supporting basis.

The sum of $150,000.00 was set apart from the regular Welfare appropriation voted by Parliament for the promotion of projects and the purchase of supplies. An attempt was made by the field officials to give particular attention to Reserves where unemployment was most in evidence and where relief expenditures appeared to be increasing. The most urgent needs of the Indian population on each Reserve determined almost wholly the scope and details of the programme. Under the direction and supervision of Indian Inspectors and Agents live stock, farm machinery and tractors were purchased and supplied to Indians. A number of the unemployed were engaged in cutting pulp wood, cleaning land, boat building and in the construction of root houses.

Twelve tractors were purchased during the year. These tractors remain the property of the Department but are placed at the disposal of Indian Bands and are operated under the personal supervision of our farm instructors.

A number of surveys have been undertaken and completed in the northern regions of the Prairie Provinces with the object of securing from the Provincial Governments areas of land suitable for the propagation of muskrat and other fur-bearing animals. An area has been secured from the Government of Quebec which will enable the Department to proceed with the development of an area suitable for beaver in the territory lying south and east of James Bay.

It is gratifying to state that despite the crop failure in the Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta the results of the special programme have been satisfactory and encouraging. It must be borne in mind, however, that the rehabilitation of the Indian population calls for the exercise of patience and perseverance and is a process that cannot be unduly hurried. It is significant that the majority of young Indians are at this time anxious to establish themselves on Reserves. It is the policy of the Department to encourage this tendency and to make life on the Reserves as attractive and as satisfying as it is possible to make it.

THE FIRST PEOPLE

SURVIVAL OF INDIAN LIFE

HAIL TO "GREAT FATHER"

By DUNCAN CAMPBELL SCOTT, C.M.G., LL.D.

The original Canadians, the Indians, will contribute a special quality to the general welcome accorded their Majesties. They are inheritors of a tradition which is perpetuated not only in formal "treaties" but in memory also. The King was the Great Father of the Indians who was friendly and benevolent towards them; they could look for justice, who was the source and guardian of their charter of rights and privileges.

This tradition will stir the minds of the Iroquois to recall the eighteenth century, when they were allies of the Crown, a sovereign people in their own country. The Six Nations, the Iroquois Confederacy, were then, as they are now, the exponents of all that is admirable in the Indian character, and there are a few who still think of alliance with the white relations. But only a few; it took the stern realities of the Revolutionary war and all the struggles to establish themselves as themselves on the Grand River to make them realize that they were subjects of the Great Father and no longer partners in sovereignty. The idea of a race stronger than their own tribal laws prevailed and spread abroad wherever contact was made with aborigines, and we can quote the words of a princess of the Iroquois in 1876: "Have compassion on the manner in which I was brought up; long ago it was good that I was first made. I wish the same were but again. But now the law has come and in that I wish to walk."

Any estimate of the population of the territories included in the Dominion of Canada when the white man first explored the country is conjectural, but the most trustworthy places the number at 220,000. The census returns of the present gives us a total of 144,000.

COLONIAL PRECEDENT

The vicissitudes of the race in the intervening years have been so many and so severe that its preservation is a tribute to its strength. Maladjustment between aboriginal and civilized customs, disease among them, and the burdens of modern life have all taken toll. But it can now be reasonably asserted that the Indians of Canada will not perish through years of gradual decay and loss of characteristic stamina. That assertion may be supported by a survey of the policy of the Dominion Government, adopted from British Colonial precedents, which stresses the education of the Indian, his protection while in a state of tutelage, and which educates him and assists missionary endeavor and experiment both in education and christianization.

Every thread of that policy and the spirit of the Royal Proclamation Statute, which established the legal status of the Indians point to that end. It was wise and just of the British North America Act which gave to the Dominion the power to legislate for Indians; this ensured a uniform administration. Decision was thus made and there is disposed of doubt as to the legal status of any individual and Indian Reserve lands were protected from the pressure of encroaching settlers.

The Indian Reserve is in fact the foundation of Indian policy. The special areas set apart by agreement between the Crown and the Indians are almost always without the consent of both parties. While enjoying freedom to go and come, to acquire property elsewhere and to use all his faculties in a larger life, the Reserve has given the Indians a needed sense of security.

In the older Provinces, after more than a century and a half, the results of the policy are evident. In Ontario and Quebec, the native type of the Indian unit and of the individual life is worthy of comment. We find reserves developed into towns and villages, flourishing village communities; and everywhere we find individuals actively engaged in our cities and towns. They enter the professions; teach in both the best Indian schools, fill clerical positions in the public service and in business; they are employed in the mines, in the factories, bridges and buildings where steel is used; they are valued as domestic servants, and, in fact, are to be discovered in every walk of life.

THE FINAL CHANGE

The word "discovered" is used advisedly, for these Indians speak English or French fluently and often can hardly be distinguished by physical characteristics from their fellow-Canadians. They are imitative and quick to adapt themselves to modern conditions. They own electric cars, automobiles, and agricultural and domestic machinery; and the telephone, the radio, and the gramophone are in common use. This is not complete degeneration from the higher standard, but it is well maintained and at the lowest level the Indian does not fall below the white.
Several of these Indian communities and many individuals are now ready for the full responsibilities of citizenship. The Indian Act has been a great social change; numbers have given up their Indian status; many more are deterred by the conviction that government guardianship is positive harm.

When we look to the west, to the Prairie Provinces where the relationship has existed for only about 35 years, we find different and discouraging conditions. The Indians east of the Great Lakes never had to face such a major catastrophe as disappearance of the buffalo, and the Government never had to provide suddenly for them a food supply and a method of livelihood.

But in the west these problems confronted the parties and had to be solved quickly. The Government provided rations and the Indians had to become accustomed to an abundant food flow. Instruction in farming and ranching was introduced and lavishly supported, and the Indians, whose physique and habits were not fitted for this work, had to become mired to novel hardships. But the result has been, upon the whole, a success which can be measured by millions of bushels of grain saved from the prairies, and thousands of cattle marketed or consumed by the Indians.

The natives of British Columbia are, anthropologically, the most interesting of the Dominion Indians. They are a mountain and sea people, and in their primitive state possessed the vigorous qualities which come from these environments. They have deteriorated now and are fighting what may be a losing battle with our civilization, which has none of its degrading features has treated them cruelly. It is beyond the scope of this article to deal with the subtle characteristics of the social systems of the Northern tribes or to set forth the mastery with which they put their natural gifts to practical use, or to dwell upon their desire for something beyond the practical which resulted in unique carving and ornamentation by pigment or by other means upon even the most humble of their utensils.

Very little can be recorded of progress among the mining and fishing Indians that large attention is being given the market with furs. Their children are in boarding schools and medical attendance and hospitals are freely provided, but they are subject to all the vicissitudes of the chase and to the competition of white hunters. Progress under these conditions is inevitable, but the outlook for native outlook is encouraging and sympathetic and the effort to add a permanent supply of buffalo meat to the native food stocks is one of the most interesting of later developments.

An educational system covers all the provinces and has the assistance of the religious denominations interested in the christianization of the Indians. The work of day and boarding schools is carried on in modern, well-equipped buildings by qualified teachers. Results in the Eastern Provinces are gratifying and allowing for inherent difficulties, the degree of success is noticeable among Indians whose forebears were nomadic.

A highly proficient professional medical service has been developed and proven methods for the prevention and cure of tuberculosis are generally applied and trachoma is being controlled. The instruction of prospective mothers and care of children in their first days and years has resulted in the decrease of infant mortality. Many well-equipped hospitals have been established on reserves and a determined effort is being made to save the race by scientific methods adapted to the special needs of the Indians.

The review will not have failed to give an impression of native tribes surviving with a reasonable hope of permanence and with the destiny of the race not as a distinct race but through a process of neglect and decay, but by gradual increase of capacity for civilized life and by merging with the population of the Dominion.

May 15, 1939.

It was a wise provision of the British North America Act which gave to the Dominion the power to legislate for Indians; this ensured a uniform administration. Descent was fixed in the male line, which disposed of doubts as to the legal status
of any individual and Indian Reserve lands were protected from the pressure of encroaching settlers.

The Indian Reserve is in fact the foundation of Indian policy. The special areas set apart by agreement between the Crown and the Indians cannot be alienated without the consent of both parties. While enjoying freedom to go and come, to acquire property elsewhere and to use all his faculties in a larger life, the Reserve has given the Indian a needed sense of security.

In the older Provinces, after more than a century and a half, the results of the policy are evident. In Ontario and Quebec the highest type of the Indian social unit and of the individual life is worthy of comment. We find reserves developed for agriculture and stock-raising or as village communities; and everywhere we find individuals actively engaged in our cities and towns. They enter the professions, teach in both white and Indian schools, fill clerical positions in the public service and in business; they are expert workers in the construction of bridges and buildings where steel is used; they are valued as domestic servants, and, in fact, are to be discovered in every walk of life.

THE FINAL CHANGE

The word "discovered" is used advisedly, for these Indians speak English or French fluently and often can hardly be distinguished by physical characteristics from their fellow-Canadians. They are imitative and quick to adapt themselves to modern conditions. They own and operate automobiles and agricultural and domestic machinery;
and the telephone, the radio, and the gramophone are in common use. There is, of course, derogation from the highest standard, but it is well maintained and at the lowest level the Indian does not fall below the white.

Several of these Indian communities and many individuals are now ready for the full responsibilities of citizenship. The Indian Act provides for this final change; numbers have given up their Indian status; many more are deterred by the conviction that government guardianship is a positive benefit.

When we look to the west, to the Prairie Provinces where the relationship has existed for only about 75 years, we find different but not discouraging conditions. The Indians east of the Great Lakes never had to face such a major catastrophe as disappearance of the buffalo; and the Government never had to provide suddenly for them a food supply and a method of livelihood.

But in the west these problems confronted both parties and had to be solved quickly. The Government provided rations and the Indians had to become accustomed to eat bacon and flour. Instruction in farming and ranching was introduced and lavishly supported, and the Indians, whose physique and habits were ill-adapted for labour, had to become insured to novel hardships. But the result has been, upon the whole, a success which can be measured by millions of bushels of grain poured into the elevators and thousands of cattle marketed or consumed by the Indians.

The natives of British Columbia are, anthropologically, the most interesting of the Dominion Indians. They are a mountain and sea people, and in their primitive state possessed the vigorous
qualities which come from these environments. They have deteriorated now and are fighting what may be a losing battle with our civilization, which in some of its most degrading features has treated them cruelly. It is beyond the scope of this article to deal with the subtle characteristics of the social systems of the Northern tribes or to set forth the mastery with which they put their natural assets to practical use, or to dwell upon their desire for something beyond the practical which resulted in unique carving and ornamentation by pigment or by other means upon even the most humble of their utensils.

Very little can be recorded of progress among the hunting and fishing Indians—that large division which supplies the market with furs. Their children are in boarding schools and medical attendance and hospitals are freely provided, but they are subject to all the vicissitudes of the chase and to the competition of white hunters. Progress under these conditions is imperceptible, but the administrative outlook is enlightened and sympathetic and the effort to add a permanent supply of buffalo meat to the native food stocks is one of the most interesting of later developments.

An educational system covers all the provinces and has the assistance of the religious denominations interested in the christianization of the Indians. The work of day and boarding schools is carried on in modern, well-equipped buildings by qualified teachers. Results in the Eastern Provinces are gratifying and, allowing for inherent difficulties, the degree of success is noticeable even among Indians whose forebears were nomadic.
A highly proficient, professional medical service has been developed, and proved methods for the prevention and cure of tuberculosis are generally applied and trachoma is being controlled. The instruction of prospective mothers and care of children in their first days and years has resulted in the decrease of infant mortality. Many well-equipped hospitals have been established on reserves and a determined effort is being made to save the race by scientific methods adapted to the special field of operation.

This review will not have failed to give an impression of native tribes surviving with a reasonable hope of permanence and with the destiny of final disappearance as a distinct class; not through a process of neglect and decay, but by gradual increase of capacity for civilized life and by mergence with the population of the Dominion.

Day schools were constructed during the year at the following reserves:
- Caughnawaga, Quebec; New Credit, Rabbit Island, and Caradoc, Ontario; Berens River, Island Lake, and Little Saskatchewan, Manitoba; Ahtahkakoops, Saskatchewan; Pemberton, Bella Bella and Bella Coola, British Columbia;

At Rabbit Island and Caradoc, Ontario, and at Pemberton, British Columbia, schools were established for the first time; the other seven schools were constructed to replace buildings that had become totally unsuitable for educational purposes.

Educationists in this and other countries continue to stress the need for practical and vocational training. The need of the Indian pupil for this form of instruction is even greater than that of the white pupil. Labour opportunities for him during the years that lie immediately ahead must follow relatively simple lines, such as farming, stock-raising, logging, fishing and hunting and trapping. (The opportunities existing at present for Indians to enter the professions are in no sense encouraging.)

An attempt has been made during the year to encourage a number of pupils who would ordinarily proceed with high school studies to take up vocational courses such as the diploma courses in agriculture and courses in auto mechanics and domestic science.

In addition to the regular vocational courses, for which provision has now been made at practically all day and residential schools, special courses have been organized, largely by way of experiment, at a number of Indian schools. At Caughnawaga, classes in hand-loom weaving have been organized. The girls engaged in this project have been successful in producing hand-loom woven ties, scarves and shopping bags. There appears to be a steadily increasing market for these...
products. At the Qu'Appelle Residential School, Lebret, Saskatchewan, and at the Morley School, Alberta, two mink farms have been established. There has been a feeling for some time on the part of residential school principals that the care and feeding of fur-bearing animals should form part of the training provided at Indian schools. At the Brandon Residential school a group of students, under the direction of the Principal, are engaged in a bee-keeping experiment. This experiment is likely to provide practical training for the boys and an adequate supply of honey for the institution.

At the Mount Elgin Institute, Muncey, Ontario, the pupils have responded enthusiastically to the wrought metal projects which have formed part of their studies during the year.

WELFARE

Last year legislation making provision for the establishment of a revolving fund was passed by Parliament. Bands or groups of Indians can, by assuming collective responsibility, secure loans from this fund for the purchase of farm machinery, live stock, etc. Loans secured from this fund, which cannot exceed the sum of $100,000 per annum, are repayable over a five-year period. Seventeen applications from groups of Indians were approved during the year, involving advances amounting to $35,528. With the single exception of the Abenakis band, the members of which secured a loan for a basketry project, these loans are being used for the clearing of land and the purchase of farm equipment. Thirteen fully equipped community farms, supplied with equipment in whole or in part from this fund, are now in operation in the prairie provinces.

Agricultural returns from Indian reserves, with one or two exceptions, have been more encouraging than they have been at any time in recent years. This is particularly true of returns from the prairie provinces, where a number of reserves were supplied with farm machinery, live stock, etc., from the welfare vote of last year. It is encouraging to note that there was a reduction in relief costs immediately following the harvest season. On the Blood Reserve, in southern Alberta, with a population of 1,300 Indians, the grain threshed this year amounted to 255,000 bushels. The community farm on the Cote reserve, Pelly, Saskatchewan, with an Indian population of 354, one of the first farms of its kind organized under the welfare programme last year, produced 11,000 bushels of grain and 2,300 bushels of potatoes.

Handicraft projects have been organized on eastern reserves where relief costs were high and where the agricultural resources were either limited or non-existent. These projects have been particularly successful at St. Regis, Caughnawaga and Pierreville, Quebec, and at Muncey, Ontario. During the period under review, a number of worthwhile Indian handicraft exhibits have been organized and placed on display at Ottawa, Montreal and Vancouver.

No matter what Reserve one drives through he is sure to see children of school age playing on the road. It seems too bad when one thinks of all the money paid each year towards educating the Indians and they do not take advantage of it. I cannot see that the Indian will ever be brought to the level of the white man even the best educated ones fall back. A few years ago I happened to be speaking to the late Dr. Papineau who knew Indians very well. I mentioned to him the fact that the Indians were so neglectful in sending their children to school.
He told me that Indian children are let do pretty much as they please and that we must take the Indians as they are not as they should be. He said that many of them haven't even a clock in their homes. He laughed and said "Time means nothing to an Indian and when the children do go to school they never get there on time yet the parents are always complaining that the teacher never calls school on time."

I certainly do feel that you are doing the right thing in closing the Indian schools for a time at least to help win this war.

Yours truly,
Wm. Stevens.
Ottawa, June 18, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant and to thank you for the comments on our educational policy, contained therein.

You will be interested to learn that while certain groups of Indians still remain indifferent to the education of their children, the situation throughout the Dominion as a whole is more or less encouraging. I note that the average attendance for the last fiscal year amounted to 77.5%. This is a higher average attendance than the average attendance at public schools about 10 or 15 years ago. I certainly agree with you, however, that there is still room for improvement. It is my hope that by closing our schools during the month of September the attendance will steadily improve during the other months of the regular school year.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

WELFARE

Relief and welfare costs for the year indicate a reduction amounting to $86,712.95 for the provinces of Prince Edward Island, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and North West Territories and an increase amounting to $53,741.63 in the provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Quebec, Alberta and British Columbia or a net increase for the Dominion amounting to $6,971.72. Per capita costs have been as follows:- Nova Scotia $26.16; Prince Edward Island $22.84; New Brunswick $27.58; Quebec $16.30; Ontario $4.65; Manitoba $6.75; Saskatchewan $6.64; Alberta $8.75; British Columbia $4.52; North West Territories $6.17; and Yukon $9.15. It is significant that per capita costs range from $4.52 in British Columbia to $37.58 in New Brunswick. It would appear that despite slight advances in the price of a number of basic commodities - woollens, flour, etc. - relief costs remain low in the provinces where the Indians have at their disposal the lands and hunting and fishing concessions necessary for their support and remain high in provinces where such resources are limited or non-existent.

A steadily awakening interest in the improvement of home conditions has been in evidence throughout the year. A large number of Homemakers' Clubs have been organized under the direction of the Inspector of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan and a number of somewhat similar groups have been organized in the Kamsack and New Westminster agencies, British Columbia, in the Sittle and Fisher River agencies, Manitoba, and in the Six Nations agency, Ontario. The members of these clubs meet monthly. The programs provided usually consist of worth-while projects such as knitting, dressmaking, fruit preserving, the canning of vegetables, lectures on health, sanitation, child care, etc. The officers of the Provincial Extension Services have willingly responded to the requests that have reached them to arrange seasonal programs and provide lecturers for these clubs.

The number of Indians seeking loans from the Revolving Fund has not been as large as might have been expected. Nineteen groups of Indians have been provided with loans amounting to $35,530.78 from this fund. With the exception of two loans amounting to approximately $7,000.00, secured by the Caughnawaga and Akensaki Indians of Quebec, all loans secured were used for the organization and promotion of collective farm projects in the Prairie Provinces. The largest single item of expenditure has been the amount necessary for the purchase and operation of tractors. Loans are authorized only after a thorough investigation of local conditions by the Indian agent and by the inspector and then only to responsible groups of Indians and in amounts not exceeding $5,000.00 in each case.

Handicraft projects remain in the experimental stage and from a promotional standpoint have been confined almost wholly to the provinces of Ontario and Quebec. Experience indicates that exhibitions and displays, coupled with practical demonstrations by skilled handicraft workers, are an important factor in stimulating interest in Indian welfare and in the sale of handicraft products. Two exhibit and demonstration centres were organized during the year. The exhibit organized at the Canadian National Exhibition, Toronto, received wide publicity and appeared to be one of the most attractive exhibits on the exhibition grounds. The display was arranged in an attractive and suitable setting provided in the courtyard of the National Industries Building. Black ash and sweet grass baskets, carved figures, bark work, beaded moccasins and hand-wrought metal utensils, valued at $2,000.00, were sold. Forty Indians took part in the demonstration.

Six Indians took part in the exhibition and demonstration of handicraft work organized at Winnipeg and goods valued at $5,000.00 were sold during the display, which covered the period from November 25 to December 21, 1939.

Indian handicraft projects, to be successful, impose upon the Department an obligation to provide constant supervision and this obligation has until now confined our efforts largely to reserves in Eastern Canada. Faulty workmanship and the failure of wholesale and retail marketing agencies to secure a constant supply of high standard quality handicraft products have in the past militated against the success of the Indians in building up their reserve industries. Only by constant and capable supervision can good workmanship and continuity of supply be guaranteed to a market which has grown steadily and encouragingly since the inception of this work three years ago.

Day schools were constructed during the year at the following reserves: Salmon River, N.S.; Bel Ground, N.B.; Maria, (4 rooms) Que.; Metegami, Sud Lake, (6 rooms) Six Nations and Sucker Creek, Ont.; Little Grand Rapids, Ont.; Big River, Sask.; Boothroyd, Comox, Little Qualicum and Seton Lake, B.C. Schools were established for the first time at Metegami, Ont., and at Big River, (R.C.) Sask. The other schools were constructed to replace buildings that had become unsuitable for educational purposes.

The Ste. Catherine's day school, Cowichan Agency, B.C., is a consolidated four-room school with full basement accommodation for vocational instruction. About 170 pupils are conveyed to this school daily by bus. If successful, schools such as this may in the course of time displace a number of residential schools now operating on Indian reserves.

An unusually large number of residential schools were destroyed by fire during the year. Residential school
buildings at Carcross, Yukon; Albany, James Bay, Ont., and Ahousaht, West Coast Agency, B. C., were totally destroyed. The boys' building at the Alert Bay residential school, Kwakwaka'wakw agency, B. C., was partially destroyed and the Indian day school at Hunter's Point, Timiskaming Agency, Que., was totally destroyed. In view of these losses and others sustained from time to time, it is doubtful if in the future residential schools should be built other than those of fireproof construction.

There appears to be a growing awareness on the part of our Indian population of the direct relationship between worthwhile secondary school courses - academic and vocational - and the ability of the members of the younger generation to establish themselves on a self-supporting basis. This awareness has led in recent years to a widespread demand for tuition grants. An arrangement has now been made whereby the first year high school course will be provided at a large number of Indian day schools. Assurances have been received from the Correspondence Branches of the provincial departments of education that they will be willing to co-operate with the Department in the promotion of these courses.

Indian day and residential schools in the provinces of Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta are regularly inspected by public school inspectors and in the provinces of New Brunswick and British Columbia, by inspectors employed by the Department. The reports received from these officers indicate that courses of study have been adjusted to meet the peculiar temperament, outlook and needs of the Indian pupil. They indicate also that the teachers in charge of Indian schools with rare exceptions are fully qualified in a professional sense, deeply interested in the welfare and progress of their pupils and anxious to co-operate with Indian agents and farm instructors in the organization of women's clubs, the cultivation of subsistence gardens and general welfare work on the reserves.

Your letter of April 26, addressed to the M. S. C. C., Winnipeg, Man., has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I am sending forward, for your information, the last annual report of the Indian Affairs Branch. You will find an answer to a number of your questions in the tables contained in this report.

Indian residential schools, except in one or two instances, have been built and are kept in a state of repair by the Government. The Churches supply food, clothing and instruction, for which they are allowed per capita grants, ranging from $100 to $200 per annum. The teachers at residential schools are employed by the churches, and it is my understanding that practically all the churches are now demanding full academic and professional standing from the teachers they employ.

Recruiting for residential schools is usually undertaken by the principal of the school in cooperation with the Indian agent. The aim of our educational program at the present time is to so equip the pupil that he can return to his reserve with the hope of establishing himself on a self-supporting basis and live a useful life. The courses at residential schools throughout the Dominion have become increasingly more vocational in character and this is particularly true of our schools in British Columbia. The courses provided at these schools compare, in my judgment, very favourably with the courses provided at any public schools -

Miss Kathleen Porter,
R. R. No. 2,
Chemainus, B. C.
schools in the Dominion.

The question is constantly being asked: Do the Indians revert to their former level of living when leaving school? It is somewhat difficult to answer this question definitely. Indians in Canada differ widely in the progress they have made and in the extent to which they have detached themselves from primitive instincts and primitive modes of living. The Indians of Caughnawaga, Que., are the finest steel workers in the world and have recently been engaged on the construction of the bridge at San Francisco. As you are probably aware, Indians were employed on the construction of the Empire State Building, New York. These Indians are practically indistinguishable from ordinary white citizens. This is also true of the Indians of the Six Nations Reserve, Brantford, Ont. There are 14 Indian day school teachers employed on the Six Nations Reserve, and of these, 13 are Indians, who received their instruction in these schools and who at this date enjoy full academic and professional standing. The Head of the Economics Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources is an Iroquois Indian, as is also the Doctor now in charge of the Indian Reserve at Caradoc, Ont. It will thus be seen that Indians who have been intimately in contact with white civilization for a century or so are becoming gradually assimilated - or perhaps it would be more accurate to say - have reached a stage in their development when they can compete successfully with the white man and assume the full responsibilities of democratic citizenship.

I am personally disposed to favour the Indian day school and thus avoid the necessity of moving Indian children from their homes. It must be borne in mind, however, that there are thousands of Indian homes in Canada, not equipped to provide the children with either the nourishment or the care necessary for their
development. Provision, for the time being at least, must be made for the care of these children in residential schools.

Economies have been effected as the result of the war, but the reductions in the expenditures provided for Indian education and Indian welfare have not been drastic.

I am sending forward herewith a brief summary of the Inspector's last report on the St. Michael's School, Alert Bay, B. C.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

HANDICRAFT

Substantial progress has been made in the marketing of handicraft products and in the promotion of handicraft projects on a number of eastern reserves.

Arrangements have been made with two well established wholesale houses for the marketing of Indian handicraft products such as split ash and sweet grass baskets, carved figures, small birch bark canoes and hand-loom weaving products such as scarves, ties, rugs, etc. These wholesale houses have experienced no difficulty in disposing of these products and the demand appears to be growing from month to month. In addition to this new outlet, a number of the more progressive Indians, profiting by the instruction and supervision given by the Department, have been able during the year to secure a large number of orders for themselves and have made shipments direct to their customers.

Three handicraft exhibits were held during the year; at St. Helen's Island, near Montreal, at which $1,200 worth of craft-work was sold, and at the Canadian National Exhibition, Toronto, and at Winnipeg. The amount received from the sale of goods at the Toronto and Winnipeg exhibits exceeded $10,000.

Certain Indian bands have been encouraged to open roadside stands on public highways, close to their reserves. These bands have been assisted by the transfer in care of the local Indian agent of basketry products and novelties from other Indian reserves. The fact that these products are sold to the Indians at wholesale prices enables them to sell at a profit and place on display a variety of products likely to attract the attention of tourists.

The failure of Canadian and American wholesale houses to secure adequate supplies of novelty products from Europe is reflected in the steadily increasing number of orders now reaching the Department.

WELFARE

Relief and welfare costs for the year show a reduction amounting to $101,842.10. This is the most substantial reduction that has taken place at any time in recent years.

A marked improvement in employment conditions was in evidence throughout the year. The skilled workers of the eastern reserves, particularly the steel workers of Caughnawaga, have experienced little difficulty in securing work in war industries. A large number of unskilled workers, however, have not yet secured permanent employment.

An attempt has been made in recent years to encourage reforestation on a number of reserves. It is gratifying to report that a steadily increasing number of Indian bands are cooperating with the Department in the extension of this work. Toward the close of the year 15,000 trees were secured from the provincial forestry station and planted on suitable lands at the Caradoc reserve. A start was also made at the Moravian agency, where 2,000 trees were planted. The trees at this reserve are designed to provide windbreaks and additional shelter for Indian homes.

It cannot be said that economic conditions in the Prairie Provinces have been wholly satisfactory. A number of community farms established in 1937 and financed from the revolving fund have experienced difficulty in meeting their obligations. An attempt has been made to adjust our farming program which should result in greater emphasis on subsistence farming. Indians have been encouraged to produce crops for home consumption rather than for export and to keep live stock - cows, pigs and sheep - in sufficient numbers to provide the meat necessary for domestic consumption.

Relief and welfare costs in British Columbia remain low and appear to have reached a figure when further reductions can scarcely be expected, if adequate provision is to be made for the old and physically incapacitated members of the bands. Employment conditions in the lumbering and fishing industries have been satisfactory. The number of Indians engaged in agriculture has shown a substantial increase. Late in the year an interesting experiment was undertaken at the Seabird Island Indian reserve, where an experimental plot of five acres was seeded to fibre flax. The seed for this experiment was secured from the Agassiz Experimental Farm.

An encouraging feature of the work of this year was the progress made in the development of an educational program designed to meet the needs of an Indian population scattered over 9 provinces, the Yukon and North West Territories. This Indian population includes the highly skilled steel workers of Caughnawaga, Que., the fishing and trapping Indians of the northern sections of the Dominion and the Pacific coast, and the Indians engaged in extensive farming operations in Ontario and the Prairie Provinces.

The progress made at Indian day and residential schools in the province of British Columbia has been particularly gratifying. In addition to the regular academic courses, special vocational courses have been successfully organized. These courses, for girls, consist of the treatment and spinning of locally grown
wool and the knitting of woollen garments, Cowichan sweaters, socks, etc., dressmaking, fruit preserving, crochet work and home management, and for boys, boat-building, auto mechanics, Indian arts and crafts and elementary agriculture. The Koksilah, Inkameep and Ste. Catherine schools have been outstandingly successful in the organization of these courses, all of which are based on the needs of the Indians on the adjoining reserves.

Mr. Anthony Walsh, the teacher in charge of the Inkameep Indian day school, has succeeded in the dramatization of a number of Indian legends. The presentation of these at the Banff Drama School created a great deal of interest amongst Indian educationists in Canada and the United States. Mr. Walsh, in addition to these presentations, published during the year, in cooperation with his pupils, a booklet entitled "The Tale of the Nativity". This teacher has had a number of invitations to organize drama festivals in the United States.

An interesting experiment in fur ranching took place at the Morley residential school, Alberta, when a small mink ranch was established 2 years ago. This ranch started with 6 mink, netted 75 mink last year and still has on hand 50 mink as breeding stock. The principal of the school, commenting on the work of the ranch, states: "The Indian boys have taken to this work in a very fine way and I believe that at least a dozen boys could find employment if they so desired among the large fur ranches in the vicinity of Calgary".

Toward the end of the year a representative of the Department spent 3 months at the schools of Alberta. This visit was arranged in an attempt to bring the courses of study into conformity with the vocational opportunities on the reserves of the province. This is the first vocational survey that has been undertaken by the Department. If successful, it will be gradually extended to the other provinces of the Dominion.

The four-room classroom building, constructed at Alberni as a unit of the residential school completed in 1940, was totally destroyed by fire in February, 1941. A fire which resulted in the destruction of the blacksmith and carpentry shops at the Kootenay residential school also occurred during the year.

A number of educational problems remain to engage the attention of the Department. Of these, perhaps the most difficult is irregularity of attendance. Attendance at Indian day schools, even in the case of schools where transportation is available for pupils, is far from satisfactory.

An acute shortage of fully qualified teachers exists throughout the country, and it has become increasingly difficult to secure male teachers for Indian day schools in outlying districts. It is difficult to over-emphasize the effect of this condition on the educational
standards that have been reached at our schools and upon the general progress of Indian pupils.

A textbook for use in Indian day schools, the subject matter of which emphasizes forestry and wild life conservation, was prepared during the year. This is the first textbook prepared and published by the Department.

MEMORANDUM
Re.: A. J. Hatcher.

The Department of Indian Affairs deals with Indian Education. Some of the phases of this Education may have points in common with Half Breed Education. The following brief is sent in the hope that it may be suggestive and helpful.

SOME AIMS OF INDIAN EDUCATION:

1. The Indian School must seek to develop a love for the life the child must later lead and to prepare him to live it efficiently.

2. To promote social adjustment and responsibility.

3. To develop skills and impart information.

4. To promote health, both physical and mental.

5. To provide activities suitable to child development.

1. To develop a love for the life the child must lead and to prepare him to live it efficiently.

There are but three careers available to the Prairie Indian: Farming, cattle raising, hunting and fishing. It is true that some may find their way to some profession but these will be the exception and must be classed as exceptions.

To make these people happy in their mode of life should be one of the important concerns of the school. A system concerned primarily with the acquisition of academic skills will prevent the continuity of the school and 'Life' so necessary to happy efficient living.

2. To promote Social adjustment and responsibility.

The Indian leaves a small social group, the family, for a larger social group, the school. In most cases the family social conditions demand changes. It is at the school that these readjustments must be made. It is at the school that children should learn to be helpful and dependable. They should partake in activities that will encourage this development: Sports, Student Councils, Manual Training, etc.

3. To develop skills and impart information.

The Indian should be able to handle efficiently the skills of basic academic subjects: Reading, Writing, Arithmetic. He should moreover develop manual skills necessary to his mode of life. General Shop should be a part of every Indian School.

4. To promote health, physical and mental.

5. To provide activities suitable to child development.

Dramatization, chorals, music, rhythm bands, singing games, etc.

Dear Mr. Hatcher:

Please pardon me for not acknowledging receipt of your letter of July 18 until now. I have been absent from the office on holidays - hence the delay.

I am sending forward, for your information, a number of excerpts taken from Inspectors' reports that have reached the Department on Indian day and residential schools. These excerpts will enable you to grasp to some extent the courses of study that we have been attempting to promote at our Indian schools. It would appear that we have made greater progress in the province of British Columbia than we have in the other provinces. This is due in part to the fact that we have our own Inspector in that province. Capable teachers and regular supervision make up about four fifths of the battle in Indian educational effort. Latterly our aim has been to devote about one-third of the regular instruction period to vocational projects.

It would appear that during the period ahead of us there are but three careers available to the Indian and half-breed—farming; cattle-raising; hunting and fishing. It is true that some may find their way to the other professions, but these will be the exception and must be classed as such. An educational program, therefore, in my judgment should have a vital and direct relationship to the tasks the pupils are likely to undertake immediately following their departure from school.

I was very much interested in your reference to the History that might be taught in half-breed schools -

Dear Mr. Hatcher:

The following excerpts are taken from a letter received by the Department from Mr. Z. M. Hamilton, Secretary of the Saskatchewan Historical Society, Regina, Sask.:

"You asked about the "Pride of Race" possessed by the western Metis. I can assure you that to them it is a very real thing. The original Metis were the off-spring of the early French explorers, the officers of the Hudson's Bay Company, and the officers of the North West Company, and, usually, the women of the Indian Chiefs of the tribes amongst whom they lived.

"In the early days of the last century, a number of the children of the fur traders of the mixed blood received their elementary education at the parochial schools of the Roman Catholic and the Anglican Church which were established on the banks of the Red River, and some of them were sent to eastern Canada for their education, and, in some instances, even to the old country.

"Originally, the Metis people were reliable and trustworthy, and some of them became very important in the life of the country. Such names as the two Louis Riels—père and fils—Ambroise Lepine, Gabriel Dumont, Charles Nolin, John Norquay, an early Premier of Manitoba, Hon. James Mackay of Silver Heights, a Minister of Agriculture in an early Manitoba Government, William Mackay, of the Hudson's Bay Company, who was the Hudson's Bay officer in command of Fort Ellice who ruled practically the whole prairie country, and in more modern times, Hon. Mr. Justice Mackay of the Saskatchewan Court of Appeal, and his brother, Thomas Mackay, an early member of the Territorial Legislature, indicate that the western natives of the mixed blood were no mean people.

"There is a book dealing with the history of the Metis people written in French, by a gentleman named du Tremondon, (I am not perfectly sure, however, if this is the correct spelling of the name), that you would find of great service. I do not have a copy of the book in the office or I would send it to you, but I think you could procure one by writing to Samuel Nault, President of the Manitoba Metis Society, Great West Permanent Building, Winnipeg. Another book that I am sure you would find very interesting—

A. J. Hatcher, Esq.,
Inspector of Schools,

interesting is "A Critical Account of the Red River Insurrection of 1869-70," written in English by Rev. Father Morice, O.M.I. I think you could get that by writing to the Rev. Father Deschambault, Archbishop's Palace, St. Boniface.

To All Teachers of Indian Residential and Day Schools

Although at this time and under the present state of affairs it is hard to anticipate what might transpire a year hence it is, however, requisite to plan ahead, taking for granted that the usual course of events will not be disturbed. By this I am referring to the annual Indian Exhibit at the Regina and Prince Albert Fairs, which we hope will take place in 1942.

A new curriculum has been issued by the Provincial Department of Education, which designates certain changes to be brought about in the daily program of school education. Undoubtedly it will be necessary, as a result, to modify the prize list for Indian exhibits, so as to conform to the changes brought about in the School subjects. To deal with this more effectively is to ask the Principals of the Schools, and the teachers, to suggest what changes should be made, and, in doing this I would advise them to take the old prize list, look it over, and submit to this Office their suggestions for a modification.

When your suggestions are received here they will all be given closest attention, and from this an Indian Exhibit list will be drafted for examination and approval of the School Exhibit Committee.

I might say here, for future guidance, and while it is fresh in my memory, that, with reference to Sections 9, 10, 11, 12, and 13 of this year's list, the Judges were critical of some of the exercise books. They were saying that some students exhibited books not in compliance with the instructions in the prize list. Some books seemed not to be the daily work of the pupil, as required, but a special scribbler into which was copied the daily work. If this is true this practice will have to be stopped and closer attention should be paid to the regulations in the Prize list.

Another matter I want to emphasize is with reference to the shipping of the exhibits. Not enough attention is given to this. Some schools send their exhibits wrapped up in two or three, or even more, carton packages, tied with strings. The unpacking of such containers, and peaking again, involves a great deal of work and grief on the part of the Exhibits Staff. Each school could have, as some do, a wooden box made at the school, with a lid hinged, in which these exhibits could be sent. I wish to impress upon you that this is important.

Upon going over the list of schools that participated in the Indian Exhibit at Regina and Prince Albert I note that too many of them were not heard from. Every teacher must know to a certain extent child psychology—that children must be inspired to work. This can only be accomplished through some incentive which might vary from day to day or from year to year. Competition amongst children is one incentive by which better results in education might be attained. Indian children particularly lack a competitive spirit, or shall I say it lies dormant in them and needs to be aroused. I am, therefore, very much convinced that if your pupils were encouraged to participate in the school exhibits at the summer Fairs they would find themselves competing against other children in other schools and would thus be inspired to improve their educational standard. Teachers also could use this as their gauge in the educational standing of their pupils. Consequently I am interested to see that more schools take part in exhibiting their work and would ask the teachers to encourage their pupils in having their work forwarded for competition at the Provincial Exhibition.

I also find that some of our teachers have carried on their work at the school, teaching year in and year out but have done nothing to improve their own standards, or to refresh their own knowledge. By this I mean they have not been attending Teachers' Conventions nor have they been participating in other formal functions arranged by teachers or an educational institution for discussion of better teaching methods. It is a well known fact that once a teacher, or anyone, becomes...
that once a teacher, or anyone, becomes a recluse in his own vocation, he also becomes somewhat stale and careless in his work. It is, therefore, suggested that Indian teachers attend teachers conventions and participate in everything that will help them to improve their teaching standard at their school. They should seek ways and means by studying the experience of other teachers so as to use newer methods to bring about better results in the Indian school.

In conclusion I wish to say that this letter is intended to include my general remarks and views on school activities for Indian children. I cannot over emphasize the fact that while many of our teachers are doing good work and obtaining magnificent results there are too many whose schools are found to lack sufficient life and are making no progress. This is particularly true, and you will agree with me to see that not taking an active part outside the school, to remedy the situation. In most instances the teachers are not aware of the sad state of affairs and this is because they do not know what other teachers are doing. It is quite obvious that the responsibility of the whole school lies with the teacher and his influence extends far beyond the school. It is, therefore, urgent that no efforts should be spared to bring life into a school, which can only be done by the teacher taking an active part in everything that will help them in this direction.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

On my visits to the different schools in this Province I have found that while some of the teachers in the schools are doing good work there are other schools which seem to be dead and something is required to put life into them.

I thought we might remedy this situation by circularizing a letter to the various Indian Residential and Day Schools bringing this to the attention of the teachers. I am herewith attaching copy of a letter drafted for this purpose and also a statement indicating therein the names of the schools, the equipment as shown in the report dated March 31st, 1942, the number of exhibits forwarded to the Regina and Prince Albert Exhibitions, the number of prize winners such as first, second, third, and fourth, and the percentage secured in prizes.

As you know, the exhibits for the Regina and Prince Albert Exhibitions are handled through this office and I have been in a position to know which schools take an active part and have their pupils exhibit their work. This has been a great source of information regarding the work the various schools are doing and I am of the opinion that one way of encouraging and putting new life into a school is to more or less insist upon the teachers submitting the work of their pupils to one or both of these Fairs.

In conclusion, after this circular has been perused I would ask that the Branch write me a letter expressing their opinion in this connection. Any further suggestions will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

October 7, 1941.

Re: School Exhibits.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 30 and also draft of the circular letter addressed to the Indian day and residential schools of Saskatchewan, attached thereto.

The officials of the Welfare and Training Division are of the opinion that the receipt of this circular letter by the teachers may arouse their interest in the annual exhibits and prompt them to put forth a greater effort to make the contributions from their schools really worthwhile. These officials agree with you that the element of competition or rivalry in school work should be encouraged.

You are probably aware that an official of the Department, Mr. A. J. Doucet, undertook a survey of the Indian schools of Alberta during the last year, with the object of organizing worthwhile academic and vocational courses at these schools. Mr. Doucet has since his return completed this course of study and forwarded it to the principals in charge of our schools in Alberta. It is our intention to have a somewhat similar survey undertaken in the other provinces, but the officials are of the opinion that the experiment now being made in Alberta should be followed closely for a year, with the object of determining its suitability. If no weak spots appear in this course of study during the year, a somewhat similar course might be adopted in Saskatchewan. The principals in charge -

Mr. M. Christianson,
General Superintendent
of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Building,
Cor. Scarth & Victoria Streets,
REGINA, Sask.
charge of the Alberta schools will be called upon to submit a report each month on the work accomplished.

You are aware that our Indian day schools throughout the Dominion are now operating on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis. In view of this fact, a number of inspectors in the province of Ontario recommended that school fairs and school exhibits at agricultural fairs be temporarily abandoned. These inspectors were of the opinion that the time consumed by the average teacher in organizing these exhibits was out of all proportion to their actual worth. They pointed out that it was particularly inadvisable to devote so much time to the organization of exhibits toward the close of the academic year, when the teacher should be engaged in reviewing the year's work, preparing the pupils for their tests, etc. There is a suggestion here that the teachers in Saskatchewan should be reminded that too much time should not be devoted to the actual organization of exhibits at their schools.

Yours truly,

T. F. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. McVitty:

In response to the request contained in your post card of November 2, I am sending forward, under separate cover, certain reports and certain excerpts from Inspectors' reports, which I trust you will find helpful in taking part in the discussion which is to be held on November 10, under the auspices of the St. Thomas General Ministerial Association.

In view of the fact that this information is not likely to reach you until the morning of the 10th, it is my hope that the members of the Ministerial Association will see their way clear to postpone the discussion to a later date and thus enable you to become reasonably up to date on the subject.

We have at this date an Indian population in Canada of approximately 120,000, increasing at the rate of approximately 1% per annum. This means that each year we have at least 300 additional Indian pupils for whom it is necessary to provide educational facilities.

Our school enrolment at this date - approximately 19,000 - is divided somewhat evenly between Indian day and residential schools. The tendency on the part of the Government in recent years has been to multiply Indian day schools rather than residential schools. You may be interested to learn that a great deal of criticism has been directed against residential schools since I entered the Department about 5 years ago. There seems

Rev. S. R. McVitty,
32 Wellington Street,
St. Thomas, Ont.
to be a growing feeling that with the exception of the remote northern regions our Indians have outgrown the necessity for such institutions. I have been primarily interested since I entered the Department in promoting vocational courses of study at our schools. The Minister of the Department at the present time is of the opinion that our courses of study must become increasingly more practical in character. The excerpts from inspectors' reports, a copy of which I am enclosing, will give you a fair idea of the success we have had in the promotion of manual training and practical projects at a number of our schools.

It is scarcely necessary to add that should you require additional information, I want you to feel free to communicate with me again.

With kind personal regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

R. A Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare Training.

December 1, 1949

Gentlemen:

Once again, it is time to start planning for the employment of university students at the end of the academic year. Although many veteran students have already graduated there will still be exceptionally large classes, due to the presence of veterans, in 1950 and 1951. It is obviously important that employment be found for them - permanent for graduates and temporary for undergraduates.

It may seem rather early to introduce this subject but dealing with the problem involves several months' work and an immediate start is therefore imperative. The full resources of this Department and the National Employment Service will be used to assist in filling your requirements and in finding positions for students seeking them. However, your assistance is vital without it the problem could not be solved. It would be greatly appreciated therefore if you would list your estimated requirements on the enclosed form and return it to the address given at the top of the form. It is requested that, in listing requirements you supply as full information as possible on such items as remuneration, types of training, whether you will consider applicants from all universities or on some more restricted basis, etc. Complete information will greatly assist in efficient selection of applicants.

Even at this early date you will no doubt be able to give a fairly close estimate of the 1950 graduates you will require. It is realized that at this time it may be more difficult to judge exact requirements for summer employees. However, it will be most helpful if you will list known openings now and indicate a date when further information will be available. Officers of the National Employment Service will then get in touch with you at the time indicated.

Should you make a practice of visiting universities to make your own selection of students, this letter will serve as a reminder that it is time to consider your planning on student employment. It is also a request that employers who make a direct approach will nevertheless furnish the National Employment Service with information as to how many students will be engaged so that the general picture of available openings will be known. Lastly, it is to advise you of assistance available from the National Employment Service in such matters as arranging interviews on the campus, etc. At the Prairie universities, full time N.E.S. offices operate on the campuses throughout the academic year. At other universities, N.E.S. liaison officers work in co-operation with university staffs.

When you avail yourself of this service, it would greatly increase the efficiency of the whole scheme if, when positions are filled, you would immediately notify the N.E.S. local office in your city. When this is done, all offices will be notified and be governed accordingly.

Your cooperation in this matter will be of great assistance and will be appreciated by the students themselves and the university authorities, as well as the government organizations concerned.

Yours very truly,

It ended in English-French rivalry and war for North America.

The British Canadians disliked the Quebec Act because, having tested the benefits of a parliamentary system of government in Britain, they wanted the same democratic system in the Canadian Colony.

The American Revolution against Britain broke out in 1775 and the invasion of Canada followed.

The French Canadians remained loyal to Britain and successfully fought with the British against the Americans.

The Loyalists left the American colonies to settle in Canada.

Lord Durham was sent out from England to investigate the trouble.

Lord Durham's Report of 1839 advocated -

Both the British and French-Canadian reformers in Upper & Lower Canada continued their fight against the power of the Governors and their appointed councils. This fight was peacefully conducted after 1837.

The Reformers triumphed during the famous Baldwin-Lafontaine government with the great Lord Elgin as Governor.

The final step in the development of our Canadian nation was taken in 1931, with the passage of the Statute of Westminster (Canada became an independent sovereign state within the British Commonwealth of Nations).

The voter receives a ballot of paper from the Deputy Returning Officer, goes to a polling booth compartment, makes a cross opposite the candidate's name of his choice and folds his ballot. It is then deposited in the ballot box.

This is called secret voting because no one sees you mark your ballot, nor is there any way of checking how the voter marked his ballot.

Please find enclosed a mimeographed copy of an illustrated primer on Canadian Geography, History, and Government, "What a Canadian Should Know." The questions and answers print highlights of Canada's story in such a way as to show our evolution to self-government and its significance in individual work.

H.L. Keenleyside, Esq., Ph.D., LL.D.,

OTTAWA, Ontario

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

The 'History in the Making' series of weekly commentaries on current international developments, sponsored jointly by the Adult Education Committee of Carleton College and the Ottawa Branch of the United Nations Association in Canada, is resuming on Thursday evenings beginning January 12.

A considerable number of regular members of the group are officers of the three Services working towards promotional examinations. They have suggested the usefulness of an evening on Canada's Northland, and I am writing to ask if you could suggest some member of your Department who would be prepared to talk for 35 or 40 minutes about the topography, resources, development and future prospects of this area, and to answer questions from the group. The date suggested is Thursday, January 19, at 8.15 p.m.

The previous meetings in this Series have been of a high level of discussion, and we would like to have this atmosphere continued by the most authoritative meeting we can provide. May I therefore ask your help in securing a speaker for this date?

We would also welcome any suggestion you might make for a speaker on the St. Lawrence Seaway Project (tentative date, Thursday, February 2).

Yours sincerely,

J. A. Gibson
Professor of History.

ENCL.
November 9th, 1928.

Sir,

The Department directs your attention to the necessity of the most careful examination of application forms in regard to Indian children who are presented for admission to residential schools. I have, therefore, to invite your attention to, and compliance with, the subjoined facts and instructions.

On the "Application for Admission" form, the agent signs the following declaration: "I hereby approve of the admission of the above child and certify that he is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil."

There is a departmental ruling to the effect that half-breed children living the Indian mode of life or a reserve are eligible for admission to the boarding and industrial schools, or, more fully: "While it was not considered that the children of half-breeds proper of Hamilton and the Prairie Provinces should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the Department, it was conceded that all children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian reserve and whose parents on either side live as Indians, even if they are not annuitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools. However, every application for admission should be accompanied by satisfactory evidence that the applicant is a half-breed to whom the rule applies, and not a person who has been adopted by or otherwise brought into association with Indians with the express purpose of gaining admission to our schools."

At the time you forward an application, write a covering letter in the case of half-breed or non-Treaty children, giving your reasons for believing the child to be a charge on the Indian Department.

When you have reason to believe that the accommodation of the boarding or industrial school is limited, preference should be given to orphan children or those that are neglected by their parents.

Exercise every care to ensure the placing of the child in a residential school under the auspices of the religious denomination to which the parents adhere. No Roman Catholic child shall be sent to a Protestant school and vice versa. You will please adhere strictly to this provision of the Act. (See Section 10 (4) of the Indian Act.) Concerning the age of applicants for admission to our residential schools, only in very exceptional cases will the Department authorize the admission of any child other than between the ages of 7 and 13 inclusive.

Check carefully all applications that come before you, giving particular attention to the age, religion and status of the applicant before asking the Department to admit them as grant-earning pupils to a boarding or industrial school.

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Walter,

Please be good enough to read and accept this article.

I should be glad to take up many copies of the publication containing it. Yours sincerely H.L.Bergan.

What is the best method of teaching primitive people? The same as that of teaching primitive children, not by making them listen to lectures, but by making them work. They should take an active part in the work of the class. Gestures are more important than words. Doing something is more important than listening to a lecture. Body exercise will improve their health. They should know something about the geography of the world and have first place to places from country to country. In this way they will easily learn all that they are being taught.

I applied these principles in my world-class. For this reason I bought a plot of ground (60 yards long by 30 yards wide) in 1948. The pupils of my class laid out a world-garden in it. This garden was, as it were, a large map of the world.

Each of the pupils had a little plot of ground of his own which represented a certain country. They sold the products of their own countries and, if possible, grew them in their own gardens. The world and their own countries were their "center of interest" for years and years.

In this way every teacher can use his own textbook. The pupils will be more receptive than in the old class. They will work in this world and the teacher will give them a useful general knowledge of this world instead of a dangerous knowledge of special subjects.

H.L.Bergan, Student No. 11146, 1-5-49.
11. What is the best method of teaching primitive peoples?
The same as that of teaching primitive children, which method is this? The method of working hard. The best method for primitives demands few new words and ideas, no jumping from one thing to another, one structure, only one building-up factor, which word unites the education from the primitives to farmer, practically and theoretically? This word is "work", movement, hard work is the base of the worldclass. Why an education without base? Without fundament? One word, unitwork is needed. The worldgarden will give an idea of this work.

How to make clear that hard work is needed for the rise of peoples? The answer is: by numbers numbers which demonstrate that hard work is the corner-stone of the building (rising) of generations and the world. Numbers as reliability-factors... not by making them listen to lectures but by making them work. They should take an active part in the work of the school. Gestures are more important than words. Especially primitives are poor in words, but movements can say much. A gesture to ear, eye, or mouth can say sentences like: hear, see, be silent.

The method of movements before productively, in stead of reproduction. For in the art of teaching, the great art of teaching primitives is: how can these movements be made ten times more instructive? By movements in the worldgarden. The world is reviewed from 26 different points of view (branches of the curriculum). There is, consequently, some repetition which will serve a useful purpose as revision and production - in stead of reproduction.

Idleness is the root of all evil. Movements are the root of saying, creating, eating, breathing. To act and say sentences like the above mentioned is double as instructive. The productive method is worth twice as much as the reproductive. Movements from place to place can be double as instructive again, for the memory of place is the strongest, especially with primitives. Even fictive movements are tenfold instructive within the worldclass.

Movements can be tried as instructive as reproduction from books. Four times more instructive can be movements, then going from place to place. This multiplied instructiveness is doubled if the place lies in a fixed, regular, symmetric structure like the worldclass. These movements for primitives 10 times more instructive than the reproductive... the art of teaching.

A number of experts have come to this conclusion here.

I put these principles into practice in my worldgarden and worldclass. For this reason I bought a plot of ground (50 yards long, by 30 yards) in 1945. The pupils of my class laid out a worldgarden in it.

This garden was, as it were, a large map of the world. Every pupil occupies his country, has his place, which is indicated by a number denoting the longitude and the latitude of the country, on a square or field. If need be without frontiers this plain or field represents the world as a world-wide farmland representing the grasslands, etc., in 35 countries. In 35 places or pupils on the field or in the classroom without the map-character.

Given without frontiers for the world the class can play there all branches. The pupils grow the food, fictively or in reality. They are instructed in order to become servants of the Uncsoo. They sell their product and keep their book (book-keeping).

How to make the reproductive method productive? One of the pupils e.g. lives in San Francisco, California; his name is chosen from the environment and his surname, but, from one of its products, Cal Nut. From this name the class evolves a sentence from 33 names 33 sentences, self-made. This lesson in 10 tenses, 10 persons, 10 forms, with 10 determinations (adjectives), consequently so in 10,000 forms is an introduction to the book "The world".

Afterwards in 4 languages. Every teacher can type and multiply his own book. His mind has a natural tendency to reject the other books. Translations of the book are to be learned in one tenth of the time, for the move this are known, the succession, the composition too.
