School, food and people.

Fundamental education. Movement is the fundamental question.

How are we to fight famine in this devastated world? How are we to cultivate enough food for the rapidly increasing population of the world? How are we to secure a higher standard of living? How can we prevent slums and unemployment? In short, how can we build a better world, create mutual understanding and secure a feeling of safety?

By a change in food production. Hard work. The change that would most increase food production would be to transform the present predominantly peasant type of rural economy to a mixed farm type as adopted in the more advanced countries.

While increases in food production can be confidently expected, they will certainly involve considerable work and much scientific study. There is no prospect of easy living.

1000 of millions of people suffer from food shortage now.

Every year the population of the world increases by 1%. But every year the area of food-producing soil decreases by 2%.

What will the situation be like after a century? After a comparatively short time the population will be doubled, the cultivated soil halved, the need quadruples.

How can double the population be fed on half the cultivated soil?

This is possible, if:

First - the food-shortage is fought not,
Secondly - the farmer-to-be (peasant) not is disaccustomed
from hard work, from vigorous movements,
Thirdly - the farmers are given an agricultural-scientific
education, prepared in the primary school,
Fourthly - we prevent the hoarding of food for the next war,
if the world restore this as world, as unity.

In 1870 the war was won by the teacher. In 1970 the war will be won by the teacher who gives his pupils a good technical education (electricity, etc.). The pupils should be taught, not only to fight in a military war, but also to fight food-shortage and unemployment.

Unemployment increases with the poverty in the world. The more-sale of the U.S.A. was every year 600 million dollar.

In June 1949 there were four millions of unemployed labourers.

This proves that even the richest nation of the world cannot fight unemployment successfully in its own country.

Unemployment is an international problem.

If new agricultural countries produce and sell more agricultural products, they can buy more and fight unemployment.

How to increase this production? In 1850 Mr. Van Hoek came to Noord-Brabant, a province of the Netherlands, as a teacher of agriculture. At the time there was only one dairy-factory in the whole province. In 1857 there were 125 dairy-factories, with a large export-trade, and less unemployment also in the other parts.

To increase the number of these factories in this district from 1 to 125 takes up less energy and time than to raise that number from 125 to 250. Therefore the best plan is to begin with the development of underdeveloped regions. Unesco tries to educate the backward nations. They should be quickly educated. Their soil should be cultivated and their agriculture be developed.

This is an international experiment of the greatest importance, because national experiments are bound to fail.

Sound agricultural instruction is essential. The guidance of the Unesco is necessary. The agricultural instruction should be adapted to the country where it is given. Already in the primary school physics and biology should more frequently be taught.

The elementary school will give this preparation without to be technical. With the view to education in agriculture and hygiene the class is as a worldwide fixed form in the classroom. The pupils, the desks are the countries, 3x1 countries, symmetric, regular, in the same structure as the numbers, one structure and not more.

By more structures there are orders and contra-orders with the physical distress, the psychological press with the stuttering, with the destroy instead of the construction.

INTERNATIONAL LABOUR OFFICE

GENEVA

18 Nov. 1949.

No. GL. 1001-1-103.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to my letter of the 16 July 1949, with which I forwarded you a copy of the Resolution on conditions of life and work of indigenous populations adopted by the Fourth Conference of American States Members of the International Labour Organisation (Montevideo, April-May 1949), and to my letter of 28 September 1949, in which I informed you of the questions which the Governing Body of the International Labour Office had decided to place on the agenda of the first meeting of the Committee on Indigenous Labour.

In accordance with point 3 of the above-mentioned Resolution and in pursuance of the decision of the Governing Body, the Office is assembling first-hand information on the experience acquired by various countries with respect to indigenous workers, with special reference to (1) development of programmes of vocational training; (2) recruitment of indigenous agricultural labourers and mine workers; (3) extension of social insurance and other forms of social assistance; (4) protection of indigenous handicrafts; and (5) safety in industry, and in particular in mining undertakings.

This information will be utilised in the preparation of reports on these questions which the Office will submit to the Committee on Indigenous Labour.

In order that the information on the situation in your country may be accurate and complete, I venture to request that you may be so good as to forward to the Office as soon as possible a memorandum on the economic and social conditions of indigenous workers in your country and the measures which your Government has taken or proposes to take in the near future for the benefit of those workers, with respect to the five points mentioned above, in so far as they are relevant to conditions in your country.

It would be greatly appreciated if you would include in the memorandum information on the following points: - (a) the definition, as given in Federal or Provincial legislation, of the terms "indigenous", "indigenous population", "aboriginal" or "aboriginal population"; (b) approximate number of the indigenous population and the proportion which it represents of the total population of the country; (c) regions or districts in which the indigenous population is chiefly located; (d) approximate occupational distribution of the indigenous population in relation to the chief occupations and regions and the proportion which it represents of the total number of the gainfully employed population of the country; (e) general health of the indigenous population, with an indication of the nature and frequency of the chief illnesses and the medical and health services available in regions inhabited by indigenous groups; and (f) illiteracy among the indigenous population.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

(Signed)

The Minister of Labour,

Department of Labour,

Ottawa, Ontario.

David A. Morse,
Director-General.

MEMORANDUM TO THE SECRETARY

RE: International Labour Office

With regard to your request of December 17 for details of the development of programs of vocational training among indigenous populations, I am pleased to submit the following report:

Indian boys and girls are introduced to vocational activities by an integrated program of studies. Following this first phase, these pupils are gradually introduced to special training. The boys begin their shop work which includes mechanics, woodwork, metal work, leather work, gardening and farming. The girls begin their various activities in domestic science which include cooking, housekeeping, sewing, weaving and gardening.

Any students showing special aptitudes and desires are placed in provincial or privately operated trade schools, often these are schools receiving funds through the Canadian Vocational Training Plan. Those boys and girls who take well to secondary education, are encouraged to complete their academic training and we particularly try to guide them into two professions, namely nursing and teaching.

There is a great need for nurses and teachers on their home reserves and we feel that trained Indian workers can accomplish much in improving home conditions, etc. The Department now employs about 50 Indian teachers in its own schools while
a number of Indians are teaching in provincial schools. Some Indian girls are now employed in the hospitals of the Department of National Health and Welfare as nurses while others have been trained as nurses' aids. Our Branch endeavours to guide Indian pupils into channels for which they are best suited. In many cases these Indian children adjust themselves quite well to this different mode of life and become assimilated into the communities of Canada.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

REDUCTION IN ESTIMATES

When the Deputy Minister and yourself are called before the Treasury Board, I would strongly suggest that you might point out to them the changes which education, particularly in a day school, can bring to an Indian community. The attached newspaper article describes the work of our welfare teacher at Fort McPherson. Three years ago there was no school at Fort McPherson and most of these Indians had never been educated.

I will let Miss Hinds' article describe the changes which have resulted since the little day school has been established for these Indians and their children. I would emphasize that we are trying to do more than merely educating the Indian children. This article should convince the members of the Treasury Board that communities such as this are desperately in need of educational facilities. We have been able to provide them at Fort McPherson - we can only provide them at similar Indian communities elsewhere if funds are available. Mr. Bryce and the other members of the Treasury Board might also read with profit the article which recently appeared in the Toronto Star on "Higher Education at Caughnawaga". There they will read how we are trying to educate the Indians of the southern regions into Canadian citizenship. There our problem is entirely different and it is a matter of providing facilities for higher education for Indians rather than the simple elementary education provided in such places as Fort McPherson.

It might be also pointed out that our schools have for years lagged behind the provincial schools. We are now
devoting every effort to improving our educational standards. That we are succeeding is best illustrated by the article on Caughnawaga - entirely unsolicited and written without prior knowledge of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

CORRESPONDENCE COURSE IN OFFICE MANAGEMENT

GENERAL INFORMATION

1. Origin of this course:

This course came into being as a result of a recommendation made by a sub-committee of the Interdepartmental Committee on Staff Training. It was originally prepared by Officers of the staff of the Comptroller of the Treasury and presented to their employees holding supervisory positions. It has now been revised by the Staff Training Division of the Civil Service Commission to adapt it for presentation to Civil Servants throughout the various government departments across the country.

2. Purpose of the course:

The course has been designed to give personnel employed in a supervisory capacity and personnel who look forward to such responsibilities, some practical instruction in management techniques to help them acquire the knowledge and ability to handle an executive position more efficiently.

3. Structure of the course:

a) Papers - The revised course is made up of twenty papers with a detachable assignment at the end of each. These assignments are of the objective type, namely: True-False, Multiple Choice, Completion or Matching types. A proper time limit for the completion of each assignment is two weeks. In this way every registrant will be able to have completed the necessary papers by the dates set for the Term-Tests. The corrected assignments will not be returned to candidates.

b) Term Tests - A mid-term test will be forwarded to each candidate immediately after Paper X has been completed. This test will be of the Essay type and candidates will have two weeks to handle it. To be eligible to write this test, all of assignments 1 to 10 inclusive must have been received for correction by the Staff Training Division of the Civil Service Commission, Ottawa.

A Final Test will be administered under supervision at specified centres across Canada. This test will be held about two weeks after completion of Paper XX. This test will also be of the Essay type and will be devised to ascertain whether candidates have applied or can apply to specific tasks the principles advocated in the course. To be eligible for this Final Test, all of assignments 11 to 20 as well as Mid Term must have been completed by each candidate.

4. How to Study:

Instructional matter contained in each paper should be mastered fully before attempting the assignment at the end of each paper. Likewise, time spent on studying references listed below would be time well spent. The assignments are done on your own and you should be able to answer questions without back-tracking to the paper itself. This is most important in order to derive maximum benefit from each paper. Where two or more candidates are located in the same area they may benefit by setting up a study group of their own. Suggested topics for such study groups are to be found at the end of each paper.
5. References:

Many interesting and enlightening books have been written on Office Management and Personnel Management. It is recommended that you study at least a few of these to supplement instructional matter contained in the twenty papers. Students are referred to the following which are probably available in departmental or public libraries.

The Office Supervisor - by Henry E. Miles and Mary C.H. Niles published by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Textbook of Office Management - by Leffingwell and Robinson published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Manual of Practical Office Short Cuts - by National Office Management Assoc. published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Office Management - a handbook by Coleman L. Maze published by Ronald Press

Human Factors in Management - by Schuyler Dean Hoslett published by Harper & Brothers

Practical Office Supervision - by Glenn L. Gardiner published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Personnel Management - by Walter Dill Scott published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Psychology for Business and Industry - by Herbert Moore published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Personnel Administration - by Tead and Metcalf published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

6. Ratings:

Ratings will be based on the twenty assignments and the two term tests. An official certificate will be issued to successful candidates by the Staff Training Division of the Civil Service Commission.

PROGRAMME OF STUDIES FOR INDIAN SCHOOLS

The programme of studies herein prescribed shall be followed by the teacher as far as the circumstances of the school permit. Any modifications deemed necessary should be made only with the sanction of the Branch.

Textbooks: While in the case of most subjects, Provincial textbooks are used, it should be noted that the Indian Affairs Branch prescribes certain books which have been found specially suitable for Indian Schools. Particulars regarding these books may be obtained on application to the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Requisitions: When preparing requisitions for school material ask only for those texts authorized above. The Indian Affairs Branch requires you to adhere strictly to this rule. Teachers will please note the instructions on the "Requisition for School Material" form No. 413. Indian agents will supply these forms.

TEACHERS — NOTE THE FOLLOWING SUGGESTIONS

Language: Every effort must be made to induce pupils to speak English and to teach them to understand it. Insist on English even during the supervised play. Failure in this means wasted efforts. (In some schools in Quebec, where French is the classroom language, the word "French" should be substituted in the above instruction where the word "English" appears.)

Reading: Do not hear the children read, teach them to read. Do not use the phonetic method to teach beginners unless it is for children with serious disabilities. Remember reading is a basic skill. Great care should be taken to teach it properly. The primary division members should be grouped and regrouped for reading practice upon the basis of their reading ability and not upon the time spent in school. Pupils should be tested at the beginning of each year and grouped accordingly. Apply remedial measures whenever necessary.

Vocational: Teachers are expected to emphasize the importance of vocational instruction. Dressmaking, crochet work, knitting, hand loom weaving, elementary domestic science, gardening and care of poultry are recommended for girls; and elementary carpentry work, general shop, Indian handicrafts, gardening, and poultry raising for boys. At residential schools the care of livestock, auto mechanics and cultivation of land should be emphasized. Cultivation should conform to the requirements of the home of each pupil. This is especially true of residential schools where pupils come from different reserves.

Physical Education: Lay stress on physical activities that will strengthen the body and improve physique. Special attention should be given to outdoor group games, supervised play and exercises, accompanied by singing, to afford variation and improve physique.

Vocal Music: Simple songs and hymns; the theme of the former to be interesting and patriotic; the tunes bright and cheerful.

Religious Instruction: Spiritual reading, the Ten Commandments, the Lord's Prayer, the Life of Christ, etc.

Character Training: Teachers will strive to develop the spirit of responsibility among the children, giving responsibility in turn, even in small things; gathering books, pencils, etc., for the smaller ones. Give greater responsibility as the child advances in age. Commend success and tactfully reprimand failures. Teachers will stress obedience, courtesy, cleanliness, self-respect, thrift, self-maintenance and patriotism. Cultivate honesty and the spirit of fair play. Teach respect of law, order, authority and public property. Explain the relation of the sexes as to labour, home and public duties.
Health Education: The object of health education is to have the pupils form worthwhile habits. Habits cannot be taught in the traditional way as book-learning; but must be acquired by constant practice. Methods must be worked out by the teacher, who will have the pupils make health posters, join classroom health activities and health games, etc. It is of the utmost importance that Indian pupils be taught to recognize the value of a well-balanced diet. Recommend the use of meat, milk and vegetables. The teacher should stress the relationship of such diet to physical fitness, growth and general health.

Great care must be exercised by the teacher to see that the school-room is kept thoroughly clean. The floor should be swept daily and scrubbed frequently. The air in the schoolroom should be completely changed during recesses and at the noon hour, even in the coldest weather, by the opening of windows and doors. Spitting on the floor, or inside the school building, should not be allowed. Cleanliness in the classroom as well as in the surrounding buildings and school yard is a definite phase of health education. Great stress will be emphasized on these by the teacher.

General: Whenever possible the teachers will employ the activity programme. Teachers must keep in mind that the text-book is but an educational instrument. Pupils must be well grouped according to their ability. Objective achievement tests should be used as frequently as necessary.

School Hours - Day Schools

Reference your 112-6-3 of February 21

The hours of instruction and the arrangements for religious instruction will normally be the same as for schools under provincial control.

During most of the year in Indian schools the hours will be:

Mornings 9.00 - 12.00
Afternoons 1.30 - 4.00

Through November, December, January and February by arrangement between the Superintendent and the teachers the hours may be as follows:

Mornings 9.30 - 12.00
Afternoons Terminating at 3.30

You will note the exceptions that may arise concerning the length of the noon intermission. During the months when the weather is severe and the daylight of shorter duration, as the children usually bring lunch to school, the noon intermission is usually reduced to one hour. In other months a longer noon intermission is usual, and it is expected that there will be supervised play.
It may be, however, that at some schools in your jurisdiction there exist certain conditions which require modification of the length of the noon hour. This period is to be regularly scheduled, and you should arrange, accordingly, with the missionary workers and teachers concerned that the visits of missionaries adhere to a regular schedule i.e., always on the same week day and at the same time, preferably the last half-hour of the afternoon session.

EDUCATION OF CANADA'S INDIANS

(Summary of talk given to the Professional Institute of the Civil Service of Canada on March 13, 1950, by B.F. Henry, Superintendent of Education, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration.)

Due to the time limit of ten minutes the speaker divided his talk into ten questions and answers covering the points most commonly asked about Indian education.

1. Q. How many schools are operated by this Division?

A. There are nearly 450 day school classrooms in operation, mainly one-room schools; there are 70 residential schools, 7 hospital schools and about 20 seasonal schools. There are also a few schools jointly operated with the provinces.

2. Q. How many children are receiving education in these various schools?

A. About 27,500.

3. Q. What kind of schools are operated by your Division?

A. The day schools are for Indians living on settled reserves. The residential schools are for welfare cases and the children of Indians whose parents earn their living by trapping and similar occupations. The hospital schools are for both children and adults in Indian hospitals. The seasonal schools are for Indians particularly in Northern Quebec and Ontario, who come out to trading posts for three or four months in the summer holidays. The joint schools are increasing in number and are operated for both Indians and Whites.

4. Q. Where are these schools situated?

A. They are located in each of the provinces, in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon. The majority of the schools are in Ontario and British Columbia, which two provinces have the largest Indian populations.

5. Q. How are the Day schools operated?

A. By the Department with teachers being classified as Civil Servants mostly on a seasonal basis (ten month year).

6. Q. How are the Residential schools operated?

A. These are conducted for the Department by various religious denominations. A per capita grant is paid for the maintenance and education of each Indian child.

7. Q. How many teachers of various types do you hire?

A. There are over 450 teachers hired with nearly 400 being classified as school teachers and 30 as welfare teachers. These latter teach in the hospital schools and on isolated reserves where their duties are many and varied. We also hire a number of seasonal school teachers and part-time teachers.
5. Q. What curriculum do you follow?

A. With few exceptions we conform to that of the province in which the school is located. Special emphasis is of courses held to health and physical education and the stress in social studies is on Canadian history and geography.

9. Q. What are your urgent educational problems?

A. (a) Supervision and inspection of a widely scattered school system.
(b) The building of schools in isolated districts.
(c) The hiring of good teachers when the schools are isolated and so far from stores, doctors, etc.

10. Q. How many Indians are receiving tuition benefits for higher education?

A. There are nearly 400 Indian children receiving provincial secondary education including vocational training, teacher training and enrolled in university courses. There are also nearly 200 Indian children enrolled in secondary grades in our own schools.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

INDIAN EDUCATION 1939-1949

Many changes have taken place in Indian education during the past 10 years. The following statistics will show the growth of the Indian school population during that time:

| Fiscal Year | Residential Schools Enrolment | Average Attendance | Day Schools Enrolment | Average Attendance | Total (All Schools) Enrolment | Average Attendance | Percentage of Attendance |
|-------------|-------------------------------|--------------------|-----------------------|--------------------|-------------------------------|--------------------|-------------------------|
| 1938-39     | 9,179                         | 8,276              | 9,573                 | 6,232              | 18,752                        | 14,508             | 77.36                   |
| 1948-49     | 9,368                         | 8,345              | 12,511                | 10,320             | 21,983                        | 18,759             | 85.33                   |

You will note that the total includes more than the pupils at the residential and the day schools as there are a number of children attending joint schools.

The greatest growth in school population has taken place during the past 3 years. For example, in the year ending March 1949, the enrolment at day schools had increased by 1,529 pupils.

In addition to the 21,983 pupils shown above, there were 925 Indian children in elementary grades and 377 in secondary grades in provincial schools. This meant a total of 23,285 Indian pupils enrolled in educational classes. It is difficult to accurately estimate the number of school age children until the next census is completed. The 1944 census showed 28,429 children between the ages
of 7 and 16. It is therefore safe to estimate that there are now about 31,000 of school age. This means that there are over 7,000 children for whom no educational facilities are yet provided.

Percentage of Attendance

During the past few years there has been a steady increase in the percentage attendance. This is particularly noticeable in Indian day schools where formerly the pupils attended irregularly. The day school attendance, however, is now improving steadily as a result of family allowance payments, the better calibre of teachers employed, the improvement in classroom techniques and equipment, and finally the awakening interest of Indian parents in the education of their children. We intend to stimulate this interest by the formation of Parent-Teacher groups, adult education classes, and other community movements.

Education in Association with Other Children

In accordance with the recommendations of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, we have been accomplishing major changes in having more Indian children admitted to white schools. In British Columbia alone the number has increased from about 200 in September 1948 to nearly 700 in September 1949. We will continue to work towards the admission of more Indian children to provincial schools in accordance with the recommendation of the Committee.

Erection of New Schools

The number of new schools erected can best be illustrated by the fact that the Department hired 285 day school teachers in 1948 and is now employing nearly 450. This growth represents the opening of new schools and also additions to existing facilities.

At residential schools we have erected several classroom blocks and one dormitory block. One new residential school is presently under construction and the tender has been let for the erection of another. Both of these are in northern Canada.
Improvement in the calibre of teachers

Unless good teachers are appointed to fill the new classrooms being provided, educational progress among the Indians will not continue to improve. Therefore, the department has been constantly weeding out unqualified and inefficient teachers and replacing them with certificated teachers as conditions permit.

In spite of the great teacher shortage which presently exists, we have been able to accomplish a great deal during the past 3 years. A review of the situation can best be presented graphically as follows:

| Day School Teacher Percentages | January 1948 | January 1950 |
|-------------------------------|--------------|--------------|
| Grade 1 (Third Class or no certificate) | 34 % | 22 % |
| Grade 2 (Second Class Certificate) | 30 % | 25 % |
| Grade 3 (First Class Certificate) | 27 % | 39 % |
| Grade 4, Principals and Welfare Teachers | 9 % | 14 % |

To summarize the above statistics, you will note that we have reduced the number of non-qualified teachers from one third of our staff to nearly one fifth of our staff in a space of 3 years. During the same time we have increased the number of teachers with First Class Certificates from 27% to 39%.

Secondary Education

There has been a steady increase in the number of Indian children who are enrolled in the secondary grades. In the academic year ending June 1949 there were 277 children in high school grades in provincial schools and 284 in our own schools.

Director.
Ottawa, March 31, 1950.

Memorandum:

COLONEL ACLAND

Education of Indians

Please find attached a statement of statistics which should do a great deal to correct the misstatements made by Brigadier Martin.

The figures show that we have reduced now to about 6 or 7000, the number of children for whom educational facilities are provided. The number of day school classrooms has risen from 285 to nearly 450 within the last three years.

We can not provide statistics for the qualifications of teachers in residential schools as these are controlled by the denominations concerned. In the day schools, however, we can definitely report on the improved qualifications of our teachers.

In 1948 we hired 352 day school teachers of whom 120 (or 34%) had only teaching permits, licenses or no certificate. We had 97 teachers (or 28%) with First Class Certificates and 120 (or 34%) with Second Class Certificates.

In January 1950 we were hiring 432 teachers of whom 95 (or 22%) were Grade 1 teachers, 172 (or 40%) were Grade 3 teachers and 109 (or 26%) were Grade 2 teachers.

A review of this situation can be presented graphically hereunder:

| Teachers | January 1948 | January 1950 |
|----------|-------------|--------------|
| Grade 1  | 34%         | 22%          |
| Grade 2  | 32%         | 26%          |
Teachers

January 1948 | January 1950
---|---
Grade 3 | 28% | 40%
Grade 1, Principals and Welfare teachers | 6% | 12%

In other words, we have reduced the number of non-qualified teachers from 1/3 of our staff to 1/5 in a space of two years. We have increased the number of teachers with First Class Certificates from 28% to 40%.

SECONDARY EDUCATION

We have noted Brigadier Martin's statement concerning part-time education. This did apply to our schools three years ago but we have greatly reduced the number of schools in which the children are not fully occupied in classroom work. By the introduction of labor-saving devices such as potatoe peelers, washing machines etc. and by the large increase in the per capita grants we have attempted to make the school management less dependent on the use of children for work in the schools.

CONCLUSION

As I was dictating the above information, there was placed on my desk a letter from the Canadian Education Association outlining the shortage of teachers in schools across Canada. Several provinces report schools closed because of the lack of teachers and the number opened but without qualified teachers is indeed a revelation. There are 750 such schools in Nova Scotia, 703 in Saskatchewan, 609 in New Brunswick, 603 in Manitoba and even 300 in Ontario. I, therefore, feel that our day schools have little to be criticized in this regard.

Memorandum:

COLONEL ACLAND

Education of Indians

Please find attached a statement of statistics which should do a great deal to correct the misstatements made by Brigadier Martin.

The figures show that we have reduced now to about 6 or 7000, the number of children for whom educational facilities are provided. The number of day school classrooms has risen from 285 to nearly 450 within the last three years.

We can not provide statistics for the qualifications of teachers in residential schools as these are controlled by the denominations concerned. In the day schools, however, we can definitely report on the improved qualifications of our teachers.

In 1948 we hired 352 day school teachers of whom 170 (or 34%) had only teaching permits, licenses or no certificate. We had 97 teachers (or 28%) with First Class Certificates and 120 (or 32%) with Second Class Certificates.

In January 1950 we were hiring 432 teachers of whom 95 (or 22%) were Grade 1 teachers, 172 (or 40%) were Grade 3 teachers and 109 (or 26%) were Grade 2 teachers.

A review of this situation can be presented graphically hereunder:

| Teachers | January 1948 | January 1950 |
|----------|-------------|-------------|
| Grade 1  | 34%         | 22%         |
| Grade 2  | 32%         | 26%         |
Teachers

January 1948 | January 1950
--- | ---
Grade 3 | 28% | 40%
Grade 7, Principals and Welfare teachers | 6% | 12%

In other words, we have reduced the number of non-qualified teachers from 1/3 of our staff to 1/5 in a space of two years. We have increased the number of teachers with First Class Certificates from 28% to 40%.

SECONDARY EDUCATION

We have noted Brigadier Martin's statement concerning part-time education. This did apply to our schools three years ago but we have greatly reduced the number of schools in which the children are not fully occupied in classroom work by the introduction of labor-saving devices such as potato peelers, washing machines etc. and by the large increase in the per capita grants we have attempted to make the school management less dependent on the use of children for work in the schools.

CONCLUSION

As I was dictating the above information, there was placed on my desk a letter from the Canadian Education Association outlining the shortage of teachers in schools across Canada. Several provinces report schools closed because of the lack of teachers and the number opened but without qualified teachers is indeed a revelation. There are 750 such schools in Nova Scotia, 703 in Saskatchewan, 609 in New Brunswick, 603 in Manitoba and even 300 in Ontario. I, therefore, feel that our day schools have little to be criticized in this regard.

Bernard F. Neary,
Aupt. of Indian Education.

Reference your 112-6-3 of February 21

The hours of instruction and the arrangements for religious instruction will normally be the same as for schools under provincial control.

During most of the year in Indian schools the hours will be:

Mornings 9.00 - 12.00

Through November, December, January and February by arrangement between the Superintendent and the teachers the hours may be as follows:

Mornings 9.30 - 12.00
Afternoons Terminating at 3.30

You will note the exceptions that may arise concerning the length of the noon intermission. During the months when the weather is severe and the daylight of shorter duration, as the children usually bring lunch to school, the noon intermission is usually reduced to one hour. In other months a longer noon intermission is usual, and it is expected that there will be supervised play.
It may be, however, that at some schools in your jurisdiction there exist certain conditions which require modification of the length of the noon hour. You should discuss these with the teacher and decide upon the schedule which seems to suit the particular situation best, so that, allowing for a recess of 15 minutes each morning and each afternoon, the hours of instruction may be:

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR:

Regional Inspectors of Indian Schools

Since our conversation of yesterday evening, I have just received a letter from Mr. Ostrander, our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan.

As a result of a letter sent to him by me, Mr. Ostrander has had each of his Superintendents submit a report on the various Day School teachers in their agencies. On the basis of these reports he is recommending the dismissal of eight teachers. I can best present his viewpoint by quoting from his letter as follows:

"In each case the Indian Superintendent has given his frank opinion of the teacher, and in no case do I feel inclined to disagree with him. It is my opinion that the following teachers should be replaced at the beginning of the next term:

Absalom Halkett, Shoal Lake Indian Day School,
Mr. John L. Lowe, Red Earth Indian Day School,
Mrs. W.F. Donahy, Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School,
Mrs. M. Burbridge, James Smith North Indian Day School,
Mr. James A. Gardner, Kinistino Indian Day School,
Mr. F.C. Monaghan, Poorman's Indian Day School,
Mr. Robert Hick, Day Star Indian Day School,
Mr. G.R.J. Chouinard, Meadow Lake Indian Day School.

Consideration might also be given to replacing Mr. W.F. Cavanaugh, at the St. Francis Indian Day School. Mr. Cavanaugh is doing fairly good work, but is quite aged, and is doing nothing but strictly classroom work."
I believe that the time has been reached when we should discontinue employing aged teachers at Indian day schools. It is beginning to appear to me that Saskatchewan teachers are now realizing that salaries at Indian day schools are fairly good, and the number of applications from well qualified teachers is gradually increasing. However, there is also another increase which is not so promising, and that is the increase in the number of teachers who, having retired from Saskatchewan schools, on pension, try to get into our service. If they are too old to teach white schools they are certainly too old to teach Indian schools. It is time for us to start weeding out our presently employed aged teachers and to refuse to accept any more of them. In this connection I refer particularly to such cases as the case of Mrs. B.C. Eugenie Thomas, referred to in Department Letter of March 17th, 1956, File 1-1-12 (S), who is applying for a teaching position, and such teachers as Miss Moore, Mrs. Stewart, Mr. Domachy, Mrs. Burbridge, Mr. Cavanaugh, Mr. Redner, Mr. Monaghan, and Mr. Pick, to mention some of them. We need to cheer them up, their careers in front of them, rather than behind them. This fact is especially emphasized at this time because of the fact that our teachers, if young and well qualified, can become permanent Civil Servants, making a career of their work, and having a substantial superannuation at the end. There is also the other important factor which must be considered, and that is the fact that most of these teachers who have retired from Provincial schools have done so because they were too old to want to, or be able to, comply with new and improved teaching methods. They come to our service hoping that we are so old fashioned that we won't ask them to change their methods. If there is any one thing needed more than any other thing in our Indian education, it is a willingness to continually change for the better.
It is very difficult for elderly people to change, at least they do not, whether we hope they will, or not.

When you are discussing this matter with the Deputy Minister I feel that Mr. Ostrander's views should be presented to him.

It is very difficult for the Department to decide in each of these eight cases as some of the teachers may be doing good work in the classroom but not impressing the Indian Superintendents in other ways. Naturally, our Indian Superintendents are not professional educators and are not qualified to report upon the teaching efficiency of these various teachers. This places me in a difficult predicament in that we have only non-committal Provincial School Inspectors' reports on most of these teachers. I need a frank report from one of my own School Inspectors so that a proper decision can be reached on the proposed replacement of such of these eight teachers.

We are now employing 478 teachers in this Division, and with no adequate supervision system, it is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain the efficiency of our educational system. The need for these Regional Inspectors is so apparent that even the Civil Service Commission Investigator has recommended the establishment of such positions.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
April 11, 1950.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

ONTARIO EDUCATIONAL ASSOCIATION MEETING -
APRIL 10, 11 AND 12.

As requested by our previous Deputy Minister, I am pleased to submit the following report on my attendance at the above meeting:

1. Ontario School Inspectors' Association

This meeting took place on Monday April 10 and as usual, the officials from this Branch were made welcome to these meetings which are restricted otherwise to Ontario school inspectors. The main discussions were on the new curriculum for grades 7, 8 and 9. Reports were received from the various committees which had been established for each subject of the course of study. There was heated discussion from the floor concerning the revised curriculum and we were able to get valuable advanced information concerning the changes in the Ontario course of study.

At the annual luncheon of the Ontario School Inspectors' Association we were very pleased with the reception given to the choir from the Six Nations No. 2 Indian Day School. There were only 8 girls in this group but they performed most admirably under the direction of their teacher, Miss Jamieson. We received many personal compliments from the school inspectors after the luncheon concerning the fine singing of these Indian girls.
2. Education Association Lectures

The three outstanding lectures were given by Dr. A. S. Artley of the University of Missouri, Sir Alfred Zimmern of Oxford University and the Honourable Dana Porter, Minister of Education for Ontario.

Dr. Artley is a specialist in the teaching of the language arts and his two lectures on "Helping Children Become Independent in Word Attack" and "Vocabulary Development" were most applicable to our Indian schools. I was able to obtain valuable notes and will later write an article for our Indian School Bulletin on the information thus received.

Sir Alfred Zimmern's lecture was on "Education for Life in the Atomic Age". His address was given before several thousand people and was an outstanding example of the ability of a trained lecturer to hold the attention of even a large audience. His philosophy of education is exemplary for all teachers in a democracy and his lecture left a vivid impression of the importance of the work of the teacher.

The Honourable Mr. Porter's address was concerned with the new curriculum for Ontario.

I also attended other lectures on social studies in the primary grades and on rhythmical activities in the junior grades.

3. Meetings with Officials of the Ontario Department of Education.

As every school inspector is required to attend this meeting, I was naturally able to solve many problems with regard to our many Indian day schools in this province. Their co-operation is always most keenly appreciated and much correspondence can be avoided by this annual meeting.

I attended a meeting with Dr. Brown, the Registrar of Teachers, and Mr. Elborn, the Superintendent of Professional Training. At the present time, teachers in Ontario can obtain teaching certificates after two years of teaching, two good
inspector's reports and two professional summer schools. However, such teachers are required to sign a statement certifying that they will teach for at least one year in a provincial school after obtaining such a certificate.

I was able to gain a valuable concession from this regulation and in future our Indian school teachers will be able to obtain certificates without signing such a declaration. As I have at least five teachers in this predicament now, I feel that this effort was indeed worth while.

I also met Mr. Cannon, the Superintendent of Elementary Education, concerning joint schools in the northern part of the province, and Mr. J. G. Walsh, concerning future plans for joint schools.

4. Meetings with Officials of Church Denominations

Dear Mr. Neary,

I have just discovered that you are a friend of Dr. Gaitshell's (I taught Indian craft on his summer course for teachers two years ago) so I phoned him today to enquire whether you ever had headquarters in Toronto. He said not but that you did come to Toronto occasionally. I suggested I should write and ask whether you might care to see me. I would perhaps very kindly let me know when you would be in Toronto.

I came to Canada ten years ago to study Indians. I married a treaty Indian and am a member of Lake Nipissing Reserve. I put a brief in the Project Manual Committee re Indian craft.

At present I am collecting information for a Who's who of talented Indians which I hope to reproduce in mimeograph.
comes later - under the heading of each province will be lists of Indians talented in crafts, painting, writers, leadership, woodcraft, singers etc. - a list Indian organizations or white people actively interested in Indians.

This would provide some communication by which both Indians & whites could hear of talented Indians & contact them.

I am doing this as much as possible directly through Indians, many of whom are quite active in the field. I am also collecting paintings by Indians, portraits if they can be had from me for exhibition - e.g., Gaitskill would like to show them at his summer course.

I am greatly interested in Indian affairs in general, a topic of the subject which I would greatly appreciate an opportunity of discussing with you. Various commercial Indians have suggested our I contact you - the whole subject is one
I have already had a meeting with Mr. Asher, but he does not.

Yours sincerely,

Gisela Commanda

The increase in the percentage of attendance reflects the effect of better teachers, schools and equipment and the increasing realization of the Indians of the need for education.

The building of new day schools has continued and the effect of this program can be seen in the increase in day school enrolment of over 3,000 pupils within the last two years. We are reducing the number of children for whom educational facilities are not provided and are building new schools in the northern sections of the provinces and in the Northwest Territories. Previously, many of these Indian children had no schools whatsoever.

Table 2 shows an increase of nearly 200 children enrolled in provincial schools. New agreements are being negotiated now to further increase the number of Indian children attending such schools.

In table 3 it will be noted that the number of Indian children receiving secondary education continues to increase at a satisfactory rate. We now have 465 children attending secondary grades in provincial and
private schools. In our own schools (as shown in table 4) we have a total of 369 children. This raises the total of Indians attending secondary schools and universities to 834 as compared with 661 pupils last year.

Teachers at Indian Day Schools

A steady improvement is shown in the qualifications and experience of teachers employed in our Indian day schools. The number of non-qualified or Grade One teachers decreased by 7 and the number of teachers holding First Class Certificates increased by 39. The raising of the standard of teaching has resulted in improved attendance and a reduction in "drop-outs". This is shown in table 4.

Vocational Education

The Supervisor of Vocational Education has reported that the Proficiency Badge system has proven quite successful. A total of 7,648 badges have now been distributed to Indian pupils for proficiency in various basic operations.

In day schools it is often difficult to encourage a programme of manual training because so many of our schools have but one teacher. In order to help these teachers and also other manual training teachers, two booklets have been prepared entitled "First Year Woodwork" and "Second Year Woodwork". A third book is in course of preparation.

In residential schools we are gradually securing the services of more and better qualified instructors. We are also beginning a programme of erecting small manual training shops at the larger schools.

Physical Education and Recreation

A new supervisor has been recently appointed and is now conducting surveys at various reserves and schools. We have purchased considerable supplies of sports equipment and have encouraged athletic activities of various kinds. Our school teams have been particularly successful in hockey and several bantam, midget and juvenile championships have been won.

A programme of adult education has been started and we intend to encourage further courses, particularly at day schools. Some home and school associations have been started and this new official will encourage the formation of others. It is felt that Indian parents must be encouraged to take an active interest in the education of their children.

Memorandum:

THE DIRECTOR.

Report on School Openings, Southern Ontario.

1. Mohawk Institute:

I arrived in Brantford at noon Sunday May 14 and there met Mr. Morris and Colonel Randle. We visited a new brick four-room school being constructed at Princeton, near Brantford. This is the type of building which Colonel Randle wishes for an intermediate consolidated school at Ohweken. I will submit a separate recommendation on this proposal.

We found things improved at the Mohawk Institute with Mrs. Zimmerman in a better state of health. I would recommend that we proceed with the principal's residence as soon as possible. We are wasting valuable space in the main building and are further jeopardizing her mental health by leaving things as they are.

The work being done on the upper dormitories is proceeding satisfactorily. The workmanship is good and I am particularly impressed with the use of Masonite panels instead of plaster. I feel that we could use this on all the lower walls in dormitories hallways, etc., in future.

We are including an amount for further work on this building in our Supplementary Estimates as we can now proceed with the many repairs required to the walls in the various rooms.
2. Diocese of Huron

Unfortunately, I was not able to see the Bishop of Huron as their Synod was in session. However, I did meet the Diocesan Commissioner and discussed various matters with him. We naturally discussed Mr. and Mrs. Zimmerman.

3. Bank Settlement School

This opening was held at 10:30 a.m. on May 15th. There was a good crowd of Indians in attendance. The Provincial School Inspector, Mr. Oakes, Mr. Joblin and Mr. Morris all spoke well. EDUCATION OF THE INDIANS.

From the time of the Recollect Fathers in 1616 until Confederation formal education of the Indians was limited almost entirely to missionary activities of the churches. In lower Canada there were day schools in Lorette, St. Regis and Pierreville and residential schools in Chateauguay, Christieville and St. Sulphice seminary where general education and some instruction in farming were offered. In Upper Canada some 40 schools were established mostly by the Wesleyan Methodist and Roman Catholic churches. In Western Canada the churches took the initiative but as in the East received some financial support from the Government and associations of Indian band councils.

In 1868 Indian Affairs were placed under the direction of the newly-created Department of the Secretary of State and transferred five years later to the Department of the Interior. In 1894 the Indian Act was amended to provide for compulsory attendance and the establishment of industrial boarding schools which are conducted under the auspices of the churches. In 1948, 45 such schools were conducted by the Roman Catholic Church, 18 by the Church of England, 8 under the United Church and 2 under the Presbyterian. The day schools were provided by the government.

The Indian schools follow the curricula of the province in which they are located with emphasis on languages, reading, domestic science, manual training and agriculture.

In 1947-48 there were a total of 365 Indian schools in operation, including 73 residential schools with an enrolment of 8966, and 285 day schools with an enrolment of 10,982 Indian pupils and 7 combined public and Indian schools with 133 Indian pupils enrolled. The total enrolment of Indian pupils was 76,101 in 1947-48, the average attendance about 80.34 p.c. of the enrolment. High school work was taught in some of both the day and residential schools. The sum of $3,614,804.04 was expended on Indian education during the year.

A large number of Indian pupils are now attending provincial schools and a survey is now being made to determine the actual statistics. In many cases the fees are paid by the Indian parents and the Department has previously had no record of such attendance.

Indian Schools:

The Governor in Council has placed Indian schools under the duties of the Department of Mines and Resources, (Indian Affairs Branch).

The Crown may establish day schools on any Indian reserve and provide Industrial or boarding schools for the children of any reserve or other designated territory.

The Crown may declare as an industrial or boarding school any school or institution whose managing authorities have entered into a written agreement with the Minister to admit Indian children and provide them with board, lodging and instruction.

The Minister is empowered to prescribe standards for buildings, equipment, teaching, discipline and inspection of the schools and may provide for the transportation of Indian children to and from the boarding or industrial schools and for the annual vacations.
The Chief and Council of any band have the right to inspect any school in which the band has children, at such reasonable times as are agreed to by the Indian agent and principal.

Every Indian child between the full ages of seven and sixteen years, who is physically able to, shall attend such day, industrial or boarding school as designated by the Minister for the full period the school is conducted. Whenever it appears that an Indian child should be retained in school for a longer period, the Minister may direct that such child remain in school up to but not beyond the full age of 18.

No Protestant child shall be assigned to a school under Roman Catholic auspices and no Roman Catholic shall be assigned to a school under Protestant auspices.

The Minister may appoint any officer or person as truant officer, vest him with the powers of a peace officer and the privilege of entering any place where he has reason to believe there are Indian children of school age, or when requested by a teacher, chief or Indian agent. He shall warn the truants and their parents or guardians in writing; after three days notice such parent or guardian on complaint of the truant officer is liable to a fine of $25 and costs or ten days or both and such child may be arrested and conveyed to school.

Absence is excusable when such child is unable to attend because of sickness or other unavoidable cause; has passed the entrance examination; has been temporarily excused by the Indian agent or teacher to assist in husbandry or necessary household duties.

The Governor in Council may take the land of any Indian for school purposes upon payment of such compensation as is agreed upon or determined by the Minister.

Every member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and any constable on an Indian reserve shall be a truant officer.

The Chief or Chiefs of any band in council may, subject to confirmation by the Governor in Council decide the religious denomination to which the teacher of the school in the reserve shall belong. If the majority of the band belong to any one religious denomination the teacher shall belong to the same. With approval a Roman Catholic or Protestant minority may have a separate school established.

Such council may also make rules and regulations as to the construction and repair of school houses, council houses and other Indian public buildings and the attendance at school of children between the ages of 6 and 15. In practice this is seldom done.

Tuition grants are provided to enable Indian children to receive higher education. A special tuition grant application form is completed and signed by the teacher and Indian superintendent. On this form is indicated the amount to be provided by the parents and the sum required from the department. As a result of this aid Indian pupils and adults are now enrolled in practically every type of educational institution from universities to trade schools. Officials are stressing the necessity of vocational guidance and are pointing out the need for more Indians in two professions particularly; teaching and nursing. There are now some forty qualified Indian teachers and an increasing number enrol in Normal Schools each year. These teachers are proving successful and a few are now teaching in provincial schools.
Free textbooks and school supplies are provided for Indian pupils and teachers requisition for such supplies annually.

The position of Indian Welfare Teacher was created to assist in improving living conditions for the Indians on isolated reserves. It will give recognition to those teachers who form Homemakers' Clubs, Institutes, etc.; sponsor community recreation of all kinds; encourage home gardening and home improvement clubs, endeavour to improve living conditions, encourage adult education and co-operate with Indian agents, doctors, and nurses in administration. Such teachers will be allowed the usual Civil Service holidays consisting of eighteen days a year and statutory holidays. Each three years they may be granted seven weeks to attend summer school.

Academic Year.

The school term consists of 195 days. Holidays include Saturday, Labour Day, Thanksgiving, Remembrance Day, Victoria Day and the King's Birthday, Christmas vacation and Easter vacation of about 10 days each, and the longer summer vacation from the end of June to the day after Labour Day. Roman Catholic Indian Day schools are allowed three Holy Days extra. The summer holidays may be changed to some other time on the recommendation of the local Indian agent and with approval of the Department. Schools may be closed for epidemics, local fairs or Teachers' Conventions.

Types of Indian Schools.

As indicated previously there are two main types of schools, namely day and residential. The latter type of school is necessary because of the nomadic nature of certain Indian tribes and because of the type of occupation followed by them such as trapping, fishing, etc.

In addition, there are two other categories namely seasonal and hospital schools. As the name implies the seasonal schools are operated for three of four months in the year only, usually in the summer. They are provided for Indians whose main occupation is trapping and who live in the bush except for a few months in the summer when they come out to the trading posts. There are now twenty-five such schools mainly in Quebec, Ontario and Manitoba. The teachers are usually male university students who are planning on teaching or medical careers.

With the entire approval and cooperation of the doctors in charge, patients in seven Indian hospitals in Western Canada now "go to school". Qualified school teachers are attached to the staffs of Indian hospitals at Millar Bay, Coqualeetza and Nanaimo in British Columbia; Edmonton, Alberta and Brandon, Dynevor and Clearwater Lake, Manitoba. Later others will be placed at North Battleford and Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan.

Teachers in Indian Schools.

As previously indicated, the Indian residential schools are operated by denominational authorities for the Department, therefore all the teachers in them are appointed and paid by these churches. The Department can recommend the dismissal of any such teacher whose work is found to be unsatisfactory.

In the Indian day schools the teachers are appointed by the Department. Greatly concerned by the difficulty in obtaining qualified and experienced teachers, it has recently made a distinct effort to attract a better calibre of teacher. In September 1947, a salary schedule was introduced, similar
to those in effect in various provincial departments of education.

Shortly after, Indian day school teachers were made eligible to contribute to the Civil Service Superannuation Fund as permanent civil servants when qualified. As a result there was, in one year (1948) an increase of 20% in the number of qualified teachers and a corresponding decrease in the non-qualified teachers.

SALARY SCHEDULE FOR INDIAN DAY SCHOOL TEACHERS.

A salary schedule for Indian day school teachers was approved by the Treasury Board in 1947. Salaries are based on qualifications and experience and provision is made for the Indian school teacher who teaches 10 months a year and the Indian Welfare teacher who conducts school for 10 months but remains on the reservation for 12 months with 18 days holidays as in the Civil Service. The welfare teachers are posted on isolated Indian reserves located at some distance from the nearest Indian Agent and in Indian hospital schools.

The salary ranges are as follows:

| Teacher Indian School Grade | $1020-1320 | Grade I | $1260-1860 |
|-----------------------------|------------|--------|------------|
| " II                        | $1440-1920 | " II   | $1920-2400 |
| " III                       | $1500-2200 | " III  | $2280-3000 |
| " IV                        | $1800-2520 | " IV   | $2340-3060 |

The grades should not be confused with the practice in many provinces of classing teachers with the minimum qualifications, possibly Grade X plus normal as third class while first class refers to teachers with senior matriculation and normal training.

Grade I teachers are those holding third class certificates and teaching permits. They are hired during the present teacher shortage and departmental policy is to replace them with Grade 2 and Grade 3 teachers when such teachers are available.

To qualify for a Grade II under this classification teachers must have junior matriculation or its equivalent and have completed a teachers' training course (Second Class Certificate). Grade III teachers must have high school matriculation or its equivalent and normal school training (First Class Certificate) or be classed as a specialist with a First Class Certificate in Industrial arts, Household Science, Agriculture etc.

For a Grade IV certificate teachers must hold a High School Teachers' Certificate or its equivalent or a specialist high school certificate in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture etc., and spend 50% or more of their teaching time in high school subjects.

The above categories salaries begin at the lowest level with some ten increments for experience but credit is also given for improved academic standing. Increments in all cases are $60 each.

Salaries for Indian Welfare teachers are for a twelve month year and are as indicated above. The regulations for these teachers are as for the above groups. Provision is made for them to improve their standing through correspondence courses and a leave of 7 weeks each 3 years is allowed during which they will take courses in social welfare, child psychology or related topics in a Canadian or American University or school recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.
Principals are classed as Grade I, Grade II, supervising Grade III and supervising Grade IV with salary ranges of $1620-2340, $1740-2460, $1980-2700, $2100-2820. Grades I, 2 and 3 must have a first class teaching certificate. Grades 1 and 2 must have at least 3 years of successful teaching experience. Grade 3, 6 years or more.

A Grade I principal must supervise 3 or 4 classrooms. A Grade II, five or more classrooms. A Grade III (Supervising Principal) up to 11 classrooms and a Grade IV (Supervising Principal) 12 or more. The Grade IV principal must have a high school teachers' certificate and 8 years experience.

These last two categories of principal are often responsible for the supervision of all the day schools on a reserve.

Five years experience may be allowed for teaching experience in public schools outside the Indian Affairs branch.

English speaking teachers shall be employed in English-speaking schools and French-speaking in French-speaking schools.

Superannuation:

Teachers who receive permanent appointment become permanent civil servants and automatically contribute under the Civil Service Superannuation Act. Such teachers are required to take a physical examination and may elect to make contributions for past service, provincial pensionable service and war service. Day school teachers with valid certificates and two years successful teaching in the Indian schools can make application to become contributors under the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

Leading agencies in Canada, the United States and England are becoming extremely film conscious. They realize that only film can guarantee ten to thirty uninterrupted minutes of the public's concentrated time. They realize that this can be delivered for only a few cents per person through the vast network of 100 Canadian film libraries and councils. And they realize that films can dramatize a product, a plant or a plan and thus move people to action.

Many agencies now employ their own film experts and departments as liaison between their client and the producer. Advertising Age, March 13, 1950

All TV Shows on Film Soon,
Says Y&R's Telford

NEW YORK—Within a year nearly all TV shows will be on film.

This is the prediction of Frank Telford, producer-director of "Silver Theater" (CBS), who is demonstrating that a filmed telecast need not be more expensive than a live one.

Young & Rubicam recently sent Mr. Telford to Hollywood to work with the Jerry Fairbanks Studio on the filming of a new 30-minute International Silver dramatic telecast. Filming the show, which had been carried live since its inception last fall, was viewed as a strictly experimental move.

International Silver and Y&R were so pleased with the experiment that the show will be filmed in Hollywood for the remaining 13 weeks of the current season. The rent-production cost for the telecast will remain $7,500 weekly.

Careful planning, which has made possible efficient use of everybody's time, has enabled the show to switch from live to filmed without increased production expenses, Mr. Telford explained.

"We know what we want before we start shooting. And we use the television technique of shooting with three cameras simultaneously," he said. "Films of the past have been very expensive because they were shot for 40 shots and then decided what they wanted. We decide what we want, then take one shot."

Mr. Telford's reasons for seeing films especially made for TV as an important factor in the future of video go much further than the cost aspect, however.

"Certainly, things that can't be done on live television become routine. It's a superior method which enables you to eliminate the mistakes that would go on the air in a live show. We can concentrate on one segment at a time. In two days of rehearsal are required compared with the seven days we spent rehearsing the show for radio," he said.

"There is another very important consideration. When you film a show you own it. It's your property; you can take it out of a drawer later and repeat it when TV's circulation has changed sufficiently. This, of course, makes such a show an even better investment for a sponsor."

The Education and Training Group of the Professional Institute of the Civil Service of Canada met in the Board Room of the Civil Service Commission, Jackson Building, on Monday afternoon, May 16, 1950, with 21 members in attendance.

Some discussion took place concerning the relationship between the Education and Training Group and the Education Committee of the Professional Institute. It was agreed that each group could be of assistance to the other. Dr. T. Shore, Chairman of the Education Committee, was in attendance.

The Group was addressed by Dr. O.E. Ault, of the Civil Service Commission, who outlined the purpose for the Group's existence. He stressed the following purposes:

1. To protect the interests of Group members concerning such matters as classification, pay, hours of work, superannuation, etc.
2. To maintain a sort of solidarity by working with those engaged in similar work.
3. To help to give professional status to the Group the members represent.
4. To maintain a high standard of entrance into the Group.
5. To maintain a high standard of craftsmanship.
6. To advance new methods and research.
7. To maintain professional relationships.
8. To maintain high ethical standards.

Those associated with Education in the federal service play largely the role of fund dispensers and that of teaching wards of the Federal Government. Those associated with the Training role perform a service in their own right. However, all must help to develop and further a rational educational consciousness. Wider educational activities are likely to develop in the near future which will result in the expansion of the Group. The problems of the moment are those connected with international relations and culture and the training of people for public administration.

The Group can render a worthy service by supporting educational programmes and ventures put forth and by advancing the idea that learning does not stop with leaving school.

Dr. Ault advanced a number of topics for research by way of presenting specific things that the Group might undertake thereby helping to make its existence worthwhile. These topics included:
(1) an educational profile of the Civil Service in its various classifications and grades, (2) the need for scholarships for Civil Servants (3) how much money is being spent on Education from the Federal Treasury and how is it being spent? (4) recommendations to the Civil Service Commission on such matters as classifications, educational qualifications, etc.

The Group should decide what should be given priority. Dr. Ault suggested that a Research Committee might be set up within the Group.

Your Group Executive recommends as the first topic for research the following:

"What is being done by the Canadian Government in (a) Education and (b) Training, and what is the cost of such services?"

The result of the quinquennial census of Indians completed during the fiscal year 1949-50 reveals clearly the vigor of this, the oldest, Canadian racial group and its proven ability to perpetuate itself.

Notwithstanding enfranchisements, whereby the Indian population is diminished by the provisions of the Act, there were 10,825 more Indians reported than in 1944. In that year there was a 7,308 increase over those reported in the previous census year of 1939.

It is obvious, therefore, that the Indian population, receiving increasing welfare benefits such as Family and Old Age Allowances, better housing, medical care and schooling, will continue to increase at a proportionate rate, thereby increasing administrative responsibilities year by year in no small measure.

The trend towards higher education was again apparent and increased attendance in the secondary school grades and at universities is a reflection of the progress being made in the whole field of education. In the 1948-49 school year there were six hundred and sixty-one Indian pupils attending classes above Grade VIII; this represented a considerable increase over the previous year. However, during 1949-50 eight hundred and thirty-four students attended classes above Grade VIII. This splendid record indicates not only more class-rooms and improved teaching methods but also the fact that Indian youth is taking greater interest in his own education.

The enrolment at residential schools decreased slightly over the previous year but there was an increase in the day school enrolment of 1,582. It is of interest to note that since 1947 there has been a total increase in day school enrolment of 3,111 pupils.
During 1949-50 there were 1,180 Indian children enrolled in the elementary grades of provincial and private schools and 465 in such secondary schools. When these pupils are added to the total of those attending Indian schools it reveals that during the year 25,054 Indians attended educational classes.

The construction of new day schools continued during the year and the effect of this program can be seen in the increased day school enrolment which has risen by more than 3,000 in two years. This also materially reduced the number of Indian children for whom previously no education facilities were provided. During the year particular attention was given to the construction of schools in the northern sections of the Provinces and in the Northwest Territories.

NON-TREATY CHIPPEWA INDIANS

This is the concluding instalment of an article by Mr. Stelton which was started in our June issue. It should be noted that the material was written before this group of Chippe-

was signed a treaty with the federal government.

The Chippewa were visited by Peter Panyman when he travelled the North Saskatchewan river in 1798 and they traded with the Hudson's Bay Company at Rocky Mountain House when David Thompson arrived in 1798. They continued to trade with the Hudson's Bay Company at Rocky Mountain House as long as there was a trading post kept by that Company on the north bank of the North Saskatchewan river on section 26, township 47 range 27, west of fifth and in full view of the confluence of the Clearwater and North Saskatchewan rivers. They still bring their furs to sell to the Hudson's Bay representative (Henry Selkirk) in Rocky Mountain House.

Families who are living in a state of abject poverty and who are in dire need of such help as suitable shelter, accommodation, food and clothing ought to be suitably cared for, whether they are Indians or otherwise. If they were white people, the public would openly demand that the provisions be made for them and I venture to say that the Mounted Police Force in Alberta would see to it that they were cared for.

Why is it that the Non Treaty Chippewa Indians who have not even a house to live in although they can call their own as passed by unnoticed like fallen leaves and left to wither and die.

What Can Be Done

THOSE of you who have a spark of love and kind thoughts in your hearts for those who are less fortunate than yourselves can surely express your feelings by doing something of a material nature for these Indians. No, not by sending your old coat off clothing or anything else by giving lavishly of your bounty to those whom you owe a debt to which you will never fully pay.

When I think of the millions of dollars worth of oil being annually drawn from the oil fields of Alberta, it amazes me that a portion of it is not utilized for the purpose of bringing cheer to the homes of Indians who today are destitute. The vast resources of Alberta are actually a portion of the heritage of the people of Alberta, then why is not a portion of the revenue which is derived from these resources utilized for these same Non Treaty Chippewa Indians in a manner beneficial and agreeable to them.

I don't want any of you who read this article to get the impression that the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources at Ottawa has not tried to help these unfortunate Non Treaty Chippewa Indians. The said Department, in fact, year after year offers help in the form of food, clothing, medicines and a Reservation of Land, but such help was refused by the old Chief and his Council because they felt that they had never been suitably compensated for the land which the English-speaking people took from them and for the buffalo and other wild life which white people exterminated on the land which the Chippewa claimed to be their God-given land.

Although they have spurned help from the Indian Affairs Branch of the Government of Mines and Resources, they do appreciate help from individuals or societies which are interested in their welfare. And they do ask that the Government of Canada grant suitable areas over which they can hunt and trap unmolested by white men so that they can carry on their own natural avocation of making a living and be in a position to buy the necessities of life for their families.

Visit to Yellowface

A FEW weeks ago I visited the grave of my old friend and brother "Yellowface" Kowasate-Kwan which is on a high spur of ground on the north bank of Prairie Creek overlooking the valley. It is a lonely place which the old chief chose for his last resting place and is situated in a poplar grove commanding a magnificent view of the surrounding country and of the eastern slope of Rocky Mountain House in the southeast corner of the southwest quarter of section 26 in range 47, 8 west of the 1st meridian, on land belonging Henry Selkirk Comber.

As I stood at the grave of my old friend the many pleasant memories came back before his eyes as he heard the sound of the wind through the trees whom he thought was his son. He roved over to the point where he thought there was a little animal that looked something like a little man but could change itself into a kind of a figure. This animal changed itself into a bear and led the father deeper into the woods until he came to a spot where nobody could see him. After they were out of sight, the animal changed itself back into its proper form.
