AT THE GOVERNMENT HOUSE AT OTTAWA

WEDNESDAY, the 19th day of July, 1950.

PRESENT:

HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board, is pleased to make and doth hereby make the following regulations governing the payment of school fees and transportation costs in respect of the children of certain employees of the Government of Canada who reside on Government property and who by reason of the conditions of their occupancy are not subject to municipal taxation in respect thereof:

REGULATIONS

1. In these Regulations,

(a) "child" does not include a person who has attained the age of eighteen years at the commencement of the school year;

(b) "federal land" means land owned by His Majesty in right of Canada;

(c) "Minister", when used with reference to an employee, child of an employee, or land, means the Minister having the direction, control and management of the employee or land;

(d) "non-taxable employee" means an employee of His Majesty in right of Canada who, by reason of the conditions of his occupancy of federal land, is not subject to municipal taxation in respect of that land, and who applies to the Minister for financial assistance towards the cost of educating his children; and

(e) "school authority" means, with reference to a school, the corporation, board or other body that, with due authority, levies taxes to meet the expenses of operating and maintaining the school.

2. Where a non-taxable employee resides on federal land that, in the opinion of the Minister, is within easy access of a school established by the Minister of National Defence, the Minister shall, unless the facilities are insufficient, arrange with the Minister of National Defence for the accommodation at that school of the children of the employee, while he is so resident, in accordance with the provisions of Order in Council P.C. 44/2300 of 6th May, 1950.
3. (1) Where a child of a non-taxable employee is not accommodated at a school mentioned in section two, the Minister may arrange for the child to be accommodated at a school in another municipality in which the employee resides. If, in the opinion of the Minister, the school facilities in that municipality are inadequate, or a school in a municipality having adequate facilities is not available, a report shall be submitted to the Treasury Board whenever attendance at a school outside the municipality in which the employee resides becomes a necessity arising from the arrangement and the additional costs resulting, if any.

(2) Where a child is accommodated at a school pursuant to an arrangement under subsection (1), the Minister may pay to the school authority in such amount during each school year as the Minister considers reasonable, but not exceeding the school fees actually charged for the accommodation of the child resident at the school.

(3) The amount payable under subsection two may be paid to a non-taxable employee to the extent that he has paid school fees to the school authority in respect of the child's attendance at school, and the school authority shall be reduced by the amount so paid.

4. (1) Where a child of a non-taxable employee, pursuant to an arrangement under section three, attends a school in a place other than fifteen miles and not more than thirty-five miles from the place of residence, and to attend the school uses a public transportation service approved for the purpose by the Minister under the provisions of either subsection two or an urban public transportation service, the Minister may pay to the employee the difference between the cost to the employee of the service that is rendered to the child exceeds three dollars a month.

(2) Where the Minister of National Defence provides a transportation service for the purpose of rendering a child for the purpose of attending a school pursuant to an arrangement under section three, the Minister may arrange for the transportation service on such terms and conditions as the Minister of National Defence may prescribe.

5. Where federal land is made available for reallocation, the Minister shall, except where in his opinion it is not feasible, lease the land on terms that will not deprive the municipality in which the land is situated, or its ratepayers, of the benefit in respect of his occupancy of the land.

6. No payment shall be made under these Regulations in respect of a person who resides in federal lands:

(a) that is included in Crown property in a municipality that receives a grant under section five of the Municipal Grants Regulations for the purpose of computing the grant; or

(b) that is situated in a municipality in which he is subject to municipal taxation in respect of his occupancy of that land.

7. Any payment or arrangement made under these Regulations shall be made through the Municipal Grants Division of the Department of Finance.

8. These Regulations, except section nine, are deemed to have come into force on January 1, 1949.

Recent Developments in Indian Education in Canada

The Special Joint Committee of the Senate and the House of Commons into Indian Affairs began its sittings in 1946 and focused the attention of the Canadian people upon the inadequacies of the Indian school system. As the hearings continued it soon became evident that there were complaints not only from the Indian people but from the churches concerned and also from other interested organizations. The striking fact was the large group of Indian children of school age who were not receiving any education, the number at that time being estimated at 11,000.

The Government, realizing the seriousness of the situation took immediate steps by providing greatly increased sums of money for the improvements which were obviously necessary.

School Building Program:

A program of building new schools was inaugurated at once and construction commenced on various Indian reserves. At the end of 1947 there were some 219 day schools with 382 teachers employed. By the end of 1950 these had increased to 373 day schools with 487 teachers employed. This increase in the number of classrooms being operated reflects the heavy building program which has been undertaken.

The aim of the Indian Affairs Branch is, of course, to provide educational facilities for every Indian child. To accomplish this it is necessary to assess carefully every reserve and determine the type of school which can best serve the children. Educational survey committees were established to carry out such investigations and often large areas and many reserves are covered; as a result of these studies, decisions are made with regard to the size and type of school to be erected and also its location. Then there follows a period of overcoming the difficulties and obstacles which must be faced in erecting schools in the isolated sections of Canada in which these Indians live. It may be the carrying of materials by tractor train to a reserve in the Norway House Agency of Manitoba; it might involve the transportation of a prefabricated school to a fishing village on the coast of British Columbia; or the hauling out of logs for the erection of a log school in the Yukon.

The main problem is that of the Indians who have been neglected in the past and for whom it is difficult to provide schools. These are the Indians living in the so-called "Fringe of Civilization". Transportation is the main difficulty and the day schools are erected in many and varied ways with buildings of log, metal and prefabricated parts all being found. Where day schools are not feasible, due to the nomadic habits of the Indians concerned, residential schools are erected. Three such schools are under construction now, all in isolated parts of Canada.

We may summarize the success of our day school building program in particular by the fact that since 1947 there has been a total increase in day school enrollment of 3,111 pupils. It is confidently expected that this number will have risen to over 4,500 by the end of the present academic year.

In addition to the program of building new schools, there has been carried out a thorough overhauling of existing educational facilities both in day and residential schools. A modernization of these schools has cost millions of dollars.
Education in Association with Other Children

The Parliamentary Committee made a fourth report on the 2nd of June, 1946. In this report it made the following recommendation with regard to Indian education:

"The Operation of Indian Schools.

Your Committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children."

An entirely different problem from that of providing a basic elementary education for the northern Indians mentioned above is presented by the need for changes in the Indian school system on reserves located close to white communities. In carrying out the above recommendation of the Parliamentary Committee, the Department of Citizenship and Immigration has been negotiating with local School Boards and Provincial Departments of Education. We are now appointing Regional School Inspectors who can deal locally with such problems by being in constant contact with provincial and municipal officials. There are now over 1300 Indian children in elementary grades in such schools. This is a growth of over 300 pupils in one year and we expect similar increases in future years. While statistics were not accurately kept, there were only about 200 children enrolled in Provincial schools in 1934.

Qualifications of Teachers

It has been fully realized that the building of schools alone will not improve the educational standards among Indians. The calibre of teachers in the schools must be improved in order that the Indian schools might keep pace with the Provincial schools. It was fully realized that many of the Indian schools were on isolated reserves where living conditions were far from attractive. Therefore, good salaries had to be paid and comfortably furnished living accommodation provided. To this end, the Department has introduced a salary schedule which now places teachers with First Class Certificates in a range of from $1650 a year to $2100; those with Second Class Certificates in a range from $1560 to $2040. In addition to these salaries, free teacherages are provided in practically all day schools. This salary schedule is now under revision and will be increased in line with the recent salary raises given to Federal Civil Servants. As an aid in retaining teachers, the benefits of the Federal Civil Service Superannuation Plan have been extended to them. Many teachers have taken advantage of this offer and are now permanent Civil Servants.

The efforts of the Department to improve the teaching standards in Indian schools may then be summarized as follows:

1. The introduction of a salary schedule with regular increments as described above,

2. The provision, free, of a better class of living accommodation for teachers and improved classroom facilities for the children,

3. The extension of superannuation benefits to teachers.
In hiring new teachers, the policy of the Department has been clearly stated as follows:

1. The elimination of unqualified teachers;
2. A gradual reduction in the number of teachers holding Second Class certificates;
3. The employment, wherever possible, of teachers holding First Class Certificates.

Recent Developments in Indian Education in Canada

The Special Joint Committee of the Senate and the House of Commons into Indian Affairs began its sittings in 1946 and focused the attention of the Canadian people upon the inadequacies of the Indian school system. As the hearings continued it soon became evident that there were complaints not only from the Indian people but from the churches concerned and also from other interested organizations. One striking fact was the large group of Indian children of school age who were not receiving any education, the number at that time being estimated at 11,000.

The Government, realizing the seriousness of the situation took immediate steps by providing greatly increased sums of money for the improvements which were obviously necessary.

School Building Program:

A programme of building new schools was inaugurated at once and construction commenced on various Indian reserves. At the end of 1947 there were some 249 day schools with 352 teachers employed. By the end of 1950 these had increased to 373 day schools with 487 teachers employed. This increase in the number of classrooms being operated reflects the heavy building programme which has been undertaken.

The aim of the Indian Affairs Branch is, of course, to provide educational facilities for every Indian child. To accomplish this it is necessary to assess carefully every reserve and determine the type of school which can best serve the children. Educational survey committees were established to carry out such investigations and often large areas and many reserves are covered. As a result of these studies, decisions are made with regard to the size and type of school to be erected and also its location. Then there follows a period of overcoming the difficulties and obstacles which must be faced in erecting schools in the isolated sections of Canada in which these Indians live. It may be the carrying of materials by tractor train to a reserve in the Norway House Agency or Manitoba; it might involve the transportation of a prefabricated school to a fishing village on the coast of British Columbia; or the hauling out of logs for the erection of a log school in the Yukon.

The main problem is that of the Indians who have been neglected in the past and for whom it is difficult to provide schools. These are the Indians living in the so-called "fringe of civilization". Transportation is the main difficulty and the day schools are erected in many and varied ways with buildings or log, metal and prefabricated parts all being found. Where day schools are not feasible, due to the nomadic habits of the Indians concerned, residential schools are erected. Three such schools are under construction now, all in isolated parts of Canada.

We may summarize the success of our day school building programme in particular by the fact that since 1947 there has been a total increase in day school enrolment of 3,111 pupils. It is confidently expected that this number will have risen to over 4,500 by the end of the present academic year.

In addition to the programme of building new schools, there has been carried out a thorough overhauling of existing educational facilities both in day and residential schools. A modernization of these schools has cost millions of dollars.
Education in Association with Other Children

The Parliamentary Committee made a fourth report on the 22nd of June, 1948. In this report it made the following recommendation with regard to Indian education:

"The Operation of Indian Schools.

Your Committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children."

An entirely different problem from that of providing a basic elementary education for the northern Indians mentioned above is presented by the need for changes in the Indian school system on reserves located close to white communities. In carrying out the above recommendation of the Parliamentary Committee, the Department of Citizenship and Immigration has been negotiating with local School Boards and Provincial Departments of Education. We are now appointing Regional School Inspectors who can deal locally with such problems by being in constant contact with provincial and municipal officials. There are now over 1200 Indian children in elementary grades in such schools. This is a growth of over 300 pupils in one year and we expect similar increases in future years. While statistics were not accurately kept, there were only about 200 children enrolled in provincial schools in 1934.

Qualifications of Teachers

It has been fully realized that the building of schools alone will not improve the educational standards among Indians. The calibre of teachers in the schools must be improved in order that the Indian schools might keep pace with the provincial schools. It was fully realized that many of the Indian schools were on isolated reserves where living conditions were far from attractive. Therefore, good salaries had to be paid and comfortably furnished living accommodation provided. To this end, the Department has introduced a salary schedule which now places teachers with First Class Certificates in a range of from $1650 a year to $1820; those with Second Class Certificates in a range from $1560 to $2040. In addition to these salaries, free teachersages are provided in practically all day schools. This salary schedule is now under revision and will be increased in line with the recent salary raises given to Federal Civil Servants. As an aid in retaining teachers, the benefits of the Federal Civil Service Superannuation Plan have been extended to them. Many teachers have taken advantage of this offer and are now permanent Civil Servants.

The efforts of the Department to improve the teaching standards in Indian schools may then be summarized as follows:

1. The introduction of a salary schedule with regular increments as described above,

2. The provision, free, of a better class of living accommodation for teachers and improved classroom facilities for the children,

3. The extension of superannuation benefits to teachers.

1. The elimination of unqualified teachers;
2. A gradual reduction in the number of teachers holding Second Class certificates;
3. The employment, wherever possible, of teachers holding First Class certificates.

In one year, therefore, there has been an increase of 40 per cent in teachers holding First Class Certificates and a decrease of 20 per cent in unqualified teachers. It should be further pointed out that many of the "unqualified" teachers hold Third Class certificates and permits, and have been employed for several years. During this time they have come to understand their Indian pupils well and have rendered valuable service.

While statistics are not available for residential school teachers, as they are hired by the churches concerned, there has also been a definite improvement in the calibre of these teachers.

### Secondary Education:

The increase in the number of pupils in Indian schools and the improvement in the calibre of teachers being hired has resulted in a steady trend towards higher education. In 1949 there were 661 pupils
attending classes above Grade 8, this representing an increase of about 200 over the previous year. In September of 1950 there were 834 students attending secondary classes, and it is expected that the 1,000-mark will be passed by next year. This splendid record indicates that Indian youth is taking a great interest in its own education. Many of these young people can go through for vocations which will be of assistance to their fellow people. They are being particularly encouraged to make their profession either teaching or nursing. The Department has been pleased with the results of many of the day schools which are being taught by qualified Indian teachers. On the Six Nations Reserve, the Supervising Principal and all eighteen teachers in charge of day school classrooms are Indians. The Department is proud of this achievement and hopes that other reserves will follow this pattern.

Vocational Education

A program of vocational training, adapted to the needs of Indian pupils, is being followed in the larger day and residential schools. Certain basic skills are taught, and at the end of each year of the program merit badges are awarded to foster interest on the part of the children. Such skills as trapping, poultry raising, sewing and knitting are covered in the courses.

In addition, regular courses are given, where sufficient older pupils are available, in wood-working, metal work and electricity.

Social Workers

An important development in Indian administration is the recent addition of trained social workers. Five workers are already in the field and four more are to be appointed. These workers, operating on a provincial regional basis, are an integral part of the larger educational picture, and through their efforts a degree of adult education in the sphere of the home is expected to result. Of particular importance is the work accomplished by these social workers in assisting to organize and to encourage Indian women's organizations such as the Homemakers' Clubs. The improvement of home living conditions, juvenile delinquency problems, sanitation safeguards, development of child care and
instruction, and home economics are aspects of the social worker's responsibilities which, it is considered, will react favourably on the whole educational program on Indian reserves.

------------------------

The Department realizes it is still far from its goal of providing educational facilities for every Indian child. Slowly, however, it is pushing into the isolated reserves and its teachers are blazing new frontiers in education and social progress. Many of them are classified as Welfare teachers, living on the reserves for twelve months in the year and working with the assistance of the social workers toward the steady improvement of living conditions among the Indian people. The loneliness of these posts holds no fear for these teachers and their contribution towards the steady progress of the Indian people can never be measured. This is a great public service and one of which all Canadians can be proud.

MEMORANDUM TO DEPUTY MINISTERS OF EDUCATION

regarding

MR. GARFIELD WESTON'S TOURS FOR GIRLS
ADMINISTRATION AND SELECTION

1. General

Please refer to the minutes of the CEA Executive for November 29 and 30, 1950, pages six and eight, and to my memo of December 15, 1950, on the above subject.

With the approval of our Executive I would respectfully request your co-operation in the selection of high school girls from your province to go on a tour of the United Kingdom, with all expenses paid, in the summer of 1951. It is hoped you will be able to co-operate with Mr. Weston and with the CEA in this project in your capacity as the senior educational official in your province.

The purpose of these tours is to promote a better knowledge of Canada and of the U.K. in the young people of each country. A very valuable by-product of the tours has been the promotion of Canadian unity through the knowledge gained by young people of different parts of Canada and of each other.

Will you please advise me at your earliest convenience if we may count upon your co-operation in this project?

2. Administration of the Tours

All arrangements for the tour will be made by Mr. Garfield Weston and his representatives in Canada and the U.K. In Canada the project is under the immediate direction of Public & Industrial Relations Limited, Toronto. Administrative details such as transportation, accommodation, passports, etc., will be looked after by specially appointed persons from these organizations. Heading the tour for Canadian girls will be Dr. Mariel Roscoe, Principal, Victoria College, McGill University. One of Mr. Weston's daughters will accompany the party in a supervisory capacity. Still to be selected are two additional supervisors, a graduate nurse and a woman competent in the field of guidance. A representative of Public & Industrial Relations Limited will be business manager for the English girls during their stay in Canada, and similar help will be provided to the Canadian girls while in the U.K.

The responsibility of the CEA is limited to selection of Canadian girls only, but its advice on other matters relative to the project would be welcomed.

3. Time and Itinerary. The Canadian girls will sail from Montreal about July 13 and arrive back in Canada about August 20. The British girls will leave the U.K. July 30 and arrive again in England about September 10. No air travel is anticipated.

Object of the tour is to see as much as possible of the history, culture, industry, and way of life of the people of the U.K. The rate of travel will be slower than that last year for boys and the intention is to
remain in some central locality with suitable accommodation for a week at a time. This place will be used as a hub from which surrounding areas will be visited.

The proposed itinerary is shown in Appendix C hereto.

4. Method of Selection

It is the opinion of the CEA Committee that the senior educational official in each province should select the girls. It is believed that conditions vary and that such organization as might be set up should be left entirely to the discretion of the authorities in each province. However, it was agreed that very specific qualifications for the selectees, as set down by the Steering Committee, should be adhered to by the selectors.

5. Eligibility for Selection

(a) Age - The girl's date of birth should be between June 1, 1933, and June 1, 1935. It is hoped that the majority of girls will have passed their sixteenth birthday, but not yet reached their seventeenth birthday, at the time of the tour.

(b) Education - The girls should, unless under exceptional circumstances, be intending to take further educational training (academic, commercial, vocational, college, normal school, nursing, etc.) for at least one year. The majority of girls should have completed Grade XII in Ontario and British Columbia, and Grade XI in the other provinces in June, 1951. No girl may be selected who is not a competent student.

(c) Health - The girls selected must be in good health. While the girls being considered need not have a medical examination, those selected must, as soon as possible after their selection has been announced, obtain a certificate from their local physician that their health is satisfactory for such a trip. This is to be forwarded to the CEA office. The Canadian government requires that all persons entering Canada from abroad, including Canadian citizens, must have proof of vaccination within the last three years. Those selected must provide proof of such vaccination as soon as possible after their selection is made. Forms for this purpose will be sent to the girls selected after their selection has been announced.

(d) Consent - The consent of the parent or guardian of the selectee should be obtained on the form attached (App. F.). Forms for this purpose are being sent to you in sufficient quantities for the places available in your province.

(e) Qualities of Personality - In considering the suitability of girls the following personal qualities are important:

(i) Sense of responsibility - the importance of staying with the party, being on time for trains and boats, not mislaying personal effects, and appreciating the opportunities provided through such a tour at no personal expense give this factor unusual weight.

(ii) Adaptability and ability to get on with a group.

(iii) Intelligence - general alertness of mind, the ability to observe and to profit by experience.

(iv) Appearance

(v) Poise and deportment - the tour members will receive considerable public attention abroad and will meet many national and international figures.
(vi) Ability to speak before school and adult groups

(vii) Spirit of enthusiasm

6. Responsibility for Selection and Number to be Selected

The Departments of Education of the different provinces, as the responsible authorities in education, are being asked to undertake the selection of a specified number of girls for the tour described above. The allocation of places to each province is shown in Appendix A. However, it is considered most politic from several angles for the CEA to assume responsibility for announcing those selected across Canada on the basis of recommendations from the Departments.

In the event that from the over-all point of view one or two candidates seem unsuitable, or in case illness or home problems prevent some girl from going on the tour after arrangements are otherwise complete, you are asked to recommend further names to the CEA as alternates, in addition to places allocated, on the basis of four each from Ontario and Quebec, one from P.E.I., and two from each of the other provinces. While it is considered appropriate that final approval of those selected to go on the tour be made by the Steering Committee, you may be assured that selections will be only from those names your Department supplies. Will you please list the names (and addresses) of those whom you recommend for the places allocated to your province. Alternates should be shown on a separate list, or in a separate column, and ranked as to first, second, etc. Consent forms (para. 5 (d) above) should not be completed for these alternates, nor should they be advised that their names have been submitted, to avoid disappointment on their part.

7. Time of Selection

So that arrangements for the tour, such as clothing, transportation, vaccination, documentation, passports, etc., may be completed in good time, the sponsors of the tour are anxious that selections be completed by March 1, 1951. In order to make arrangements for these necessary administrative details, the names of those recommended together with the names of the alternates mentioned in para. 6 above must reach the CEA office by March 8, 1951.

8. Announcement of Selections

Although the tour is limited to fifty girls, the goodwill benefits and the understanding the tours promote are broadened by the public attention they receive through press and radio. It is, of course, important that no premature announcement be made before each selection is confirmed by us. For this reason, and to avoid scattered announcements, material will be prepared by this Committee and forwarded to you for release as of a certain date. You are, of course, welcome to amend it in any way you see fit.

It will obviously be necessary, before names are sent to the CEA office, for the recommended girls to be advised that they are among those being recommended, in order that the consent of their parents may be obtained. Public announcement on the part of those recommended can be avoided, however, by advising them that official approval of those selected must be forthcoming from the Steering Committee before the selection can be regarded as final and public.

9. Private Schools

Four of the fifty girls are to be selected from private schools. Two of these will be chosen from private girls' schools in Ontario and two from Quebec. Selection of the two from Ontario will be arranged directly
with the private schools by the CEA; the two from Quebec will be selected from private schools in the province of Quebec by such method as appears most suitable to the Department of Education of that province. To maintain provincial distribution these girls from the private schools should also normally reside in the province from which they are selected.

10. Geographic Representation, now and in later years

It will perhaps be helpful for you to know, in case criticism or disappointment is evident, that Mr. Weston hopes, the international situation permitting, to offer similar tours to Canadian girls in the future. Some care should be taken to avoid selection from small local areas in which boys were chosen last year. It is desired that representation from each province be as wide-spread as possible. Rural and village areas should have representation as well as urban areas, preferably on an equal basis with urban areas.

The CEA should be advised of any special expenses in connection with the tour to which a department may be put beyond its ordinary responsibilities.

Memoandum:

THE DIRECTOR

The Minister's Notes on the School Section of the Indian Act

1 (a) Day Schools

This is correct but there are still a few day schools remaining which were built

(a) by the churches
(b) by the Indians (band funds)
(c) by the Department in conjunction with (a) and/or (b).

1 (b) Residential Schools

Buildings

Some of these schools were built by the Department and are referred to as "Government-owned". Of the 69 residential schools, some 46 are in this category. The remaining schools were built by the churches (18 Roman Catholic and 5 Anglican) and are referred to as "Church-owned" schools.

Operation

A per capita grant is paid to the school management for the education and care of each Indian child whose attendance is duly authorized by the Department.

Maintenance

In addition the Department pays the following items:

(I) Major repairs in accordance with our regulations. At a "Government-owned" school we can exceed where necessary, items listed in our Estimates. At a "Church-owned" school this cannot be done without approval of the Governor-in-Council. For example, if a repair job at a "Church-owned" school costs $1,005.00 and the Vote only allows $1,000.00, then we must arrange a transfer and secure an Order-in-Council for the additional $5.00 required.

(II) Equipment such as desks, blackboards, laundry machinery, electrical generators, etc., in accordance with our regulations. As in (I) above, the "Church-owned" schools cannot exceed the sum specifically voted.

(III) School supplies including texts, scribblers, manual training tools, etc.

(IV) Grants towards salaries of night watchmen for winter months at certain schools.

(V) Grants towards salaries of manual training instructors where their qualifications meet our requirements.

I would also point out for the Minister's information the fact that the Department can request the dismissal of staff members or of the Principal. This has been done on several occasions in the last few years and we have always had the co-operation of the church concerned.
We agree that in Section 10(2) of the old Act the difference between "A Roman Catholic (or Protestant) School" and a "School conducted under Roman Catholic (or Protestant) auspices" lay in the point of ownership. In other words, it is believed that the meaning of a "Roman Catholic (or Protestant) School" was a school both owned and operated by the church concerned. A "School conducted under Roman Catholic (or Protestant) auspices" is believed to have referred to a school owned by the Government but operated on its behalf by the religious denomination concerned.

Nomination of Day School Teachers

In certain day schools the Department allowed the churches to nominate the teachers but retained the right of dismissal if such teachers proved unsatisfactory. This practice of nomination has been greatly reduced in the last three years and will probably disappear. The Department of course will have to make certain that teachers are appointed who are of the denomination of the majority of the Indians concerned as provided for in Section 121 of the new Act. This precludes the appointment of teachers by the Civil Service Commission, and leaves the matter in the hands of the Department as authorized by Order-in-Council.

3. Provincial schools vary of course in the use of the term "public". In Quebec these are Roman Catholic schools; in other provinces they are "non-denominational". We pay tuition fees for Indian children who attend such schools.

The Minister is correct in his summary of the three types of schools to which Roman Catholic children might be sent but we might also add a fourth category of school,

(a) a provincial school or private school in which religious instruction in the Roman Catholic faith is given by the teacher or by a priest.

Section 118

I agree with the Minister's summary concerning this section and feel that the adjective "residential" school should be eliminated throughout this section.

Our practice at the present time where we have pupils of a religious minority, insufficient to establish a school, is to take one of the following actions:

(a) send the children concerned to a residential school of the faith concerned;

(b) send the children to a nearby provincial school or separate school if available.

Revolt Against "Modern" Schooling

Alberta teachers start drilling pupils in grammar, adding and pronunciation as pendulum swings from modernism

By James H. Gray

CALGARY — It took a long time, but the bloom is falling off one of the late William A. Aikinart's more successful local publications, promoting "modernizing" teaching methods. The educational pendulum is once again swinging over to the conservative side. All kinds of his own theories, dreamed up usually by the super-intellectual bureaucrats, are being quietly junked not only in Alberta but elsewhere on the Prairies.

In addition to being a prophetess, Biblical student, monetary reformer and politician, the late Mr. Abbott was also a schoolteacher. By all accounts he was one of the best. Because he was a superb teacher, he could use all kinds of unorthodox methods and still have his classes whom through departmental exams. Because he got such results with his methods, he assumed that universal adoption of the methods would produce similar results for all teachers.

The departmentalizers got the green light. The old-fashioned idea that the fundamentals—reading, writing, arithmetic, grammar, etc., could only be taught by thorough drilling was discarded. Pupils were encouraged to remember memorize arithmetic tables. They learned that 5 times 5 made 25 by indirection, not by memorizing the five-times table. The same applied to the alphabet and the sounds. Nothing was learned by rote.

The hours once spent in dismal drills were turned over to "projects" and ethical studies. Parents, who knew their experience in an effort to aid their young hopefuls in their studies, got snarky notes from principals.

For a decade everything was wonderful. But as the small fry of 1938 became high school students in 1948, the defects of the system became evident. High school teachers had to try to teach Latin and French to pupils who had never been fully exposed to the formal rules. Most pupils didn't even know a past participle from an irregular verb. Other teachers discovered that many of the rules of simple arithmetic learned by the indirect method, had been forgotten.

Gradually the teachers have been gathering doubts about the whole thing. A questioning of the soundness of it all is now being heard through the teachers' ranks. Those who were against the reforms but had perforce to accommodate themselves to the new system, have become vocal critics now of the teachings.

Equally important in the growing reaction against the modernists has been the attitude of the business world. The plain fact is that the theories don't work when it comes to providing pupils with a working knowledge of arithmetic, spelling or grammar. At very least, the old system enables people to add small sums in their heads and make change accurately. A store clerk who cannot add $6.23 and $1 and get $7.10 is not too useful to an employer.

Yet the ability to add small sums mentally is so rare today that many employers have been forced to compel their employees to use a pencil and scratch pad before they touch the cash register. Why perhaps most of the stores in the prairie cities are today equipped with scribbling paper to enable employees to add six and five and be sure it is eleven.

Secretarial schools, which once confined their efforts largely to stenographer courses in spelling, now find it necessary to give great blocks of time teaching spelling that was once taught in the primary grades.

The mispronunciation of simple words is a constant source of amusement. One radio station operator, who blew his top in an argument with some teachers, was told that the fault was his own. Instead of hiring people out of high school, he was told he should hire only university graduates because only they had really completed the course that began with him. His reply was that university graduates were worse than high school graduates. The former could neither be taught or trained while the latter, because they had done before university, could be convinced they did not know everything.

All this is regional, rather than something strictly Albertan. It is reflected by a rising tide of dissatisfaction with the educational system. It has nothing to do with the advancement of vocational and academic studies. It is simply that the educational tools that are essential to daily life in our society are being provided. As educational costs are continually rising, public griping is bound to be reflected in criticism of school expenditures. Not only are parents threatened or driven by impatient parental complaints, many teachers are voluntarily and quietly going back to the old methods. They are sneakily telling their number work, quietly encouraging parents to insist on some homework being done. That, to business men going mad enough to find secretaries who can spell and punctuate, should be really big news on the Prairies.

The Honorable Walter Harris M.P.
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Sir:

There are some things which I discovered on my recent trip through the Lubicon (Prairie) Lake area, northeast of town, which should be brought to your attention.

This area is quite isolated and except for treaty time is visited by very few white men. My purpose in making this 366 mile trip was to investigate the request for a school. The Indians thought your department should be responsible for a school, but I found only one-third of the 60 children concerned are treaty. You have already provided two excellent residential schools at Wabiskaw and Grouard, which were intended to be used by these Indians. Since visiting with them, it seems they are determined not to send their children out to these schools, because they are too far away for the parents to visit their children. (It would take them a week or more each way, traveling as they do by team.)

The Indians and Metis all want a school, even if they have to build one for themselves. Since two-thirds of the children are non-treaty, we are trying to work out a plan whereby the Alberta Department of Education will provide a day school and we are planning to build a dormitory. If this idea works out, will your department be willing for us to include the treaty children in this plan? How much do you pay toward their support?

In deciding the location for the school the question is again raised concerning the promised Indian Reserve at Lubicon Lake. Ten or twelve years ago these Indians were promised a Reserve comprising 22 sections of prairie land at the west end of Lubicon Lake. Do you have any record of such
an agreement? Has the plan for a Reserve at Lubicon been abandoned? If there is to be a Reserve, the school should be located near it, but not necessarily on it, since two-thirds of the children are non-treaty.

There is considerable fuss being made relative to the children's allowance. The non-treaty Metis are receiving the allowance, when their children are not in school, but the treaty Indians are not. Could you use your influence to have a standard rule relative to the children's allowance? The Indians need this extra money as much or more than anyone else.

One other matter should be mentioned. The Lubicon Lake Indians have not been exrayed for T.B. The trader and some of the Indians expressed concern, because last year the treaty party did exrays everywhere except at Lubicon. I do not know why they were omitted, but will you please include the exray outfit with this year's treaty party at Lubicon? Treaty time is the only contact their people now have with medical care. We plan to have a nurse at the school when it opens.

Thanks for your patience in this lengthy letter. These are matters I knew you would be interested in and I know they will receive your careful consideration.

I have the honor to remain,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Rolland C. Smith

I wish to thank you for the interest you have taken in the various Summer Missions, to which we hope to send teachers, this year.

I will especially refer to your letter of March 25th.

There are seven missions in all. For two of them, you have authorized two teachers each. This makes nine men in all.

First of all, as to the choice of men. It is difficult to bring back the same men every year. Students change their plans; some of them are more successful than others, and there is no doubt, that a man is more efficient, in his second year, at the same place.

I have secured two men from St. John's College, Winnipeg, whom I would like to send to the Nakina District, for two reasons. It is only two or three hundred miles to Winnipeg, and Manitoba University closes about the first of May, which gives the men a longer period.

I would have no objection to your dealing directly with the men, before they go into the field. The trouble is, that the Department so far has not paid any travelling expenses, and most of the men have to travel by plane, for at least part of the journey, therefore, the financing of the students has always been a worry, because the men expect to receive their whole travelling expenses besides their upkeep at the missions; in other words, they want take home pay.

Dear Col. Neary,

By the way, I would like sometime, to talk to you, about the situation, as between Pagwa and Calstock. You probably know something or its history. All the people, at both places, come from the Albany River on James Bay. What is happening is, that, most of the independent and young people are staying at Pagwa, while the old and dependent people have gone to Calstock, where they find it easier to get relief and Government Help. Now with regard to the Summer Students. Dear Colonel Neary,

I have just returned from London and Toronto where I met some of the students who are going north. Scharfiter and Meikle met me in Toronto and I have arranged for them to go to Montreal to meet the manager of the Mistassini Hudson's Bay Co. store. I have heard that the old Hudson's Bay house is still habitable and will give them shelter. I have authorized them to purchase whatever is necessary for their trip. Any house equipment the mission will pay for. Other things like personal luxuries they can pay for themselves. I have advanced each of them $100 and have given them an order on the Mont Laurier Aviation Co. at Roberval for return plane fare. They are both keen and competent and will leave early next week. I have also written to Mr. C. H. Brown and Mr. G. W. Thomson who live near Toronto and instructed them to travel to Senneterre. I have given them an order for a plane fare to Waswanapi. So far these are the only men for whom I have advanced money and I am sure that there will be no difficulty. I will either send the bills to you or have them pay me. I would much rather not have to take their cheques myself so that there will be no money transaction between us. If I have made any mistake in assuming that Mr. Brown has accepted you can let me know. I expect to begin my air journey about June 1st at Central Patricia, going down the Albany River, visiting about 6 posts and then around James Bay from Amepioutou to Whale River and perhaps the Belcher Island then I will go overland to Mistassini and Waswanapi, ending the journey at Val D'Or. It will be nearly 4,000 miles. I wish you could have sent one of your men with me, or come yourself.

Yours faithfully,

Robert Moosonee

Dear Colonel Neary,

One of the lads whom I am proposing to recommend very strongly to you for a temporary teaching job this coming summer, asked me whether, by any chance, there might be a position available for husband and wife. Needless to say, I did not know, but I promised to pass the question on to you.

I can recommend the young man whole-heartedly, and he wishes me to be perfectly clear that he was anxious for the position, quite irrespective of any possibility of his wife. In other words, this is not a case of an applicant wishing to raise difficulties, or asking for consideration.

Dunning, the man in question, tells me that his wife taught public school in New Zealand for several years, so she must hold whatever the legal teaching requirements may be in New Zealand. I have met Mrs. Dunning, but only in a very casual way. Curiously enough, she reminded me that I had met her when she first came to Canada a few years ago and was serving as a counsellor at Camp Tanamakoon, in Algonquin Park, where I happened to be a dinner guest. I know something of the standards of this camp, and feel perfectly sure they would not have counsellors who were not of good quality. My understanding is that the present Mrs. Dunning came from New Zealand to visit one or more Canadian camps, with, I assume, the intention of returning to New Zealand with the experience and knowledge gained in Canada. However, she got married instead.

Obviously, I have no knowledge of whether you have ever taken on a husband and wife on a summer job, but on the face of it, the Dunnings seem a perfectly possible combination.

With best regards,

Yours sincerely,

T. F. McIlwraith

Dear Colonel Neary,

I take it for granted that you went home by air. I heard from Archdeacon Clarke during your visit and I want to tell you that I am very glad to know that you have seen something of our problem on James Bay.

Archdeacon Clarke will be here next Wednesday for the meeting of our Executive Committee and I will be able to learn then, something of your decisions.

With regard to the Indian Day Schools on the Bay I have already received the back payments for three of the missionaries. The only one remaining is the account of Louttit at Factory River. This morning I had a cheque for him for $108.00 and it was dated January 31st. I take it for granted that it is for his salary for the first month of this year. I am very anxious that each of these four men will stand on his own feet and feel responsible for his reports to the Department.

You have been very interested and helpful about the summer day-schools. I have written to Griess but I am afraid that he will not be available this year. He has other ideas. THE BISHOP'S LETTER

My Dear Friends:

The fifteenth Synod of the Diocese of Moosonee was held in St. Matthew's Pro-Cathedral on May 14th, 12th and 13th.

We were honoured by the visit of the Most Reverend Dr. Carrington, D.D., D.C.L., the Lord Archbishop of Quebec. I think we all feel that the visit of the Archbishop was one of the highlights of the Synod. Dr. Carrington's personal charm, originality and humour has left a pleasant memory. The first service was held on Wednesday morning, the following Deacons were ordained to the priesthood:

Reverend E. R. dePendleton, B.A., the Reverend E. C. Grey, Reverend Lloyd Howard, and the Reverend George Loosmore. Mr. W. H. Thompson of Calstock was ordained Deacon. The Archbishop preached the sermon. Everyone was delighted to see the Venetian Archdeacon Woodall, D.D., in the chancel. His presence brought its own benediction.

In the afternoon the Archbishop conducted a quiet hour for the clergy.

The Synod service was held at eight o'clock in the evening, the Archbishop again being the preacher. The Synod then adjourned for preliminary organization. There was a good number of new members. Among the clergy and the laity there were new faces and fresh voices. The debates were very keen; I have never seen such a lively Synod in Moosonee.

On Thursday evening there was a reception held at Bishop's house; there were nearly a hundred people present. Archbishop Carrington fascinated everyone with a most original and beautiful coloured film of the Lambeth Conference. On the last day of the Synod the main feature was the report on our Indian Missions in James Bay given by Archdeacon Clarke. His story of the building of the great hospital at Moose Factory was quite thrilling.

When the Synod was over I felt that the only lack was the presence of our clergy from James Bay. Before next Synod I hope to arrange that every priest in the Diocese will be able to attend.

In spite of the fact that we are losing three men from the Diocese, our Missions and Parishes are almost completely filled. There is a spirit of optimism and happiness which will make this Synod a bright omen for the future.

Yours faithfully,

Robert Moosonee
Northward Ho

By the Archbishop of Quebec

I came northward at the invitation of the Bishop of Moosonee to address the Synod of the Diocese and to take part in its fellowship. It is a Diocese of 350,000 square miles and runs out into James' Bay. I have long been interested in it because our own has a certain resemblance to it; we have 280,000 square miles, and run out into the Straits of Belle Isle. Somewhere there is a frontier between the two Dioceses; it is called the Height of Land. As you make your way north you find the rivers running south until you come into a high flat region about a thousand feet above sea-level, full of lakes and rocks and trees; this is no man's land; a few miles north of this the rivers are found to be flowing north. You have crossed the Height of Land, and passed into the Diocese of Moosonee. Just where you did it, you do not know.

Actually I struck northward from the Diocese of Algoma. From North Bay the Ontario Northland Railway runs along the Ottawa River through Haileybury and Swastika. Somewhere in that neighborhood in the Height of Land is its source. A few miles further are Porcupine and Schumacher and Timmins; and in this area the Athabasca river, and flows north into James' Bay.

Near Schumacher on the Porcupine Highway is the See House of the Diocese, a charming open-air residence beautifully situated in the woods. It is written in the Scriptures that a bishop must be the husband of one wife, and given to hospitality; it is the first of these requirements which makes possible the execution of the latter. In "Bishoplope" as the See House is called, hospitality is unbounded.

The Synod Service was held in St. Matthew's Pro-Cathedral at Timmins under the direction of Dean Robinson. It is a new clean attractive church. Synod members had come from great distances. Some were too far to be able to come. Police have to be laid down for two kinds of work; one is the continuation of Bishop Hardwick among the Indians. The other is the provision of school and clergy for the mining and paper making towns which are coming into existence now. Great progress has been made in both respects under the imaginative and energetic leadership of the present Bishop. The "Northland" magazine, edited by Mrs. Reinson, carries the challenge of the Church's work in this country far and wide.

The Diocese is about a thousand miles long, five hundred wide and twenty-five hundred deep for the spiritual jurisdiction of the bishop is not confined to the surface. Far below Timmins and Porcupine and Schumacher are passageways in the rock which total hundreds of miles. Not far away are Kirkland Lake and other mining centres. We did not descend the whole seven thousand feet. Twenty-eight men with three horses and two dogs descended with passengers and saw the veins of quartz in the hard rock, from which the precious gold is extracted. In minealls and rubbers and tin hats equipped with lamps, we made our way round and asked all kinds of questions about this pioneer enterprise in our national records. If a hundred years ago such the first failure (of gold) occurred in California in 1849, men from all over the world arrived and staked out their claims. Fortunes were won and made. Time has moved since then. The methods of hundred years ago were primitive indeed compared with those we use today; and yet the principle of cracking and washing is the same.

That California 'Gold rush' with others of its kind in Australia, New Zealand, Klondike, and elsewhere, played its part in the great British and American expansion of the nineteenth century. The gold, passing into circulating promoted trade. Today it mostly finds its way under the roof of the KINSHIP Club via the modern up-to-date plant. I felt it was exhilarating the reactionary in the most interesting way. Our talks with the Manager and with the Chief Engineer gave us some idea of the type of man who operates these ventures, scientific knowledge, good judgment, and readiness to take a risk are necessary.

These northern communities are alike in many respects. They are new settlements of modern houses with scientific adventures under primitive conditions. They are often made up of persons who have chosen to come and settle here have an element of enterprise in their make-up; they are skilled persons, often with high educational qualifications; they see things in a big way and are not afraid to take action where action must be taken. Often there is an element of culture in these communities, although in many cases they feel that position. Some families settle down in their new surroundings, but more of them move on after a while. The communities constantly change.

For many temperaments, Canada turns her most attractive face towards the north. Certainly that is where she is now advancing and forging ahead; and the Church is going forward on this front too.

The forest-land is still the home of the bear and the moose. The rivers are still the highways of the Indians, though of course boats an outboard motor. What of the Indian, as the industrialist sweeps into his hunting grounds?"
We have given him the gospel. It is over a century now since missionaries of our Church first began to preach Christ to the Indians, and the Indian accepts His grace. We have the motto, Christians in our Anglican Church that the Indians of this great Diocese. They treasure their prayer books and their hymn books; they hold their own services in the woods; they pass on the Christian tradition to their children. Some of the Mistassini Indians of the Moosonee Diocese, appear in summer in our Diocese of Quebec. I have held Confirmations and administered Communion for them, and though they do not know a word of our language, and we do not know a word of theirs, we can see how much it means to them in their reverence and in their eyes.

We have a great responsibility for these Indians as Industrialism strikes deeper and deeper into their hereditary woods.

Good luck to the Diocese of Moosonee! It needs stout-hearted men in the north, and I thought from the look of their Synod that they seem to have them.

P. Q.

The Bishop Visits His Flock

By Margaret E. Plant

After the long winter months, a bright spot in the spring season is the annual visit of Rt. Rev. R. J. Renison, Lord Bishop of Moosonee.

This year the Bishop arrived at Hearst on the evening of Friday, April 8th. Of his many week-end engagements, one was to visit, on Sunday afternoon, Calstock Indian Reserve, Anglican Mission.

My husband and I were very kindly invited to go along. Due to the unavoidable absence (a great disappointment to us) of Mrs. Renison, it seemed fitting that I should pioneer with her.

The Calstock Reserve is situated on the shores of Lake Constance thirty miles west and north of Hearst. As we approached we noticed small dark skinned boys, posted as it were, at intervals along the road, appearing uninterested but we knew, quite excited over the arrival of the Bishop. We were guided by willing children to the teacher's house where we received a warm welcome from Mr. Thompson, missionary teacher in charge, and an even warmer welcome from his husky dog.

As I watched the preparations of the Bishop and Mr. Thompson, for the three o'clock service in the school house, and later saw the light in the faces of the Indians as the Bishop walked into the building, I realized as I never had before, the significance of this service in the lives of these Cree Indians.

There were about seventy-five souls present, of all ages down to babes in arms, or in their gaily decorated "tagahnabgahn." Their baby dark eyes peeking out from among brightly coloured blankets and tartan wraps. Extra bottles and trinkets were brought along by their mothers, who themselves wore their brightest and best dresses and scarves.

My glance fell on the attractive improvised altar, which I later learned was built by the Indian boys under the direction of their teacher. It was set on small wheels, had shelves on the back for books, and on the front, an altar cloth of snow-white linen bearing the Cree characters meaning, Holy, Holy, Holy.

I sat on a bench beside Chief Sutherland and looked on his Cree prayerbook, thinking what a clever man you must be, to be able to read that? I was amazed at the prompt and sincere responses of the Chief and his people. The hymns which were led by Mr. Thompson were sung in English, and appeared to be well known.

The Bishop, who misses nothing important, however small, had the Scripture read by David Soloman, a lay reader of many years, whose halting voice gave evidence of tired and failing eyes but whose willingness to take part was not diminished.

The service was conducted by the Bishop partly in Cree and partly in English, the English being translated into Cree by George Ferris. It was heart warming to see how every word was absorbed by these Indians. Even the little children appeared to be influenced and comforted in their small way.

There were twelve, seven girls and five boys, in the Confirmation class. The girls looking sweet and pretty in their dresses and veils of many colours, blue, red and bright yellow, so lovingly and carefully sewed and made by their mothers. The dark eyes shone, as they knelt before their Bishop for the Laying on of Hands.

The Communion Service now began, fifty-five communicants, in groups of twelve, first the men, then after an exchange of babies one for another, the women in turn, knelt before the altar in deep reverence, renewing their pledges of love and loyalty to their God.

Last, but by no means least, the hearty clasp of hands and exchange of greetings, with their Bishop, enquiries of relatives and friends at James Bay and other reserves, problems aired and advice given. The fishermen of several ships came ashore, and were drawn up close. After posing for pictures, which these people love to do, we watched them wind their way back to their cabins, each one, I know, feeling strengthened, spiritually and morally, and with a stronger sense of security in this great northland.

Personally, I walked away from the school house as if I were on a different plane, and feeling very humble.

At the tea table, Mr. Thompson served excellent tea, which was much appreciated. After which he accompanied us on our return trip, to spend, in Hearst, the holiday which follows the visit of the Bishop.

My husband and I were left off at Hearst, while the Bishop continued on his way to Mattice, to conduct the third service of the day, and to return late that night to the delightful surprise of finding Mrs. Renison, who had arrived by train early in the evening, awaiting him. So ended a glorious Palm Sunday.

A YOUNGSTER LOOKS AT SYNOD

From the Bishop's Charge of May 7, 1949

"The first Bishop was consecrated in Westminster Abbey and lived at Moose Factory on James Bay. Fifty years ago the only habitation of a Synod was the snowshoe trail from the distant posts on the east and west side of Hudson Bay when the missionaries came down to get the winter packet with the news of the last six months. Before the postman arrived from Mattawa five or six lonely men met their Bishop at the old log residence on the Island. It was only after the First Great War that Bishop Anderson organized the first Synod."

A few "highlights" seem to stand out, impressing this "youngster" as he looks back upon the Fifteenth Missionary Synod, held at St. Matthew's Pro-Cathedral, Timmins, May 11th, 12th and 13th, 1949.

THE SYNOD SERVICE, of course, is expected to "set the pace" for the whole session, and we were extremely fortunate in having as Synod Preacher the Most Rev. Philip Carrington, Archbishop of Canterbury, neighbouring diocese for the past. After drawing many illustrations from his work at the recent Lambeth Conference, and also referring to his own diocese, which is so similar to ours, he concluded by saying: "You have a job to do in holding the line here in this strategic area, a job that no one else can do."

It seemed to this "youngster" that the whole aim of the meetings that followed was "to get on with the job".

IN HIS CHARGE the Bishop reviewed the accomplishments of "The First Five Years," and "nailed the colours to the mast" for the next voyage. His "crew" supported him. The next Synod will commemorate the centenary of the landing of the first bishop, John Horden, on James Bay in 1861. For nearly a century the diocese of Moose Factory has been fighting on two fronts. Now, with the erection by the government of a modern hospital at Moose Factory, the line has been joined.

THE INDIAN MISSIONS on James Bay still hold a great fascination for the Church. Archdeacon Clarke's report was received with enthusiasm and the clergy called for copies to read to their congregations. The heroic labours of the missionaries at the outposts came in for special mention.

A diocese cannot operate without money, and this "youngster" thought that much of the Synod's work could have to do with cold facts and figures; but the TREASURER'S REPORT showed that the human element in financing had not been overlooked. Mr. Jamieson said he had been opposed to any centralization of church finances. He believed missionary diocese should keep their responsibility and give leadership to the whole Church. He was given a great ovation by the Synod.

As a "youngster", we were impressed by the idea of a SUMMER CAMP FOR THE TRAINING OF YOUTH LEADERS, a project introduced by Rev. G. R. Stanley of Kapuskasing. The Synod authorized a grant IF the money could be raised by the parishes. The laymen were particularly enthusiastic and pledged their support. We had FAITH, that was about all; but faith does work miracles.

This "youngster" believes he will be at that camp this summer!

At work and no play makes Synod a dull time. Bishop and Mrs. Renison kindly arranged a reception at "Bishop'scope" for the delegates and their hosts on the second evening of Synod. The feature attraction was a showing of the films taken by Archbishop Carrington at the Lambeth Conference, with His Grace's interesting commentary. We all enjoyed a very pleasant evening.

Before Synod closed, the Bishop delivered by Canon Walton "AFFIRMING OUR LOYALTY, LOVE, AND ESTEEM, TO BISHOP RENISON IN THE GREAT WORK HE HAS UNDERTAKEN IN THIS DIOCESE."

While all the delegates rose to express their approval, the Bishop, visibly touched by this demonstration could only say "it's been great fun."

This "youngster" considered that youth is not so much a question of age, but a state of mind.

The Diocese a century old, the Synod only fifteen. What does a fifteen-year-old stripling look for but fun, the fun of adventure, of blazing trails toward unlimited horizons.

—D.N.M.

CONFIRMATION

By Canon J. A. Watton, B.A.

It is only a writer's privilege to coin words and phrases, yet I feel sure that such a privilege should be extended to include clergymen. There are no words available, either ecclesiastical or common, that can describe the event of Easter and Confirmation when they fall on the same day. Such an event happened to us at St. Peter's, Kirkland Lake, this year. For the confirmation words would fail to express the import of such a day—the beautiful joyous Easter messages in lesson and song, culminating in the solemn, moving, hopeful rite of Confirmation in the evening.

For the Bishop and clergyman such an event is both mystical, joyous—and confusing.

As the Easter sun rises out of the East it lays its fingers of light on the already moving celebrant. As it climbs higher and higher as the day progresses, so also there arises the crescendo of worship and service. Then as the softer glow of evening gives eerie light, the long line of "brides and ordinands" process before their Bishop to receive that ancient historical rite—the laying on of hands.

Long after the sun has gone to rest, still they stand as they receive and congratulate those who have so recently "come of age" in the Church of God.

Two days later, the world seems to have slowed down to a more or less normal pace and once again the Bishop and the Rector can look out with more or less normal vision. And they see (as they have felt in even the most confusing moments) that it was all infinitely worthwhile. That here again the hand of God has been stretched out to guide and strengthen and sustain all who will come to Him.

THE BISHOP'S CANDLESTICK

In the days of Victor Hugo the Church was living in a Golden Age. She enjoyed the greatest possible power and authority—the world beat a pathway to her door. It was only natural that the visible head of that Church, the Bishop, should enjoy the greatest benediction of material possession.

Nothing was contained in his palace but material of the very best—aptly personified by solid gold or silver candlesticks. 'Tis a far cry from those days to our present generation. Little could Victor Hugo visualize a Bishop skimming over the snow on clumsy instruments made from the internal organs of a cat. Nor could he possibly foresee the dawn of an elder dark as the modern version of the four poster.

But least of all could he have foretold the replacement of the golden candlesticks, by its counterpart in flesh and blood.

Of all the prized possessions, I'm quite sure that ye olde Bishop held his candlestick as the most necessary, as it lighted his way in the dark, as it watched with him in his lonely vigils and drove away the shadows from a shadowy world.

So also today, while the vulgar display of wealth would be hard to locate in a Bishop's life, the candlestick is still there, lighting his way in the dark, giving light and hope and protection along a rough and ofttimes lonely trail. We have changed its name to suit its nature—we call it a Bishop's Wife.

J. A. W.
