In Christ there is no East or West,
In Him no South or North,
But one great fellowship of love,
Throughout the whole wide earth.

The Appeal

My dear People:

The collect for Easter has the following suggestive words "We humbly pray thee, that as by thy special grace preventing us thou dost put into our minds good desires, so by thy continual help we may bring the same to good effect;" It is in this spirit I want you to keep Easter.

There are many New Canadians among us who have known a real Calvary in Europe. Can you do something to make the joy of Easter real to them? We have a great Church and it is set in a great field of opportunity in this country—the New North. We must pray for minds and hearts big enough and strength great enough to meet it. Do not let sectionalism narrow us, or littleness weaken us. Our vision must be large enough so that in a small way we can build the Kingdom of God. We have known enough of hatred which makes one man a foreigner but in Christ there is no East or West, North or South, so let us make a start of trying His way.

Our late Primate, Archbishop Owen, used the following words while addressing the Synod at Niagara in 1927. "We have a great work to do, and a great work can be done only in a great way, and by men who, in humility and faith, have seen a great vision." A vision is not enough unless we are prepared to live that vision.

Come yourselves to the Easter Services of your Church and bring a New Canadian.

Your friend and Rector,

Norman D. Knox.

The Response

The words of this hymn provided the inspiration for our Easter Services. The local English language newspaper "The Star", published in Val d'Or, devoted a column to describe the theme of our Easter Pastoral Letter which appealed to the congregation to welcome the New Canadians. The response was wonderful and our churches were filled with people from every walk of life and every part of Europe.

In the churches we had Russians, Ukrainians, Poles, Germans, French, English, Irish and Scotch. The old European scarf wound over the head and the dainty flowered Easter bonnet both seemed to be quite natural. Even the quiet undertone of familiar prayers in the various Slavic tongues did not distract us from our central act of worship.

Christ is Risen—He is risen indeed.

We thought of the pilgrims in the streets of Jerusalem—of that great congregation in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, and churches in England and in England, and we prayed that the vision of a Fellowship of the Nations under Christ might be known to them.

For some of our foreign born people it was their first time to attend any Service in English. They were shy and a bit hesitant at first, but after awhile their faces began to reveal a sense of joy and tears wet the faces of some as they left the building.

One New Canadian (a D.P.) hesitated for a moment as though to say something before leaving. He struggled with limited English to express what it meant to him. There was an embarrassed silence and then I suggested "Christ is risen."

Immediately his face flooded with a radiant smile and the reply came,

"He is risen indeed."
HOW THE NORTH GROWS

The Field Secretary On The Wing

By H. G. Watts, D.D.

Thirty-five years ago the Missionary Society published an attractive little twelve-page pamphlet entitled "Moosonee," showing that although the Diocese had then been formed for more than forty years, the total population for the whole 600,000 square miles was 18,500 White, 6,000 Indians, and 1,000 Eskimos. Approximately two-thirds of the total population were members of the Church of England. Almost the entire pamphlet is taken up with the discussion of the work among Indian and Eskimo, with very little mention of White work.

Continuous changes have been taking place since then, but the last five years have undoubtedly shown unusual development in the life of our Church in this area. No longer can we claim two-thirds of much expanded population as the advance which has taken place in our Church life as a whole is conspicuously inspiring. It is now six years since I visited the Diocese myself for the first time, but I found in my recent visit that in that brief interval every place where I went there was a real growth in all sides of Church activity. I was only able to spend fifteen days in the Diocese and that time was given entirely to visiting the ten parishes.

There are many things about which I might write which pleased me to see—the splendid new St. Peter's Church at Kirkland Lake with its so suitable and striking reredos; the new Rectory at Rouyn; the changes that have been made in the Pre-Cathedral at Timmins; the new Church at Cochrane; the spirit of cooperation and enthusiasm which was typified by the decision to erect a new church at Noranda; the friendliness and hospitality of the younger clergy and older clergy alike; the extraordinary devotion to duty of some of the older clergy who have been giving so many years of service in isolation; the indefatigable energy of the lovable Bishop, and Mrs. Renouf, with all her enthusiasm for the way that she has adopted the work. Each or any one of these would have made an interesting article.

But it's difficult for me to write about what I found because on looking back over the recent copies of the "Northland" I find that already special articles have been written upon most of the developments. There was one phase of the work however, which was most interesting and engaging which I have not seen a great deal in the "Northland." This is the Japanese-Canadian settlement at Opasatika. The settlement there has been organized by the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company which has generously provided a school for the children under the capable principalship of Miss Ide, a Japanese-Canadian, and has also thrown open the doors of one of W. A. missionaries Miss Foster, as her assistant. The Rev. G. R. Stanley of Kapuskasing kindly arranged for me to go there and made very careful plans. Early in the evening upon which we were to pay our visit, the Spruce Falls Movie Projector truck arrived at the Rectory with all the necessary equipment, including an electric generator as there is no electric power at the Japanese settlement. The night was quite cold enough, but not so cold as it had been just before, and the snow was still falling heavily and I found myself throughout most of the twenty-five miles of snow-covered roads with the visit that he had paid a week previously. How that at that time the truck had broken down in the course of the journey leaving them stranded some distance from any building and that how his fellow-passenger had suffered seven frost-bites to legs and feet as a result of the delay.

The settlement is on a little side road, one and one-half miles from the main road. We were able to get through with the truck as far as the end of the settlement. It was too dark to see faces, but cheerful voices welcomed us and busy hands quickly helped us unload as we picked our way round the accumulated snow. From there our equipment had to be pulled to the school house at the far end of the settlement on sledges.

I have visited many places but never have I received a more enthusiastic welcome.

The little lamp-lighted school house was packed with about thirty-five children and their mothers. There were only two or three men as the others were away at work in the bush. The walls of the school had been decorated with thirty-five posters of welcome, each drawn by one of the school children. They knew Dr. Watts was coming and excitedly sought of them thought he could make me believe they had depicted him with a little black bag. Without exception everyone of the posters was quite cleverly done and they were given to me at the close of the evening. Several of the posters quite artistically portrayed the arrangement of the houses of the settlement and helped me to picture what it was impossible for me to see in the dark.

Unfortunately, everything didn't work out just as we had hoped. The talkie, being the collecting equipment either on the truck or on one of the sledges, was the "talkie" part out of commissions. However, I was able to show one film and be the "talkie" myself. The children were intrigued to discover someone who could speak to them in the language which they hear in their homes, but while they understood Japanese, they were all well-acquainted with English. I am not sure that Mr. Stanley and our truck...
driver appreciated the latter part of the evening quite as much as I did. A delicious meal was served, but Japanese food is an acquired taste. Following the meal, I was presented with an envelope containing money which was to be sent as a gift to the M.S.C.C.'s Kindergarten Training School at Nagoya in Japan. It was one of the largest collections taken throughout the whole of my visit and a great surprise to me. The journey back to Kapuskasing, after reloading the stuff onto sleighs and then onto the truck, was quite a cold one, but as the three of us sat crowded in the cabin of the truck the enthusiasm of the meeting dispelled the chagrin which our driver and movie operator had felt on account of the first time that his projecting equipment had ever failed him.

And so now in the Diocese of Moosonee there is another enterprise, that for the Japanese-Canadians. I am confident that it will not be long before the work will bring its reward in a number of baptisms both among the children and the adults, and will play a real part in forming the families into the life of our country of which they too are full citizens.

In the preface of "The Canadian Japanese and World War II," recent book of Professor F. E. LaViolette of McGill University, it has been pointed out how important it is "That those Canadians of other races who in years to come meet their fellow-citizens of Japanese race, should know what it has meant to be for five years a displaced person in your own land. And it is important that the Canadians to whom goes the word 'Democracy' may rise should determine what it means to them." THE SNOWMOBILE REPLACES THE HORSE AND BUGGY

My Dear Lord Bishop:

The notoriety suffered by yours truly relating to the kidnapping of Indian patients, so called "Mercy Flights" and other silly things, that are all in the day's work on this job, may have made me a "Legendary Figure," as you remarked, but I'm afraid I have not earned many of the nicer things reported.

I am very happy in my new work and at the risk of being inconsistent with reference to the last paragraph, I feel that I am doing a more worth-while job in my profession than I have ever done before.

On the evening of Friday, April 8th, having received word by radio, on the two days previous, that your Reverend Sam Iserhoff at East Main had all the symptoms of a post-influenza pneumonia, my man, Jimmie Gunner, and a clerk of the H. B. Company, started from this Post with our snowmobile in bright moonlight at ten P.M. (Of course I went along too.)

The going was pretty good on the frozen snow except where we had to cross the mouth of several creeks and run into bad slush. We traversed the twelve miles to the mouth of the Moose River by midnight, circumvented the shoreline of Hannah Bay, having to stay within the tide mark, and reached the midway point between East Point and Connaught Point opposite Stag Island, the peninsula between Hannah Bay and Rupert's Bay at daylight. Here we made a pot of coffee and enjoyed a can of heated soup, refilled our gas tank with a spare ten-gallon drum of gasoline and set out across the channel to the leeward coast of Stag Island. This was quite an experience.

You may recall this stretch. There is, I believe, a very fast current here in open water, and during the great storms in the fall of the year, when the ice is first making, the sea runs between the currents, and storms pile the ice up into huge masses with the cakes tumbling whichever way. Some of these masses are as big as your house and all seas from that down to that of the snowmobile. Valleys anywhere from four to ten feet deep between the windrows, with sharp crests formed from cakes of ice four to six inches thick, lying at an angle of 45 degrees to the horizontal, make most treacherous travelling. We had to wind our way over a zig-zag course for about eight miles of this stuff, taking nearly two hours to make the crossing.

We arrived at the mouth of Bonswain Bay at the foot of Sherrick Mountain at about seven A.M. There we had breakfast of bacon, a can of spaghetti and bread soaked in the bacon fat, washed down with steaming mugs of coffee. Does this bring back recollections and make your mouth water?

After breakfast, we had pretty good travelling from point to point and island to island up the East Coast to East Main, arriving there at twelve-twenty noon.

Mr. Iserhoff was quite ill and I found my diagnosis correct. He has an excellent heart and this has stood him in good stead. With large doses of penicillin administered then and again the following day and a preparation that requires three or twenty-four hours' action, he is much improved when we left to return on April 10th. The H. B. C. Manager at this Post was instructed in the use of giving further penicillin treatments and the most recent word received is that his condition is much improved. I have every hope for complete recovery now, although I never knew just what to expect in such serious conditions as this, in a man of his age. He is a very fine old gentleman and everyone in this area is concerned. He is loved and respected by all.

We made an uneventful return trip, leaving East Main about ten a.m. and arriving back to Moose Factory about nine-thirty p.m. We covered 287 miles on the round trip. This is a new mode of travel and certainly a great improvement on horseback. There is also an advantage over the aeroplane, in that we can travel at night, through ordinary storms and under a low ceiling, all of which make it impossible for plane travel.

The letter you enclosed from Mrs. Wallbridge of Belleville, concerning the surgical instruments, was certainly a most kind gesture on her part and I appreciate it very much. It was good of you also to have my case in mind when you knew of the loss I sustained in the fire which destroyed the offices and the hospital and Nursing Station. The instruments can be used to great advantage in treating the Indians under my care. I shall write to her immediately and explain things, requesting her to forward them to me. Thank you kindly for this.

Miss Iona Andrew of Fort Harrison (still in her east) is now assisting me in the office here.

With very best personal regards to Mrs. Renison and yourself.

Here we made a pot of coffee and enjoyed a can of heated soup, refilled our gas tank with a spare ten-gallon drum of gasoline and set out across the channel to the leeward coast of Stag Island. This was quite an experience.

You may recall this stretch. There is, I believe, a very fast current here in open water, and during the great storms of the fall of the year, when the ice is first making, the action between the currents tides and wind lifts the ice up into huge masses with the cakes every which way. Some of these masses are as big as your house and all sizes from that down to that of the snowmobile. Valleys anywhere from four to ten feet deep between the windrows, with sharp crests formed from cakes of ice four to six inches thick, lying at an angle of 45 degrees to the horizontal, make most treacherous travelling. We had to wind our way over a zig-zag course for about eight miles of this stuff, taking nearly two hours to make the crossing.

We arrived at the mouth of Boaswain Bay at the foot of Sherrick Mountain at about seven A.M. There we had breakfast of bacon, a can of spaghetti and bread soaked in the bacon fat, washed down with steaming mugs of coffee. Does this bring back recollections and make your mouth water?

After breakfast, we had pretty good travelling from point to point and island to island up the East Coast to East Main, arriving there at twelve-twenty noon.

Mr. Iserhoff was quite ill and I found my diagnosis correct. He has an excellent heart and this has stood him in good stead. With large doses of penicillin administered three or four times daily, he is doing a recuperation that requires done every twenty-four hours only; he was much improved when we left to return on April 10th. The H. B. C. Manager at this Post was instructed in the use of giving further penicillin treatments and the most recent word received is that his condition is much improved. I have every hope that he will be completely recovered although no one knows just what to expect in such serious conditions as this, in a man of his age. He is a very fine old gentleman and everyone in this area is concerned. He is loved and respected by all.

We made an uneventful return trip, leaving East Main about ten a.m. and arriving back to Moose Factory about nine-thirty p.m. We covered 287 miles on the round trip. This is a new mode of travel and certainly a great improvement on dog teams. There is also an advantage in using the aeroplane in that we can travel at night, through ordinary storms and under a low ceiling, all of which make it impossible for plane travel.

The letter you enclosed from Mrs. Wallbridge of Belleville, concerning the surgical instruments, was certainly a most kind gesture on her part and I appreciate it very much. It was good of you also to have my case in mind when you knew that I suffered the fire which destroyed our office and contents in our new Nursing Station. The instruments can be used to great advantage in treating the Indians under my care. I shall write to her immediately and explain things, requesting her to forward them to me. Thank you kindly for this.

Miss Iona Andrew of Fort Harrison (still in her cast) is now assisting me in the office here.

With very best personal regards to Mrs. Renison and yourself.

REPORT OF THE ARCHDEACON OF JAMES BAY

My Lord and Members of the Synod:

In presenting my first report as Archdeacon of James Bay, may I say I am deeply conscious of the great honour, and responsibility placed upon my shoulders, and ask for your prayers that I might measure up to the challenge presented.

I think it is safe to say, without appearing to be boasting, that we are beginning to get on our feet.

By far the greatest item in this report is the new Government Hospital now being built on Moose Island.

The official capacity of the hospital is 250 beds. It will serve not only it its own immediate needs from all over James Bay and northern Quebec, and even reaching into the Diocese of Keewatin. What a fertile field. The hospital will also contain two chapels of equal size. Daily services will have to be said, letters written for the patients and staff, and many other services to be rendered. If we can't do these things we are not justified in doing so. An additional Priest for Moose Island is a "must." This also brings up the question of living quarters, etc.

In the last year there has been some staff changes. Rev. David Mitchell left Rupert's House to become Rector of South Porcupine; Rev. M. Donaldson has been transferred from Albany Mission to Rupert's House. Mr. Cyril Elliott has been appointed missionary-in-charge at Albany. The Ojibway Missions were placed under the Rev. Mr. Vollrick who however, was released by the Bishop this spring for work in Huron Diocese. And the Rev. Eric DePendleton is to be in charge in the Ojibway Missions Area.

While we are on the subject of men in these points I would like to stress a very important fact. In our diocese we need more and closer contact between the men in these sparsely settled areas and the clergy and laity in the denser populated areas. You may not think it, but these men can get lonely. A letter, a magazine would help to build a comrade-ship that we all need, so much. We are not a divided Church. This is a great opportunity for our Laymen's Associations and others, and I would be happy to discuss plans with anyone interested.

At this point I would like to mention a special job of work being done by Rev. E. Louttit of Old Factory and Rev. Sam Schurhoff of Eastmain. They are developing a Primer for the speaking of Cree based on a similar system used by the Government in teaching English to European Immigrants to Canada. This will be of great assistance to summer students and others in their work.

On the material side work has progressed satisfactorily. Rupert's House has a fine new church. I wish to thank Rev. David Mitchell for his fine work there. It made a grand finale to his ministrations on the Bay.

Repairs are being made on a cottage at Collins to enable a summer student to conduct a day-school and take services at that very vital spot.

The church at Wabequa has now the needed doors and windows, thanks to the generosity of Mrs. Emmet, the wife of Archdeacon Emmet of Orillia, who asked that her Life Membership fee be placed there; and to the generosity of the W.A. of the Diocese of Rupert's Land, who at their annual meeting last February took up a collection for the suspended work of Green's Harbour Church, Rupert's Land, and the proceeds were donated to the same church. St. Matthew's W. A. Winnipeg, arising from this same meeting, have undertaken to equip our mission house at Lansdowne House on Lake Attawapiscat.

We cannot speak too highly of the good works of the W. A. both on a Dominion and Diocesan scale in their efforts and kindness to our missionaries, and their missions.

The Rectory at Moose Island has been improved considerably, and the old day school is being changed into a parish hall.

Old Factory Church needs a tower and outside covering. This is a memorial church and though the interior completed last year is excellent, the exterior leaves much to be desired. There is surplus of lumber at Rupert's which will take care of the tower, and money will be needed to cover the outside with suitable material.

At Albany the mission house needs a general overhaul, windows reset, roof renewed, etc., and the church painted. This is a very important spot, as the Church of Rome have an excellent set-up with buildings in fine shape, and we have a perpetual comparison.

As you all know, the Bishop has started a fund in Toronto for construction of a new church at Moose Cree. There is no question of the need, as the present building, once the day school used by the Rev. Fred Mark, has seen better days.

The last portion of my report deals with Anniversaries. This year the Diocese of Rupert's Land celebrates its centenary. Something should be done by us to recognize this important event, as we are a child of Rupert's Land, and it was the seat of our first authority.

Secondly in 1951 St. Thomas Moose Factory will be 100 years old. A fund is underway to restore the church, and make improvements. But something from the Diocese should be done to mark this occasion, both from the point of assisting the restoration, and a suitable celebration.

We have entered into the second phase of the plan, so well conceived and put into force by our Bishop. The initial thrill of success is now behind us. We have now the difficult yet perhaps less spectacular job of maintaining "the pace set." There is no idea of slackening off by others, we have tacked our colours to the mast, we must go on in the words of St. Paul, "Let us run with patience the race that is set before us."

Respectfully submitted,

Neville Clarke.

I let the paddle drip and raised my eyes
And wondered how these rivers find their way,
Spilled down the border hillsides, where they rise
To finish up next year in Hudson's Bay.

Is draining into the vast watershed.
An ocean on the march! a vast migration
Shouldering along a beaten path
And hurling its stupendous inundation—
I stopped. Someone was giving way to wrath,
And looking round to comment: "Better learn.

TRANSITION

and then came Easter

By Elizabeth Renison

"My dear, is the Bishop's wife eccentric?"

"What a question!"

"Well, I saw her the other day walking around the drive-way, looking at the trees, pausing and pointing at this and that bare stick of a shrub that peeped above the snowdrifts. It was that fearful cold day in February, 10 below zero and snowing. 'What ARE YOU doing in that freezing weather?' she said, 'Gardening.'"

I had put "The Northland" to bed, and saying joyfully, "Well, that job is done for three months," took Chimo and Reggie and Judy out for a hike, and then fell by the wayside, and planned all the changes I wanted to make in our five acres.

Bishopstope kennels flourished; Reggie sired twelve. His family multiplied at the Hoyle Mine (since closed). We took him, Michael, the pick of the litter, and Judy, young and alluring, but showing the lesser breed of her mother.

Michael was hit by no less a personage than the Provincial Police car as it sped along the Porcupine Highway. The law allows a speed of 59 miles an hour in front of Bishopstope's drive. So Michael followed his predecessor, Michael 1st, our Iris Setter.

Judy had a comparatively brief reign. Chimo ignored her. Reggie was the adoring father and boy friend.

One day, the little five-year-old girl who delivers us eggs every week, from further along the highway, said gravely to the Bishop:

"Judy was naughty."

"What did Judy do?" said my husband.

"She bit one of our chickens in the neck, and made it bleed."

"Did you punish Judy?" said the Bishop.

"No, she ran away."

The Bishop then produced the egg money and said,

"There is ten cents extra; five cents for you and please give the HEN the other five."

Without a smile the child said:

"I will."

(Enquiries revealed that the HEN was no worse.)

Three weeks later, we returned from one of the Bishop's periodical trips. Judy, Chimo and Reggie welcomed us joyfully, and also three other friends of Judy's.

Then Judy, spring fever and a love of snow proving too much for her, paid another visit to the HEN house, disposed of the egg, and carried it to our house and deposited it at our door. Having paid for this in full, and requested that THEIR dog, a collie, be kept from our grounds, if possible, and THEIR wire fence fixed, where it was sprung, we kept Judy at home.

Three days later Judy leapt our enclosure. Her collie friend was sitting outside making insulting remarks about helpless females—the two raced down the highway to the HEN house, and the door having been left open for a few minutes, Judy revenged herself for her confinement, to the tune of ten.

Judy is now banished to the counterpart of Siberia, and Reggie is disconsolate. The collie stays at home.

Pre-Easter Confirmations—where we were touched by a strong sense of the need caused by the growth in these places—Trinity College School, Port Hope; Hearst; Calabogie; Mattice and Kapuskasing.

A 260-mile drive to Kirkland Lake—Easter Day there. The Bishop celebrated at one of the early Services, while Canon W. J. went to another Mission.

The 11 a.m. Service at St. Paul's, Virginiatown, (the first in its history), when the little church was packed to the doors and many stood all through the Service. The Bishop's wife acted as solo singer in a copy of psalm while the parents of the occupants stood up to make their Communion. Many new Canadians attended this Service. We shared a Prayer Book with one but when it came to the hymns we each sang our own version and it was equally pleasing to our Father.

Confirmation in the evening at St. Peter's when a class of 31 were presented. Three of these came from Swastika.

This Service was memorable, as this was the first Easter in the new St. Peter's. "We are compassed around by so great a cloud of witnesses," said the Bishop,—let us run the race that is set before us, looking unto Jesus, the Author and Finisher of our Faith."

Afterwards downstairs in the Parish Hall, when the Confirmation certificates were presented, I heard someone say, "Mrs. Renison is wearing a veil."

"She has to. Her hair is terrific."

Satan whispered to me in Holy Week. "Why not be beautiful for Easter?"

I went to the newest beautician. I dozed, and emerged, shorn, bleached and curled, looking like Amelia Earhart with her curly wind-blown mop, but Amelia was in her twenties!

And Then Came Easter.

"WATCH AND PRAY"

By Canon J. A. Watton

Just one short year ago it was the duty and privilege of "The Northland" to introduce to its readers the "five smooth stones" as they were ordained into the deaconate of the Church of God; missiles from the hand of God. Today they have received their full direction, for today they have entered upon the priesthood of the Church.

There they stand—four now—one having been redirected physically as well as spiritually—and before their father-in-God make these heart-searchings promises, that to hear alone is a form of consecration for the hearer. As they kneel, one feels that the many hands of the priests laid upon their heads, are but the symbol of the manifold gifts of the Holy Spirit poured out in consecration. Here is one hand, calloused and gnarled by the effort of honest physical toil—and the fruit of the Spirit is love and joy. This hand is lined and not too firm and upon the head of the candidate is laid—and the fruit of the Spirit is long-suffering and gentleness.

There is a hand—a perfect poem in symmetry, with long fingers, finely tapered—and the fruit of the Spirit is goodness. The dark firm hand of the native Canadian is there, and the fruit of the Spirit is faith.

Then the hand that is the functional hand—there are many of these—so may they have in abundance the fruit of the Spirit which is meekness and temperance.

And over and above them all through the lips of the Archbishop of Quebec comes the loving command of God—"Watch and pray", "watch and pray".

There is only one thing lacking—and one lack that never can be filled—it is that all people should witness the deep religious depths of this Service. That they might see the laymen take their first step in the coming of ordination, that they might see a few moments later the final step of self-consecration as four are made priests—that they might see in the hands laid upon their heads the fulfillment of that self-consecration in the lives of others and hear the challenge of love—"Watch and pray".

Dear Miss Morrison:

I have answered your letter of July 24 and sincerely appreciate your interest in one of our Indian summer schools.

However, I feel that I must be fair in explaining to you now that we only appoint married women who accompany their husbands to such schools.

As you are doubtless aware, these seasonal schools are in very isolated parts of Northern Quebec, Ontario and Manitoba and we would be most reluctant to send in a single woman. Dear Colonel Neary:

I have been hoping that there might be some reason to take me up to Ottawa, but the excuse has not appeared. I hope our panel will reconvene, although I suppose everyone is so busy that it is difficult to find time for anything that is not immediately vital.

Although this may be too early, I am writing to ask about temporary summer teaching jobs. Among those who would be interested this year is a particularly able and well-balanced young woman whose ambition is to go into Ethnology and who wishes accordingly to get in touch with people in process of adjustment as soon as possible. The girl in question, Miss Joan Presant, was second in a class of over a hundred in her first year last year, and has gone into Anthropology which is entered at the second year level. Miss Presant had intended to go into Anthropology from her high school days and succeeded in working her way into a number of archaeological expeditions while she was still in high school. I took her on two and have found her an extremely co-operative, able and level-headed person. Year before last she was accepted for work on a joint expedition of the University of British Columbia and the University of Washington, where she was, I think, both the only girl and the only non-graduate student. She made good, although she was not even an undergraduate at the time.

Frankly, I have a great deal of confidence in Miss Presant both as a student and, which is much more important, as a level-headed young woman able to get along with people under diverse conditions. If it were ever possible to take a woman on to your temporary jobs you would never have a better bet than Miss Presant.

With best regards,

Yours sincerely,

T. F. McIlwraith.

I have several applications from men already, but there is no doubt that a man can be very much more valuable when he has been on the spot before.

Dear Sir:

I have been requested by the Rt.Rev. R.J.Renison, Bishop Of Moosonee, whose name I submit as reference, to write to you concerning Summer Employment in the Moosonee District.

I am twenty-eight years of age. I received my elementary and secondary education in Aurora, Ontario. I served with the Canadian Army in Canada from November 1943 to May 1946. Upon discharge I entered the Rehabilitation School in Toronto where I completed my Senior Matriculation. I attended the University of Toronto and received my Bachelor of Arts degree in June, 1949. After graduation, I enrolled in the Trinity College Divinity School, where I am now completing my second year. During this time I have taught Sunday School and have had two courses in Christian educational methods at Trinity College.

Concerning other work, I have always been in an office. This includes about two years with the T.Eaton Company, and the past three summers with the Provincial Government of Ontario. While with the latter I worked one summer for the Mothers' Allowance Commission and two summers with the Ontario Public Trustee.

I shall be available for work from May 1st.

Yours Truly,

(Russell A.Sayer)

As you know, the problem of finance is very important to these young men, most of whom are working their way through college and in the Christian Ministry; they will never be rich.
